It is scary as hell  and extremely expensive.We have been doing alright  but a recent hiccup in my steady income (when combined with her medical inability to get to work) has made the last portion of her medical bills go to collections and begin to take its toll on our household.We have tried going to Social Services  but Indiana has some very strict laws concerning what is and isn't a disability... meaning the government programs for this sort of thing are no help.I have seen others in my industry fall on hard times and need to reach out to their fans  friends  and family; I have helped where I could. Now  it seems  we look to the universe to see what  if any  aid we can gather. My new freelance wages can pay our day to day and keep our family fed and warm  but the numbers keep growing and the tunnel that has that light at the end... well  it feels like it is just getting longer and longer.I want to be able to pay all of this back medical debt  but the life of a game industry professional is more than a little check-to-check  and as a husband and father... I'm not too proud to know when I need help. Thanks for reading all of this  and even if you can't or won't help us in this rough patch... please share the link and spread the word.Thanks again."

When Callie was born on 2/26/2014 she was healthy in every way with the exception of her right ear and right jaw.  Her ear condition is called microtia.  Microtia is a congenital deformity where the pinna (external ear) is underdeveloped.  Her jaw condition is called hemifacial microsomia.   Hemifacial microsomia (HFM) is a congenital disorder that affects the development of the lower half of the face  most commonly the ears  the mouth and the mandible.  Callie's parents have made certain that Callie expresses herself and is very involved with decisions involving her treatment.  Recently she has been talking more and more about how she would like a real ear (she wants to be able to wear earrings and sunglasses.... basically  she wants to be able to have two ears like mostpeople do).  Callie will be starting kindergarten in the fall and the family is hoping that she will have her right ear by then.Treatment options are surgical or prosthetic.  Callie's parents have decided on a prosthetic ear at this time.  If Callie decides when she is a little older that she would like surgery then she still has that option (her mom and dad really want her to be comfortable with decisions made regarding her treatment).  Robert R. Barron  former CIA Disguise Specialist will be doing Callie's evaluation at her appointment in March.   Mr. Barron is committed to restoring identities through prosthetic devices.  He has people travel from China to consult with him.  He has made guest appearances on Oprah  Montel and Botched.  Unfortunately Callie's health insurance will not cover any of this because it is considered cosmetic.  They do not consider the pain that Callie might endure because let's face it.... bullying and ridicule are way too prevalent in our world.  Fortunately  Callie has charisma and inner strength that just blows us away.  We are asking for donations so that Callie can have the ear that she is so excited about by the time kindergarten starts.  The total cost for the ear is $7000.  In order for Mr Barron to begin making the impressions Callie's parents will need $2 300 with the remainder due soon after.  Thank you so much for taking the time to read this.  All of us are forever grateful for any help that you can give .... This could make such a positive difference in this little girl's life.

It’s tough enough when one spouse in a family has a major medical surgery. But  when the other spouse has a major medical emergency just two weeks later it is devastating physically  emotionally AND financially. On November 1  Tim had his third cancer surgery  removing malignant lymph nodes around the throat area. The surgery went as well as can be expected. However  he has had no income since he could not go back to his work with Chris’ Tree Service. In addition  Tim has a minimum health insurance policy which has him facing significant medical bills.Two weeks later on November 14  his wife Jan suffered a major heart attack  was revived by EMS personnel and underwent emergency surgery to get blood to her heart. She was put into a medically induced coma for three days to lower her body temperature so as to improve her chances of not suffering major brain injury. She recently made it home and is facing a long recovery with quite a bit of therapy.Thank God that she and Tim are recovering but  they face significant medical expenses as well as lost income from  being unable to work. We estimate that the medical bills not covered by insurance will exceed $15 000 and three months of lost income to be at least $20 000. In fact  Jan may be permanently disabled and not be able to return to work. Tim and Jan have two teenage daughters at home  Anna and Amelia  who are dependent on them.Together  we can make Jan and Tim’s world a little better by taking a lot of the financial burden off of them and help them focus on their physical and emotional recovery. Thank you and please share with your friends and family!

storyTitle: Diane Kearns' Battle With Breast Cancer
story: After five years without health insurance due to financial constraints and no job benefits  Diane finally had a full time job with benefits.  That’s when Diane started catching up on routine testing and exams to take care of her health. One of those tests was a mammogram. The day before Thanksgiving  when everyone else is thinking about how they are going to finish prepping for dinner the next day and planning shopping for Black Friday  Diane was told there was a nodule on her mammogram that needed a biopsy.  It’s surreal how your life can change course in such a short time.  Fast forward two weeks  and Diane has been diagnosed with an aggressive breast cancer that will require surgery and chemotherapy.  She will have a long treatment road ahead of her and her health insurance  although grateful to have it  only pays for a portion of her surgery and her copayments for all treatments are high.  As a single mom  these donations will help ease the stress and burden of financing this life saving treatment.  Diane is an amazing  funny and generous person who would do anything to help someone else in need....we are lucky to have her as a friend.   Diane is a wonderful mother  daughter and sister who has family and friends who love her dearly.  Please help ease the financial burden that comes along with this journey  as no one should have to worry about how  to finance taking care of their well being and health.

storyTitle: Help me raise money for Kristine
story: My daughter  Kristine< was admitted to the hospital in Bali Indonesia on October15th for a non hemorrhaging stroke. She is 45 yrs old. Her husband is a pilot  and had just accepted a new position .  He is not \official\" until he completes his training in December. There are no family members living in this country.  They had just moved into a new apartment last weekend. Needless to say  they are feeling overwhelmed. Its too soon to tell what her deficits will be< if any< but the medical bills are mounting up fast. They are exploring an international health insurance plan but that doesn't help the here and now. Everything happened so fast.  Due to a chronic medical condition   I am not allowed to travel by air and her doctor won\"t allow her to fly back to the States!  Imagine how I feel!!  Please help us??"

storyTitle: Urgent Medical Matter; Jennifer needs your help!
story: ￼￼￼￼ For many years I've been making light of my distressing medical situation  but the truth is that an expert team of (medical professionals including) a therapist  medical doctors  and surgeons all vehemently agree: I need $75 000 for vital  life-changing  medically necessary surgeries. Instead of doing what I have always done  quietly powering through and worrying alone  I am doing the most difficult task of my life: asking for help. Will you help me because I am feeling hopeful and overwhelmed? There is nothing more gratifying to me than to help others. In the salon  it has been helping salon guests find and develop their beauty. At Redken  it has been helping fellow stylists  salon owners  and colleagues grow personally and professionally. At home it was raising my sons so they could become the loving  successful  independent men they have become. Now  at home  it is caring for my husband  a disabled US Army veteran  and our dog  BB King  my husband’s service dog. By helping to fund this surgery  you are creating the hope and possibility that I can continue in my career  and be active enough to enjoy my life  my family  and my future grandchildren. I have been suffering physically and psychologically with chronic pain and infection for a very long time… and it is the expert medical opinion that I will continue to experience ongoing pain every day of my life until I am able to access this treatment. After an extensive series of physical and psychological evaluations  my team of doctors and I have arrived at a comprehensive surgical plan which we are confident will provide massive relief to my pain and radically improve my life. My entire care team agrees that it is profoundly urgent for me to begin treatment as soon as possible. We have already spent most of our savings trying to access care. I have been fighting hard to get some of the procedures covered by my health insurance  but even in the best-case scenario I will only be able to get them to cover a small fraction of the treatment plan my doctors have put together. I desperately  urgently need your help! Any help you can give is greatly appreciated. Thank you for reading this and thank you for helping me. Much love  Jennifer Gonzales (Tully)

Jessica  mother of three  has been diagnosed with Stage 3 Hodgkin’s lymphoma with multiple masses on her spleen. She is also fighting the lingering effects of Lyme’s disease and several other health issues. Jessica has had mysterious symptoms for several years  but only recently has the cause been determined.It wasn’t until May of 2018 that the devastating medical diagnosis of lymphoma was finally confirmed. This was about a year after her husband Jared had taken a new teaching job in Alabama. Their move away from Texas and their extended family had been filled with the excitement of settling into a new community and job  but their lives were soon turned upside down. For those of you who don’t know Jessica Velnosky Painter that well  she is a devoted wife and mother. This diagnosis has been especially hard since her children are aged 2  7  and 9. She became unable to care for her family  and all the responsibility fell on her husband  since there was no family nearby.  Her passion for fulfilling her Godly destiny  and her love for her family  are Jessica’s reasons for living. Jessica has health insurance  but it will not cover all of the treatments that she needs. Since she is fighting multiple health issues  some of the treatments are very specialized  and many of them are not covered by insurance. It takes all of Jessica’s time and energy to follow the healing protocols prescribed. She is determined to overcome all of this and is putting a great deal of effort into doing everything she can—physically  emotionally  and spiritually. Along with the expense of the treatments  they have other extra expenses  such as medical travel  expensive dietary needs  and daycare for the two-year-old. Jessica has been receiving weekly treatments in a nearby state for about two months now. She is definitely seeing improvement and the cancer factors in her blood are decreasing. The swelling in her lymph nodes is going down. We are all very excited to see these positive signs. But the credit card is maxed out and expenses are quickly getting out of control. They really  really did not want to ask for financial help  but to keep receiving treatments and to avoid financial ruin  it seems that now is the time to ask others to help in this worthwhile cause.Please consider donating to this wonderful family. Each dollar will be used wisely. We are fully convinced that Jessica will be made whole and able to complete her mission here on this earth. There are not words that can fully express our appreciation for your generosity. God bless each of you. TEAM Jessica–Melissa Stephens (Best Friend)  Terry Velnosky (Mother)  Debra Painter (Mother-In-Law)

My good friend Danielle was recently diagnosed with Thyroid cancer.  In typical Danielle fashion  she is determined and focused on the challenges ahead of her with dignity and grace. Those of you who know her well  know that Danielle is always the first to reach out a helping hand  offer a shoulder to cry on  or give spot-on advice.  She has always been one of the first people I turn to when I need help  a good laugh  or just need to talk to someone who always  always keeps it real.  In her work as a coach and interventionist she has helped many  many people and families in their hardest times  and now she is experiencing a difficult time of her own. I am a cancer survivor myself  as well as a woman in recovery from alcoholism  like Danielle  and she has helped me in countless ways over the years - not just when I need help staying sober but in many  many ways - and now it's my turn to give back to her.Thankfully her type of cancer is very treatable and the forecast for her recovery is good  and she is approaching this next chapter with hope and determination.  She will have a long surgery sometime over the next few weeks  and after this surgery  there will be more information about her course of treatment.It's hard sometimes to know how to help someone you care about when they are facing a cancer diagnosis. The medical bills for Danielle will be high  and the best way we can collectively help her is to donate to this fund to help her keep up with these substantial expenses. Health insurance will kick in and help but only after she pays a high deductible  which is causing her more stress at a time when she should be focused solely on healing and fighting this disease. As many of you know  she left the corporate world several years ago to start her own business  so she does not have the support of paid time off or medical leave plan. She wants to be able to keep up her important work with people in recovery as much as she can  and will pay as much of the expenses as she's able to  but every little bit helps. If you could contribute ANY amount - no amount is too small - it would be a great help to her. It's hard to ask for help  and so I set up this campaign because it was done for me when I had cancer  and I know how much it relieves anxiety about keeping up with even daily expenses when your world has been turned upside down.I am honored to be able to help give back to a woman who has given so  so much to me over the years.  Thank you  so much   for anything you are able to donate.  We will update this CaringBridge page with her progress to keep everyone informed.  Thank you  truly  for any amount you are able to give.  We are so very grateful for your support.- Ellie Schoenberger

As most of you are aware Eileen has been battling GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome) since September 2018. She has made many gains in her journey; however  she will continue to face obstacles ahead of her. Eileen continues to work hard in out patient therapy to work on her goals. She remains out of work since September and  is determined to return to work as soon as she can . Although she has good insurance   medical expenses are quickly accumulating and her leave of absence has expired forcing huge COBRA payments every month to maintain health insurance until she returns to work. Many of you have asked how you can help  so we have established this page to support Eileen and her family. We hope to assist by alleviating some of the financial burden so she and her family can put their time and energy into healing .Any donation would be appreciated. Eileen and her family thank you for your continued support and prayers during her journey.

Dear Family and Friends that are Family  We write to you today as part of a Private Fundraiser to help and support all of our best friend  Khelse. Khelse is fighting an unimaginable battle to regain her strength. To provide a brief background  Khelse’s journey to regain her well-being began in January 2018 when she was admitted to the hospital for a massive blood clot in her portal vein – a vein conveying blood to the liver from the spleen  stomach  pancreas  and intestines. During her treatment  she was diagnosed with chronic  but microscopic thrombosis (blood clots). As time progressed  Khelse continued treatment plans for thrombosis that included weekly and monthly specialist appointments to regain the strength of her liver and other affected organs  and to understand the long term affects of these blood clots.Although Khelse was on blood thinners for months  she was admitted again to the hospital on Christmas Day 2018 and diagnosed with 5 blood clots  terrifyingly  one which traveled through her heart and lodged in her lung; very often a lethal path. It was clear then that the blood thinners Khelse had been taking were not effective. As a result  she was diagnosed with an extremely rare blood clotting disorder that the hematologist/oncologist cannot specify.For over a week  Khelse remained in the hospital building her health and strength with endless treatments and care plans. Finally  on January 2  2019 she was allowed to go home. Although she followed her physician’s orders without error in an attempt to regain normal life and to fully recover  with great sadness  she was readmitted to the hospital on February 4  2019 in even worse condition than any time before. Today  Khelse is undergoing countless procedures to determine the cause of her current state. Due to the complexity of her situation and illness  the medical team of doctors taking care of her are discussing and even disagreeing over the next steps of her treatment  procedures  and surgeries. Overall  Khelse has undergone multiple operations and will have many more. As we write this  her anticipated hospital stay is multiple weeks and her anticipated recovery time is 3 months.As we can only imagine  hospital stays and treatment of chronic diseases are extremely expensive. Because she exhausted all of her paid time off during her priorhospitalization and recovery process  Khelse will not earn a paycheck during her present time away from work  and does not have Short Term Disability to cover her missed salary. Khelse's last paycheck was $33.00. Khelse is a level-headed  hard-working young woman with health insurance through her employer  Baylor College of Medicine. Yet  even with this partial coverage  Khelse’s medical bills are reaching extraordinary costs. Currently her out-of-pocket expenses total over $20 000.00 and it’s hard to discern the exact amount of her medical bills before she is recovered. To give you a bit of insight  Khelse’s deductible alone is $6 000 which after she is responsible for 25-30% of her medical expenses. She is currently on a number of permanent medications costing approximately $250 per month after insurance and she is required to have multiple doctor appointments ranging from $140-$200 per appointment. She will also be required to have several high dollar procedures done such as MRI’s and CT scans.To make matters worse  because Khelse has been hospitalized and missed work for treatment since January of 2018  her FMLA is running out in the coming days putting her employment and health insurance in severe jeopardy. Most importantly  Khelse’s normal responsibilities remain in the forefront  such as her rent  car payment  and other general monthly expenses.Since Khelse’s second hospitalization in December 2018  many people have contacted her and us with inquiries of how to help her. For most of last year  Khelse silently took personal and financial responsibility of the repercussions of her hospitalization and newfound illness  but at this point it has become apparent to all those very close to Khelse that the financial consequences of this 2+ week hospitalization and 3+ month extensive treatment will be insurmountable. For these reasons  we humbly started this fundraiser for a specific way to help Khelse be able to focus solely on her health rather than the accompanying stresses associated with being in the hospital. In any regard  on behalf of Khelse's family and with all of our heart  we thank you for your continued love and support of Khelse. It has touched her in ways you cannot imagine and truly helps her get through every day of this process.Respecting Khelse's privacy  we request in advance that this GoFundMe be kept amongst those with access to this page. You are all Khelse's family who have loved and encouraged her throughout this inconceivable journey. For now  we ask that you please keep this information off of the general Internet  including Facebook and other social media sites.

storyTitle: Strength in Numbers Help Monah fight Breast Cancer
story: On December 17  2018  our sister/friend/family member Monah was diagnosed with Stage Two Breast Cancer. Since then Monah’s life has drastically changed. Shortly after receiving this heart-breaking news she had to start chemo because of the type of aggressive cancer she was diagnosed with. Her next year of treatment will be a long road but we have faith and believe she will be healed. Monah will go through 6 months of chemo with surgery that includes a lumpectomy or mastectomy and then radiation. Monah works full time taking care of sick patients every day. She has been recently told by her doctors that she may not be able to continue to work and as a single woman who has worked hard and owns a home  this has quickly become a financial burden. Bills have already started to stack up and without being able to work she also risks the chance of losing her health insurance. Those who know Monah knows that she has always been there for her friends and family and now it’s time for us all to be there for her. We all must fight with Monah and with our “Strength in Numbers” Monah will prevail.

storyTitle: Help Amy VanHecker on her Breast Cancer journey
story: On November 30th our sweet friend Amy was diagnosed with Breast Cancer. This was quite a shock because of Amy's young age and there not being a history of breast cancer in her family. After multiple doctors appointments Amy and her husband Brad started learning more and more about her journey to becoming cancer free. Amongst a long list of new information  they found out that due to chemotherapy Amy will be put into menopause and the chances of conceiving naturally afterwards are significantly decreased. If you are lucky to know either one of them  you know they will be amazing parents one day.  Thankfully Amy has the opportunity to freeze embryos to increase their chances of having a child in the future. While they are grateful for this  unfortunately it is really expensive.Although Amy has health insurance that assists with the cost of treatment  it does not cover a large majority of many things not to mention all the time off from work she will be taking. Amy is loving wife  daughter  sister  friend  and a dedicated social worker who is always there for others with a smile and helping hand. The hope is to relieve Amy and Brad from some of the financial burden  so she can focus on her health and kicking breast cancer in the behind!The holiday season is upon us and the gift of giving is truly magical. The goal to lessen the financial stress is to raise $10 000. No amount is to small and every single dollar is appreciated. Thank you for considering! Happy holidays!

Hello everyone! My name is J.R. Goodbred. My parents are John and Susan Goodbred. Most of you know them and for those who don't  we will all attest to the remarkable  and selfless people they are. My purpose for this hopeful endeavor  is to ask for help. Something my family  and especially my parents do very seldom. But  with a heavy heart my mom has been diagnosed with Cancer  for a second time. She previously beat a brutal diagnosis of Head and Neck Cancer  about a decade ago. I have no idea how she did it. It was very intense and damaging.  It was extraordinary  how she rose to the challenge  the surgeries  radiation  and chemotherapy  and came out the other side to live a full life to this day. That in-of-itself is enough for one human being  not to diminish the permanent  and long term effects that she has to live with day in and day out.      Even though they have health insurance ( the companies fight to deny her legitimate claims still to this day making it more costly and upsetting) i think we all know the burden finances place on top of the worry of appropriate and adequate treatment. Yet  they never complain(ed)! They just did and do what they have to do to pay and maintain their lives the best they can. My brother  sister and I are going to do everything we can to help  but even we can only do so much to combat the staggering costs  which is why i nervously do this venture so far outside our comfort zones.      If anyone could help  even just a little  not just money  but even a kind message or a share of this  would really go far and be appreciated. My parents are not going to be happy i did this probably ( so if you could refrain from letting them know about this until the time is right) but I'll take the heat if it means life will be just a fraction easier while going through this.      They always put themselves last! To us  they'll know  at least this once  they are First! From my entire family  Thank you so much for your time  and i hope your lives are filled with happiness and love!                                                                                                      -J.R. Goodbred-                                                                              ￼

“TO GIVE IS TO RECEIVE” That’s what Sharon always says… to her kids  to her family and to her friends…. Unfortunately  now SHARON NEEDS YOUR HELP…. Sharon has been a part-time realtor and physical therapist for over 25 years and has dedicated most of her life to her children and others providing her therapy skills and selfless time for others.  Sharon loves to help others whether it is to help someone in pain  sit and support someone in need  or provide physical therapy to a neighbor or friend…she always gives so much of herself.  She is a mom  a daughter and a sister. She cannot work now as her doctors say she is in a fragile situation and it is very dangerous to function at a normal capacity  as her spine is compressed and her severe spinal stenosis is too extreme and activity must be kept to a minimum prior surgery.   She is in a delicate situation.   She works independently so her family obtained private health insurance that they struggle to pay which is almost $800 a month to be sure they were covered if any unexpected event would occur…So… they assumed… Sharon discovered she needs an IMMEDIATE MULTI-LEVEL SURGERY OF HER CERVICAL SPINE ASAP that she CANNOT AFFORD… Her current insurance plan has NO HOSPITAL OR SURGERY COVERAGE… She is working to upgrade her policy but if even successful  she cannot cover the deductibles  excess premiums with limited coverage  MRI’s  out of work and the bills are already coming in… Unfortunately  after several visits and out of pocket costs to spinal surgeons  initial MRI  blood work…she is running out of time and her resources depleted… Since she has cord compression  bony osteophytes  and .5mm of severe cervical stenosis at multiple levels  she is already experiencing weakness  numbness  and burning in her fingers.  She is terrified of such a massive surgical procedure but more terrified since she CANNOT PAY for the surgery as PARALYSIS  LOSS OF BOWEL AND BLADDER  AND LOSS OF BALANCE IS HER NEXT FUTURE PROGNOSIS.  IF THE SURGERY IS NOT DONE  PERMANENT PARALYSIS IS THE HER FUTURE… Sharon has always selflessly given her time to help others with support both mentally and with her therapy skills to relieve pain  give motion  and restore function.  She always is silly in nature and treats all her patients as if they were family members.  Her motto has always been  “to give is to receive.”  She is devastated that she CAN’T FIX HERSELF as she so often does for others.  She is pained to see the fear in her own mother’s eyes as she worries for her daughter.  Her friends will be there to help but SURGERY FOR HER PROCEDURES ARE BEYOND HER SCOPE AND HER CIRCLE OF FRIENDS AND FAMILY.  After surgery  will be a long haul for recovery and out of work to heal.  She has one son in college and another in high school  household daily bills  and now surgery  medication  hospital alone estimated over $100K and rehab to follow that will be accumulating putting her more and more deeper into debt…She is too proud to ask for anything herself.  She paid her way through college  her kid’s education and worked 3 jobs whenever needed  now she can’t work and this is why her friends are hoping to spread the word…to give back to her…. TO GIVE IS TO RECEIVE  please HELP SHARON with a PRAYER and or a CONTRIBUTION so she can continue to “GIVE” TO OTHERS WITH HER SPECIAL AND PASSIONATE TOUCH TO HEAL… IF ONLY SHE COULD HELP HERSELF…   We LOVE HER and want to bring her CONTAGIOUS SMILE and her bounce back to her step!   BRING BACK ALL THOSE PATIENT SMILES WITH SHARON NILES…. PLEASE SAY A PRAYER    AND ANY DONATION     IS SO HEARTFELT APPRECIATED!!! LET US HELP HER NOW…. What You Can Do !!!!You can help Sharon and her family by:Donating to this campaign through:1. The Donate button on this page2. Sharing this campaign:Please take five minutes out of your day to share Sharon’s story to as many people as possible. A quick email or a post on Facebook will make all the difference in creating a successful fundraising campaign for Sharon!  After surgery  recovery and rehab will be a long road…

Our beloved Eleanor Boyd-Davis has been a member of the Fernbank Elementary family for over 15 years.  She worked in the cafeteria for many years and made sure that all the students had a  healthy breakfast and lunch.  She is a daily aftercare employee and now also works as a custodian on the main level of the building.  Her youngest child also attended and graduated from Fernbank Elementary.  Eleanor has been bravely fighting cancer for about a year. She returned to work this February after months of chemotherapy. Recently  she was rushed to the hospital unresponsive and very ill due to a wide spread bacterial infection.  She was in ICU for 3 weeks and has finally been moved to a regular room at the hospital.  Thankfully  she is improving   but must undergo months of rehabilitation to regain her strength and abilities.  Eleanor's family is overwhelmed with excessive and out of pocket medical expenses.  Before her health insurance will pay the sizable bills  Eleanor and her family must come up with many thousands of dollars for deductible and out of pocket amounts.  In addition to these out of pocket expenses  Eleanor's  family members have lost numerous days of work  and Eleanor has used up all of her medical leave days.  She will not be able to return to work in the near future because she will be focusing on her rehabilitation.Eleanor has gone above and beyond for the staff and students of Fernbank Elementary  and now it is OUR time to go above and beyond for her!  Please donate what you can to Eleanor and her family so that they can focus on her recovery instead of the unending monetary stress of medical and household bills.

storyTitle: Help Dee Survive & Thrive - Diedra Brooks Lanphear
story: We are raising funds for my wife Diedra to continue pursuing alternative treatments against her stage IV metastatic ovarian cancer. These treatments have been and will continue to be instrumental to her survival  but are not covered by health insurance. Dee  as she is known to many  is really struggling right now and has been battling her ovarian cancer and it's recurrences since 2005. Dee is a joyful person who loves and embraces life. Dee is a spiritual person  a person of faith  ever optimistic and cheerful  and always lifts up and lends a hand to others. She is the sweetest person with the sweetest soul I have ever met. People that meet her often comment that she is a ray of sunshine that lights up the room she is in. Dee is a voracious reader and has done much research on her illness and has employed many natural and alternative therapies in addition to conventional medicine. Now she must re-double her efforts as the cancer that has recurred for the fourth time is inoperable  has and will require more and ongoing alternative therapies to shrink and eradicate it.  Dee's first diagnosis and major surgery were at Christmas in 2005. Since conventional chemotherapy and radiation were not proven effective against Dee's particular clear cell cancer  she sought both conventional and alternative treatment at Dr. James Forsythe's integrative oncology practice in Reno  Nevada in 2006. Dee was six years removed from that initial diagnosis  surgery  and treatment  when in early 2012 during her career as an international flight attendant with American Airlines  she became ill in London soon after working a trip from her beloved New York City base. After days of being too ill to travel and being confined to her hotel bed in London  she was finally able to fly as a passenger and return to our home in Durham  North Carolina. Unfortunately  tests revealed the severity of her illness  that being a mass in her abdomen that had perforated her colon and caused an infection and internal bleeding. In March of 2012 after five hours of surgery  the mass and a portion of her colon and small intestine were removed and it was diagnosed as a Stage IV recurrence of her ovarian cancer. Needless to say after a leave of absence she had to medically retire as the cancer precluded her return to flying and working. She returned to Dr. Forsythe in Reno  we invested in expensive but extensive testing to identify the most effective treatments to her particular cancer and we employed those therapies designed to build her immune system to combat any random cancer cells left behind from the surgery. Unfortunately and more than three years later in the fall of 2015  symptoms and a CT scan revealed a 2nd recurrence of her ovarian cancer in the form of another abdominal mass. Two weeks after receiving and amidst processing this news  Dee slipped and fell breaking her right arm at the shoulder. Dee was incapacitated without the use of her dominant arm for some months while determining the best course of action to deal with this 2nd recurrence. Having met and befriended members of a foundation for healing from Basel  Switzerland  on our return to New York during our last vacation in May of 2015  Dee pursued the alternative treatment suggested in hopes of building her immune system to fight the cancer and to shrink the mass. She traveled in January of 2016 to a clinic on the Baltic sea in Travemunde  Germany and received three weeks of intensive treatments via the clinic doctor and other members of the healing team. It was also unfortunate that my father  Dee's father-in-law (whom we cared for since the passing of my mother from glioblastoma cancer of the brain in 2006) was diagnosed with terminal lung and bladder cancer shortly thereafter. Our care for him precluded our complete focus on Dee's health  as his surgeries and hospitalizations both preceded and followed Dee's hospitalization and her very complicated and delicate six and a half hours of surgery to remove the mass and more of her bowel in September of 2016. The surgery was performed by Dr. Karyn Stitzenberg of the Lineberger Cancer Center at UNC Medical Center - Chapel Hill.After my father's passing in 2017  Dee's CT scan just before Thanksgiving in November of last year revealed a new abdominal mass. Dr. Stitzenberg again performed a complicated surgery to remove the mass and a portion of her duodenum and stomach that the tumor had attached to. Unfortunately  Dee had to spend another Christmas in the hospital and a longer recovery time  but we were grateful for another successful surgery.A CT scan at the end of July this year indicates that another mass has formed and it's proximity to vital organs and vessels precludes surgery. That was a shock but despite being inoperable  Dee as always is steadfast  resolute and optimistic she can beat this and shrink this tumor via alternative treatments. After experiencing severe abdominal pain resulting in a trip to the ER in August  another CT scan showed the mass was growing   compressing her stomach and bowels and causing a partial bowel obstruction. She was admitted to the hospital. Following her release  having already researched and with a trusted friend's recommendation and first hand account of numerous success stories with cancer treatment  Dee went to Bavaria in September for three weeks of intensive treatments and infusions (highlighted by local thermotherapy treatments to the area of the cancer  as described on the clinic's website) with Dr. Alex Weber at the private in-patient clinic for integrative medicine   www.klinik-marinus.com . Dee stayed for the fourth week of treatment as ultrasounds indicated the hyperthermia treatments were arresting the growth of her mass and the clinic provides such a healing environment  as is evidenced by accessing the link to their website above. Dee was too weak to climb stairs when she arrived at the clinic  but by the third week was walking daily on the paths in the meadows around the clinic and was even well enough to do some sight-seeing in nearby Kufstein and Salzburg  Austria at the end of her stay. Although we bought out Dee's retirement to fund a majority portion of the approximately $24 000 cost of the initial four weeks of treatment at the clinic  we used a credit card to pay the balance upon leaving the clinic after her last day of treatment on October 15th. Many of the clinic's patients return time and again for the beneficial \maintenance\" of the treatments. It was like night and day for how Dee looked and felt from arrival to departure from the clinic. We always envisioned her returning at some point next year  but are now considering a return as early as January 7th. After six weeks of renewed vibrancy being home from the clinic  Dee experienced complications  namely acute nausea and vomiting causing pronounced weight loss and weakness. A recent CT scan and cancer markers in her blood work preceding a hospital stay again last month indicated the mass has started to grow again and is further compressing her stomach and bowels. Dee was readmitted to the hospital again last week after renewed nausea and other complications were attributed to hypercalcemia  an elevated level of calcium in her blood. After treatment for dehydration and the hypercalcemia  Dee was able to keep soft foods and liquids down again and was released from the hospital on Saturday. We are now formulating our plan of attack to stabilize Dee's symptoms and to stop and shrink the mass. By employing the diet and nutrition plans of the likes of Chris Wark and Dr. Schultz  and by pursuing any and every measure of alternative treatments locally  such as vitamin and mineral infusions and ozone therapy  we hope to rebuild Dee's strength to allow a return to the healing environs of the Klinik Marinus am Stein in Germany in the New Year! Hopefully like below  she will be able to play hymns on the piano in the dining room for her fellow patients again in 2019! Although we have been reluctant to this point to ask for  expect or accept any help other than the continued prayers  well wishes and the positive words of encouragement that lift Dee up...any donations will help to defray some of the costs of the treatments she has already received and perhaps will help Dee to be able to pursue the additional and ongoing alternative treatments she will need moving forward!Thank you for your encouragement and support of our darling Dee!           May God Bless You!  Brad Lanphear"

The name Sofi Tsingos means different things to different people. To some  it is the name of the founder of GT-Moto  a Dallas-based motorcycle fabrication business born from the desire to generate money (over $50 000 to date) for cancer research  veterans with PTSD  and even helped a local moto-mom raise money to help pay for her medical bills after being diagnose with breast cancer. To many  it is the name of their genuine  immensely-thoughtful and fun friend who has experienced many setbacks in her lifetime but still manages to keep a smile on her face through them all. To others  it means sister  daughter  or fiancée.In 2016  after months of doctors visits and not being able to work in the garage  Sofi was diagnosed with and treated for an autoimmune disease called ulcerative colitis (UC). Due to the nature of the disease  she was unable to absorb any nutrients from the food that she consumed and could not function for more than 10 minutes at a time without feeling the need to pass out  while also dealing with constant excruciating abdominal pain. Any time she has a flare up  this causes her to be laid up in bed for months and takes a couple more month to gain her strength and stamina back. Although she is currently in remission  she still experiences significant relapses in periods of high stress and is required to take medication for the rest of her life  while still being constantly threatened by an increased risk of colon cancer or the eventual need for one of many surgical procedures to remove her colon entirely.Stem cell transplant therapy has been identified as an effective method of improving the quality of life of people with UC and reducing many of the aforementioned risks. Due to regulations in the US on such treatments  Sofi is forced to explore options outside of the country that are not covered by health insurance. This amounts to an approximate out-of-pocket cost of nearly $30 000.Though she is always donating thousands of hours and tens of thousands of dollars for charity  Sofi has never once asked for help with her own mishaps  so we think it is time for us to step up and help her. She will be immensely grateful for every little bit that you are able to provide!

Sometimes life throws you a curveball  one so monumental and humbling that you have no choice but to realize how fleeting and precious life really is.  My beautiful cousin spring has been thrown such a curveball.  Spring has been experiencing malaise  exhaustion and debilitating migraines for quite some time.  At 39 years old she was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor.  We are blessed to report that it is benign and operable  with minimal chance of returning.  As you can imagine this is a very costly procedure  requiring months of physical therapy and recovery.  Unfortunately her health insurance doesn't cover much of these medical expenses.  With a family to support she desperately needs our help!  So on her behalf we are starting this go fund me page for her as she is to modest to ask herself.  Please consider donating to her medical funds.  Any amount helps and is so unbelievably appreciated.  Thank you so much to everyone that has reached out with words of love and support.  We will continue to update this page as we track Spring's progress.  Lots of love and thanks-Spring's family

Duane Misico is a hard working person that has always provided for his family. Being a self employed contractor for decades he does not have health insurance. Duane has been dealing with many different crippling medical issues and the doctors still don't have answers or a treatment plan. Since Duane has been unable to work for a couple years there has been no income and the related medical expenses have wiped them out financially.  They have exhausted all retirement accounts  bank accounts  and credit cards. This has put him in a dangerous financial hardship.He can't afford daily items like food  gas  etc. Let alone not getting needed prescriptions to help him improve.Duane has always been there to help family  friends and even strangers. Anything you can do to help is greatly appreciated  even if its prayers and positive thoughts.

“HAVE A HEART” There was a wise Dean of St. Paul’s Cathedral who used to say prayers over those with birthdays.  What I remember most was the words “longevity is not promised”.  That impressed me to realize longevity is not a passive action but dependent on active action taken by the individual and sometimes by those who are in our circle.Close friends of mine - Christopher and Pamela Black  and their one year old son have been faced within their short years of marriage  Christopher’s severe Cardiac Problems.  As with every young couple their dream of buying a home  having a child and living happily ever after – has been over shadowed and shattered by Christopher’s unexpected and declining illness  as well as accrued debt from ongoing treatment.  That which has threatened the loss of income  loss of job  their home and ability to pay the uncovered medical expenses realized by an inadequate and costly health insurance industry.  And most of all the risk of a life cut short.Christopher who has been diagnosed with severe Atrial Fib  a rare blood clotting disorder  mitral valve damage  poor cardiac ejection fraction rate  and poor response to cardiac medications will have to endure open heart surgery due to the critical nature of his heart condition.  The outcome is tentative.On  January 21st  Christopher and his family will travel to the Cleveland Clinic for this surgery.  Christopher will be hospitalized approximately 2 weeks after the surgery if everything goes well  with at least a 2 month recovery period – and potentially some level of disability thereafter.   Pam must take FMLA with 50% reduction in pay to be with her husband during his hospital stay and during the acute period of recovery once Christopher is home.I am proposing this worthy “Go Fund Me” Initiative to assist this Family with the additional burden of expenses they will incur.    Taking into consideration these extraneous costs  I am proposing this “Go Fund Me Campaign”. My hope is that you will “open up your hearts” and consider a contribution to make a difference in the lives of this family who are just getting by financially.I am of the belief that whatever we do comes back “tenfold”.  Thank you for your compassion and prayers.            “A kind gesture can reach a wound that only compassion can heal”.        -Steve Maraboli

storyTitle: Help This Warrior fight her battle
story: Jai Phillips  a dedicated Sheriff’s Deputy  has recently been diagnosed with an aggressive cancer that has created a great financial burden for her to attend treatment. Also  her health insurance company will not cover all the necessary testing associated with treatment  causing even more of a financial crisis. Please show your love and support and help Jai with her battle.

We want to start this off by saying that we are hopeful  and we can't thank you all enough for the love and support that we  and our mom  have already received from the community. We believe that our mom will get through this and be stronger for it. Also  there are many close friends in our community and we are writing this on behalf of all those who know and care deeply about our mom. Thank you for being in this with us. ---The DiscoveryOn Friday December 7th  Nancy went to the doctor after discovering a lump in her side and having very low energy for many days. Upon doing a cat scan it was discovered she had two large tumors (measuring roughly 4x3x3 inches each) in her lower abdominal area. She was told they need to remove her uterous  ovaries  and lymph nodes all around that area as soon as possible. That will likely be followed with chemo or similar therapy  but we haven't been briefed on the options yet. Fortunately the cancer is \stage 3\" and hasn't yet metastasized to her intestines or vital organs. She was scheduled for an appointment on 12/18 with a surgeon at the Swedish Hospital in Seattle to discuss surgery. In the past few days pain has increased a lot and it seems to have progressed a lot for the worse  so we are hoping they will schedule the surgery for as soon as possible. We will post updates here as we know more.Help With ExpensesObviously Nancy is not able to work during this time and it will likely be a lengthy process. She has health insurance and we are still waiting to find out what exactly it will pay for or not. In any case  the expenses will rack up and will likely be in the many thousands. If you know Nancy  you know that while she has never had much  she has always given to others freely. She is not currently set up with savings to handle a situation like this. As her children  we are pulling together to cover whatever needs to be covered  and upon encouragement by several close friends we decided to put together this GoFundMe as a way for our friends and community to take part. About NancyNancy moved to Orcas Island in 1997 from Seattle and has lived in the islands ever since  while spending some years on Lopez before returning back to settle on Orcas. She is a mom of four  a grandma  and a \"Nana\" to many island youth. She is a caregiver  a midwife  a gardener  and a musician. If you live on Orcas Island you may know Nancy as the \"Marimba Lady\". That's because she has played and taught marimba music in the islands for the past 20 years. For many years it was a common occurrence on Orcas to hear marimba music resonating out from the town park. Nancy's signature during a performance is always to convince a random person from the audience to come up and learn to play on the spot  and which point she'll teach them a part and they'll be performing with the band in no time!\"Family-style\" Marimba in the parkNancy with baby Ruby 28 years ago.---With Gratitude Learner  Ruby  Lucas and Davis"

storyTitle: Help Theresa Recover and Get Back to Work
story: Our friend and sister  Theresa Johnson hasn’t been able to work since September 2018 and needs help for the next 4-6 months to stay in her home and get back on her feet physically and financially. For those of you who don’t know Theresa  she is the kindest  most generous and hardworking woman we know. She has spent her adult life working outdoors as an organic  farmer and an organic gardener and landscaper creating incredible beauty throughout the Berkshires. Theresa is proud and strong and fiercely independent and is terribly uncomfortable that we are doing this for her. In 1992 at the age of 25 Theresa not only had a new baby but was diagnosed with Stage 4 Non Hodgkins Lymphoma. After 18 months of multiple forms of chemo plus radiation she went in to remission. 27 years later those life saving treatments came back to haunt her with devastating consequences. In August 2018 Theresa was diagnosed with a form of breast cancer now known to be a direct result from the scatter effects of the radiation. Having had a lifetime dose of radiation in 1992 a lumpectomy and radiation were not an option. Theresa had a bi lateral mastectomy in October 2018. Just prior to the surgery she was also diagnosed with Tachycardia which can be life threatening and has gotten worse since the surgery.  Symptoms include racing heart  fatigue  pounding headaches and blurred vision.  Heart and lung damage are also some of the long-term side effects from the forms of chemo used in the 1990’s as well as the radiation.  Theresa is part of the Dana Farber Adult Survivorship Program which studies  follows and treats the later effects of previous cancer treatment. Extensive testing and procedures in Pittsfield  Springfield and Boston over the past 4 months have been inconclusive. Until the doctors can figure out the cause and the treatment she is unable to work and must restrict her physical activities. Theresa is fortunate to live in MA and have great health insurance through Mass Health.   Our goal is to raise $25 000 to cover everyday expenses and out of pocket medical expenses and give Theresa the time to have the reconstruction and heal her heart and get back to work.

On January 25 2019 I was waiting for my sister  my bestie   to head out to our planned girls overnight(which are few and far between) when I got a call from she and her OBGYN(and personal friend) who told me that she just had a severely abnormal mammogram that suggested she likely has breast cancer.  I had no idea she had concerns before this appointment.  The weeks to follow would be a whirlwind while we waited for definite answers. Tests showed that due to the size of the tumors and some lymph node involvement she is at a Stage 3.  Good news  if there can be good news from this  is that her cancer is estrogen and progesterone receptor positive which makes long term prognosis in her favor.   Here we are 2 months later and 4 chemotherapy treatments in.  My sister has lost her hair and just feels awful.  She is pushing through and trying to remain strong while working and taking care of her two littles.  While she is still working she is missing a lot of days because these treatments leave her absolutely debilitated.  She has 12 more infusions left.  We met with her surgeon last week who says she is making good progress.  She is planning on a double mastectomy Im guessing in August followed by radiation treatments and reconstructive surgery.  I would like to at the very least lesson her financial burden by raising money to pay her deductible  so that she can focus on her mental and physical health.  Nobody ever plans on having cancer and unfortunately health insurance doesn’t cover everything.  Please consider helping in any way you can  no donation is too small and lots of prayers are welcome.  Our family truly appreciates you all!

My wife Natalie suffers from a gradually progressive nerve disorder called myasthenia gravis. Just over a year ago she underwent a major  open rib cage surgery (thymectomy) that put her MG into a form of remission  but we have since learned from her neuro-specialist that such a surgery can have some major side effects. One of these side effects is ferocious pain and occasional numbness in her extremities. This can  and has recently  cause her to be unable to move about or stand for periods if time. This means that  as that she is a full time cake decorator  she is unable to perform her duties at work. Her job  sadly  does not offer sick time or paid days off; if you can't work  you don't get paid.As a professional in the game industry I myself don't get offered Health Insurance  and we have been paying unconscionably high monthly insurance rates so she can go to her specialist  get her needed medication  and sadly take 2 Emergency Room trips in the last year when \attacks\" occur. It is scary as hell  and extremely expensive.We have been doing alright  but a recent hiccup in my steady income (when combined with her medical inability to get to work) has made the last portion of her medical bills go to collections and begin to take its toll on our household.We have tried going to Social Services  but Indiana has some very strict laws concerning what is and isn't a disability... meaning the government programs for this sort of thing are no help.I have seen others in my industry fall on hard times and need to reach out to their fans  friends  and family; I have helped where I could. Now  it seems  we look to the universe to see what  if any  aid we can gather. My new freelance wages can pay our day to day and keep our family fed and warm  but the numbers keep growing and the tunnel that has that light at the end... well  it feels like it is just getting longer and longer.I want to be able to pay all of this back medical debt  but the life of a game industry professional is more than a little check-to-check  and as a husband and father... I'm not too proud to know when I need help. Thanks for reading all of this  and even if you can't or won't help us in this rough patch... please share the link and spread the word.Thanks again."

When Callie was born on 2/26/2014 she was healthy in every way with the exception of her right ear and right jaw.  Her ear condition is called microtia.  Microtia is a congenital deformity where the pinna (external ear) is underdeveloped.  Her jaw condition is called hemifacial microsomia.   Hemifacial microsomia (HFM) is a congenital disorder that affects the development of the lower half of the face  most commonly the ears  the mouth and the mandible.  Callie's parents have made certain that Callie expresses herself and is very involved with decisions involving her treatment.  Recently she has been talking more and more about how she would like a real ear (she wants to be able to wear earrings and sunglasses.... basically  she wants to be able to have two ears like mostpeople do).  Callie will be starting kindergarten in the fall and the family is hoping that she will have her right ear by then.Treatment options are surgical or prosthetic.  Callie's parents have decided on a prosthetic ear at this time.  If Callie decides when she is a little older that she would like surgery then she still has that option (her mom and dad really want her to be comfortable with decisions made regarding her treatment).  Robert R. Barron  former CIA Disguise Specialist will be doing Callie's evaluation at her appointment in March.   Mr. Barron is committed to restoring identities through prosthetic devices.  He has people travel from China to consult with him.  He has made guest appearances on Oprah  Montel and Botched.  Unfortunately Callie's health insurance will not cover any of this because it is considered cosmetic.  They do not consider the pain that Callie might endure because let's face it.... bullying and ridicule are way too prevalent in our world.  Fortunately  Callie has charisma and inner strength that just blows us away.  We are asking for donations so that Callie can have the ear that she is so excited about by the time kindergarten starts.  The total cost for the ear is $7000.  In order for Mr Barron to begin making the impressions Callie's parents will need $2 300 with the remainder due soon after.  Thank you so much for taking the time to read this.  All of us are forever grateful for any help that you can give .... This could make such a positive difference in this little girl's life.

If you know Josh Dean at all   you know what an amazing person he is.  He is a father  a husband  a son  a brother  and a friend. He is humble and shares his heart openly.  He’s an artist  and a photographer.  He is hardworking and a master at his craft installing beautiful tile for the last two decades.  Our family made the move from Massachusetts to Maine a year and a half ago for a better way of life. This past October  the day after his 42nd birthday  he got the call that a yearly endoscope procedure revealed some trouble spots that came back diagnosed as diffused stomach cancer.  Since receiving this news  Josh has been to a multitude of appointments with various teams of physicians and other medical professionals  all performing many different tests to determine the staging and course of action. It has been determined that it is Stage 4 metastatic stomach cancer. Josh’s treatment plan is to undergo chemotherapy first to shrink the cancer that’s there now.  After the first round of chemo  more tests will be done to determine the next steps.  Eating has has already become an issue and a feeding tube has recently been installed. When he is able to eat  he will be eating according to a very strict nutritional diet plan and will be taking a number of supplements that will hopefully  strengthen his body's ability to handle the strong doses of chemo. He will also be looking into more natural types of treatment. The current plan will be Josh’s best chance at survival. While Josh does have health insurance  he will have to travel to the hospitals that are best suited to administer his treatment. Right now  this means traveling for chemotherapy and other additional treatments  and it is not definite that our insurance will cover the high cost of such treatments  and all the procedures that are an integral part of the treatment plan. We are also looking into treatments in Boston  but again It is not certain that they will accept our insurance  and it would be out of pocket expenses for us.During the course of treatment  Josh’s immune system will be seriously compromised  he will be exhausted   as well as dealing with a myriad of other pains and side effects that come with cancer treatments.  As a result  he will not be able to work. He is a self-employed individual  carrying the weight of his career by himself..  he will not be getting any type of compensation the whole time he is not working and may not be able to actually go back to a construction lifestyle.. This means that Josh will have no way to contribute towards rent  utilities  food  child care  pet care  or any other of life’s expenses.  So  not only does Josh have to worry about getting better  he also has to worry about paying his and his family’s basic living expenses. I have just started a new job in the last couple of months  and while the company has been very accommodating  starting as a new hire with this kind of news  needing time off for appointments  care  etc  will be difficult at times. I will be the only one working through this journey  as well as taking time off to help him. Even with a solid support team behind us it is guaranteed to be a tough road. There is also a very brave little 10 year old girl  who loves her Daddy very much  involved with this! One can only fathom the anguish a child feels while a parent deals with such a dilemma. We will be trying our absolute best to maintain normalcy thru the days  as he will be receiving his treatments straight through the holidays.This is where you can help.  Through your donations  whatever they may be  love  light  positivity  snacks or even a heartfelt “Hey  hope you’re all doing OK!” each of you has the power to give Josh our love and thanks  to be there for him in this difficult time  giving him peace of mind that he and his family will be taken care of while he is not able to do so. Please join in donating whatever you can to help Josh beat cancer! Layla and I thank you all tremendously. It is hard for us to reach out and ask for help  but in times like these  help is needed. Thanks for your support.Love and warmest regards Ilana Dean

Hello!  We’re Jen and Peter Bayreuther  and we know Cheryl and Randy Kilgore because we’ve been walking alongside them as friends and working alongside them as co-laborers in their ministry efforts for over 15 years.  As some of you already know  a perfect storm of serious health challenges and a drop in both donors and the amounts those donors are giving is having a disastrous impact on Cheryl and Randy.  It is heartbreaking to watch  especially as they continue ministering to and helping others around them.   (Please see below for some of the many things the Kilgores do to help others as they also serve Jesus.)  The Need:  After nearly two decades of active ministry  Cheryl and Randy now find themselves at the very edge of fiscal  emotional and physical collapse.  With no reserves and very little extended family  the Kilgores have worked tirelessly to bring hope and help to people in need without ever asking for anything for themselves in return.  Three years ago  they began to experience a series of relentless health challenges that have cost them more than $80 000 in medical expenses beyond those covered by their health insurance. In 2016  Randy underwent open heart surgery to repair a life-threatening defective artery. Earlier this year  Cheryl was diagnosed with endometrial cancer  requiring major surgery and a lengthy recovery period. In between  Randy had two additional weeklong hospital stays  one to address gall bladder surgery and another to clear a blocked colon  Cheryl was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes  and their son battled serious illness that left him without income and work for nearly three months. Will you come alongside Randy and Cheryl with us in this time of need? This is not abstract; it's concrete  meaningful  and life changing. Our goal is significant AND reachable. Your gift of $25 or $2500 brings tangible relief to a family near and dear to all of us.  Our goal is to raise $25 000 to help them cover their medical bills  premiums  automobile repair  as well as groceries and utilities while they are ramping back up.  Smaller gifts will enable them to tackle specific items while larger gifts will help them pay the huge medical premiums and bills still coming in. Actual medical costs are expected to exceed $30 000 in the coming year  so any funds received above our goal will be used to cover those costs as well. A History of Helping: After nearly a decade with a Boston-based ministry that folded in 2006  Randy founded an international initiative  the Theology of Work Project  Inc. ( www.theologyofwork.org)  and Cheryl served as it’s Project Manager.  It’s initial goal was to provide commentary from each book of the Bible on what God teaches about work.  At the same time  the Kilgores founded Desired Haven Ministries  Inc.   an evangelistic and discipleship organization aimed at helping people encounter and know the great love of God  with a specific emphasis on informing their work lives.  One of the highlights of their ministry are writings and teachings from Scripture useful in everyday life.  Because of their own inability to access certain helpful tools because of their cost  Cheryl and Randy have always believed God wanted them to make their resources available at little to no cost so no one was denied access regardless of their personal financial situation.  This sacrificial view  however  has often meant living on the edge of God’s provision week after week even when their health issues weren’t major.Beginning in 2012  God began moving them beyond their more narrow focus on workplace ministry  calling them to spend more time writing for and ministering to the people who find themselves marginalized by organized religion. Of particular importance is their desire not to add to the fighting that presently dominates the public debates on the front lines of culture.  For example  with suicide rates increasing at a dramatic pace  Cheryl and Randy work to address some of the causes for the hopelessness that leads to this tragic action. This includes writing about best care and ministry practices already available  as well as developing new tools to help people cope with mental illness  addictions  anxiety and depression  and other issues of everyday life.  God has also called the Kilgores to provide support to Christians and others in the LGBTQ communities  including strengthening and building new bridges between families split by hard attitudes and harsh treatment by extremists in and out of the church. In addition to new tools  Cheryl and Randy are eager to understand what help is already out there for the people they serve; and and how to build bridges between the people in need and services already available.  Their new website ( www.IntersectionZ.com) not only provides a way for them to write about both the need and potential help  but also gives them a chance to spread the word about volunteer and giving openings that exist  all while building an online community of people who understand the issues and want to help.

storyTitle: Help us make her a cancer SURVIVOR
story: Anyone that has ever met Laura knows that her smile is contagious and that her heart is made of gold. Her biggest joys in life are her children and her grand babies. Her door has always been open to anyone that needed it  and even on her bad days she is always there to make us smile and tell us that everything is going to be okay. She is the glue that has held the family together through its toughest moments. She recently left California and moved to Idaho to enjoy retirement and be with their youngest daughters and grandchildren. But unfortunately bad things seem to happen to the most amazing people. Our Laura has just been diagnosed with a horrible form of cancer... Pancreatic  which is a rapidly fast spreading cancer. She lives on social security and has poor health insurance  with that being said our family is terrified and asking that you please help us get her the treatments that she needs to fight this and be the miracle that she has always been to all of us! Its our turn to make sure she is okay  she is a fighter and we are all praying that you can help us help her. Thank you in advance The Reeves Family

storyTitle: Help Lisa  Medulloblastoma treatment and care
story: On December 18   2018  Lisa Pepper-Byron a 34-year-old loving mother of 3 young daughters; ages 2 6  & 7 of Concord North Carolina was diagnosed with Medulloblastoma  a cancerous tumor—also called cerebellar primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET)—that starts in the region of the brain at the base of the skull  called the posterior fossa. These tumors tend to spread out to other parts of the brain and to the spinal cord. Lisa was working diligently as a wedding planner to support her family before she was diagnosed and currently is without health insurance. Since Lisa started her radiation treatments  she is unable to work and support her family.  All funds collected will go to Lisa’s treatments  medication   a reliable vehicle  and short term expenses for her and her family. With high hopes we sincerely hope you support this campaign so that Lisa can undergo her chemotherapy treatments without the worries of her finances.

storyTitle: Rachel's extended hospital stay for Baby Wilson
story: Rachel and I (Samuel) were expecting our first baby on May 26th  2019. We had a very healthy pregnancy that was progressing well until March 28th when Rachel's water unexpectedly broke at 31 weeks. We went to the doctor that Thursday afternoon and talked to them. After running tests the doctors believed the baby had simply pushed some urine out and that all was well  they sent us home with the belief that things would resolve themselves. The next day the same issue of leaking fluid was still happening  so we made another trip to the hospital hoping that all would be okay. Upon arriving in the room  the doctor ran a swab test that immediately confirmed Rachel's water had in fact broken. Following this realization  the doctors started piling info onto us regarding what the next few weeks would look like.  First  Rachel was admitted into OU Children's hospital for roughly two weeks while the doctors have tried to speed up lung development and avoid infection. Steroids have been administered for speeding up the development of the baby's lungs and Rachel was given antibiotics to lower the risk of infection (that risk had gone up since the baby is now exposed to the outside).While these things were being administered  Rachel stayed in a labor and delivery room. There they had the resources that would be needed in case Rachel were to go into labor naturally.  She remained stable during the first 12-16 hours of observation.  Once the immediate threat of labor passed  she was moved to the Special Care section of the labor and delivery floor.  Now she is being observed each day with and the goal is to stay pregnant until she is 34 weeks along.  Once she turns 34 weeks on April 14th  the plan is to induce labor and have our baby.  If she develops an infection or goes into labor the plan is to deliver sooner rather than later.  Either way  the baby will go directly to the NICU to continue development before going home.This leaves us hopeful yet anxious for our first child's well being.  The nurses and doctors here are some of the best  and we know God is watching over us.  However  the financial burden of this unexpected turn is overwhelming and hard to navigate.  We want the best care for our family  but Rachel has left work much earlier than expected and is left with little to no maternity pay.  We know that God will provide for us and that he works in mysterious ways to make miraculous things happen.  Turning to our loved ones for help has been a humbling and incredibly grateful experience.  Thank you for reading this and for any prayers or support you can provide.With everyone's help  we're hoping to raise $7000. This to us is a staggering amount of money. The total is made up of a $5000 health insurance deductible which will help keep our insurance covering 75% of the remaining total instead of dropping to an unknown percent of coverage if we are unable to pay. We had a plan consisting of Rachel working until the end of the school year and receiving paid time off during the summer as self earned maternity leave  unfortunately that plan is no longer viable. Because that plan essentially fell apart and we lost half of our income overnight  the other $2000 is to help with any costs  bills  and emergencies that happen in our day to day lives outside of the hospital  like loan payments  utility payments  car repairs  food  gas  etc. Please let us know if you have any questions that we can answer. Everyone's support  generosity  and aid mean more to us than we can possibly express. -Rachel  Samuel  and Baby Wilson.

Addison Kinchen is the 2-year-old daughter of one of our co-workers. She has been diagnosed with a tumor in the brain that is called a Glioma. Addison underwent brain surgery to perform a biopsy on the tumor and determine a path forward.  A team of doctors will know more relatively soon  after the review of the biopsy has been completed  and the oncology team has developed a path forward and treatment plan to beat this cancer. For now  the doctors have installed a Ventricular catheter that is attached to a reservoir just underneath the skin for any excess spinal fluid “brain fluid” to go as her brain is not doing this correctly on its own and has been causing extra pressure.  Brent  her father  works in North Dakota while the family stayed behind in Washington to be closer to Seattle Children’s Hospital to receive the best medical care for little Addison. The road to recovery will be long  emotionally straining and expensive. While they have health insurance  expenses such as travel  meals  and additional medical treatments not covered by insurance  will cause undue pressure on the family. We would like to help relieve some of the strain felt by her parents by helping financially and allowing them to focus on loving and support Addison in the fight for her life.  Let’s team together  give generously and show the Kinchen family the true spirit of support and love.

storyTitle: Help Pitz with Medical Bills After Heart Surgery
story: Pitz Quattrone and Mick Jagger  both had heart valve replacement surgery last week.  They are both lucky to be strong and healthy and are both on the road to recovery. The only difference between these two mighty souls is their ability to pay their medical bills and the impact that their lost wages will have on their families.  Pitz and his family need $10 000 to pay their medical bills and maintain their monthly bills because of his lost wages. Pitz went to the ER on March 19th with chest pains.  He quickly found out that he had aortic stenosis  which was caused by a congenital heart defect (bicuspid valve....2 instead of 3 flaps).  He had heart valve replacement surgery at UVM Medical Center on April 4th and is recovering well.  Pitz stopped working at the advice of his doctors on March 20th and will most likely be out of work for an additional 6-8 weeks.  Pitz and his family (partner Amy and daughter Tillie) pay for their own minimal health insurance and have a hefty deductible to meet before it will begin to cover Pitz's hospital  doctor  and medication bills for his heart surgery.  Amy is self employed and Pitz works part time hosting the Getaway a weekday music show on WDEV Radio Vermont where he doesn't qualify for health benefits.  Pitz supplements his radio work with didgeridoo related performing and workshops.  Their monthly bills are already piling up due to Pitz's medical leave.  Pitz  Amy and Tillie have been overwhelmed by the love and support that they have received from family and friends over the last several weeks.  Your love and good energy have certainly seen Pitz through the toughest part of this ordeal.  Please consider contributing to this fundraiser to help Pitz and his family! And...perhaps there will be a Pitz and Mick Cardiac Rehab Tour later in 2019!

Our mom Tammy was diagnosed a month ago with stage 1b uterine cancer. After undergoing a complete hysterectomy  it was determined that the cancer had spread to her cervix  and that she has malignant cells in her abdominal cavity. She will need to undergo 6 rounds of chemotherapy  3 rounds of radiation treatments  and a colonoscopy in hopes to rid her body of the cancer. Unfortunately  she does not have health insurance at the moment  and it is imperative that she begin treatment immediately. We have found that it will cost $7000 just to insert the port needed to administer the chemo. For those of you who know our mom  you know that she is an extraordinary human being. She is cheerful  loving  unbelievably strong  and always puts her friends and family before herself.Now  it's time that we send back some of that love and support to her. We want her to be able to focus on beating this  rather than the struggle of being able to afford it. Anything we can do to help surround her with love during this difficult time is of the utmost importance  so if you are able donate  it will be truly appreciated. Anything helps. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

My name is Mark  and I am too weak to write this  so my son is doing it for me.How did I get to this point  I worked hard all my life both for the City of Chicago  as an Asphalt Engineer  and running a part-time construction company to provide for my wife and our six boys. Yes  six boys  I always put my families needs above my own and sacrificed long hours to make sure we had a good roof and food on the table. I did not come from money just the opposite a broken home  and we were relatively poor but strong in spirit.  I had the American dream work hard and grow old on my retirement pension. However  that dream came crashing apart very quickly in 2016.Ten years after I retired  from the City of Chicago  whom I worked for 32 years  which guaranteed me 80% of my salary and would provide me with health insurance as part of my compensation in my pension deal. Sounds like a great deal  right.  However  three years ago in 2016 the city made a decision to cut-costs and stopped all health insurance benefits on retired pension holders  stating that going forward we would need to purchase our own health insurance as the city was in a deficit. On a take-home pension of  $50K per year  I now had to front $32  160 per year to cover my spouse and myself for health insurance.  This didn't even allow me enough money to cover my mortgage payment  credit card debt  utility bills  car insurance  and other standard living expenses.To make matters worse at the end of that same year  2016   I was diagnosed with MDS Blood Cancer  which over the next two years morphed into AML Leukemia.
