The past three years have wiped us out financially  and now the banks threaten to take our house as I sit in the hospital literally fighting for my life.  I now have till the end of April to come up with money to save my house with mounting medical bills  and I am praying to God for a miracle that I may survey this life-threatening disease and still have a home to come to if I survive.If by any chance you have the means to even give a $1 or two and to please share my story  I might actually be able to come up with the funds to stop the bank  so that I can still have a roof over my head if I survive.  Thank you for reading this and God bless you and keep you safe.

Local Police Officer Finds Perfect Donor Match in Wife!We are friends and co-workers of Angela who want to help in any way we can.The scene: 1980’s. Brownsville  TX. High School Spanish class. ... Sitting at her desk  a young Angela spies a handsome Arturo (Art) sitting at his desk  across the room  and it is love at first sight!  She told her 2 best friends that she was going to marry that boy. She had found her soulmate. She can’t believe her good fortune when the two start dating. Over the course of the next seven years  after surviving high school drama and the pressure of playing competitive sports  Art worked many jobs so Angela could finish her college degree  because that’s what you do for someone you love – your perfect match; you are there for them. They were blissfully married on June 12  1998  blessed with their first child and Arturo went on to complete his college degree. In 2008 the family made the difficult decision to leave everything and everyone they had ever known to take advantage of the many opportunities a bigger city  Houston  TX  has to offer. Both Angela and Art were educators in the school system  but had to face the hard fact that education jobs in Houston were few and far between at that time. Despite that  Art and Angela fell in love with Houston and Art could no longer ignore his deep desire to “protect and serve” his new community and proudly became a Houston Police officer. They are beyond blessed to have 4 amazing children;  Alyssa 20  a Junior in college  Audrey 18  a senior in high school  Abriana 15  a sophomore in high school  and Aj 12  a seventh grader.  Art has been their softball coach since they were old enough to swing a bat and continues to coach them throughout their lives.   Fast forward to March 2018. Art now has 10 years on the force at the Southwest Division where he has earned several top performer accolades from his department. Unfortunately  Art found out his kidneys have failed him due to his lupus. He is told he is in need of a kidney transplant ASAP.  Art comes from a family of 7 and even though his siblings offered to be tested  Art strictly refused. Art being Art  he did not want to complicate anyone’s life by taking their kidney. The family and friends who did get tested  unfortunately  were not a match. Remember  Art and Angela are soulmates  a perfect match  so it stands to reason that Angela would be tested. This had to work. After months of being poked and prodded  Angela was a match! Now it is her turn to be there for him. She is able to give her husband  her soul mate  the father of their children  their provider and coach  the ultimate gift - her kidney; because that’s what you do for someone you love. After staring death in the face and refusing to accept its’ calling  Art will be able to continue to serve the community that he loves  be the supportive and loving husband and father he is and live a long healthy life.  The procedure is scheduled for December 17th  2018.  Even though both Art and Angela have health insurance as a benefit through their jobs  being a perfect donor match for your husband comes with its’ own set of challenges; 1)      Recovery time - Art: The family will be without either parent working for a few months. No amount of health insurance will cover the necessary expenses a family of 6 faces every day. This will be a financial hardship like the family has never known before. As many police officers do  Art works extra jobs to help maintain the financial stability of the household and he will not be able to do this during his recovery. 2)      Recovery time – Angela: Due to certain policies at her current job  Angela will not be compensated during her recovery time. On behalf of the amazing Garcia Family  we are asking for any monetary support you can provide.The out-of-pocket expense for this procedure is astronomical. We understand that the holidays are just around the corner  but please consider donating to help this loving family get through this incredibly trying time. No donation is too small and will be forever appreciated.

Hernando or Nando as we many of us call him is so much more than just my brother-in-law. He's a man of great intellect  dad humor  and most importantly- a family man. His love for his wife and kids is fueled by a generous heart and the tenacity of being and immigrant. He was diagnosed with stage IVA Tongue Squamous Cell Carcinoma in January of this year. Because he does not have health insurance in the states  he went back to Colombia to have surgery on Feb 4th. This month he will start his treatment. He will undergo 33 sessions of radiotheraphy and 6 sessions of chemotherapy. There's lots of uncertainty about the future.  In the meantime  we are doing all we can to emotionally support his family here. I would like to raise some money to help pay their rent for the next 6 months  giving them some room to breath and make some of the hard decisions that are coming up. We are so grateful for the life we have here.  I personally have been blessed by their family and love  so I am asking you to dig deep and help me  help them.

In August of 2018 Don Jr. was diagnosed with Stage IV pancreatic cancer that metastasized to his liver and stomach. At his 6 month PetScan the tumor had grown in strength and size. He recently had a GI tube put in  along with a TPN IV for liquid food.  He currently can not eat any solids.  We are hoping that with radiation the tumor that is blocking his stomach will shrink  and he will be able to eat his favorite foods  again.  Unfortunately while Don Jr. was receiving treatment his wife Debbi became unemployed and they lost their health insurance coverage.  In order to keep going to the Cancer Center of America they had to rely on getting Cobra  which is quite expensive.  Your funds will go towards  his health care which will improve his quality of life.  Don Jr. is a fighter and is anxiously awaiting the birth of his first grandson.

In October 2017 at age 51 my cousin Don found himself in the ER for visual like disturbances  etc. A CT scan found a brain tumor.  This was eventually diagnosed as a Stage III Malignant glioma  astrocytoma.  The brain tumor was surgically removed but about 10% could not be excised due to its proximity to his speech areas. He also had 6 weeks of radiation. Don did well for quite some time and was able to perform light duty jobs at work up until September 2018.   The remaining tumor though has been progressing and the last few months aggressively. Don has been fortunate in being well taken care of and loved by his family.  Although it is a difficult stage  he is now in Hospice care at home. I know their services are much needed and will be a blessing to the family. Many ask what they can do?  This account is being set up for the family to help with finances  loss of income  health insurance premiums and patient responsibility costs for the next months. Don’s insurance was valid until November 30th. His Social security and Medicare were approved  but a waiting period must be met and he is not eligible until March of 2019.  Debbie is continuing his insurance but the premiums must be paid out of pocket now and it is expensive. It seems Don was always helping someone with fixing ‘something’ right?  Help us to financially support the Dadula family...Don  Debbie  Alex  Bella and Tim. Their faith sustains them through these struggles. Perhaps you might have the ability to help in any small way to alleviate some of the financial burdens at an already challenging time.

I want to begin this post by thanking everyone that has reached out to our family during this challenging time. Your kind words and prayers lift us up every day. On December 1st my dad  Gregorio Esquivel  suffered a severe stroke. Initial treatment was timely and appropriate  but still his condition worsened. He was admitted at SSM University Hospital in St. Louis. Multiple scans showed that significant damage had occurred in my dad’s brainstem  specifically an area needed for movement. Due to the stroke  he is currently paralyzed from the neck down. He also has weakness of his head and neck which means he cannot eat or drink by mouth and he cannot vocalize his words yet. We are happy to say that he is out of ICU and is stable. He is completely conscious  aware of his surroundings  and as smart as ever. Gladly  his spirit and sense of humor are intact. Based on the symptoms  the doctors agree that his stroke should be treated as if it were a spinal cord injury. His best chances at regaining movement is by going to a rehab center that specializes in this type of therapy. But the story does not end here:In 1999 we moved to the US from Monterrey  Mexico. For nearly 20 years he has called the US his home. During that time my dad has worked tirelessly  paid his taxes  provided for our family and enjoyed every day of it. He is a good member of his community and a friend to all. In the early 2000s  he began communicating with the Immigration Services to gain citizenship. However  it can take 20-30 YEARS for immigration applications to go through  this includes my dad’s application. They are currently reviewing applications filed in 1998 and 1999. Although he may be lawfully here  he is not a citizen  nor does he have a green card. To further complicate things  he does not currently have health insurance. This is where we are stuck and in the most humble way we are asking for help. If my dad is to accept Medicaid or any sort of government help  his request to gain citizenship in the future will likely be denied. We have been given the option of sending him to Mexico but if both of my parents go  they could be penalized with 10 years of no re-entry. We are working hard every day to find out what options we have available. We are confident we will solve these problems. But the fact remains that my dad is lying in hospital bed and mom remains attached at bedside. My dad is 53 years old and has lifetime of memories left to make. Help us help him. Help us get him the help that he needs and deserves. He has long road to recovery  but we have high hopes and even higher faith that he will recover and together we will get through this.

storyTitle: Help & Support Paul Ariaz fight to beat Cancer
story: ****************************************************************************My dear cousin  Paul Ariaz  43 years old  was recently diagnosed with Multiple Myeloma cancer in his bone marrow.  For those of you who know him  you know that he is an extraordinary human being.  He is a devoted and proud father of 5 beautiful kids. He is cheerful  loving  unbelievably strong and always puts his family and friends before himself. He's been undergoing many tests and exams and as a result  he will be having to undergo even more of an intense form of chemotherapy soon  followed by bone marrow surgery. Because of this  he has been unable to work and will likely not be able to return until further notice.  As we hear from many cases  the lack of quality health insurance is though and many employers and insurance companies make it very challenging to obtain. Paul has been denied many services that some of us are fortunate to have and the accumulations of hospital bills has taken a toll on his family. Unfortunately  short term disability does not provide full pay.  Some of his medical expenses are not covered and with the everyday necessities of life  money is getting tighter and tighter.  Paul is one of the strongest  most selfless people we have ever known and is always there to give his love and support or the shirt off his back to anyone that needs it.   Now  it's time that we send back some of that love and support to Paul and his family.  Thank you for your unwavering love and support. Anything you can donate will be truly appreciated.  Everything we can do to help and surround him with love is what is most important so he can focus on beating this thing. We will do our best to keep you updated on his status.Please spread the word. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts…muchas gracias!Mariana Rodriguez Ortiz

We are sad to say Mike Spinney has been diagnosed with colon  cancer at the beginning of December. He has been a Glenwood Springs City Market family member for the last 18 years. He is our grocery manager  and all around amazing person to have around. His wife Monica works with us as well  they have a 4 year old boy together John Michael . At this time we are asking for help as bills begin to pile up and only continue to stack higher even with health insurance the expenses are unbelievable. At this time Mike is unable to work . All proceeds will be donated directly to the family❤ Anything helps at this time Thank you!

From May of 2018 through August of 2018 my cousin Chong felt a lot of discomfort. Some from an aggravating injury at work and a small hernia. He had formed a mass on the upper part of his right leg and began to favor it with a limp. He began to experience pain in his back and met several times with various doctors and a general surgeon. While waiting on word from workers comp and pending insurance approval for a hernia operation  on the morning of September 5th  2018 he was headed out to work but returned home shortly. As he was trying to wake up his wife  he was panting and near collapsed. He was on the floor unable breathe and had stabbing pains in his back. She quickly rushed him to the ER. Being convinced it was a possible broken rib they awaited the results of all the tests. The Xrays showed he had formed a blood clot in his lung and in the some of the scans it showed enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal area. They needed to admit him for further testing and start him on blood thinners. They also suggested this could possibly be cancer. A WORLD FOREVER CHANGED For 8 days in the hospital he was receiving heparin via IV to reduce the likelihood of the blood clot to worsen. More screening tests and scans were ordered. They took a biopsy of the mass on his leg. On September 2  2018 they performed a surgery on the lymph node removing about 1/3 for further testing. Tests were still pending and on Septemer 13  2018 he was discharged with a pending prognosis. They suspected it could possibly carcinoma  soft tissue sarcoma or even possibly rhabdomyosarcoma. On October 2  2018 my cousin went back for a prognosis. Testing was not conclusive so they performed some more testing and had him return on the 10th. It turns out my cousin Chong has has enlarged lymph nodes throughout his entire his body all the way up to one in the neck. It was categorized as a Stage 4 High Grade Pleomorphic Soft Tissue Sarcoma. The worst part is  it is high grade and travels through the lymph nodes of his body. It has already spread to his liver. On the 12th of October he received his first chemotherapy treatment. Last night on October the 16th he was hospitalized as his kidneys gave out to chronic kidney failure and we are praying for a speedy recovery but it seems he won't be able to receive his scheduled his 2nd chemotherapy trearment this coming Friday. HOW WE CAN HELP 1. Prayers are greatly appreciated as there are many studies whether we believe them or not that blind prayers could help in a manner that is beyond explanation. A prayer wont make Stage 4 cancer go away but we can ask for courage and strength so that he can battle the cancer head on. 2. Recently my cousin and his wife bought their first home together. While Kristen has a good job  my cousin Chong is not able to work which has reduced them to single income. Kristen's boss has been more than supportive allowing time off but a fight with cancer isn't a short battle. 3. All money raised will go directly to my Chong and Kristen so that they can use the money to pay for all the things that health insurance doesn't cover. There are many costs associated it with it from something as simple being able to eat in the hospital cafeteria all the way to covering expenses related to every day life. We are not expecting a million dollar donation  but if everybody could give anything even if it's a single $1  a share of the page would go a long way. 4.... hmmm being from L.A. I'm a Dodgers fan  but if the Astros could make it to the World Series and give the Dodgers a good series and then go to a game 7  maybe I would be happy with either outcome since it would lift his spirits. Thanks for taking the time to read this.

John is in surgery today  December 13  for the removal of the tumor that caused his colon cancer.In June  at 46 years old  John was diagnosed with stage 3c colon cancer.  In August John started chemotherapy. By September  his reduced the size of his tumor to more than half in September and the tumor is out of the lymph nodes and has decreased significantly. In October he was having chemo and radiation treatments 5 days a week for 5 and a half weeks.  In November his tumor had gone from the size of his fist to the size of a large walnut. Hopefully today it should be the size of a marble.His surgery will remove the tumor  but he’ll be in the hospital for 3 to 4 days and unable to go to the salon for 10 days after that. He’ll also resume chemotherapy. He still has a long road ahead.Throughout it all these past 6 months  John has been positive and inspirational to many of us  as always. He’s going through radiation and chemo  lost much of his hair  he’s exhausted  he’s going through a divorce  but he has continued to make so many of us beautiful by going to Blanc  rocking Moroccanoil  raising his wonderful kids  working out  doing yoga and never letting us know how hard it is every single day.  This GoFundMe campaign is to help John cover his expenses while he’ll be out of work the next few weeks and continuing to recover in the ongoing months. While he has health insurance  his savings account has taken a big hit from lost time at the salon and his insurance deductible. Financial support through this GoFundMe will go a long way in helping John in one burden so he can concentrate on the most important thing now  getting well. Anything you can give financially  spiritually and emotionally helps.

Hello Everyone. I am the daughter-in-law of Travis Wright. I made this GoFundMe page to help Travis pay for medical bills. As many of you  have heard  my father in law helped save our neighbors' lives by escaping the fire himself  calling for help  and bringing the help down on his quad to retrieve our neighbors. He has also suffered from injuries which include: smoke inhalation  burnt and blistering hands and scalp  and a very swollen leg that he has trouble walking on. He was reluctant to go to the hospital because he does not have health insurance (from being let go from his job at Feather River Hospital). He ended up needing to go to Sutter Roseville Hospital last night due to worsening pain in his leg making it very difficult to walk. They did a chest x-ray and an x-ray of his leg  thankfully his leg is not broken.  They also gave him a breathing treatment and medications.  Emergency Room visits are very expensive  especially without insurance. My family lost just about everything; I would like for them to not worry so much about medical bills on top of everything else. If you are able to help donate towards Travis's medical bills that would make a huge impact on our family in this time of need. I know Travis and Carole would never ask for anything and have always helped other people  but at this time  they are the ones who need our help.ABC10 interviewed Travis and aired it  here is his interview:  https://www.abc10.com/article/news/local/paradise/couple-miraculously-survives-camp-fire-by-sheltering-behind-boulder/103-614339454?fbclid=IwAR22AbOBb0Esa-l_TnA6wzYd_yqDbj8cZs6lQH7L8vFhdQHkqyuxHDS_YT4

Our friend Adam Engelbrecht was recently diagnosed with a Synovial Sarcoma tumor in his shoulder. This is a very  very rare and sneaky form of cancer that likes to spread  and he needs your help.  While cancer is scary and expensive for anyone who is unfortunate enough to get it  in this case it is a little more so.Adam is self employed as a commercial contractor and the family has always relied on Aly to provide private medical insurance. However  in June of 2018 Aly lost her job. After shopping for public health insurance and confirming that the insurance would cover the doctors and medical facilities  they bought a public insurance plan.  Little did they know that the insurance covered the doctors and facilities but NOT the treatments  so essentially they have no medical insurance to cover his radiation  surgery  and (possibly) chemo.   Adam and Aly are expecting the upcoming medical expenses to be around $300 000.   While Aly is aggressively looking for work so they can get back onto a private healthcare plan  the treatments for this cancer cannot wait. State hospitals and treatment centers unfortunately require that all treatments be paid for in full before they are started.  While Adam and Aly have enough money in their savings to start radiation treatments  this money will soon run out and they will not have enough money to cover upcoming expenses. Adam’s cancer is currently at stage 3.  If it progresses to stage 4  Adam’s chances of long term survival drop significantly and the chances for recurrence rise.We would like to raise $300 000 to help Adam aggressively fight and beat this cancer.Adam and his wife Aly have 2 children  Wyatt (age 11)  and Owen (age 8).  They enjoy visiting family at Lake Chelan and trekking the coastal beaches of Washington and Oregon.  Bryan and Grant Lewis have been friends of Adam since childhood  and are starting this fundraiser to benefit Adam and his wife Aly.   All funds raised will be sent to Adam and Aly to help pay for medical treatments and expenses related to treatment.  Any additional funds raised will be used to support Adam’s wife and kids during his recovery and the ongoing watch to ensure this cancer does not come back. Please help Adam by donating and by sharing his story. Every dollar helps. Thank you!Here is Adam (leading the charge)  Bryan (making the face)  Grant (holding the baby)  and all of the old 109th Ave crew.

storyTitle: Sunshine Shannon Schroeder’s Fight Breast Cancer
story: SHANNON SCHROEDER and her amazing story to fight cancer! She is a ray of sunshine to everyone she meets!Shannon Schroeder:At the age of 40  hearing you have breast cancer is not something you could ever prepare yourself for.  I have lived and  worked my entire life in the Beaumont Area.  I have 3 beautiful children  Cole who is 14  Cassidy 11  and Caylee 9  and I will fight for my life in order to see them grow up.  They are by far the best thing I have accomplished and enjoy in my life.  DiagnosisJune 11  2018  was the day I was told I had infiltrating mammary carcinoma   along with regional lymph node metastasis.  Which is cancer cells that spread to new parts of the body.Treatment Plan• Being treated at the University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center for breast cancer. Received chemotherapy every three weeks for 6 months.On completion of chemotherapy  I will proceed with a mastectomy surgery January 2019  followed by 6-8 weeks of radiation therapy  and  also require and additional 8 treatments of immunotherapy after surgery/radiation and 5-10 years of oral endocrine therapy.Shocking News • I can honestly say I will never forget December 5  2018.  Not only is it the day we said our goodbyes to my grandmother  I received a phone call from my job of 14 years that I was being laid off and it was my last day of work  and my health insurance would be ending 2 days later with no option of Cobra.  If you could only imagine what was going through my mind at the time.  How you can helpDonations will be used for:  Covering medical bills  and day to day living for my family.New insurance requires displacement from my home and family• I will have to stay in Houston for 6-8 weeks for daily radiation treatments Monday-FridayThank you for helping me in this fight with cancer! Shannon Schroeder

On Saturday  March 2nd  2019  Kelly suffered an intracranial hemorrhage  or stroke  in the basal ganglia region of the brain at age 44. A ventricle drain was inserted to relieve pressure. He was put on a respirator and kept under anesthesia. On Monday  March 4th  the question was “let him go” or “operate”? It was decided to give Dr. Ahmad Bader permission to operate in order to remove the hematoma and cauterize the bleed  which he did successfully. For another 7 days Kelly remained on a respirator under anesthesia. The respirator has now been removed and replaced with a tracheostomy  and the feeding tube inserted into his stomach.I thank you all for your kind thoughts and prayers as many of you have followed Kelly’s progress; you know the change has been significant. However  he does have impairment on the left side of his body. On Monday  March 18th  Kelly moved out of ICU and into 6 Center Rehab at St. Luke’s Hospital. The road ahead is long and tough  and will require his determination and stubbornness during therapies – physical  occupational and speech.While he does have health insurance from his employer  Alburnett School District  there are limits to his short and long-term care coverage; for example  long-term-acute care (lTAC) is not covered  and how long he will need such care is unknown. There are many unanswered questions at this time.While the GoFundMe goal is set high  stroke rehabilitation is expensive. It is unknown what expenses are ahead  for how long and whether he will return to independent self-care. Please donate and together we can get Kelly on his feet and keep him there.

Hello everyone  My brother John Gonzalez was just diagnosed with Gleason 5+5 Prostate cancer  stage 4. He is having issues with his Lymph Nodes  Kidneys  and Bladder  and is swelling due to the cancer.  He is on medication right now to shrink it  so they can do surgery and chemo.He is currently unable to work. My brother is having to pay for his health insurance out of pocket  plus anything that is not covered. This is a huge financial burden. Money donated will be used for medical bills and any day to day expenses. Any and all donations would be appreciated. If you cannot give  prayers for my brother would be most welcomed. Thank you and God Bless ❤

As many of you  have heard  my father in law helped save our neighbors' lives by escaping the fire himself  calling for help  and bringing the help down on his quad to retrieve our neighbors. He has also suffered from injuries which include: smoke inhalation  burnt and blistering hands and scalp  and a very swollen leg that he has trouble walking on. The respirator has now been removed and replaced with a tracheostomy  and the feeding tube inserted into his stomach.I thank you all for your kind thoughts and prayers as many of you have followed Kelly’s progress; you know the change has been significant. However  he does have impairment on the left side of his body. On Monday  March 18th  Kelly moved out of ICU and into 6 Center Rehab at St. Luke’s Hospital. The road ahead is long and tough  and will require his determination and stubbornness during therapies – physical  occupational and speech.While he does have health insurance from his employer  Alburnett School District  there are limits to his short and long-term care coverage; for example  long-term-acute care (lTAC) is not covered  and how long he will need such care is unknown. There are many unanswered questions at this time.While the GoFundMe goal is set high  stroke rehabilitation is expensive. It is unknown what expenses are ahead  for how long and whether he will return to independent self-care. Please donate and together we can get Kelly on his feet and keep him there.

Hello everyone  My brother John Gonzalez was just diagnosed with Gleason 5+5 Prostate cancer  stage 4. He is having issues with his Lymph Nodes  Kidneys  and Bladder  and is swelling due to the cancer.  He is on medication right now to shrink it  so they can do surgery and chemo.He is currently unable to work. My brother is having to pay for his health insurance out of pocket  plus anything that is not covered. This is a huge financial burden. Money donated will be used for medical bills and any day to day expenses. Any and all donations would be appreciated. If you cannot give  prayers for my brother would be most welcomed. Thank you and God Bless ❤

A principios de octubre de este año  a mi madre Sarisbelia le diagnosticaron con cáncer. Mi padre y yo estamos haciendo todo lo posible para trabajar y estar al día con todas las citas médicas / hospitalizaciones diarias de  ella. Afortunadamente para nosotros  ella tiene un seguro de salud que cubre parcialmente parte de esto  pero ha sido extremadamente caro mantenerse al día con el resto y aun así dedicarle tiempo al hospital. Estamos limitados a la cantidad de tiempo que pasamos con ella debido a que tenemos que mantener nuestros trabajos para mantenernos al día con las facturas médicas a medida que se acumulan.Las donaciones son muy necesarias y muy apreciadas para ayudar a mis padres con los gastos adicionales para los que no están listos. Cualquier cosa sería de ayuda. Tenemos mucha fe en la recuperación de mi mama. Este ha sido un proceso muy lento y agotador. Sin embargo  estamos haciendo lo mejor que podemos con los recursos disponibles para nosotros.Agradecemos su ayuda durante este tiempo tan difícil.Con mucha fe La Familia Alvarez.In early October of this year  my mom Sarisbelia was diagnosed with cancer. My dad and I are trying our best to work and keep up with all my mothers daily medical appointments/hospital stays. Luckily for us  she has health insurance that partially covers some of this - but it's been extremely expensive to keep up with the remainder and still dedicate time at the hospital with her. We are limited to the amount of time we get to spend with her due to us having to sustain our jobs to keep up with medical bills as they are piling up. Donations are much needed and greatly appreciated to help my parents with any extra expenses they are not ready for. Anything would be of help. We have a lot of faith in my moms recovery. This has been a very slow and draining process. However  we are doing the best we can with the resources available to us. We appreciate your help during this very difficult time.With lots of faith  The Alvarez Family.

We met Jessica during our freshman year of college at Whitworth University. She and Michelle were assigned to be roommates  and I lived next door. We quickly developed a bond that lasted through the ups and downs of college life and beyond. It was the best kind of friendship  one where you could be absolutely honest and ridiculous (as anyone who knew us in college can attest) and transparent and just yourself. Jessica was  and is  one of those rare  beautiful  kind people that is so easy to befriend. If you know her  you know what we mean  and you know how special Jessica is.And that's why we're asking for your help. In 2015  Jessica began to experience a number of troubling health problems  including severe pain and fatigue. She was initially diagnosed with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome. Despite seeing many different doctors and pursuing various treatment options over the next couple of years  Jessica's symptoms worsened to the point where she became bedridden. Once a vibrant school counselor who lived a physically active life  Jessica found herself unable to work or even do much to meet her own basic needs. In March of 2018  Jessica learned of a naturopathic clinic in Pocatello  Idaho  that specializes in helping people with similar chronic health issues. The doctor there discovered Lyme bacteria in Jessica's blood  along with other chronic infections. After a month of intensive treatment at the clinic  Jessica's body showed some improvement. Nevertheless  as she headed back home to Tacoma  she knew the road to full recovery would be long and arduous.Since then Jessica has continued to receive treatments from providers in the Tacoma/Seattle area. Although there have been some improvements  her overall health is still severely compromised. Due to persistent nerve pain  extreme fatigue  and neurological symptoms  she continues to live a hugely restricted life. Most of her time is spent lying down. She can only stand or walk for a minute or so before needing to get off her feet. Her vision and auditory system have been impacted in such a way that she must limit the use of her eyes and avoid noise as much as possible. She had to give up her apartment and now lives with her mom who provides care for her. Jessica depends on others to do all of her grocery shopping  errands  food prep  dishes  and laundry. No longer able to drive  she remains homebound and only leaves the house when someone takes her to an appointment.  Jessica now receives frequent in-clinic treatment from a doctor near Seattle who specializes in complicated chronic illness. He has told her that the majority of his patients have seen at least a dozen doctors before finding him. She believes that her new doctor’s comprehensive approach will eventually make a significant difference. This doctor is quite hopeful for her but estimates it may well take 24 months for her to regain enough health to get a part-time job.When Jessica had to quit work in 2017  she initially received long-term disability income that covered her living expenses. Unfortunately  that has since been revoked. She is in her third phase of applying for Social Security Disability Income  but her chances of receiving support through this avenue seem slim. Chronically ill patients often have a hard time proving the disabling effects of their illnesses. The Social Security Administration  in addition to companies that provide long-term disability insurance  want applicants to provide hard data that measures their debilities. Since Jessica’s lab tests have mostly yielded normal results  she is unsure if she will be able to win her case.After three years of pursuing medical interventions and two years of being unable to work  Jessica has run through her financial reserves. Her parents are currently covering her living expenses and have already poured large sums of money into her treatment. And although Jessica receives very limited health insurance  it does not cover any of the alternative treatments she needs  which typically cost $2 000 per month. Jessica is now at the point of needing to look beyond herself and her immediate family in order to pay for ongoing treatment.For Jessica's friends and family  this whole situation has been overwhelming and difficult. Obviously  for Jessica  it's been even more so. But if you have talked to Jessica at all during this journey she's been on  you already know that she's handling all of this with unbelievable tenacity and grace. As she wrote in one of her update emails to family and friends  \If this health journey has taught me anything so far  it’s that I truly do not need to figure everything out. God holds all the puzzle pieces and I am relieved that I only need to focus on the piece that is currently in my hands.\"So  how can you help Jessica beat Lyme and recover her health? Here are a few suggestions:- If you are a praying person  Jessica would love prayers for this journey. Please pray not only for healing and provision  but also that she would have hope  peace  and faith in the midst of circumstances that feel wildly out of control.- If you have the means to do so  please consider contributing to this GoFundMe campaign to assist with covering Jessica's medical bills. Even the smallest donation would make a big difference for her.- Share encouraging words with Jessica here on her GoFundMe page. One side effect of her illness is that it has isolated her physically and emotionally  so this is one place you can reach out to Jessica to let her know you're thinking of her.- Share this page with others who would benefit from hearing Jessica's story or would like to support her in her journey.On behalf of Jessica and her family  thank you for your support and generosity! - Katie and Michelle"

Our local real estate community is a tight-knit family filled with many amazing people. One of those family members is David Lord. A professional home inspector since 1999  David has worked with us in St Johns  Duval  Flagler and Putnam Counties for 19 years. A couple of months ago  after having some dental work  David noticed a lump on his neck had appeared. Thinking it was some swelling after the visit to the dentist  he gave it a week to see if it would go away. When it didn’t  his wife Tracy suggested a trip to the doctor for a professional opinion. Although tests came back normal  the physician ordered an ultrasound which showed abnormal lymph nodes triggering a biopsy. The diagnosis came back as squamous cell carcinoma. The doctor thought it could be localized to the left tonsil and surrounding areas so the tonsil was removed. Thankfully  the pathology post-surgery came back negative and the prescribed course of treatment is radiation for a period of 5-7 weeks. 70% of the time radiation is successful and no second surgery is required and we are all hoping this is true for David. He went back to work the week after the surgery and plans to work during his radiation treatment  although on a more limited schedule during that time.David is self-employed which means his health insurance premium is higher than his mortgage payment. Back in August he switched his insurance plan so all the medical expenses incurred since the diagnosis in November and up to January 1  2019 must be paid out of his pocket.For those of you who know David  you know he’s typically the one offering help and not the one asking for it. So we  his friends and colleagues  are asking for him. Any financial help you can provide will be greatly appreciated and will offer David and his family some peace of mind during this holiday season. Your generosity will allow him to focus on beating the cancer and not worrying about how the family will pay the medical bills.All donations will be used solely for the out of pocket medical expenses. On behalf of David and his family we thank you in advance for your generosity and compassion during this difficult time. Wishing you all a wonderful holiday season and a bright new year.

Johanna Heureaux was in a rock climbing accident (bouldering accident to be precise) where she broke her left leg at the knee. Johanna had just started her new job two months before the accident. This was her first job after graduating with her Ph.D. in mechanical engineering from the University of Michigan (Go Blue!). She was excited to close her education chapter and was going to become the breadwinner for her family. After the accident  Johanna has had three surgeries and needs to do physical therapy around the clock or else suffer more damage. At the moment Johanna still cannot walk and is working on regaining knee mobility. The recovery for these kinds of injuries takes over a year and  unfortunately  she has lost her job due to the accident and does not qualify for long-term benefits. Moreover  she lost her health insurance and she needs for physical therapy and care from doctors.  Medical bills have piled up to the ten of thousands and her student loans  car insurance  and day to day expenses will not go away. It’s estimated that she will be unable to work for at least the next six months. Johanna has always given back to the community by volunteering and serving as a mentor. She and her family need all of the help they can get to cover expenses that are currently overwhelming. Your support for Johanna during this time is greatly appreciated and please consider sharing this message. Thank you in advance.Spanish Version:Johanna Heureaux tuvo un accidente donde se rompió la pierna izquierda a la rodilla. Johanna acababa de comenzar su nuevo trabajo dos meses antes del accidente. Este era su primer trabajo después de graduarse con su doctorado en ingeniería mecánicade la universidad de Michigan. Estaba entusiasmada por cerrar el capítulo de educación. Después del accidente  Johanna se ha sometido a tres cirugías y necesita hacer terapia física durante todo el día o puede sufrir más daños. Por el momento  Johanna aún no puede caminar y está trabajando para recuperar la movilidad de la rodilla. La recuperación de este tipo de lesiones lleva más de un año y  desafortunadamente  ella perdió su trabajo debido al accidente y ella no califica para los beneficios a largo plazo. Además  perdió su seguro de salud y necesita terapia física y atención médica. Las facturas médicas se han acumulado hasta los miles de dólares y préstamos estudiantiles  seguro de automóvil y gastos diarios no desaparecen. Se estima que Johanna no podrá trabajar durante los próximos seis meses. Johanna siempre ha devuelto a la comunidad ofreciéndose como voluntaria y sirviendo como mentora. Ella y su familia necesitan toda la ayuda que puedan obtener para cubrir los gastos que actualmente son abrumadores. Su apoyo a Johanna durante este tiempo es apreciado y por favor considere compartir este mensaje. Gracias.

We are constantly asked by Pat's tribe of friends and loved ones... how can we help?  If you want to help  prayers are our #1 continued request and if you want to contribute in other ways  here is an opportunity. This most recent surgery in November 2018 down at Duke was again successful ... thankfully ... but the costs just for this one surgery were so incredibly high  plus the ongoing costs associated with ...  high medical health insurance premiums  out of pocket deductibles and co-pays   surgery  ongoing tests  doctor fees  MRI's  and the costs of medication ... all of these expenses continue to mount.  Even with good insurance  the out of pocket costs are extraordinary.    Pat has courageously been dealing with brain cancer since 2010  undergoing 2 brain surgeries and years of treatment with so many family and friends supporting him every step of the way.  At 30 years old  we want Pat to continue to live his life without the constant burden of such high ongoing medical expenses ... he is burdened with the challenges that naturally come with fighting this disease  but we want to spare him from the outrageously high ongoing financial burden while trying to stay healthy and receive the care he needs.   Pat does not ask for anything and this fund  is being set up for him... not by him...  there are many of us that want to protect him from these burdens... it's our way of trying to help an incredible young many who continues to show courage  bravery and acceptance of what life has dealt him.  He is modest  humble and beyond appreciative of all your prayers  love and support that has and continues to help him over these past 8 years...   his tribe of lifelong friends and our family ... thanks you from the bottom of our hearts ...  we are so grateful !

Hi I'm Ellen  Kacees'  mother.  I've been up in Baltimore since I received a call Friday morning from Kacee that she was in an ambulance heading for the hospital. She was in an accident while touring beautiful Baltimore resulting in a broken right femur and a torn LCL.  She was brought to John Hopkins Bay View Emergency Room. I arrived 6.5 hours later to find her all bandaged up - basically from her legs down. At this time we're unable to leave Baltimore or operate due to the sever swelling in her knee  the plan of care has changed several times  but hopefully I'll be able to get her home within the week and get her medical care and rehabilitation back home in Raleigh  North Carolina. Kacee will need surgery and at this time we aren't sure if it will be 3 months or 6 months of rehabilitation before she can literally stand on her own two feet again.Kacee works at a high volume men's hair salon and is on both feet all day to provide for her beautiful and amazing thirteen year old daughter  Kamryn.  Because of this situation she will be unable to work and therefore  unable to pay basic living expenses for several months for the both of them.Kacee is very upset that she can't do what she loves  cutting hair  and even more devastated and worried of how she will pay her bills and provide for Kamryn  Ollie and Loki.Kacee has health insurance  she doesn't need help with medical bills   our main concern is the day to day living expenses covered; rent  utilities  car payment   insurance and all the rest will add up quickly with her being unable to work. Kacee is a very strong and proud single mother  who has always done absolutely anything to help those in need. I'm hoping that you all will be able to help my daughter in her time of need. Anything will help! Thank you!

WE ARE 1 IN 8We are Brian & Katelyn Alexander.  In 2018  we celebrated our 8th wedding anniversary.  It has always been our hope since we started dating to multiply the love in our relationship and family with children.  Our path to those children has been a little rocky.  We made the incredibly difficult decision to start a GoFundMe page to support our journey to parenthood.  We worried about sharing our struggles and being vulnerable.  But we also knew we needed help.  It's so hard to admit that you need help and to take the step forward to ask - but here we are.OUR STORY Brian and I met in July 2007  right before I was about to start pharmacy school.  Like all modern relationships - we met online.  I like to think that fate had something to do with it.  Brian had signed up on a whim and I had a free trial subscription - we met two days before my subscription ended.  Not only that  we had lots of missed connections and way too many similar interests.  We both agree that it was love at first sight.  I talked his ear off; he made me laugh.  We both loved music and trying new things  cheering at sporting events and being outdoors.  A perfect complementary pair.We got married in November of 2010 during my fourth year of pharmacy school.  After graduation  we lived apart for a year while I completed residency - me in Lexington  KY and Brian in Columbus  OH.  Being three hours apart after only 6 months of marriage wasn't the plan  but we made it through no worse for wear.  After I accepted my first post-residency position at ETSU in 2012  we settled down in the same town (Johnson City) in the same state (Tennessee) and just enjoyed being married.  Bought a house.  Traveled.  Made friends.  Built our home and our careers.  Raised our fur-babies  Jack and Lola.  Life was good.Around 2014  a random series of doctor's appointments sent me to see a specialist and an ultrasound revealed a blockage in one of my fallopian tubes.  The cause of the blockage was (and is still) unknown.  Doctors advised that this could impact our chances of conceiving in the future  but also reassured us that sometimes these images were inconclusive.  I was advised that my best chance for getting pregnant would be immediately after coming off of oral contraceptives.  In the meantime  life happened and things got sidetracked.  Finally  in the spring of 2017  we got serious about starting our family.   Like many couples  we were starry-eyed and hopeful and sure that in a matter of months we'd be pregnant.  Months came and went  and no success.  We tried every test  supplement  and old wives' tale under the sun - nothing.  Because of my previous history  we were referred to a fertility specialist in Johnson City early on.  Further testing confirmed the tubal blockage  but also added a new diagnosis - male factor infertility.  Over the next year  we both underwent additional testing and treatment.  We sought out a second opinion from a Reproductive Endocrinologist in another city.  We tried medications as intervention.  We waited...and waited...and waited.  If I've learned one thing through all of this  it's that everything takes time and often you feel as though you have no time to wait.  There are lots of other twist and turns in our story  but in the end none of the interventions made an impact.Ultimately  based on all factors and our responses to treatment  we were advised that our one option to have biological children is through In Vitro Fertilization (IVF).OUR IVF JOURNEYFor those unfamiliar with IVF  it is not for the faint of heart.  IVF is an invasive treatment spanning several weeks and months.  To start  the woman’s menstrual cycle is regulated with medication. She then has to take various hormones  injected a couple times a day  to get her ovaries to produce lots of eggs. During this stimulation phase  there are appointments every few days to monitor the ovaries. After nearly two weeks  the doctor orders a final “trigger” shot to encourage the eggs to fully mature and release. A day or so later the eggs are collected in a procedure done under general anesthesia.  All mature eggs are then injected with sperm and the wait begins to see how many embryos are created.  Following the egg retrieval described above  I will likely need to undergo laparoscopic salpingectomy surgery to repair or remove my blocked fallopian tube.  Inflammatory fluid in blocked tubes can flow back into the uterus and lead to lesser chance of successful pregnancy.  Therefore  the damaged tube may need to be removed to enhance our odds and reduce risk of miscarriage.Once the tubal issue is addressed and I've healed  we will then go back for a Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET)  where an embryo will be inserted into my uterus and we'll pray that it successfully implants.  Assuming the best  we'll then continue for an additional 3 months of hormone treatment until my body is able to support the pregnancy on its own.Unfortunately  our insurance does not cover anything related to infertility.  All medications  surgeries  scans  lab monitoring  and appointments will need to be paid for upfront and out-of-pocket.  Total cost will be around $20 000.Our plan is to move forward with the goal of starting our first round of IVF in spring/summer of 2019.LIVING WITH INFERTILITYBefore 2017  I honestly didn't know much about infertility.  I had no idea that my health insurance would cover 0% of any medications or interventions related to helping me become pregnant.  I didn't know that 1 in 8 couples in the US struggles with infertility.  I didn't understand the deep sadness and loneliness  the disappointment and grief that I would feel.  I didn't realize infertility would rob me of the joy of celebrating pregnancies and milestones with friends and their children  because while I was happy for them it was just too painful for me. Before infertility  I never felt that sting of wanting something so bad but it being just out of my reach. I didn't realize the stress and strain it would cause.  I never thought financial constraints would come into the discussion about having a family.  Before infertility  I didn't realize how strong I was or how strong I could be.  I didn't understand how deep I could love  both those around me and that future child not yet in my arms.  I didn't appreciate how strong my marriage was.  I didn't fully know how deep faith and hope can run.  I learned that infertility doesn't define me.I also didn't realize just how many people would want to help us along the way.THANK YOUIt's said that it takes a village to raise a child - and maybe that starts even before birth.  From the bottom of our hearts  thank you for reading our story  for sharing it with others  and for helping us on our journey to become parents.   Thank you for your donation  as every little bit makes a difference.  We truly cannot express our gratitude enough for your help towards us becoming parents.Additionally  if you or someone you know is suffering with infertility please do not hesitate to reach out.  You are not alone.  It can be hard to know what to say or how to help - we're no experts either!  There is an amazing community of couples fighting infertility out there and I hope you find comfort in knowing you aren't alone  just as I have. Thank you to all of our friends and family who have been with us throughout this journey - every hug  prayer  and act of kindness has helped us through those trying times.  It means more than you will ever know.To say thank you isn't enough - we are forever grateful.Brian & Katelyn

Hi Friends & Family Thank you so much to everyone following little Grayson's journey and sending Grayson & the Carte family your prayers.  Grayson was born just 2 short months ago on September 11  2018.  Last Tuesday (11/28) Grayson started getting sick from a cold.  Cierra & Seth took him to Children's Hospital after he started having trouble breathing.  Within just 24 hours his \cold\" turned into RSV  Rhino Entero  and Bronchiolitis.  Grayson is now under 24 hour care at Children's Hospital PICU.  Cierra & Seth are staying at Children's Hospital with their little fighter while their family takes care of the two older girls. Due to Cierra & Seth's work circumstances  they could be facing the loss of health insurance  and Grayson's medical expenses are piling up.  I am creating this Go Fund Me for my best friend and her family to try and help them get through this the only way I can.  Any amount that you can donate to help the Carte's would be phenomenal.  Perhaps think of it as a Christmas or year-end donation.  I will continue to keep everyone updated on Grayson's recovery."

Our family needs your love  hope  and support more than ever. To the people who know us to the ones who don't  my dad  Pompilio John Sambogna  is a man of many titles including Husband to his loving wife  Father to his three daughters  Grandfather aka Pop to three granddaughters  Friend to all  and small business owner of Pompilio's Pizzeria and Restaurant in the small town of Westwood NJ. He is a warm and welcoming smile and a fist bump followed by light hearted conversation and many laughs to everyone he meets. Always putting everyones health and happiness before his own  he would give the shirt off his back or the very last meatball on his plate(much more important than the shirt to an Italian man) to anyone who needs it. Unfortunately  he may have given too much of himself and was left vulnerable. This past year  he has gone through carpaltunnal surgery  has had two pins put into his left ankle  rotator cuff surgery  and to top it off  after his most recent  spinal decompression surgery  he came down with a very rare post surgical virus called Guillain Barre which attacks the nervous system. Our entire family came together to get him through all of this with all of the love and support we could muster  hoping that the new year would start us off on a healthier less worrisome path. However  a few short months later  he began to see shadows or \floaters\" and streaks of light in his left eye. Having had been told he had caterax  he went to the doctor thinking that would be the issue. If only it were that simple. Because eye specialists are not easy to come by in New Jersey  he was flip flopped from one doctor to the next being poked and prodded  until he was given the recommendation for the best eye specialist in New York City.Today  at that visit  my father was diagnosed with an ocular melanoma  which is a cancerous tumor located right behind the eye.This news was a heartbreaking shock to us  but thankfully this specific tumor is treatable via a radiation patch that gets placed behind the eye for a week  then removed  followed by medications to stop the tumor from leaking fluid into the eye. As with any procedure  there are possible side effects such as radiation splash and sight loss  but we are hopeful with this incredible doctors success rate of 99.99%. Which brings me to the reason I am here writting this to all who come across it. This specific doctor does not go through any health insurance for payment  so the whole $25 000+ would have to come out of my parents pocket. They have thankfully been able to gather about half of what is needed  but not without struggle and loss. Now  I know the state of the economy and the want and need to pinch pennies wherever possible  so I am creating this page to ask for anything from a dime you found on the sidewalk to the most gracious of donations to help keep my family whole."

My sister-in-law Barb Hopkin  is a bright  vibrant 57-year-old woman with a great laugh and big heart. She has a warm and caring spirit  evident in how she has focused her life in serving and caring for others. She served with the U.S. Coast Guard with an honorable discharge  and is now a nurse and massage therapist. Barb is driven to helping people recover and feel well. Barb found a kindred spirit in my brother  Rob  who is also big-hearted and always coming to the aid of others. They met in 2009  fell in love  and married in 2013. They moved to a charming home in the beautiful countryside of Berkeley Springs  West Virginia. They love the outdoors and nurturing living things  so in addition to their day jobs  Barb and Rob put their heart and soul into farming their 4 acres of land  affectionately named Earth Family Farm. They work the soil  grow organic vegetables  and raise chickens  turkeys  and alpacas. Barb has been diagnosed with breast cancer.This diagnosis has changed the course of their lives and now this battle against cancer is part of their story. Barb is determined to keep a positive outlook--a weapon she uses to push back on the incredible stress that cancer brings. They are doing their best to face this challenge with courage and hope. The cancer is relentless though  and her disease has progressed to stage four. It’s taking its toll physically  emotionally  and financially. It is an extremely difficult time for Barb  Rob  and all who love them.  The medical expenses are great and have devasted them financially. As the disease progressed Barb had to stop working full-time and her income is virtually gone. She’s determined to do what she can  though  so she manages to work a few hours each week. They have health insurance  but the medical bills far surpass what insurance will cover. They’ve incurred $15 300 for her recent surgery  and now they need to be prepared for the radiation treatments costing $55 000  and for additional tests and procedures yet to be scheduled and costs unknown. As “givers” they are always rushing to the aid of others  so  it’s difficult for them to ask for help.  But it’s clear that this challenge is too big to for them to tackle on their own. While we can’t battle cancer for Barb  we can help to alleviate some of the financial stress so that they can focus on her recovery. This GoFundMe campaign provides a way for family and friends to rally around them and offer support. Our goal is to raise $70 000 for their medical and living expenses.Rob and Barb desperately need our help. ­Any donation is helpful and deeply appreciated. If you can help in other ways  feel free to reach out to the family. Spread the word to your family and friends  by word-of-mouth  through email  and social media. Please help if you can  and keep Barb and Rob in your thoughts and prayers.

Dwight Murray was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon and liver cancer in March 2019  at the age of 26. Since 2012  Dwight has worked at the University of Missouri as an IT professional  a position he loves and at which he excels. He plans to continue to work as much as possible as he undergoes chemotherapy.Dwight is universally liked by his colleagues for his kind and friendly demeanor. He is known throughout his building as a huge fan of video games; he plays as part of a group called TechMate Gaming.Working in IT isn’t Dwight’s only job: he also helps his wife of 3½ years  Audreonna Murray-Taylor  manage a hog barn. During the course of his treatment  it possible that she will have to hire someone to assist her in his place.While Dwight has health insurance coverage through his workplace  he still faces ongoing out-of-pocket medical expenses and the possibility of taking leave from work without pay. All funds raised will go directly to Dwight  to defray medical bills and to assist with household expenses if needed.

This endangered carnivore is highly important to his surrounding ecosystem. What he lacks in arm size  he makes up for with his fun  witty attitude and caring heart. We are asking for your help with his medical bills  living expenses  and whatever needs arise  so he can focus on stomping this cancer back to the Cretaceous period where it belongs.All joking aside  Jeremy Greene was diagnosed with stage IV pancreatic cancer on December 10  2018. Unfortunately  this diagnosis comes with a 30% survival rate. Growing up with Cystic Fibrosis  he continuously exceeded all doctors’ expectations and he is determined to do it again by beating this terrible disease.For those of you that don’t know Jeremy personally  he is an extremely positive 39 year old who loves sports  snowmobiling  and filling the room with laughter. He has a 14 year old son that currently lives in Texas with his mother. Sadly  Jeremy’s failing health had him making the tough decision to leave his son in Texas and move back to his home state of Minnesota in order to get access to the healthcare he needs. He currently owns a home with his lifelong friend  now girlfriend  Danielle  her four children that range in age from 6 to 16  and their dog Nala.As you can imagine  the costs for the medical procedures that are needed to save his life are astronomical. The medical bills for the few month it took to get the diagnosis were $297 346.35  of which Jeremy will be responsible for between 5%-10% depending on the procedure. And treatment hasn’t even begun yet. His first chemotherapy appointment is this Friday.Jeremy recently began working at the Minnesota Department of Transportation when he moved back to Minnesota to seek the medical care he needed. Because he has not been employed at his job for the required length of time  he does not qualify for the rights afforded in the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA). This means that his employment and his health insurance are in jeopardy because he may not be able to work enough hours to sustain employment during his chemotherapy treatments.So please consider donating to help this incredible man. Even $5 can make a HUGE difference. And if you cannot afford to donate right now  please share this page on social media. His friends and family love and need him more than they can express.To make you smile  here is a clip of Jeremy in his T-rex suit chasing a Jurassic Park Jeep. It gives you an idea of what a fun loving person he is. Anyone who knows him probably has a story about his crazy antics and is honored to call him a friend. Are you asking yourself  Why all the T-rex jokes? Because Jeremy’s had a T-Rex suit since before they were a “thing”. He has many fond memories playing with his son and the T-Rex suit  and he continues to use the suit to make others laugh.This GoFundMe was put together by Jeremy’s coworkers and all of the money generated through this site will go directly to helping Jeremy.Updates on Jeremy can be viewed on his Caring Bridge page at:  https://www.caringbridge.org/visit/jeremygreene88/journal

On November 27th 2018  Pablo began to have some tightening in his chest around 9am  but not thinking too much of it he decided to attend our HS Soccer game. Shortly before the game started the pain was unbearable. Pablo was then rushed to the hospital. Little did he or anyone else know this would change his life forever. A routine chest x-ray was performed that showed a nodule that required further testing. From then  many lab tests  ultrasounds  CT Scans and biopsies have been done all to find out that at the age of 17  Pablo has been diagnosed with Lung Cancer. Like anyone who has had to hear such terrible news  his as well as his family’s life has been flipped upside down. The doctors have recommended Chemotherapy and radiation for treatment. At this time his Oncologist is still determining the best course of action. Although Pablo’s family does have health insurance  it unfortunately will not nearly cover all the costs associated with this battle. With the need for doctor appointments  chemotherapy  and radiation Pablo’s family simply cannot afford what will add up to an astounding amount of money.Pablo is one of the strongest  most self-less people we have ever known and has always given his love and support to those around him.We are reaching out to family  friends  and the community for help during this difficult time. Whether its prayer  reaching out  or helping offset costs associated with the diagnosis  we thank you for your support and appreciate every single one of you for all the love we have received thus far.Check back for frequent updates as we continue to fight through this battle together.Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!  Respectfully  East Union High School Boys Soccer Program

Elisa is a loving wife and a mother of two daughters that has been recently diagnosed with stage 3 colon cancer. She currently isn’t covered by health insurance and is about to start a big fight against cancer. The money raised will help pay for surgeries and medical treatments and just getting through this ordeal. With your support we can get through this test of our faith and determination. We urge you to contribute as soon as you can because the doctor needs to start the chemo needed to stop the cancer from spreading. Help Elisa get healthy so she cancontinue to be a blessing to her family  friends and everyone she meets.

For months Lynn hasn’t felt well.  She has been extremely tired and feeling illa lot of the time. Two weeks ago she was diagnosed with pneumonia and also with pleural  effusion which is extra fluid on the lungs.   After a week of antibiotics Lynn still wasn’t feeling well plus her ankles and her legs were starting to swell so she drove herself to the ER the day after Christmas.Much to everyone’s shock and surprise Lynn was diagnosed with a serious heart issue which  is going to require surgery. She has a heart of gold:  full of kindness and compassion for others but it’s not working properly for her.  ***Update!  Effective 1-21 the company rescinded their offer to continue paying her insurance AND terminated Lynn’s employment in an EMAIL!  ***Lynn works for a small company and has health insurance.  It won’t cover 100% of the costs and since being discharged from the hospital after a week her first round of new meds alone  was $325.00.  If she were able to work that wouldn’t be an issue however Lynn has been placed on an unpaid medical leave. That means that her basic bills such as housing and car plus car insurance will need to be paid along with any medical costs not covered by insurance once she goes through the small amount of savings she has.( Not to mention the hospital bills not covered!). She’ll probably be off work anywhere from 8 to 12 weeks with this open heart surgery.  The good news is that the surgery will make a significant difference in her health and she should be able to live an even better life afterwards.   We don’t want her to have to worry about finances on top of everything else. She already takes care of two elderly parents and that’s enough stress for anybody. Add to that the concerns about her surgery and her finances and that could break her in more ways than one.  We are just asking that you look deep into your hearts (at this difficult time of year financially for others)and help her out if you can.  She doesn’t have any other source of income and the family is not in a position to assist.Lynn is a wonderful person; an  amazing  daughter  a loving sister and a great friend.  We’d really like to help her through this and we’re hoping you will too. Any amount helps from five dollars to whatever you’re able to give and you can give more than one time. From the bottom of our hearts we thank you for having a heart ❤️ for our friend Lynn.

Let’s start at the beginning.....many  many years ago  I started on a path towards natural healing.   The realization that your body is made to heal itself.   God gave your body the tools to heal itself.   If you keep your body in optimal health - it can heal itself.   You can’t just eat terribly and not take care of your body thinking there will alwasy be a drug to fix what you have messed up!  I always knew that should I ever be diagnosed with cancer  I would never physically or mentally be able to go through Chemo or Radiation.  It just isn’t a possibility for me.   When I was diagnosed over 5 years ago with breast cancer  I opted to have a mastectomy  but when I heard about the drugs and the chemo & radiation they were recommending to me  I started doing research.   I was shocked to discover all the side effects of the treatments.  And the prognosis isn’t wonderful.  I just couldn’t do it.   I know people who have done conventional treatments - you see people every day  and hear stores  horror stories  and see them  and I just knew that no matter what  I could never do that to my body.   I’m healthy  I feel wonderful every day  I have no medical issues  take no medications.  To start taking a drug that is going to make me lose my hair - make me unable to sleep - feel awful - no  I can’t do it.  I would sooner just be healthy  and feel wonderful until I don’t.  Well.  Fast forward 5 more years.  Still feeling great and wonderful.  I will interject at this point  that in my personal life during these last 5 years  I am dealing with an incredible amount of stress over a child with drug addiction  and a husband with alcoholism  and the realization that my marriage must end.   I spent a year fine tuning the details to move out on my own to start my life over  just as I’m turning 60.  I am 3 months away from a carefully planned move.  It’s at this moment that I find a small lump on my breast.  Uh-Oh.  Fear sets in.  I go to the doctor.  They don’t like it.  Start with an ultrasound - then biopsy - yes  it’s cancer.  More fear.  Then more tests - MRI - Bone Scan.  Yes  it is cancer  and it has metastasized.  It is now in my bones.  Extreme fear.  Now I know from years of reading and research into natural cures & remedies  that there ARE many ways to cure cancer  but the only conventional ways that our medical community have to offer us are surgery  drugs  chemo and radiation.  (They really should be ashamed!).  So I’m scared.  I spend days with my mind just spinning out of control and thinking I don’t know what to do - I guess I will just do whatever they want me to do this time  and do what I can to support my body through it.  But the wheels start to spin - my thinking is changing - I’m doing research into alternative treatments - and I suddenly realize that I will not do chemo & radiation.  The fear instantly leaves me in a wave of relief - I am at peace with my condition  and my decision.  My research leads me to alternative treatment hospitals in Mexico.  There really are places that do the opposite of what we do here in the U.S.  They build your body up so that it is once again the healing machine that God created for us.  It isn’t quite that simple - but is the basis for what I now know I must do.  I want to live.  I want to survive.  I have a wonderful family  and beautiful grandchildren  and a huge network of incredible friends who support me.  And I’m getting ready to start the next chapter of my life.  I can’t stop here!  I can’t die before I find love again!   I want to be here for my grandchildren.  My dogs need me!! (No one wants my crazy dog!). There is a wonderful hospital in Mexico that I must go to.  My employer provides me with incredibly excellent health insurance  however  if I go out of the country for non-conventional treatments  insurance won’t pay for it.  I must go to get treatments started.  It is time.  I know I am going.  I need to raise money because this 3 weeek stay at the hospital doesn’t cost near as much as you might imagine  but I don’t have that kind of money.  I need financial help gettting me there!   The hospital has an opening for me JANUARY 31st.   Please  please  please help me get there!!    Thank you for taking the time to read my story  and considering making a donation to save my life!!   The outpouring of love and support from all who hear my story has been truly humbling!   Thank you!

storyTitle: Help Yakov With His Road to Recovery
story: Our dear friend and colleague suffered a terrible motorcycle accident recently. Yakov sustained serious injuries to his right leg and was at high risk of losing his leg. The incredible team of doctors and staff at UCLA worked diligently to save his leg with a full hip and knee replacement surgery. Unfortunately  he has a long road to recovery with many months of physical therapy and potentially follow-up medical procedures. If you know Yakov you know what a kind and wonderful soul he is. We are asking our friends and colleagues to come together and help Yakov with what we expect very high medical expenses  as he currently does not have health insurance.  We thank you in advance for your help and support.

My name is Abigail Callery. I was born with a congenital pre-cancerous skin condition (neuro-cutaneous melanocytosis) and was placed in the care of my grandparents because my parents could not care for me. When I moved to Pittsburgh for medical care I lost my health insurance from the State of Maine. Pennsylvania did not help out right away and my family  had to pay money they do not have for my care. Now my family has no money to pay normal bills like rent  utilities and sometimes  even groceries. My grandpa has a good job and works hard but we need some help to get out of debt because of my health care.See my \tummy\"? Underneath my skin is a medical device the surgeons put in to stretch my skin and make enough extra skin for my plastic surgery. It worked beautifully!Please donate  we are still owing for all my uncovered care.  Thanks for your help!"

storyTitle: No Insurance/ Help cover healthcare cost
story: On Thursday January 10th I went to the hospital thinking I was having a panic attack. Test came back saying at age 32 I had a stroke and have a blood clot on my brain- my life literally flashed before my eyes. Since the stroke I still do not have full eyesight in my right eye and I’m unable to walk without a walker due to not having feeling in my right leg. Everyone has been so supportive and helpful and I’m so appreciative! This is the best way you can help for I do not have any health insurance  I have four kids  and going to be out of work until I am able to return. I appreciate each and every donation that is possible to be made. If your unable to donate I ask for your continued prayers through this difficult time. Thank you!!

I have started this campaign in the hopes of offering some relief to my brother-in-law and to my sister.  Debi and Jim mean the world to me  and to so many others. Jim has been hospitalized many times for medical issues during 2018  all of them life-threatening.  Just recently he received the news that he has a condition called Amyloidosis  a disease for which there is no cure.  As he continues to undergo extensive tests to determine the damage done to his body  we hold out hope for an effective treatment. He will not be able to work for the foreseeable future  and as a result he will be financially burdened with the cost of his health insurance.  The substantial loss of income will also make everyday expenses hard or impossible to manage.  Thus  I am asking for your help in making sure that they don’t have to worry about affording the care that he so desperately needs.  I am also asking for your prayers that there is treatment available and that Jim has the strength and love to continue this battle. Please feel free to share this campaign…..every donation helps  no matter how small. Thank you  and God’s blessings to all.

Hello Fallon Ambulance Family and beyond. John “LJ” Neal needs our help! He is currently hospitalized with a serious illness. Thank God he is recovering and is expected to be home soon! However  he’s going to be out of work for a bit to fully recover and knowing LJ the way we do  he’s going to rush the process! So here’s a little something that we can do to help reduce some stress and worry about medical expenses not covered by health insurance  rent  groceries and bills.  Any amount will be greatly appreciated.Anyone who has had the pleasure of working with  being trained by  been a patient of  or has been helped in any way knows what a terrific  hardworking and honorable man LJ is! He is always willing to go the extra mile for family  friends  colleagues and yes  even strangers....so now it’s our turn to help someone who has helped so many!Thank you and God bless!

This is an incredibly difficult thing to share. Three years ago I was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa. Since then I have struggled with attempting recovery  only to have the illness come back each time. I spent nine months in a specialized treatment facility last year. I had to go back to work and eventually leave the program altogether before I was physically and mentally ready due to financial reasons. I've been told by my treatment team that my current health situation is critical and I am being sent to a residential treatment facility on Thursday  Jan 24th to be medically stabilized. Because of this I am losing my job and my health insurance and will be unable to work for at least six months (if not more). As hard as this decision is  I've been told that if I keep going on like I have been much longer I am going to die. I want to recover. But I need a lot of help to get there.I have been able to cover all the medical expenses on my own up until this point  but I am now completely drained financially and cannot get the care I desperately need without help. My family is assisting as much as they can  but we need help. The money I am asking for will assist me in covering costs for medical care  health insurance  and bills while I am out of work. I do plan on filing for disability  but must be out of work for a minimum of 30 days before applying and the process is not quick or even guaranteed. And due to me being out of work so much last year  any amount I would receive would be minimal. Unfortunately  I am not covered under FMLA due to the size of the company I work for.Anorexia is considered the deadliest mental illness. 1 in 5 sufferers die. Through the years my ongoing battle with anorexia has caused damage to my thyroid  kidneys  liver  and heart. I am fighting through extreme fatigue and insomnia. My hair is falling out. I have lost consciousness on multiple occasions due to a combination of low blood pressure  low heart rate  and low blood sugar. At one point during a biweekly medical check up my heart rate was so low my doctor said she had to call an ambulance to take me to a hospital immediately because I was in danger of going into cardiac arrest.
