My heart seems to be taking the hardest hit and I have been in the emergency room multiple times due to heart palpitations and chest pain. Currently  walking even short distances doubles my heart rate because the consistent malnourishment has weakened it to a dangerous level. I know this all sounds scary. Because it is.I don't want to die. But I can't fight this battle alone. I'm ready to fight through this illness and get better. I'm ready to be happy again and to have my life back. I want to be able to have the mental ability and energy to do the things I'm passionate about  including MRKH awareness and teaching my church preschoolers about the love of Jesus. My eating disorder has taken so much from me. As hard as it is to share all this  I need help to get there. Thank you for reading. It is a challenge for me to be so vulnerable after keeping this struggle a secret for so long  but I am desperate to get better. I am stepping out in faith and trusting that God will provide during this time. Any support and prayers you can give are much appreciated. Know that I am surrounded in love and encouragement from my loved ones during this time.With love Kristen

Hi  this is Keli's friend Maggie. If you have been following Keli's posts and updates recently  you will know that she was in the hospital and had major surgery a couple weeks ago. And while it saved her life  she has a very long recovery and another surgery ahead of her. This summer she'll have another surgery to put her bowels back together and they'll do a hysterectomy at the same time. This all started and got so bad because she had undiagnosed endometriosis. She has been dealing with the symptoms since she was a teen but her doctors never took her pain seriously until it spread throughout her bowels and nearly killed her. She has a very large incision (if you ask  she'll send you a pic) that will take months to heal and a colostomy bag. Both make it very difficult to get around and she won't be able to go back to work for nearly a year. On top of all this she is a type 1 diabetic -- this complicates her recovery and she needs money to pay for her insulin and diabetic supplies. She needs your help covering her bills while she is out of work (e.g. cell phone  car insurance  health insurance  diabetic supplies and dog food). We've done some math and she'll need about $750 a month to cover the basics and she might not be able to get back to work for 8 or 9 months. So she really needs $7 000 just to cover the basics and that doesn't include hospital bills that are yet to come.  Any help you can give is appreciated. We will be updating this page as her needs change and any excess funds will go towards her medical bills.

Dear Family and Friends We’ve started a GoFundme in hopes of securing financial assistance for Kristin because she has been unable to work and no longer receives disability from her employer.  Thank you for considering our request and for taking the time to read Kristin’s story. Living her best life in Charlotte  NC  our beloved Kristin suffered a heart attack on December 9  2017  at the age of 28. Cardiologist worked to control spasms with medication and therapy which seemed to work. What they discovered six months after the attack was something no one expected. We were all devastated when doctors found a malignant mass was rapidly growing near her heart. She was diagnosed with a rare heart cancer called Sarcoma--  The cancer is so rare that symptoms are often mistaken for other illnesses and often diagnosed too late. Kristin’s life was saved by a low-grade fever which lasted for three days. Simple tests and due diligence by her primary care physician led to questions and more complex testing. She was hospitalized for 5 weeks last June in the intensive care cardiac unit where teams of specialists began an aggressive chemo regimen four days a week. They worked to shrink the mass  but not too fast because of the risk of cardiac arrest. At one point  cardiologists had to perform an emergency procedure to place a stent in an artery that was nearly closed. Kristin shared her story with only a few friends and family.  As we all prayed  Kristin began a courageous fight for her life. She has remained brave and strong  enduring the horrific effects of chemo and physical stress of the mass which caused extreme discomfort  shortness of breath  weakness  loss of strength. BUT God--  We serve an AWESOME God and we knew Kristin would fight the beast invading her body with every breath.  Most of last year was spent in and out of the hospital with family traveling back and forth to Charlotte staying months at a time during critical periods of hospitalization.  Because of this medical crisis  Kristin has exhausted her savings and has been forced to stay on medical leave without income for daily living expenses like rent  utility bills  car note  health insurance premiums  and medication.  We are extremely blessed and know that with faith and prayer Kristin will get her life back and is already working with the hospital to help other young people stricken with this type of rare cancer. We are humbly asking family  friends  and supporters to come together to help with financial support during a very difficult time.  We continue in prayer for Kristin’s complete recovery and strength. Despite all her physical and financial challenges  she remains committed to helping other young people fighting cancer. On April 27th  Kristin will participate in the Levine Cancer Institute’s  Sarcoma Stomp! Kristin’s Crusaders will join hundreds of others to fight this insidious rare cancer.Our family would like to sincerely thank you for your love  prayers  friendship  support  and donations  which will greatly help her during this challenging time!Love and Blessings to you all.The Oliver Family(If you have any questions  please email Pam Oliver pam.newslady@gmail.com or Tiffani Marshall Marshall.Tiffani@gmail.com)

Heart Attacks!  One of Lou’s 2 jobs was as an accident investigator for the County of San Diego until he had two heart attacks.His wife Angela is home schooling seven children in the close warmth of their three bedroom apartment.  Things have always been tight economically.  However  she and Lou have successfully raised nine children that have now become adults and are on their own.  The little ones are still at home.  All was well and Lou was working two full time jobs.  Suddenly he had one heart attack and while in the Hospital a second heart attack.  Right now the upper and lower chambers of his heart are working but are out of sync.  The doctors are doing the best that they can  but may have to reboot his heart in order to fix it.  The men of Lou's family have mostly died of heart disease in their early fifties  but this was more than just inconvenient.  Lou cannot work  and certainly will not be able to operate at the level as before when and as he does return.  Confined to 24/7 bed rest and praying for wisdom  that the doctors will be able to find the problem  these folks are in desperate need.  The bills go on and on. Please contribute to this wonderful family.  They do have hope and we who contribute will give them even more of it.  The funds will go directly their bank account  no middle man. They will be used to pay rent  for health insurance  keep the lights on  and put food on the table until Lou can return to work.

My wife  Theresa Liopesky suffered a stroke on July 30  2017. She is now wheelchair bound. She lost her ability to walk and talk. She was very active and outgoing prior to the stroke. There is a Neurological Institute in Boca Raton  Fl that performs a new procedure that reverses the effects of the stroke. They have had great success but is not covered by health insurance. My goal is to raise the funds necessary for her to get this procedure done. I would like for her to get as much of her life back as possible.

In early 2001  I had what was described as a \severe and unusual case of mononucleosis.\" It lasted for almost two months. It turned out that the mononucleosis triggered something that completely changed my life. Even though I thought I was better the symptoms then came back again on a monthly basis. This lasted for years  and each time the symptoms came back I lost a little more motion  balance  and coordination of my body. I do know that is a progressive autoimmune/neurological disease that continues to this day. Due to this  I now use a wheelchair.For 17 years  I have gone without a diagnosis  which could potentially lead to treatment. I have seen many doctors  including those at Harvard  New York Presbyterian  Weill Cornell  and The Cleveland Clinic  and I am currently working with a geneticist at Yale New Haven Hospital. The geneticist strongly believes my disease is genetic. She conducted one analysis (my exome genes) so far  but my health insurance refused to pay for it  so Yale absorbed the cost of this test. So far  this testing has not yielded anything that could hint at a diagnosis. She wants to conduct mitochondrial DNA testing of my genes  which could provide more answers  and genetic analyses of my parents and brother. Health insurance tends not to cover genetic testing  so I am asking for your generosity to help me pay for these tests in the hopes of getting closer to possible answers.There is a chance that the testing may not provide an answer  but I cannot know this unless it's completed. If it does yield any information  it could lead to a diagnosis and/or treatment which could help me better plan for my future. Plus  I will finally know what I have  which has been a question I have lived with for almost two decades.Every day that passes is another day where my disease is allowed to progress unchecked. I need your help today. Your kind donation will help me keep the fight going to hopefully get the answer I have been seeking."

Eugene is a single father of an awesome 12 year old son. On Monday January 21st  2019 he went to Mercy Medical Center in Durango  CO for a 3 day migraine. Unfortunately it was much worse  he had a ruptured aneurysm that was bleeding into his brain. He was life flighted to Presbyterian Medical in Albuquerque  NM and rushed into brain surgery on Tuesday January 22nd. Eugene is a lifelong resident of Bayfield  Durango  & Ignacio area. He is self employed and has no health insurance. He will face a long recovery and astronomical medical costs. Anything helps. Thank you.

storyTitle: Cancer Sucks!! Help James Burdick fight it!
story: Cancer sucks! It’s like a tornado. You can’t prevent it from striking  all you can do is batten down the hatches and hope it doesn’t take everything from you. We have friends who are sitting in a dark  damp cellar right now while the storm rages... and we can help!!As many of you know  James Burdick was diagnosed with testicular cancer about a year ago. He went through surgery and chemotherapy. Looked good! Thought he beat it! But  nope  the lab work and scans shows it has come back. James  his wife  Kristin and their two boys - Tucker and Garret are in a place none of us ever want to see. They’re watching as everything changes daily - the head of their family is in jeopardy. He is now at the start of one of the most difficult chemotherapy treatment regimens we have. He will be so weak and nauseated while going through this for the next few months that he’ll have trouble just making it to the kitchen much less driving himself to his daily chemo treatments.  He has already been told he can no longer drive.We’re really hopeful that it will work and their lives can get back to normal. But right now the entire Burdick family is in the midst of this storm. I know that they have a ton of friends who are willing to help provide a little shelter. They have health insurance but they have to take time off from work and short-term disability doesn’t provide 100% of the paycheck. Savings goes right out the window and then the credit card bills start mounting. They’re way too self-sufficient to ask for help so instead they’ll scrimp on necessities and keep working when they should stay home. Kristin  an amazing nurse who works with cancer patients  should be able to be home taking care of the most important cancer patient in her life. Meals are tasty and convenient  thoughts/prayers are lovely  good wishes are appreciated but let’s send some cash with them. Let’s give them a little breathing room financially so they can just concentrate on weathering this storm and then putting it all back together again. After you donate  please share this story with some friends. Even if they don’t know the Burdicks  you can reassure them that these are truly the type of people that make America great!

storyTitle: Help a Mom get Lifesaving Dialysis
story: My name is Leticia Marcelino I am a 35 years-old. I am currently located at he university of Iowa i have been here since Dec. 22 2018. I have 6 children range in age from 4 to 16.I wasn’t able to spend Christmas with them and was diagnosed with kidney failure in both of my kidneys. I have a U-visa (U-visa is a nonimmigrant visa for people who has suffered Domestic violence or victims of crimes)and I’ve lived in Iowa City for 15 years  but won’t be able to get a health insurance.I will need financial support to help buy an insurance plan for my needs such as a kidney transplant and the dialysis that I get 3 times a week but if I don’t receive them I would only have 2-3 weeks left and my children will not have a mom.Thank for taking the time to read this hope you donate much appreciated

storyTitle: Help our Grandfather get home safely
story: On January 6th  my grandfather  Ramon Castellanos  suffered internal bleeding in his brain and had to have an emergency surgery. He lives in Guatemala and was visiting my siblings (Camilla  age 10; Edgar  age 15) and I (Kristofer  21) in Arizona for the holidays. My mother  along with my siblings and I just moved to the States half a year ago after finally being granted permanent residency. My grandfather has no health insurance and doesn’t qualify for any federal assistance since he was just a visitor here when this all occurred. My mother and I are overwhelmed with the financial burden that suddenly weighs on us. We need to fly him to Guatemala where he is a citizen  so he can receive nationalized healthcare treatment and where the majority of our family lives and can care for him. Due to his fragile condition  he needs to be flown on an ambulance aircraft because he relies on tubes to eat and swallow. We were told that the cost for this aircraft ride would be around $32 000. My siblings and I grew up in a single mother household and we have been so blessed to have my grandfather to take on the role of a father figure to us. It is so hard to see the man I look up to in such a state of need  and we feel utterly helpless and defeated. We would greatly appreciate your prayers during this difficult time  and we ask if you would consider making a monetary donation towards the ambulance aircraft and medical expenses thus inquired. From the bottom of my heart  thank you for taking the time to read this. Sincerely  Kristopher and the Castellanos Family

Hello. My name is Tammy Millholland.And this is my wonderful brother Bryan Huseby...Bryan is in desperate need of your assistance and prayers. This is him today...But he didn’t always look this way….                                                          BRYAN’S STORYA once vibrant young man….Bryan  44 and the youngest of 4 children  used to be a vibrant young man who enjoyed life to the fullest. Through his life he was an honorable US Marine...and successful up-and-coming amateur kickboxer......who went on to become a well-respected yoga & chi gong (qi gong) instructor and practice the healing arts. He was also a kind soul to every animal and person he came into contact with.Who enjoyed a simple life and gave of himself…Bryan’s way of life has always been a simple one  albeit a unique one. For over 10 years  Bryan lived around the Sedona  AZ region. He loved to help people  was always willing to lend a hand  believed in Karma  and enjoyed nature. And while gainfully employed  Bryan even purposefully took a year and lived in a tent in the forest so that he could be at peace and enjoy the amazing world we live in. In 2016  feeling that he had been away too long  Bryan moved back to his little home town of DuBois  PA because he wanted to be around  and to help  his aging mother in her later years. Who has limited health insurance…When he moved back to his birthplace (pop. 7 454)  Bryan was quick to obtain employment where he could. He leveraged his experience and managed the costs of his simple life with the money he made from teaching yoga  chi gong (qi gong) and helping others through the healing arts. But like many  his health insurance was limited and provided only the most basic coverage. Who has endured an incredible amount of pain for 5 months…In late summer of 2018  Bryan experienced extreme and sudden pain when his appendix burst. However  with his strength of mind and years of staying in shape physically  he ‘gutted’ through the pain and thought that he would get better. However  that was not the case…After going to his local hospital twice  and being sent home twice  Bryan’s pain got so much worse. He became feeble  withered away  and became a skeleton of himself. It was only after 2 months of trying to deal with it on his own  and not asking for help or letting even his family know of his situation  that some of his friends saw how bad he was. To his friends he was literally at death’s door. They immediately paid for a flight and  seeing how bad he was and that he needed expert care  had him flown to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore  MD.A man who should have died…By the time Bryan arrived at Johns Hopkins  the poison from his appendix had already taken a major toll. His blood was septic with 5 different bacteria and he had numerous abdominal abscesses and at least one fistula. This allowed the abdominal abscesses to not only drain into his body cavity  but also allowing the poison into his abdominal organs  taking him closer to death by the minute. In addition the doctors found a small bowel perforation. He had lost more than 50% of his body weight (and he was not overweight to begin with). The doctors at Johns Hopkins  top experts in their field  told him that they were completely shocked and baffled how he was still alive.Johns Hopkins treated him the best they could. He was treated  stabilized  and discharged with multiple active drain tubes and sent back to DuBois on November 10. Too weak to move and in constant pain  his family and friends assisted Bryan the best they could.However  even with home health care assisting  Bryan’s drain tubes became infected themselves and needed to be treated. When he reengaged his local hometown hospital however  they told him that he would need to go back to Johns Hopkins to have the issues with his drain tubes resolved.… And who is fighting for his life this very minute...On Nov 27  2018 with infected drain tubes  and getting weaker instead of better  Bryan left to go back to Johns Hopkins for a follow-up. He was quickly admitted again and  as of this post  is still an inpatient at the hospital. The infection and the drugs required to fight it has taken such a toll on his body that his blood is not producing hemoglobin in large enough amounts. On Dec 11  this resulted in a required blood transfusion. The doctors are still not sure if it will work. And while this hospital picture shows him smiling (back in early Dec 2018)  he was still incredibly weak; and just just before this picture was taken could stand without assistance. He is unable to eat  but through a pic line is being given round-the-clock nutrition  antibiotics and pain medication. He has been told that he will more than likely be unable to eat anything  even semi-solid  for a long time (6mo or longer).UPDATES: 12/24/18 - John Hopkins has released Bryan! What a wonderful Christmas gift. He will be staying with our sister there in DuBois. 3/18/19 - After a short stint over Christmas at home near his family in DuBois  Bryan's condition again became unmanageable. He was transferred to UPMC Hospital in Pittsburgh in January.  After weeks and weeks of additional professional care  Bryan's condition improved enough to allow his surgeons to operate. Today  Bryan underwent over 8 hours of major surgery to try and repair the extensive damage to his abdominal cavity and intestines caused by continued perforation issues and the poison from the abscesses. It is still unknown if he will be returning home to DuBois or if he will need to go into a nursing facility.  ...In the meantime  please send any letters of encouragement or cards to: 1462 Fairfield Dr  Clearwater  FL 33764A man who has lost everything…Since this tragedy  Bryan has been unable to work. This has led to him being multiple months behind on his rent  his utilities  all of his bills. And while family and friends have helped where we can  this illness has ultimately cost him his place to live  and his two cherished pets.  He has essentially become homeless while in the hospital getting care he can’t afford and that his insurance won’t pay for.…Just needs a little help.Bryan  a fighter  a lover of life  a warm friendly smile  and kind soul is fighting for his life. However like most of us  he worries  even in his feeble state. He gets deeply concerned when he thinks about his home being gone  his pets that he loved being gone  and where he will live; how he will pay for all the medical bills  and how will he ever get back on his feet. He knows that the road to recovery will be very long  and he deeply worries about how much of a burden he will be to his family and friends. How can you help?1.      First and foremost  Bryan and his family could use your prayers and emotional support. 2.      Donate to Bryan’s Fund.3.      Share any link that you get on your Facebook  or tweet this link with the hash tag #BryanHusebyFund4.      Not getting better and not being able to take care of himself has crushed Bryan’s spirits. And while donating money here would definitely help Bryan get back on his feet  a card or a word of encouragement would also greatly help him know he is not alone.Where would your money go?All monies raised will go to paying Bryan’s medical bills  providing him with the necessary medical support once he is discharged again  and helping Bryan get back on his feet so that he can continue being a loving son and a wonderful and caring member of society.How much do we need to raise?Frankly speaking... every dollar helps. Thanks to the kind folks at places like John Hopkins and UPMC Pittsburgh  a great portion of his medical bills are being covered. However  at this point  Bryan has been in medical facilities receiving treatment for roughly 8 of the last 9 months. And even with the generosity of the facilities  he will eventually be burdened with those bills.  Not counting the surgery costs  inpatient stay alone runs up to $2500/day.  Even with 90% of the total costs discounted  Bryan is still more-than-likely facing bills easily exceeding $100 000. And that is not even getting him back onto his feet.FAQ: If he is a veteran  why isn’t he getting medical support from the VA?Frankly speaking  since Bryan served and was discharged honorably  he should be entitled to basic VA hospital benefits.  However  like tens of thousands of veterans who served honorably but never had any real health issues  Bryan didn’t’ want to be a burden on the system and hadn’t signed up with the VA. As of this post  we are working with Bryan and the military to get copies of his paperwork and start the VA process. Unfortunately  this will take ‘significant’ time to rectify and he simply cannot go without medical treatment until this is resolved.

In November Chris started to get sick and we both assumed he caught the cold that I just had. Towards the end of the month  the lymph-node in his armpit started to get big and after two weeks of nothing getting better  we went to see the doctor. After many visits  antibiotics  blood work  and miserable nights  Chris landed himself in the ER Christmas night and got admitted to Holmes for 4 days. During that time more tests were done until finally they decided they needed to biopsy the swollen lymph nodes in his neck. After a few days  they called to inform us that Chris has a form T-cell non-Hodkins lymphoma. We still have many questions and things to learn about what is happening and the obstacles that are before us. Some of you know Chris left his Job at UPS over the summer to go back to school. We went from a two income household to a one income household. While we’ve been keeping our heads above water  we have just been skimming by. He lost his health insurance when he left UPS and as a very healthy 25 year old  active male  we both weren’t concerned with finding coverage. Who would have thought  huh (If you don’t have insurance don’t wait like we did and go get it!!)? We were able to get him covered (last minute and at a lot more than we can afford). There are lots of days I’ll be missing from work to go to appointments  watch the kids while he’s going through Chemotherapy  and lots of other added expenses that come with cancer (like our giant hospital bill from our Christmas stay).  I understand lots of people go through tough times  everyone has something going on in their own lives  so I appreciate you taking your time to read about our lives and even considering to help. I’ve always had a hard time reaching out for help. It makes me feel  well  vulnerable and weak. But this isn’t about me it’s about Chris and our family. It’s about me trying to be there for all of them through this tough time and we couldn’t do it without all of our family  friends  and random strangers who support us from the kindness of their hearts. Thank you

I am raising money to help my family survive during this current medical health crisis. Both my husband and daughter have entered mental health residential treatment for crisis interventions. We have a high deductible health insurance plan which has a $5400 deductible before it kicks in for coverage. My husband will have a reduced salary while he is in treatment due to his leave of absence at his job. He is the main breadwinner for our family as I have not been able to secure steady work for the past 2 years after my own mental health crisis. We rely on his salary to cover our living expenses  rent  car payment  household bills  medications   Student loans etc.  and my income covers food the best I can. My income is only about $400-$600/ per month and we frequently find ourselves with more month than money. I am currently working as a VIPKID teacher 3 hours a day  an Art model about 2X per month  a gynocological teaching associate once a month and am in training to become a travel agent  which will take time to begin to achieve income. I am also offering cooking lessons  soap making lessons and herbal medicine making lessons but these also are taking time to show income and I do food recalls for food suppliers on an as needed basis. We are already under water with back medical bills due to the previous need for intensive mental health care for the family. This current crisis comes at a time of great financial stress for us. For February we are looking at not having enough income to cover our basic living expenses for rent and household expenses and food before we even begin to pay the deductible of $5400 we have racked up. I can no longer keep our financial situation in order with out some kind of help. I have tried to negotiate with med providers  hospitals  and gotten information assistance from NAMI( National Association for Mental Illness) but the fact of the matter is we will not be able to make rent  bill payments  food needs and pay our deductible come Feb 1 and the assistance we most need is financial. I am asking for any help you can provide to help us get through this crisis.  And please share this campaign if you feel so moved. That can help quite a bit. Thank you very much.

(**most recent info is under \Updates\") In December 2018  the Gill family received news no family ever wants to hear. Janice  mother of four   was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer. Since December  Janice has undergone a double mastectomy that resulted a 6-night stay in the hospital and the discovery that the cancer had spread to her lymph-nodes. Janice will soon begin 4-5 months of chemo treatments that will be followed by radiation treatments.The  money raised will help to offset the enormous financial burden this disease has created for the Gill family. Janice will be left with no income  as she is expected to be out of work for at least 6 months. All funds will go towards living expenses  medical bills  and health insurance. The Gill family wants everyone to know how grateful for all of the prayers  loved and support they have received during this difficult journey and give their thanks in advance."

On Febuary 18th 2019 at 4;40 pm  on Interstate 264 in Portsmouth  Va.     Dalton Furbee was driving home from work on the same route that he always takes when he was shot multiple times by a Motorist in a black Volvo SUV.  Dalton had blown his horn at a driver that jumped out of heavy traffic in the downtown tunnel & cut Dalton off so badly that he nearly ran into the wall of the tunnel to avoid the vehicle. The other driver got angry about the horn blowing & continued to “brake check” Dalton several times in attempts to make Dalton run into the back of him.  Dalton blew his horn a few more times. Dalton backed way off as theyexited the tunnel &  proceeded up the interstate & thought the “altercation” was over. Dalton noticed the other driver slowing down as if he were going to exit the interstate. This is when Dalton looked over to see the driver pointing a gun at him & he started shooting at Dalton through his passenger side window & door. Dalton was struck 5 times out of 7 rounds fired. Dalton was instantly injured critically & was barely able to maintain control & maneuver his vehicle back to the right side of the road. He was able to slow the vehicle just enough before hitting the jersey wall  coming to a stop & then rolled out of his truck onto the ground. He was lying in a growing puddle of blood on the side of the road when helpful people began to stop. Thanks to Jesus Christ  several passing motorist  Sentara Norfolk General rescue teams & the strong heart of a hard working young man...Dalton is still fighting for his life here on this earth. The police explanation is that it was a \road rage incident\". Dalton is in critical care in Norfolk Sentara hospital. He has suffered multiple gunshot wounds to the chest & abdomin. Dalton is very lucky to even be alive & now faces a long hard struggle to get back to some nomality in his life. He had a fairly good job at Branscom Asphault Co. & had been working up to 60-70 hours a week at times because he had been trying hard to get several bills \"including some previous medical bills\" caught up & paid off. He volunteered  to work any & all possible extra hours & even helped work on peoples cars in his spare time to earn extra money. His plan was to get his medical  Truck & motorcycle bills paid so he may be able to find a house closer to work to rent or buy on his own soon. He has always been a kind  Freindly & helpful in any way kind of young man. Any & all donations will go directly to Dalton to help him during his recovery as to not get any farther behind on bills & any medical or therapy bills that may arise from this incident.  I could go on for a very long time about how wonderful of a young man & friend Dalton is to so many. But anyone who knows him already knows this. I wanted to get this page up for Daltons sake. I know that he has & would never ask for anything from anyone without offering work or assistance in return... But I also know that this may be a very long recovery. Dalton has very limited health insurance so any & all help will be needed  & EXTREMELY appreciated. Within the first few days Dalton has already started recieving bills from anastesia & radiology totaling over $17 000 dollars. Anything that may help him not worry so much during this road to recovery is worth the world to Dalton  his family & friends.  Thank you kindly for your thoughts & prayers during this time.￼￼"

Our dear friend Chris Ludwig needs our assistance. He was recently hospitalized with diverticulitis and it caused a perforation of his bowel. That led to an emergency surgery that landed him in the ICU for quite some time. Due to the perforated bowel he was in sepsis and that’s a nasty thing to deal with. They left him open to deal with the infection. He was kept a sleeping bear for him to heal and was intubated to be like one of his idols Darth Vader. He has been closed up and is now awake and healing as we hoped he would. He still has a long road ahead and will need rehab and further procedures to get him back to his old self. Grand total of 4 major surgeries and too many “procedures” to keep track of. Like a lot of us he doesn't have health insurance and needs us to all carry him through this tough time. He needs help with bills and keeping a roof over his head as well as the medical situation he's dealing with. Thankfully the hospital is forgiving 75% of his debt but we are still expecting it to be over $50 000. So any help is appreciated and much needed. His friends and hopefully soon Chris himself will keep you updated of his ongoing return to the guy we all know and love!Chris casts a long shadow in our community  and has made a lot of friends over the years. Whether you know him from The Anthrax Club in the 80’s  from Trash American Style in the 90’s  from his days at East Coast Music Mall  as a local musician  as a familiar denizen of New Milford  or as a political activist…we all know he has always been quick to offer anyone help when needed. Now it is time for us to do the same  and help our awesome friend.

A few weeks ago my incredible mother  Jill Bloom  was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer. After recently being laid off  she's currently without health insurance. I'm asking for donations to assist with the cost of treatments for chemotherapy  radiation  and the countless needle prods coming her way. Thank you for your time  consideration  support  and love.

On January 2nd Sam suffered an aortic aneurysm in his chest. He was taken to Outer Banks Hospital and Life-Flighted from there to Vidant Med Center in Greenville  NC. Surgeons were ready for him  and he went into their care for about 7 hours. The care he received at both hospitals saved his life. He is now in ICU.  He is no longer on the breathing tube which is the first big step to recovery.  However  the recovery from this type of surgery is a long one and Sam won't be able to work during that time.The purpose of this fundraiser is to help Sam with medical expenses.  He doesn't have health insurance; and while the care he received is lifesaving  it is not cheap.   Please donate to help Sam with the medical bills.  Anyone who knows Sam knows that he would give you the shirt off his back.  So  now it is our time to do what Sam would do for any of us.#jamforSam#sharktoothsam#samstrong

My name is Norm Nimmo. My wife  shown in the photo is Maureen Nimmo. shortly before her massive left-brain hemorrhagic stroke August 31  2015. She spent 26 days  on the brink of death  in Intensive Care at Beth-Israel Deaconess Hospital in Boston  after life-saving emergency neurosurgery in the early hours of September 1  2015. The stroke was so damaging to her right side arm and leg  cognition  speech & respiratory system (to name only a few)  that the Post-Op predictions for her were very bleak indeed with the projections from the surgical team of her  at best  being wheel-chair ridden  breathing through a tracheotomy and eating via gastrointestinal tube for the rest of her life.Since that time  Maureen has stayed in FIVE different Health facilities  each having done much to mitigate particular issues that she has had to deal with  & then transferred to the next  either for the next issue to be handled  or because she has \plateau-ed  and there is nothing more we can do for her\"  basically code  for Health Insurance Companies to discontinue paying for her care. Yet  at each facility  Maureen HAS made progress  admittedly with a lot of my insistence  and screaming at said Health insurers until I'm blue in the bloody face for them to continue paying for her care  and soliciting the help and support of the medical staff of the respective institutions to aid me in these efforts.The fact is  Maureen has made continuous  unprecedented progress for 3.5  years  and is yet to \"plateau\".  I want to bring her home. She is the sweetest  kindest person I've ever known  and is currently making liars of the insurance companies with regard to said plateau issues. Many  actually  most medical professionals' (i.e.Neurosurgeons  and Doctors in general) and ALL Health Insurer's will tell stroke victim's and their family/friends that the window of opportunity for any sort of neurological progress after a stroke is 6 to 12 months. BUNK! Three and a half years is a little longer than that  isn't it? In fairness I must add that I have been by her side full-time advocating for her  and doing five days per week therapy with her.  Now I feel that she is well enough to come home.Trouble is  we only have a few thousand dollars left to do all of this with i.e. Home renovation  Custodial Care  therapy  prescriptions etc. I am 67 and Maureen is 65. Me  You can throw me out  but not my girl.  She's got too much to prove beyond what she has already done. I  have never asked for a hand out in my life & nor has Maureen  but we don't know what else to do. The Healthcare System (Medicaid  Medicare & Private Health Insurers) would rather spend $thousand per month keeping Maureen institutionalized  in Long Term Care than give me half that much (actually  they will give us ZERO assistance) to bring her home and keep her safe and happy. I will admit  I have NO CLUE  or experience with regard to managing a social media campaign. Perhaps you can help me-I'm all ears. I am sorry for begging  and Maureen  would be too  if she knew I was doing this  but I haven't told her yet  because I don't  want to get her hopes up too much. Thank you so much for whatever you can do  and if that is not monetary  that's o.k.  but please share our story with anyone you can via social media and friend networking in order for this wonderful recovery of Maureen's to continue........God Bless you all"

Asking for help is hard. This Christmas  our wonderful mother  Laura Strobel  was diagnosed with cancer. The Good News: It is treatable. The Bad News: She does not have health insurance and the out-of-pocket payments will rapidly deplete her small savings. Delaying treatment could turn deadly quickly  so we are moving forward.She has a tough road ahead. Her faith is strong. We're raising funds to help pay for the looming medical bills (chemo  radiation  and any supplemental prescriptions) so she can put all of her focus on getting better. She is applying for financial assistance  as well as Medicare B  but a good portion of her treatment will be underway before either kick in. She is staying with her daughter in Maryland during treatment and recovery  so food and shelter are taken care of. Please continue to pray for her. Your support is greatly appreciated.

On January  25th  Mike was admitted into the ICU in Cheyenne  Wy with complications caused by influenza. He first had viral pneumonia but due to the damage pneumonia caused  he developed ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome.) ARDS is a very serious complication with high mortality rates. But regardless he is making progress. Specific prayers requested are for his lungs to heal  for his lungs to loosen up  for his oxygen to keep being stable  for his to stabilize on his back this week and for signs that he can eventually be weaned off of the ventilator. We are asking for financial support since Mike probably won't be able to work for months. And even with health insurance  we suspect the cost of all of this will be huge! Anything is greatly appreciated! Thank you!

Coral Lynn  age 36  suffered a stroke on November 15  2018 due to blot clots traveling from her carotid artery to the muscle control area of her right brain.  Coral required a life-saving  catheter procedure to remove the blood clots and received superb follow-up critical care.  Coral is making excellent progress regaining left body movement and the neurologist has predicted that Coral will make a complete recovery with the planned treatments and rehab. Coral and her husband  Patrick  were two weeks from having their health insurance active through his new employer so none of these charges are covered by insurance. Coral and Patrick have already incurred approximately $28 000 in surgical and critical care costs in 2018 and expect about another $12 000 in physical  speech and occupational rehab costs through early 2019 to assure Coral's complete recovery.   There is an urgent need for the $28 000 to pay existing expenses and a need in early 2019 for the estimated $12 000 additional treatment and rehab costs.  A donation from you will help Coral to fully recover and eliminate the major stress of having significant unpaid medical bills.

Hello everyone and thanks for taking the time to read this and your considerations in this time of need for our family!  Obviously  the situation is serious to take these drastic measures and reach out to the community for help.  I strongly believe Living is Giving & People helping People are one of our greatest strengths.  My family and I are looking to raise as much money as possible for a critical & life-saving liver transplant  medical treatment  medications  & necessities for my brother Bryan's beautiful long-term girlfriend I call my sister-n-law  Katie Crain.  She was diagnosed with a liver disease a year ago  but the severity was unknown until recently.  She just spent 14 days in the hospital and released with a very slim chance of living for less than 90 days without a liver transplant so time is of the essence.  There are so many hurdles to cross  insurance restrictions  and financial obligations ahead but we’re willing to do whatever it takes in hopes of saving her beautiful soul.  Her liver is bleeding rapidly and cannot be stopped so critical medical attention  medications  and various treatments are needed.  Unfortunately  without health insurance the family is taking this on so we’re just looking for outside help from this strong network of friends and family  and any resources available to us. All proceeds will go towards medical treatment & to help offset the costs associated during this difficult time!When I look at this picture  I don’t just see a sick Mom  but a strong woman who is fighting to stay alive not only for herself but her children  grandchildren  family & friends that she makes such a big impact on their lives.  Katie is 46 years old  a mother of 4 amazing children:  Deidra-29  Stephanie-24  Cheyanne-22  & Gage-13 yrs old  a 1 yr old grandchild-Lucy  & another on the way in March.  She is also the stepmom of Bryan's children  Meghan-13 & Tyler-12.  A mother’s time is the foundation of a family & Katie is the rock to these children and the ray of light in their lives.  She has raised children that are not hers  taken in so many people that were not blood  and impacted so many lives in ways I cannot even relate to.  She is one of the most kind  selfless  and loving souls I have met and is a stranger to nobody.  Katie would help her worst enemy (if she had any) in a thoughtless second  which is such a rare quality anymore.  She’s given so much support to my family over the past 10 years and enriched my Brother’s life beyond means.  She truly gives the definition of family a new meaning and it’s so refreshing watching the love flow from her to those in her presence.It’s really hard to explain the character of someone you love so much but we’re not here to convince you how amazing and wonderful she is  we’re reaching out in a time of crisis.  She’s picked up so many people and it’s our time to pick up this amazing woman and help save her life!  We are not ready to say Goodbye!Any and all contributions are appreciated and every little bit helps so we genuinely thank you in advance!

After almost two weeks of pain and suffering  including being bed ridden with extreme pain all over his body  and four days admitted to the hospital  Shane Eckerman has been diagnosed with Reactive Arthritis.  He will recover  in hopefully weeks  but may be months.  Unfortunately it may be a Chronic condition he will have to live with.  There isn't a definitive time on when he will get better  and what the future holds.  Currently he still can't walk and is in extreme pain.  He has been put on Steroids  but they aren't proving to help as much as we hoped.           As most of you may know  Shane and Chelsea began the ultimate American dream and started their own business  Canyon Dirt Works  earlier this year.  Shane took his expertise in equipment and dirt-work  and Chelsea took her experience in accounting and office management  and they began their long time dream of owning and running a business together.  This venture was not taken lightly  they planned and discussed  sought advice  invested in their futures  and took the plunge.  Fellow business owners  and frankly anyone these days  can face the insanely high medical expenses that come with self-employed health insurance  or even the lack thereof  encountering $10 000 for just one night hospital stay  not to mention the fact he was admitted for multiple days.  While they do not know the total damage for his medical treatment  they are anticipating medical expenses that could be financially crippling.  Since Shane's business mostly relies on his operating of machinery (he only has one man on his business team who can operate machinery  other than him)  his business will suffer financially as well.            It breaks my heart to see Shane in this condition.  It breaks my heart that they should be celebrating their lives  and the Christmas season  instead of spending it in the hospital away from Brea.  It breaks my heart to see Chelsea and Brea worry like they are.  It breaks my heart that they don't have definitive answers for Shane's treatment or his future.  It breaks my heart that their business may be at risk.  Unfortunately  it breaks my heart that with all this in the air  they now have to worry about the medical expenses they will incur.            So.....  This GoFundMe Page is to help Shane with his medical bills.  I set the goal at $10 000  because I believe that is the cost for one night's stay.  I believe their expenses will be multiples of that $10K number  and that they will be paying the medical costs for years to come.  Along with the losses his business will likely face.            Shane and Chelsea have been our friends for a long time  I can tell you with certainty this family is one of the most honest  genuine  selfless  and caring families you could ever meet.  Not to mention sweet-hearted Brea  who couldn't be more of an angel  and good friend to our boys.            We are hoping that family and friends can donate any amount of money to help them get through these hard times.  We set a high goal  but we know how cherished and highly regarded the Eckerman family is.  We know how supportive their family is.  We know their friends are close and selfless people.  We know their Fusion Family is important to them  and we are hoping they may be willing to help as well.           Again  even the smallest donation  and sharing of the page  is appreciated.            To hopefully encourage the donations  Jeff and I will be offering three nights and a four-day stay at the two-bedroom condo in Rocky Point.  Every $5 donated  will be counted as 1 entry.  At the end of the GoFundMe campaign  we will design an excel sheet  listing all the donors  by $5 increments  and randomly select a winner.  So  even just by sharing the page  maybe someone that doesn't know the Eckerman's personally  would be interested in donating $5 for a good cause.          Thank you everyone for taking the time to read this. All our love  Jeff  Jessica  Aaron and Rory Hall(While I set up the GoFundMe page  after the GoFundMe fees  ALL proceeds will be going directly to the Eckerman family).

His big brown eyes  tousled dark brown hair  strong face and tall sturdy frame would make anyone seeing him for the first time stop dead in their tracks— out of admiration or fear. But as you sat down with him  you’d notice that the most striking thing about him wasn’t his physical appearance at all. Instead  it was his playful and charming happy-go-lucky personality; capable of leaving you smiling and feeling special about yourself at the end of the conversation. That was until earlier this year. My name is Sarosh and i’m a final year medical student at Jinnah Sindh Medical University  Karachi. Back in March  my father presented with recurrent episodes of nausea  upper abdominal pain and burning. There was nothing unusual about these symptoms. All of us have experienced them at one point or another especially in the aftermath of a large holiday meal or an untimely midnight snack. Therefore  we felt the rug pulled right from under our feet when my dad was diagnosed with Stage IV Gallbladder Cancer. Gallbladder cancer is a relatively rare and lethal malignancy. According to the Institute of Health and Metrics Evaluation it is  along with biliary tract cancers  the 20th most common cancer with only 169 019 people suffering from the disease globally. What this means is  not only the prognosis for the disease poor but treatment options are also limited due to limited data available from clinical trials. In most circumstances  the only treatment that can be given to patients is palliative chemotherapy. In Baba’s case too  after consultations with doctors from around the world  chemotherapy seemed to be the only way forward. My dad works as Deputy Commissioner in the Federal Board of Revenue— aka the Tax Department. Knowing this  would draw up a certain stereotypical image of a wealthy dishonest bureaucrat in the imagination of many; however  unlike most government officials  my dad has worked with brute honesty on a basic salary his entire life. This is why after thirty years of service  the only property to call his own is a three bedroom apartment in a middle class neighborhood. And this is also why  gathering finances for his treatment  which is unconscionably expensive  has been a challenge from the beginning. Still  using whatever savings we had and help from the family  we decided to start treatment at Agha Khan University Hospital. Naively thinking  praying  this wouldn’t be permanent  somehow with therapy his cancer would downstage and become surgically operable but the money kept pouring out and baba’s health has kept declining. Anyone that knows about Agha Khan  knows about the treatment costs there. Without health insurance and the government criminally slow to reimburse costs  we have had to spend millions of rupees (tens of thousands of dollars) on chemotherapy  procedure costs  lab tests  scans  consultations and in patient treatment by taking out personal loans  exhausting our savings and at times asking family members for help. After 6 cycles of treatment at AKU  we have switched out his treatment to a local more affordable chemotherapy center near our home. During this time  we have also discovered that certain tests can be done to determine whether my dad can be given newly researched targeted therapies. Expensive tests and treatments— done and imported from overseas. But at this point  we have been drained financially to continue getting him the standard treatment he so desperately needs let alone think about new treatment options. Baba’s disease has not only been emotionally devastating but has also crippled our family financially. For someone who started his life without a penny in his pocket to become a gazetted officer  through sheer hard work  it is painfully difficult to ask for help from others just to keep him alive. We humbly request everyone to please contribute whatever you can in the way of Allah to help fund my dad’s fight against this unforgiving disease. May He reward you for showing compassion towards His creation. Ameen.For those in Pakistan that wish to donate:Bank name: United Bank LimitedBranch number: 0297Account name: Akhter Hussain KhanAccount number: 0297029710658365For people overseas that wish to donate: Bank name: United Bank LimitedBranch number: 0297Account name: Akhter Hussain KhanAccount number: 0297029710658365IBAN: PK19UNIL0112029710658365

Ana Rosa Lorenzo Enciso is my husband  coach Javier Jiménez Lorenzo “bicho”  mother. My mother in-law  as all know  is a very healthy and active woman and an integral member of our community in Sayulita. She is the loving mother of 4 children and full time care taker to 3 of her 5 grandchildren with her 6th on the way. Mama Ana was diagnosed with gallstones a few months ago but was planning to pass them naturally. On New Year’s Eve  unexpectedly  my father in law found Ana on the floor of the bathroom violently ill and in life-threatening conditions. Coach Bichos mother  Ana Rosa Lorenzo Enciso  was unexpectedly rushed to the Hospital with abdominal pain and vomiting on Sunday. Through out the course of the day  her condition rapidly deteriorated and she fell into cardiac arrest and toxic shock. She has been diagnosed with acute pancreatic necrosis  which now has created an advanced decay of the surrounding organs. She now is being held in the Hospital Versailles in Puerto Vallarta with a specialist in the endocrine field  but she needs to be transported to receive a major open abdominal surgery and needs to be held in the ICU at the CMQ in Puerto Vallarta. This is a time sensitive condition as her pancreas is secreting fluid into her abdomen and lungs making it hard for her to breath  and the hospital will not accept her with out a deposit of $100 000mx pesos. Her hospital bill will be around $60 000mx pesos a day after the operation  not including medicine for recovery.Unfortunately  Bichos parents do not have the means to even begin to cover the hospital bill of where she is being held now  and they are unable to transport her to receive treatment because they don’t have the financial ability to make the deposit. We are calling out to all our friends and family is a desperate cry for help. We understand it is holiday season and many don’t have much to contribute  but any donation will get us closer to making sure this amazing woman and mother to coach bicho survives the new year. Ana Rosa has been our #1 supporter through our career as SUP athletes  housed and fed us when we were living in athletes salaries... she has never missed a JR SUP event or a professional race of ours. She has rescued us from injury and illness  she has provided unconditional love and support for us and the team every step of the way. We now are asking for loving support in return.Our family does not have private health insurance so all of the hospital bills and medicine are full price and we are unable to cover them personally. All the funds acquired in this gofundme will go to covering the down-payment needed to gain her access to the ICU in the CMQ Puerto Vallarta where she will be able to receive the treatment needed to be on the road to recovery. They will also help our family with the 3-4 week long hospital stay the doctors have said we are looking at. After she is released from her hospital stay  she will need monthly abdominal scans for the next year  and months of insulin injections and high powered antibiotics to control the return of the pancreatitis. We thank everyone who has helped to care for Ana  her daily visitors  and all of the kind donors who have pitched in to help my mother-in-law survive this infection.

First  thank you so much for clicking the link and reading. It's difficult to tell someone else's story and appeal to the public for help  but if there was ever a time that it was needed  now is it.On March 6th  2019  our brother Peter \PJ\" Hagerman lost his battle with addiction. It was heartbreaking for all of us  but especially scary for Mike as he has battled with addiction for years. Mike desperately wants to get clean and healthy but a major barrier for this is the cost of treatment.Mike is currently in a detox facility but ultimately needs a long term  structured care program with a dual-focus on addiction and grief counseling. While he is fortunate to have health insurance that covers detox treatment  Mike's insurance will be running out soon without coverage for a 60-day program that will provide a stable foundation on which to build his recovery. A sober-living facility with specialization in dual diagnosis and treatment is key to that success  but the cost is over $10 000.Many folks asked me what they can do to support us while we are grieving. My family's most immediate need is to get Mike the care and support he needs. By donating to this  you are contributing to Mike's first month in a treatment program- every little bit helps and I can't tell you how much Mike and our family appreciate your love and support.If you're not in a position to donate- we'd appreciate your support by sharing this on social media. By sharing you'll increasing the likelihood of reaching our goal to get Mike the care he needs- thank you!!"

storyTitle: For Our Warrior Queen, Lori Leif
story: To our Family  Friends  and Friends of Friends who have followed Lori's story....As many of you already know  life changed for our family on September 11  2018. Our mother  Lori Leif  was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer that metastasized to her liver at the age of 55. The diagnosis came after a girls camping trip to Colorado. About a week before the trip mom started having some abdominal pain and wasn’t feeling herself. We talked about cancelling the trip but we had all taken off work to make it work and done a lot of planning so she said she’d be fine and she wanted to tough through it. We made the 8 hour drive to Colorado and she was a trooper the whole time. We slept on the ground  roughed it in the woods  and set up/took down our camp. On the way home she was so miserable we decided it was time to go to the hospital. We thought it was her gallbladder so we brought her to the hospital that we work at and had everyone for her surgery picked out before even walking in the door of the ER. This alone was a big deal for mom. She always says how she wants to keep all her parts  so she was stressed out and scared about having to have surgery. It was also a big deal because mom didn’t have health insurance. We knew it was gonna be pricey but we were all willing to do whatever it took to help her feel better. After getting to the hospital on September 11th and telling the doctors her symptoms  they ordered an ultrasound to check her gallbladder. On the ultra sound they found multiple masses on her liver. They ordered a CT scan to get a better look and discovered an area on her colon that was concerning. It gave a whole new meaning to the song “ Where Were You” by Alan Jackson. Our lives were stopped in that moment. She was our person. Our only parent as we don’t have a good relationship with our dad or his parents and my moms parents are deceased. She’s who we look to in times of turmoil  frustration  sadness  etc. The tests continued and we got the final diagnosis. She was in the hospital for a week before finally being discharged. Now is where our new normal starts. She gets chemo every other week on Fridays  and will continue to do this in 6 month increments until the tumors are gone (the miracle we are praying for)  a new option  or until it quits being effective.  She gets a CT scan after every 4th cycle of chemo to check and see how the tumors are responding to the chemo. On her off weeks she comes in for lab draws to make sure that her blood levels are reacting well with the chemo. On her chemo weekends she stays in Lincoln with Miranda and Brittany. All four of us enjoy spending time together and doting on her while she is with us! On top of the cancer diagnosis  Lori's divorce was also finalized a week after she found out she had cancer. Which this was a good thing but unfortunately she is also responsible for some bad decisions made by her ex and has monetary responsibilities that add to the financial burden. Through this whole ordeal we have worked closely with wonderful advocates at the hospital to help with getting treatments covered and assisting with applying for Medicaid. But unfortunately nothing in life is free and treatments  procedures  labs  doctor visits  and life expenses all add up quickly. As Lori is not able to work at this time she does not have an income and has many outgoing expenses. We have tried to help with as much as possible but there comes a time when you have to set your pride aside and accept help. There have been many people who have reached out wanting to help and right now a monetary donation would be the most helpful for our family. Any donation would be MUCH appreciated and put towards paying medical bills  housing expenses  groceries  etc. I hold HOPE with the future being unknown  because anything is possible! We will surround Lori with love  light and support while she continues to fight back against those nasty cancer cells. Through all this  Lori remains positive and radiates love and support to those around her. She is truly one of the very best humans I know (not just because she is my mother!) and she inspires me to be a better person  grow in my faith  and love everyone around me just as she does. Thank you so much for reading this. Your time  donation and love will truly make a personal difference! We love you Lori. Not a day will EVER go by where we don't fight this cancer with you and help hold you up when you need a crutch!  Good vibes only and prayers to our Warrior Queen!

Lori's been through so much  and she struggles to make ends meet while battling this illness. Please help ♡Lori moved to Nashville in 2012 for a fresh start after divorce  and was living on her own for the first time in her life. She was thriving in her new hometown soaking up all the live music she could. I mean she really soaked it up. e.g. she went to 46 live music events in her first year in Nashville! In 2013 she purchased her first home by herself and was sure to get one just big enough for herself  a home office  and a guest room. She is passionate about helping others and opened her home to up and coming singers/songwriters/musicians to stay at no charge while they were in town writing and/or recording. She also helped fund many artists’ records anytime she was financially able. In all she unconditionally gave more than $35 000 to support musicians or struggling friends over a 3 year period. In late 2014  Lori became very ill and over the next 8 months or so went through a full range of tests to figure out what was going on. After seeing numerous specialists and enduring hours upon hours of testing she was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia and is still dealing with the effects of the condition which at times makes her unable to get out of bed. She was still working despite her condition. On the morning of March 11  2016  Lori woke and was unable to walk. She was home alone and had to call 911 for assistance. An MRI showed that Lori had two severely herniated discs in her lumbar spine impinging her spinal cord causing extreme pain. It was determined that the herniations were a result of a bad fall on ice she had several weeks prior. On April 4th she had major back surgery to fix the herniated discs and within hours after surgery she was walking on her own. It was almost miraculous! Several weeks later she was back to walking an average of 7 miles a day with her dog until one day in July she rolled her ankle and fell in the street. The back pain returned and she did everything she could to avoid a 2nd surgery but there was no relief and in November 2016 she underwent major back surgery again  only 7 months after her first one. The surgery provided some relief but not completely. She could handle the discomfort but once again  she fell and the pain became unbearable. She went through months of physical therapy but the pain would not go away. In November 2017  Lori had to have her lumbar spine fused and spent a week in the hospital. It typically takes three months or so for a fusion to heal but Lori’s bone graft was not growing. She had to wear a bone growth stimulator 24/7 for several months but the bone graft still wasn’t taking. A year had passed and in November 2018 her surgeon told her there were two options – wait and see or do a 4th surgery to revise the fusion using a different graft material. At this point  I need to mention that in November 2016 while she was on medical leave for the second back surgery  she lost her job. She continued to pay COBRA cost of health insurance due to her Fibromyalgia  spine issues  oh and the fact that she was told she is high risk for breast cancer after a questionable spot was found on her mammogram. She has had to go every 6 months for diagnostic mammograms  ultrasounds and breast MRIs to monitor the spot. Because of her spinal fusion not healing  her spine surgeon has not released Lori to return to work. Her COBRA insurance ran out in August last year and she went without insurance. Because of this she had to choose the “wait and see” option of her spine issues. Without any income since 2016  she used all savings accounts  her IRA account  her 401k  gifts and/or loans from friends and family to pay her mortgage  car payment  household bills  COBRA insurance and medical bills. She still has not been able to return to work and has reached the end of her funds. She is still in need of the surgery to revise the spinal fusion and is in a catch 22. She can’t work because of her spine and she can’t get spine surgery because she has no income. Lori started the disability application process with the Social Security Administration in 2017 and her case is still in process after multiple denials and finally getting a hearing in front of a disability judge. Lori has always done everything in her power to help others and is too independent and “proud” to ask others for help. Thankfully she did apply for assistance with food and currently receives SNAP benefits each month to buy groceries. However  she does not know how she is going to pay her mortgage or other bills next month  much less the remainder of the year.

Friends and warriors A good friend who has been fighting breast cancer has passed. Without health insurance they went to Germany for treatments over the past few years. Unfortunately  Tish  a vibrant and loving mother of two young sons took a bad turn and could not be flown home to her family by commercial flight. They were forced to use a medical flight which was ghastly expensive. Sadly  she passed just 5 hours after arriving to a U.S. hospital. Her family is of course devastated but also left with huge debt just to bring her home. Please help if you can. Jason Goodson her husband and JJ and Jake her boys are from Luling  Texas. Thank you for giving if you can.

storyTitle: Breast cancer is scary. Especially at 33.
story: A dear soul in my life  who prefers to remain unnamed  is 33 years old and at the brink of her life... Just moved in with the man she loves  hoping to build a life and family with him. Got promoted at work. Then  just days after Christmas  she received the diagnosis of aggressive and advanced  breast cancer. All the joys of her young life she was embarking on  have now been pushed aside by this life changing diagnosis. Cancer - or more appropriately  BEATING IT - is now her life. But somehow  in the midst of this terrible news  she is strong and calm and trying her hardest to stay positive. We found comfort in a negative PET scan as it could have been worse... So  those of us who love her cry with joy that she has a chance to put up a fight with this thing. She  herself  is scared but ready. But we all realize it will be a long and a rough fight. One which her current retail job (which is the sole source of her income and health insurance) may or may not be able to endure - no matter how much she hopes to maintain it. So I need your help! She has at least one years’ worth of treatment ahead of her: Chemo —> x20 weeksB/l mastectomy w/ recovery —> x4+ weeks? Radiation —> x16 more weeks. And that’s provided all goes as planned... The $goal is high. But so is the battle ahead of her. And no matter how far or close to the goal we come  it’s better than nothing.... And no matter how big or small your donation  I believe seeing people “cheer her on” in this way  is the biggest gift of all!!! So whatever you can give  it’s not about the amount  but PLEASE help me ease one less battle this beautiful  strong yet overwhelmed soul has to face this year... So she can feel even more loved and supported and focus on the big stuff - like beating this cancer’s ass!!!(Also  she knows nothing of this yet  so if you know us  maybe let me give her the update  once I have a more concrete one to give) ;) ￼￼

storyTitle: Hospital bill help for the family of Chris Terris
story: Chris Terris was rushed to the hospital after becoming cyanotic  coughing up blood  septic  and having premature ventricular contractions. As of 12/12 he is also experiencing kidney disfunction. We are waiting for an imminent lung cancer diagnosis after finding his lung lined with biconcave tumor like growths and a hole in his right lung from a ruptured growth. 2 liters of infection was drained from his lung via chest tube and he is in a delicate state.  We are unsure of his expected life span. Chris does not have health insurance or life insurance  leaving his wife and daughters with a serious financial load following his medical treatment and remaining bills.Chris’ wife is a private practice physical therapist who has had to reduce her patient load to care for him. Chris has not worked for years while battling an alcohol addiction and has not prepared to leave his family with such a serious monetary burden. Any amount of donation will help.  Chris is a father of two and grandfather to a grandson he hopes to see turn 2 in March. From the Terris Family  we all greatly appreciate any amount anyone can donate.

storyTitle: Help Sandra Knisely Battle Bone Cancer
story: Centennial  ColoradoOur amazing and resilient friend Sandra Knisely was diagnosed with bone-marrow cancer 1-1/2 years ago. This terrible disease has exhausted her savings and led to complications including osteonecrosis  which necessitated the removal of several teeth and part of her jaw bone. While on antibiotics for the osteonecrosis  she was required to suspend chemotherapy for seven months  thus interrupting her progress toward remission. Now back in treatment  Sandra is facing a mountain of medical bills  only a small portion of which are being covered by health insurance. She is seeking donations for her bills  as well as money for chemotherapy and urgent dental surgery. Sandra’s been given an improved prognosis for achieving remission thanks to an aggressive treatment that combines two chemotherapy drugs. If successful  this approach could help many others affected by bone-marrow cancer. Her goal is to “feel better”—but she wants those suffering from this disease to do so  as well. Sandra is a fighter  having successfully won a battle with breast cancer a decade ago. Since then  she’s used her time to “pay it forward” by supporting her church  friends in ill health  and others in need. She also spent many years caring selflessly for an elderly couple who suffered from dementia. Sandra has never hesitated to give of herself for the benefit of others. NOW  SHE’S THE ONE WHO NEEDS YOUR HELP. Sandra hopes  more than anything  to get well enough to spend her remaining time living at home with her beloved service dog Beckham. If you’ve known her—smart  witty  kind  considerate  generous—you also know how difficult it is for this proud  self-reliant woman to ask for help. Your donations can add years to her life. Any contribution will be most gratefully appreciated. Sandra does not use social media  so if you know of others willing to help  please direct them to this page. Thank you! Friends of Sandra Knisely

This is my (step) Dad  Eric Watson (John) and my mother Barbara.  He is a self-employed truck driver who has to cover his own insurance. Eric and my Mom have been married for 21 years and I am proud to call him my Dad.  He is a faithful Christian and the sweetest  honest  most caring and good hearted man I have ever known and I’m so happy that my Mom found him.  Mom is retired and gets a skimpy SS check every month.  Anyone that knows Eric  knows that he would do anything for you  including giving you the shirt off of his back. He is one of those guys that will drop whatever he is doing to come and help you out.  He is definitely a rare breed.  I’m sure there is a fine line of decision when you are diagnosed with Cancer…..do I let Cancer beat me or do I try to beat Cancer and strap my family with a financial burden for the rest of their lives?? Here is the story of what some people might go through to try to beat it.In the Spring of 2018 at the age of 53  Eric was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer. This came as quite a shock since he had no symptoms of the disease. He has always been healthy  doesn’t drink or smoke.  His blood work came back with high PSA (Prostate-specific antigen) counts.  They took 12 cultures of his prostate and discovered all 12 cultures had cancer present and the cancer was at a #7 and very aggressive and had to be removed as soon as possible. Then they performed a CT scan.While waiting on his scheduled surgery  he got the bill from the CT scan and his insurance had paid ZERO $$$.  When he called to find out why  he was told that his insurance DID NOT cover CT scans.  Ok  didn’t know that but it was too late to do anything about it.  In April he had his prostate removed.  The surgery went well but the Doctor’s told him that his prostate was enlarged and perforated. Therefore  the cancer got out before Dad got into surgery.  Blood tests to follow to see what his PSA is.  Blood work results are back and Cancer is still present. The only good news is that the Cancer has not spread into any of his organs.  It is still based around the prostate and that he would now have to do 33 rounds of radiation. For those of you who do not know  radiation is 5 days a week until you hit the desired number of rounds specified by your Dr.Now Eric gets the bill from his Prostate surgery.  Again  the insurance company had paid ZERO $$$.  Eric calls to find out what is going on only to be told  “We don’t cover cancer”!!  Panic sets in!  Eric is now calling other insurance companies before he has his radiation.  He is either told “we don’t cover Cancer” or “we don’t cover pre-existing”.  He has absolutely no luck in finding another insurance company to carry him.  So he has his 33 rounds of radiation which just finished in Oct.  So far the bills are around $80 000 OUT OF POCKET because his insurance did not cover ANY of it!!  And  we won’t know if all the Cancer is gone until January 2019 when his blood work is due again to see what his PSA counts are.  Even if you can’t donate  please share this so others that carry their own health insurance can be aware.  Read the FINE PRINT of your policy to make sure you are covered for Cancer before tragedy strikes you.  And if you don't see what you are looking for  call them and ask them point blank!! If you are a man of 50 years of age  get your prostate checked!!!  Doctors have stated that 33% of the male population will get prostate cancer. So please don't procrastinate!! Thank you for taking the time to read this story  for donating  and for sharing.  Veronica

On  August 3  2018 I was diagnosed with stage 2 Breast Cancer and have been recieveing several chemo treatments from Hakensack Univesity Hospital. As a single mother at 32 years old with 2 beautiful children  the word “cancer” broke me. The end of the summer consisted of me visiting my doctors numerous times to determine what would be the best plan for me. Due to my tumor size  the best choice for me is a mastectomy. This option would allow the surgeons to remove the tumor completely from my left breast along with the surrounding cells and lymph nodes. This surgery is the beginning to 3 other surgeries that will follow to complete the reconstruction of my breasts.Cancer is a journey that takes time  patience and strength. Throughout this long journey I have given up my job in order to fight this battle. I am now reaching out to those who have supported me mentally through this challenge and hoping that I can still beat cancer. This Go Fund Me page is to raise money for medical expenses that unfortunately my health insurance cannot cover.Beating cancer is much more difficult when your finances aren’t able to reach the strength that you need. Although I am extremely grateful for the endless prayers and positive energy that has been provided by friends and family  this financial assistance is the last piece I would need to win this fight and beat cancer for once and for all.My goal to reach is $10 000  Which I had  Surgery Jan 2 My first Surgery my Masectomy with expanders. My medical bills are pialing up and I still need 2 more surgeries. Any thing would help. God bless you and your family from the bottom of mine Please love  hug and connect deeper with those you love because you are never guaranteed tomorrow.Thank you so much  Maggie

I want to THANK EACH OF YOU for your generous donations!  It is because of this amazing support system that Tylor was able to have his surgery as scheduled on March 14. His surgery went very well and he is recovering nicely.  He is expected to have a full recovery.   He is beyond grateful for the outpouring of love and kindness he has received!   Tylor is the guy that can make you smile  open your door  be the life of the party  help you move  call you out when you aren't making any sense  and dance like Kevin Bacon in Footloose.  He's a Tower Climber and just started a job 30 days before he was attached from behind  and beat up by a stranger.  His health insurance has not yet kicked in.  He needs $2500 by March 13 to put down on his surgery to repair the many broken bones in his face.  Help get Tylor in the operating room  back to work and up dancing again!

As many of you already know  our beloved Heather was recently diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer. It came as a huge shock given her age and that she has always been in good health. Her husband Rob and children  Taylor (18) and Brady (8)  have been devastated  and of course baby Wyatt (1) is way too young to understand what is going on.The fight began on Aug 15  2018  with back pain. At first  she believed she may have slept wrong and strained something  but then when it didn’t subside she thought it may be kidney stones.  After weeks of severe pain  she went in to the doctor and was referred to do x-rays on October 2  2018.
