By chance  it would later turn out  the scan caught stones in her left kidney. They were not looking for kidney stones  their thinking was that the pain was being caused by something related to her bones.So  Heather went home  and after a week of heavy water intake and such  she had zero pain on the right side  it only remained on the left. That prompted a referral to a urologist  which led to the first surgery to remove the kidney stones (at that point she had two stones  large in size and no way to pass them on her own). However even the urologists she saw all stated there shouldn’t be pain associated to them since they weren’t trying to be passed  they were only sitting. This should have been a big red flag  in retrospect.  Her first surgery was on November 6  2018  to blast the stones  but they were only able to get one of them. The other required a different type of surgery and a new urologist. An appointment for that was set for Dec 5  2018. In the meantime  she was in and out of the emergency room for pain management about every three to four days (with a huge deductible  I may add). The Sunday following Thanksgiving  frustrated beyond belief with the whole ordeal  she decided to go to a new emergency room that wasn’t associated with her urologists (where she had been going at their direction so that they had access to her records). In the new emergency room  after blood was drawn  a urine sample was taken  and a CT scan was done  she was told that she had pancreatic cancer. It was a complete shock  to say the least. When the doctor walked in the room she thought he was going to tell her she had more stones. And it happened within an hour of her arrival  after so many months of not knowing the real reason for the pain  which turned out to be that the size of the cancer had grown so large it was now pressing on things around it. Within hours of her diagnosis she admitted to oncology. It was determined through biopsy that she was stage four and that it had already spread to her liver  and possibly to her lungs as well. She was told she was terminal and could not be cured. Since then  she has been in and out of the hospital for various reasons related to the cancer. It’s a brutal  painful  debilitating disease. The pain as of February has already become so bad that she can’t walk and is bed bound 24/7 when she is lucky enough to be home. Recently she was told  after putting herself through the physical trauma of chemotherapy since December  the tumor markers in her blood were spiking at last check; indicating her tumors are not shrinking. She was originally told that she would have approximately nine to fourteen months left if treatment didn’t help. She is now exploring alternative treatments in hopes it will slow the cancer. While there is no cure  she is fighting very hard for enough time to see her children grow up a little longer.I am writing this as a close friend of the family  but the fund is being set up to go directly to Heather’s amazing husband  Rob  as well as her amazing ex-husband  Steve. You see  in one of the most awe-inspiring things I’ve heard in a long time  Steve has recently moved in with Rob and Heather. Their maturity and dedication to what is best for their children is simply incredible. It’s been a huge help to Rob while he tries to work  take care of Heather  and be a dad to his stepchildren and baby son. And it’s been great for the kids  who need all the support they can get right now.Heather has been denied by insurance for a motorized scooter even though she can’t walk and is bed bound. Her hair is falling out  but she is reluctant to buy herself a wig because she feels too guilty about the medical bills that won’t stop compounding. She is still trying to work through this all  fortunately her company has been bending over backwards to try and help make it easier for her to do so; her coworkers even came together to donate their own hard-earned paid time off to her. It’s still not easy  but she needs her health insurance. She fears her company won’t be able to help her keep her job much longer  though  once the donated hours end and the work she can do from home dries up. This is particularly scary considering that the medical bills are no joke  and they just keep coming and coming. This family is already going through so much and trying so hard to keep it together  the last thing they need is to end up buried in medical bills once she is gone.If you know Heather  you know how strong she is. You know she never asks anyone for anything  she is too stubborn. And you also know that even so  she will still help you if you ever need it  with no hesitation. She needs this  she needs our help now. She deserves to be able to live out the rest of her life more comfortably. She deserves to get to be a little more mobile  so she can be around the kids more  and to let her guilt over the medical bills go  because that’s the last thing she should have to be worrying about.So please anything that you can give to help out this amazing blended family will be greatly appreciated. Of course  not all can give  so if you can’t please know that Heather also very much values all of the thoughts  prayers  good vibes and love sent her way. Thank you.-Casey

His big brown eyes  tousled dark brown hair  strong face and tall sturdy frame would make anyone seeing him for the first time stop dead in their tracks— out of admiration or fear. But as you sat down with him  you’d notice that the most striking thing about him wasn’t his physical appearance at all. Instead  it was his playful and charming happy-go-lucky personality; capable of leaving you smiling and feeling special about yourself at the end of the conversation. That was until earlier this year. My name is Sarosh and i’m a final year medical student at Jinnah Sindh Medical University  Karachi. Back in March  my father presented with recurrent episodes of nausea  upper abdominal pain and burning. There was nothing unusual about these symptoms. All of us have experienced them at one point or another especially in the aftermath of a large holiday meal or an untimely midnight snack. Therefore  we felt the rug pulled right from under our feet when my dad was diagnosed with Stage IV Gallbladder Cancer. Gallbladder cancer is a relatively rare and lethal malignancy. According to the Institute of Health and Metrics Evaluation it is  along with biliary tract cancers  the 20th most common cancer with only 169 019 people suffering from the disease globally. What this means is  not only the prognosis for the disease poor but treatment options are also limited due to limited data available from clinical trials. In most circumstances  the only treatment that can be given to patients is palliative chemotherapy. In Baba’s case too  after consultations with doctors from around the world  chemotherapy seemed to be the only way forward. My dad works as Deputy Commissioner in the Federal Board of Revenue— aka the Tax Department. Knowing this  would draw up a certain stereotypical image of a wealthy dishonest bureaucrat in the imagination of many; however  unlike most government officials  my dad has worked with brute honesty on a basic salary his entire life. This is why after thirty years of service  the only property to call his own is a three bedroom apartment in a middle class neighborhood. And this is also why  gathering finances for his treatment  which is unconscionably expensive  has been a challenge from the beginning. Still  using whatever savings we had and help from the family  we decided to start treatment at Agha Khan University Hospital. Naively thinking  praying  this wouldn’t be permanent  somehow with therapy his cancer would downstage and become surgically operable but the money kept pouring out and baba’s health has kept declining. Anyone that knows about Agha Khan  knows about the treatment costs there. Without health insurance and the government criminally slow to reimburse costs  we have had to spend millions of rupees (tens of thousands of dollars) on chemotherapy  procedure costs  lab tests  scans  consultations and in patient treatment by taking out personal loans  exhausting our savings and at times asking family members for help. After 6 cycles of treatment at AKU  we have switched out his treatment to a local more affordable chemotherapy center near our home. During this time  we have also discovered that certain tests can be done to determine whether my dad can be given newly researched targeted therapies. Expensive tests and treatments— done and imported from overseas. But at this point  we have been drained financially to continue getting him the standard treatment he so desperately needs let alone think about new treatment options. Baba’s disease has not only been emotionally devastating but has also crippled our family financially. For someone who started his life without a penny in his pocket to become a gazetted officer  through sheer hard work  it is painfully difficult to ask for help from others just to keep him alive. We humbly request everyone to please contribute whatever you can in the way of Allah to help fund my dad’s fight against this unforgiving disease. May He reward you for showing compassion towards His creation. Ameen.For those in Pakistan that wish to donate:Bank name: United Bank LimitedBranch number: 0297Account name: Akhter Hussain KhanAccount number: 0297029710658365For people overseas that wish to donate: Bank name: United Bank LimitedBranch number: 0297Account name: Akhter Hussain KhanAccount number: 0297029710658365IBAN: PK19UNIL0112029710658365

Recently my mother Diane was diagnosed with breast cancer and is awaiting surgery next Thursday. Post-recovery she will receive radiation for 6 weeks in Portsmouth and is hopeful that she will not need chemo therapy. We are hopeful and feeling positive that she will be able to return to her active lifestyle. However with every cancer story  there is also financial burden that is not far behind . Unfortunately  my mother does not have insurance at this time. While thankfully her husband Bryan has started a new job that does include health insurance   Diane’s  cancer is not able to wait for it to begin . Already she’s gone through testing and MRIs and her debt is building . With a high deductible and the new year starting   she will have 15 000 to pay out of pocket . Many of  you know that my mom is a bartender. If she doesn’t work  she doesn’t get paid. My heart breaks for her as she can not afford to take time to recover and heal . My mom works very hard   driving to Merrimack from the seacoast to pay her bills  and she needs her community to help get her through this challenging time .  Diane is a loving grandmother to 3 young children who absolutely adore her . In her free time  you’ll find her running road races and her dream this year for her 50th birthday was to run a marathon and visit her son  Keith in China . Her heart is broken knowing that this hurdle will prevent this from coming true . As her daughter   I’m willing to do all I can to be sure my mother has what she needs to make this bumpy road ahead as smooth as possible . Will you consider making a donation to help ease her worries and stress ? No amount is too small.

Imagine yourself being a young married couple building your life together. You just bought a house and was thinking about starting a family when you found a lump.....and you have NO health insurance. You'd probably brush it off thinking that you're too young to worry about breast cancer. Unfortunately  the lump was full of cancer  as well as lymph nodes in the axillary. The lump and lymph nodes have been removed  but now you are facing 4 months of chemotherapy followed by radiation treatments. There's a catch...if you don't harvest your eggs now  you will lose the possibility of having your own children. Even with insurance  fertility treatment is not covered  not even for cancer patients. There is no time to research and travel the globe to find a cheaper alternative because chemo will be starting this month.This is the true story of my dearest friend. She is not wanting her face or name shared on social media  as she is still trying to wrap her own head around the news. If you can find it in your hearts to donate for this young family so they can climb out of the mountain of medical bills ( thousands of dollars)  and get the eggs harvested and stored until she is recovered (this will cost them thousands of dollars)  I know they would greatly appreciate the help. Feel free to contact me privately if you wish to know more about this person  but for now  all I ask for is your help. They are in a time crunch as payment is required up front for the egg retrieval process. She is still recovering from surgery and has a long road ahead of her. Anything will help! $1.00  $5.00 it doesn't matter. I would love to give them an early Christmas present by helping them with their hopes of having a chance of having their own baby someday.

Firstly  for those of you who do not know  I am adopted. I was adopted when I was five years old  along with Jeanne  Joanne  Don  and Jon – triplets and twins only 14 months apart. Our biological father took another path in life – leaving us behind  and Phil Makay stepped in and gave us his name when he adopted us in 1980. He also filled a role for David and Elaine  my older brother and sister. Dad married my mom in 1979  a single woman with seven kids  and they added another to the mix  Marye. To me  he is not Phil; he is just “dad”. My folks taught me how to work. You work a job  you earn a living  you make your contribution to society  you pay your dues  and when things go wrong  you find a solution to keep things going. My dad and mom both have always worked; it’s just what you’re supposed to do. Dad vowed to serve and protect and wore the uniform for many years in our hometown of Cassopolis  Michigan. He was tough  and maybe not liked by some  but he was a damn good cop!  My dad is also a retired serviceman and served in the National Guard for over 20 years. When my dad had the opportunity to deploy overseas as a civilian contractor in 2010  he jumped at the opportunity; he loved working around the military  and he thrived in the environment. That was brought abruptly to an end by an almost 100% blockage and consequent double-bypass surgery; he never returned to contractor work again. Since then he has worked in the family business and up to recently in a local hometown factory on second shift. He even spent a number of years working to support the family business  an endeavor rooted from my mother’s vision and hard work and with the support of her family at varied times throughout its history.  My mom is a powerhouse  and she’s one woman who could probably do it all on her own. However  dad helped mom out as much as he could over the years. But now  my dad is no longer working - due to his failing health and increased exhaustion  and at the recommendation of his doctor  and this is why……you see  my dad has been diagnosed with Stage 4 Cancer. Although we only found out in September 2018  the doctor believes it has been in his body for at least two years. He is fighting esophageal cancer  and it has spread to his lymph nodes  some of his organs  and to his spine  which has caused a painful hairline fracture in his spine. He has been undergoing chemotherapy for several months now  and although it helped to shrink the mass on his esophagus  either there was no impact to the cancer in other areas of his body  or they actually increased in size. Since then  he’s undergone more chemo and now radiation treatments. Recently  he had to acquire a blood transfusion of two pints due to other complications from the cancer. The Cancer has taken over his body.  While he continues to fight  his body has weakened while he goes through treatment.  It has weakened to the point that he is now unable to work  which was his primary source of health insurance.  When he turns 65  I believe he will qualify for Medicare. Until then  he has no health insurance  and as a result  this has impacted the capability to proceed fully with treatments and PET scans. I am told that a PET scan  without insurance  is quoted at around $22 000 alone. Without health insurance  a dual income  and the energy to go to work  the situation has grown dire – physically  emotionally and financially – for both dad and for mom. At this time  my mom is doing all she can financially  but there is just so much a 76-year old driven  small-business owner and wife can to help with the financial burden. There’s just so much our family as a whole can do to help  but…we want and need to help. My dad is a quiet man  a private man  and he keeps to himself. He doesn’t like a lot of attention. He doesn’t like to ask for help. Neither of my folks do. The stress of the health bills and need for treatment will most likely detract from his ability to recover as fast as he could.  Although my dad and I were not close through many years of my life  we have worked to develop a closer bond as best we can – to overcome time lost. I want to have A LOT more time to make up for time lost…To my dad I want to say thank you.  Thank you for taking a risk  a huge leap  and for choosing to be OUR dad. I hope that I can acquire the help of friends  family  and strangers to give back to you and to mom. I hope we can help  at the least  cover the amount of a PET scan  some treatments  or even help with the financial burdens that have come with this struggle to reduce some of the stress that you and mom are handling each day through this fight. I wish I could make this all better. This is something I hope that I can do to help you both.To my friends  family  and to all of the kind strangers out there Any help – large or small - for Phil--a father  husband  police officer  and military veteran – would be so very much appreciated. Thank you.Jacque Makay

Ana Rosa Lorenzo Enciso is my husband  coach Javier Jiménez Lorenzo “bicho”  mother. My mother in-law  as all know  is a very healthy and active woman and an integral member of our community in Sayulita. She is the loving mother of 4 children and full time care taker to 3 of her 5 grandchildren with her 6th on the way. Mama Ana was diagnosed with gallstones a few months ago but was planning to pass them naturally. On New Year’s Eve  unexpectedly  my father in law found Ana on the floor of the bathroom violently ill and in life-threatening conditions. Coach Bichos mother  Ana Rosa Lorenzo Enciso  was unexpectedly rushed to the Hospital with abdominal pain and vomiting on Sunday. Through out the course of the day  her condition rapidly deteriorated and she fell into cardiac arrest and toxic shock. She has been diagnosed with acute pancreatic necrosis  which now has created an advanced decay of the surrounding organs. She now is being held in the Hospital Versailles in Puerto Vallarta with a specialist in the endocrine field  but she needs to be transported to receive a major open abdominal surgery and needs to be held in the ICU at the CMQ in Puerto Vallarta. This is a time sensitive condition as her pancreas is secreting fluid into her abdomen and lungs making it hard for her to breath  and the hospital will not accept her with out a deposit of $100 000mx pesos. Her hospital bill will be around $60 000mx pesos a day after the operation  not including medicine for recovery.Unfortunately  Bichos parents do not have the means to even begin to cover the hospital bill of where she is being held now  and they are unable to transport her to receive treatment because they don’t have the financial ability to make the deposit. We are calling out to all our friends and family is a desperate cry for help. We understand it is holiday season and many don’t have much to contribute  but any donation will get us closer to making sure this amazing woman and mother to coach bicho survives the new year. Ana Rosa has been our #1 supporter through our career as SUP athletes  housed and fed us when we were living in athletes salaries... she has never missed a JR SUP event or a professional race of ours. She has rescued us from injury and illness  she has provided unconditional love and support for us and the team every step of the way. We now are asking for loving support in return.Our family does not have private health insurance so all of the hospital bills and medicine are full price and we are unable to cover them personally. All the funds acquired in this gofundme will go to covering the down-payment needed to gain her access to the ICU in the CMQ Puerto Vallarta where she will be able to receive the treatment needed to be on the road to recovery. They will also help our family with the 3-4 week long hospital stay the doctors have said we are looking at. After she is released from her hospital stay  she will need monthly abdominal scans for the next year  and months of insulin injections and high powered antibiotics to control the return of the pancreatitis. We thank everyone who has helped to care for Ana  her daily visitors  and all of the kind donors who have pitched in to help my mother-in-law survive this infection.

First  thank you so much for clicking the link and reading. It's difficult to tell someone else's story and appeal to the public for help  but if there was ever a time that it was needed  now is it.On March 6th  2019  our brother Peter \PJ\" Hagerman lost his battle with addiction. It was heartbreaking for all of us  but especially scary for Mike as he has battled with addiction for years. Mike desperately wants to get clean and healthy but a major barrier for this is the cost of treatment.Mike is currently in a detox facility but ultimately needs a long term  structured care program with a dual-focus on addiction and grief counseling. While he is fortunate to have health insurance that covers detox treatment  Mike's insurance will be running out soon without coverage for a 60-day program that will provide a stable foundation on which to build his recovery. A sober-living facility with specialization in dual diagnosis and treatment is key to that success  but the cost is over $10 000.Many folks asked me what they can do to support us while we are grieving. My family's most immediate need is to get Mike the care and support he needs. By donating to this  you are contributing to Mike's first month in a treatment program- every little bit helps and I can't tell you how much Mike and our family appreciate your love and support.If you're not in a position to donate- we'd appreciate your support by sharing this on social media. By sharing you'll increasing the likelihood of reaching our goal to get Mike the care he needs- thank you!!"

storyTitle: For Our Warrior Queen, Lori Leif
story: To our Family  Friends  and Friends of Friends who have followed Lori's story....As many of you already know  life changed for our family on September 11  2018. Our mother  Lori Leif  was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer that metastasized to her liver at the age of 55. The diagnosis came after a girls camping trip to Colorado. About a week before the trip mom started having some abdominal pain and wasn’t feeling herself. We talked about cancelling the trip but we had all taken off work to make it work and done a lot of planning so she said she’d be fine and she wanted to tough through it. We made the 8 hour drive to Colorado and she was a trooper the whole time. We slept on the ground  roughed it in the woods  and set up/took down our camp. On the way home she was so miserable we decided it was time to go to the hospital. We thought it was her gallbladder so we brought her to the hospital that we work at and had everyone for her surgery picked out before even walking in the door of the ER. This alone was a big deal for mom. She always says how she wants to keep all her parts  so she was stressed out and scared about having to have surgery. It was also a big deal because mom didn’t have health insurance. We knew it was gonna be pricey but we were all willing to do whatever it took to help her feel better. After getting to the hospital on September 11th and telling the doctors her symptoms  they ordered an ultrasound to check her gallbladder. On the ultra sound they found multiple masses on her liver. They ordered a CT scan to get a better look and discovered an area on her colon that was concerning. It gave a whole new meaning to the song “ Where Were You” by Alan Jackson. Our lives were stopped in that moment. She was our person. Our only parent as we don’t have a good relationship with our dad or his parents and my moms parents are deceased. She’s who we look to in times of turmoil  frustration  sadness  etc. The tests continued and we got the final diagnosis. She was in the hospital for a week before finally being discharged. Now is where our new normal starts. She gets chemo every other week on Fridays  and will continue to do this in 6 month increments until the tumors are gone (the miracle we are praying for)  a new option  or until it quits being effective.  She gets a CT scan after every 4th cycle of chemo to check and see how the tumors are responding to the chemo. On her off weeks she comes in for lab draws to make sure that her blood levels are reacting well with the chemo. On her chemo weekends she stays in Lincoln with Miranda and Brittany. All four of us enjoy spending time together and doting on her while she is with us! On top of the cancer diagnosis  Lori's divorce was also finalized a week after she found out she had cancer. Which this was a good thing but unfortunately she is also responsible for some bad decisions made by her ex and has monetary responsibilities that add to the financial burden. Through this whole ordeal we have worked closely with wonderful advocates at the hospital to help with getting treatments covered and assisting with applying for Medicaid. But unfortunately nothing in life is free and treatments  procedures  labs  doctor visits  and life expenses all add up quickly. As Lori is not able to work at this time she does not have an income and has many outgoing expenses. We have tried to help with as much as possible but there comes a time when you have to set your pride aside and accept help. There have been many people who have reached out wanting to help and right now a monetary donation would be the most helpful for our family. Any donation would be MUCH appreciated and put towards paying medical bills  housing expenses  groceries  etc. I hold HOPE with the future being unknown  because anything is possible! We will surround Lori with love  light and support while she continues to fight back against those nasty cancer cells. Through all this  Lori remains positive and radiates love and support to those around her. She is truly one of the very best humans I know (not just because she is my mother!) and she inspires me to be a better person  grow in my faith  and love everyone around me just as she does. Thank you so much for reading this. Your time  donation and love will truly make a personal difference! We love you Lori. Not a day will EVER go by where we don't fight this cancer with you and help hold you up when you need a crutch!  Good vibes only and prayers to our Warrior Queen!

Friends and warriors A good friend who has been fighting breast cancer has passed. Without health insurance they went to Germany for treatments over the past few years. Unfortunately  Tish  a vibrant and loving mother of two young sons took a bad turn and could not be flown home to her family by commercial flight. They were forced to use a medical flight which was ghastly expensive. Sadly  she passed just 5 hours after arriving to a U.S. hospital. Her family is of course devastated but also left with huge debt just to bring her home. Please help if you can. Jason Goodson her husband and JJ and Jake her boys are from Luling  Texas. Thank you for giving if you can.

storyTitle: Breast cancer is scary. Especially at 33.
story: A dear soul in my life  who prefers to remain unnamed  is 33 years old and at the brink of her life... Just moved in with the man she loves  hoping to build a life and family with him. Got promoted at work. Then  just days after Christmas  she received the diagnosis of aggressive and advanced  breast cancer. All the joys of her young life she was embarking on  have now been pushed aside by this life changing diagnosis. Cancer - or more appropriately  BEATING IT - is now her life. But somehow  in the midst of this terrible news  she is strong and calm and trying her hardest to stay positive. We found comfort in a negative PET scan as it could have been worse... So  those of us who love her cry with joy that she has a chance to put up a fight with this thing. She  herself  is scared but ready. But we all realize it will be a long and a rough fight. One which her current retail job (which is the sole source of her income and health insurance) may or may not be able to endure - no matter how much she hopes to maintain it. So I need your help! She has at least one years’ worth of treatment ahead of her: Chemo —> x20 weeksB/l mastectomy w/ recovery —> x4+ weeks? Radiation —> x16 more weeks. And that’s provided all goes as planned... The $goal is high. But so is the battle ahead of her. And no matter how far or close to the goal we come  it’s better than nothing.... And no matter how big or small your donation  I believe seeing people “cheer her on” in this way  is the biggest gift of all!!! So whatever you can give  it’s not about the amount  but PLEASE help me ease one less battle this beautiful  strong yet overwhelmed soul has to face this year... So she can feel even more loved and supported and focus on the big stuff - like beating this cancer’s ass!!!(Also  she knows nothing of this yet  so if you know us  maybe let me give her the update  once I have a more concrete one to give) ;) ￼￼

storyTitle: Hospital bill help for the family of Chris Terris
story: Chris Terris was rushed to the hospital after becoming cyanotic  coughing up blood  septic  and having premature ventricular contractions. As of 12/12 he is also experiencing kidney disfunction. We are waiting for an imminent lung cancer diagnosis after finding his lung lined with biconcave tumor like growths and a hole in his right lung from a ruptured growth. 2 liters of infection was drained from his lung via chest tube and he is in a delicate state.  We are unsure of his expected life span. Chris does not have health insurance or life insurance  leaving his wife and daughters with a serious financial load following his medical treatment and remaining bills.Chris’ wife is a private practice physical therapist who has had to reduce her patient load to care for him. Chris has not worked for years while battling an alcohol addiction and has not prepared to leave his family with such a serious monetary burden. Any amount of donation will help.  Chris is a father of two and grandfather to a grandson he hopes to see turn 2 in March. From the Terris Family  we all greatly appreciate any amount anyone can donate.

storyTitle: Help Sandra Knisely Battle Bone Cancer
story: Centennial  ColoradoOur amazing and resilient friend Sandra Knisely was diagnosed with bone-marrow cancer 1-1/2 years ago. This terrible disease has exhausted her savings and led to complications including osteonecrosis  which necessitated the removal of several teeth and part of her jaw bone. While on antibiotics for the osteonecrosis  she was required to suspend chemotherapy for seven months  thus interrupting her progress toward remission. Now back in treatment  Sandra is facing a mountain of medical bills  only a small portion of which are being covered by health insurance. She is seeking donations for her bills  as well as money for chemotherapy and urgent dental surgery. Sandra’s been given an improved prognosis for achieving remission thanks to an aggressive treatment that combines two chemotherapy drugs. If successful  this approach could help many others affected by bone-marrow cancer. Her goal is to “feel better”—but she wants those suffering from this disease to do so  as well. Sandra is a fighter  having successfully won a battle with breast cancer a decade ago. Since then  she’s used her time to “pay it forward” by supporting her church  friends in ill health  and others in need. She also spent many years caring selflessly for an elderly couple who suffered from dementia. Sandra has never hesitated to give of herself for the benefit of others. NOW  SHE’S THE ONE WHO NEEDS YOUR HELP. Sandra hopes  more than anything  to get well enough to spend her remaining time living at home with her beloved service dog Beckham. If you’ve known her—smart  witty  kind  considerate  generous—you also know how difficult it is for this proud  self-reliant woman to ask for help. Your donations can add years to her life. Any contribution will be most gratefully appreciated. Sandra does not use social media  so if you know of others willing to help  please direct them to this page. Thank you! Friends of Sandra Knisely

storyTitle: Breast cancer is scary. Especially at 33.
story: A dear soul in my life  who prefers to remain unnamed  is 33 years old and at the brink of her life... Just moved in with the man she loves  hoping to build a life and family with him. Got promoted at work. Then  just days after Christmas  she received the diagnosis of aggressive and advanced  breast cancer. All the joys of her young life she was embarking on  have now been pushed aside by this life changing diagnosis. Cancer - or more appropriately  BEATING IT - is now her life. But somehow  in the midst of this terrible news  she is strong and calm and trying her hardest to stay positive. We found comfort in a negative PET scan as it could have been worse... So  those of us who love her cry with joy that she has a chance to put up a fight with this thing. She  herself  is scared but ready. But we all realize it will be a long and a rough fight. One which her current retail job (which is the sole source of her income and health insurance) may or may not be able to endure - no matter how much she hopes to maintain it. So I need your help! She has at least one years’ worth of treatment ahead of her: Chemo —> x20 weeksB/l mastectomy w/ recovery —> x4+ weeks? Radiation —> x16 more weeks. And that’s provided all goes as planned... The $goal is high. But so is the battle ahead of her. And no matter how far or close to the goal we come  it’s better than nothing.... And no matter how big or small your donation  I believe seeing people “cheer her on” in this way  is the biggest gift of all!!! So whatever you can give  it’s not about the amount  but PLEASE help me ease one less battle this beautiful  strong yet overwhelmed soul has to face this year... So she can feel even more loved and supported and focus on the big stuff - like beating this cancer’s ass!!!(Also  she knows nothing of this yet  so if you know us  maybe let me give her the update  once I have a more concrete one to give) ;) ￼￼

Sandra does not use social media  so if you know of others willing to help  please direct them to this page. Thank you! Friends of Sandra Knisely

This is my (step) Dad  Eric Watson (John) and my mother Barbara.  He is a self-employed truck driver who has to cover his own insurance. Eric and my Mom have been married for 21 years and I am proud to call him my Dad.  He is a faithful Christian and the sweetest  honest  most caring and good hearted man I have ever known and I’m so happy that my Mom found him.  Mom is retired and gets a skimpy SS check every month.  Anyone that knows Eric  knows that he would do anything for you  including giving you the shirt off of his back. He is one of those guys that will drop whatever he is doing to come and help you out.  He is definitely a rare breed.  I’m sure there is a fine line of decision when you are diagnosed with Cancer…..do I let Cancer beat me or do I try to beat Cancer and strap my family with a financial burden for the rest of their lives?? Here is the story of what some people might go through to try to beat it.In the Spring of 2018 at the age of 53  Eric was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer. This came as quite a shock since he had no symptoms of the disease. He has always been healthy  doesn’t drink or smoke.  His blood work came back with high PSA (Prostate-specific antigen) counts.  They took 12 cultures of his prostate and discovered all 12 cultures had cancer present and the cancer was at a #7 and very aggressive and had to be removed as soon as possible. Then they performed a CT scan.While waiting on his scheduled surgery  he got the bill from the CT scan and his insurance had paid ZERO $$$.  When he called to find out why  he was told that his insurance DID NOT cover CT scans.  Ok  didn’t know that but it was too late to do anything about it.  In April he had his prostate removed.  The surgery went well but the Doctor’s told him that his prostate was enlarged and perforated. Therefore  the cancer got out before Dad got into surgery.  Blood tests to follow to see what his PSA is.  Blood work results are back and Cancer is still present. The only good news is that the Cancer has not spread into any of his organs.  It is still based around the prostate and that he would now have to do 33 rounds of radiation. For those of you who do not know  radiation is 5 days a week until you hit the desired number of rounds specified by your Dr.Now Eric gets the bill from his Prostate surgery.  Again  the insurance company had paid ZERO $$$.  Eric calls to find out what is going on only to be told  “We don’t cover cancer”!!  Panic sets in!  Eric is now calling other insurance companies before he has his radiation.  He is either told “we don’t cover Cancer” or “we don’t cover pre-existing”.  He has absolutely no luck in finding another insurance company to carry him.  So he has his 33 rounds of radiation which just finished in Oct.  So far the bills are around $80 000 OUT OF POCKET because his insurance did not cover ANY of it!!  And  we won’t know if all the Cancer is gone until January 2019 when his blood work is due again to see what his PSA counts are.  Even if you can’t donate  please share this so others that carry their own health insurance can be aware.  Read the FINE PRINT of your policy to make sure you are covered for Cancer before tragedy strikes you.  And if you don't see what you are looking for  call them and ask them point blank!! If you are a man of 50 years of age  get your prostate checked!!!  Doctors have stated that 33% of the male population will get prostate cancer. So please don't procrastinate!! Thank you for taking the time to read this story  for donating  and for sharing.  Veronica

On  August 3  2018 I was diagnosed with stage 2 Breast Cancer and have been recieveing several chemo treatments from Hakensack Univesity Hospital. As a single mother at 32 years old with 2 beautiful children  the word “cancer” broke me. The end of the summer consisted of me visiting my doctors numerous times to determine what would be the best plan for me. Due to my tumor size  the best choice for me is a mastectomy. This option would allow the surgeons to remove the tumor completely from my left breast along with the surrounding cells and lymph nodes. This surgery is the beginning to 3 other surgeries that will follow to complete the reconstruction of my breasts.Cancer is a journey that takes time  patience and strength. Throughout this long journey I have given up my job in order to fight this battle. I am now reaching out to those who have supported me mentally through this challenge and hoping that I can still beat cancer. This Go Fund Me page is to raise money for medical expenses that unfortunately my health insurance cannot cover.Beating cancer is much more difficult when your finances aren’t able to reach the strength that you need. Although I am extremely grateful for the endless prayers and positive energy that has been provided by friends and family  this financial assistance is the last piece I would need to win this fight and beat cancer for once and for all.My goal to reach is $10 000  Which I had  Surgery Jan 2 My first Surgery my Masectomy with expanders. My medical bills are pialing up and I still need 2 more surgeries. Any thing would help. God bless you and your family from the bottom of mine Please love  hug and connect deeper with those you love because you are never guaranteed tomorrow.Thank you so much  Maggie

I want to THANK EACH OF YOU for your generous donations!  It is because of this amazing support system that Tylor was able to have his surgery as scheduled on March 14. His surgery went very well and he is recovering nicely.  He is expected to have a full recovery.   He is beyond grateful for the outpouring of love and kindness he has received!   Tylor is the guy that can make you smile  open your door  be the life of the party  help you move  call you out when you aren't making any sense  and dance like Kevin Bacon in Footloose.  He's a Tower Climber and just started a job 30 days before he was attached from behind  and beat up by a stranger.  His health insurance has not yet kicked in.  He needs $2500 by March 13 to put down on his surgery to repair the many broken bones in his face.  Help get Tylor in the operating room  back to work and up dancing again!

As many of you already know  our beloved Heather was recently diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer. It came as a huge shock given her age and that she has always been in good health. Her husband Rob and children  Taylor (18) and Brady (8)  have been devastated  and of course baby Wyatt (1) is way too young to understand what is going on.The fight began on Aug 15  2018  with back pain. At first  she believed she may have slept wrong and strained something  but then when it didn’t subside she thought it may be kidney stones.  After weeks of severe pain  she went in to the doctor and was referred to do x-rays on October 2  2018. By chance  it would later turn out  the scan caught stones in her left kidney. They were not looking for kidney stones  their thinking was that the pain was being caused by something related to her bones.So  Heather went home  and after a week of heavy water intake and such  she had zero pain on the right side  it only remained on the left. That prompted a referral to a urologist  which led to the first surgery to remove the kidney stones (at that point she had two stones  large in size and no way to pass them on her own). However even the urologists she saw all stated there shouldn’t be pain associated to them since they weren’t trying to be passed  they were only sitting. This should have been a big red flag  in retrospect.  Her first surgery was on November 6  2018  to blast the stones  but they were only able to get one of them. The other required a different type of surgery and a new urologist. An appointment for that was set for Dec 5  2018. In the meantime  she was in and out of the emergency room for pain management about every three to four days (with a huge deductible  I may add). The Sunday following Thanksgiving  frustrated beyond belief with the whole ordeal  she decided to go to a new emergency room that wasn’t associated with her urologists (where she had been going at their direction so that they had access to her records). In the new emergency room  after blood was drawn  a urine sample was taken  and a CT scan was done  she was told that she had pancreatic cancer. It was a complete shock  to say the least. When the doctor walked in the room she thought he was going to tell her she had more stones. And it happened within an hour of her arrival  after so many months of not knowing the real reason for the pain  which turned out to be that the size of the cancer had grown so large it was now pressing on things around it. Within hours of her diagnosis she admitted to oncology. It was determined through biopsy that she was stage four and that it had already spread to her liver  and possibly to her lungs as well. She was told she was terminal and could not be cured. Since then  she has been in and out of the hospital for various reasons related to the cancer. It’s a brutal  painful  debilitating disease. The pain as of February has already become so bad that she can’t walk and is bed bound 24/7 when she is lucky enough to be home. Recently she was told  after putting herself through the physical trauma of chemotherapy since December  the tumor markers in her blood were spiking at last check; indicating her tumors are not shrinking. She was originally told that she would have approximately nine to fourteen months left if treatment didn’t help. She is now exploring alternative treatments in hopes it will slow the cancer. While there is no cure  she is fighting very hard for enough time to see her children grow up a little longer.I am writing this as a close friend of the family  but the fund is being set up to go directly to Heather’s amazing husband  Rob  as well as her amazing ex-husband  Steve. You see  in one of the most awe-inspiring things I’ve heard in a long time  Steve has recently moved in with Rob and Heather. Their maturity and dedication to what is best for their children is simply incredible. It’s been a huge help to Rob while he tries to work  take care of Heather  and be a dad to his stepchildren and baby son. And it’s been great for the kids  who need all the support they can get right now.Heather has been denied by insurance for a motorized scooter even though she can’t walk and is bed bound. Her hair is falling out  but she is reluctant to buy herself a wig because she feels too guilty about the medical bills that won’t stop compounding. She is still trying to work through this all  fortunately her company has been bending over backwards to try and help make it easier for her to do so; her coworkers even came together to donate their own hard-earned paid time off to her. It’s still not easy  but she needs her health insurance. She fears her company won’t be able to help her keep her job much longer  though  once the donated hours end and the work she can do from home dries up. This is particularly scary considering that the medical bills are no joke  and they just keep coming and coming. This family is already going through so much and trying so hard to keep it together  the last thing they need is to end up buried in medical bills once she is gone.If you know Heather  you know how strong she is. You know she never asks anyone for anything  she is too stubborn. And you also know that even so  she will still help you if you ever need it  with no hesitation. She needs this  she needs our help now. She deserves to be able to live out the rest of her life more comfortably. She deserves to get to be a little more mobile  so she can be around the kids more  and to let her guilt over the medical bills go  because that’s the last thing she should have to be worrying about.So please anything that you can give to help out this amazing blended family will be greatly appreciated. Of course  not all can give  so if you can’t please know that Heather also very much values all of the thoughts  prayers  good vibes and love sent her way. Thank you.-Casey

It has taken us over a year to convince Anonymous to allow a Gofundme.com page to help pay medical bills.  Most people don't even know she is sick let alone drowning in medical debt.   She's been battling thyroid cancer for several years.  It's been a long and hard road so far but she never complains.  She would like to remain Anonymous and we will respect that. You can only imagine what Anonymous's medical bills are after years of battling cancer.  A few details: She's had a surgery and two rounds of radiation so far.  She has to give blood samples every two weeks  which costs money  even with health insurance.  She had her thyroid removed last year.  The medicine she must take costs around $200 monthly.  She just found out she has to have another round of treatments due to the cancer still being prevalent.  I realize it might be odd to donate blindly  not knowing who this is for.  Please trust that this person is one of the best-hearted people any of us know.  She fights for others lives and rights daily.  She has saved countless lives of individuals suffering from substance use disorder.  Let's join hands and hearts and help her fight for herself.  Let's help lessen her anxiety and suffering by offsetting the extreme medical debt that comes with chronic illness.  Please share this page and trust that you are helping someone who helps others every single day of her life and makes this world a much better place.Sincerely  Laura Kunz

On April 2nd my beloved daughter Makenna will undergo her second surgery for cancer. Two years ago Makenna received two life changing pieces of news. The first being she was expecting her second child  and the same week they found she has Thyroid Cancer. Makenna underwent surgery at 14 weeks pregnant to remove her cancerous thyroid gland  and was put on Thyroid Replacement therapy  which she will be on for the rest of her life. Traditionally  the next step would have been Radioactive Iodine  to kill any remaining thyroid tumor cells in her body  but she had to postpone till after my grandson’s birth and her provider supported Makenna in nursing for a short time. Treatment would have to wait until he was weaned. Makenna then took total control of her health. She began researching what would be most beneficial for her health  searching for which ways of eating  and food groups  were most successful in battling cancer. She lost weight  gained strength  both mentally and physically  and felt rejuvenated by the process. Despite these gains  her thyroid Cancer spread into her lymph nodes in her neck surrounding where her thyroid once was. On April 2nd she will undergo her second surgery  a more invasive and involved Neck Dissection where the surgeons will remove as many lymph nodes as possible in her neck. The surgery isn’t without significant risks  but is a necessity for her treatment plan. The current plan is 6 weeks following surgery  she will undergo radio active iodine to destroy any remaining thyroid cells in her body. When she undergoes the radioactive iodine it will require isolation from her family as it is very toxic and could harm those she comes in contact with during her isolation period.Although Makenna has health insurance through her husband Rob  there are many associated costs that are not covered. Rob will also have to miss possibly weeks of work to help provide support and care to her and the children during this process. She will need help for a while to recover  get strong  and continue on her health journey. I know how much you love Makenna and you want to help. I want to make this process as smooth and stress free as possible for her  Rob  Simone  and RJ. Your loving support will help them tremendously with medical costs  support costs  travel  missed work and more thank you again for your time and concern.

Silvia has a large cyst on each ovary and will be undergoing surgery to have them removed on Saturday  April 6  2019. She has no health insurance  and will be paying for the treatments.  If you would like to donate to help with her medical bills  this is one way you can do so.

storyTitle: TCL President Charles Toy Medication Costs
story: Hi All  This is Charles Toy  President and Founder of The Christian Left.Well  it's finally happened. I can't afford my medical costs. I'll make it short and sweet. I pay close to $800 per month for my health insurance through the ACA. I'm a Type II Diabetic and I'm insulin dependent.The monthly personal cost of my insulin went from $7 to $345 per month after insurance  savings card and finding the least expensive pharmacy to buy it. There's no way I can afford that. Rather than doing a GoFundMe every month I thought it would be best to cover the whole year at once. I have been serving The Christian Left every day for the last 10 years. I started TCL as a group in 2009 and converted it to a page not long after. I hope you can help as I have no other options and I need the insulin to live.Thanks Charles

At 27 You Believe Your Life is just starting to Blossom  until You are told a harsh disease flows inside your body. Then it All comes down crushing. Its whats happening  to Katherine. While visiting her country  Katherine went for a regular check up. At the clinic  the doctor recommended  an extra test  a Biopsy! Katherine was obviously  alarmed  but it was only supposed to be as a precaution  so she got it done.Katherine is a sweet  hard working and responsible woman. She helps her family in Colombia while working on creating her own swimwear brand  She participates in events to help kids and women and her bigger dream is to be a MOM. Sadly  a week after she came back to The States  she  received the results of her biopsy and found out she has CANCER.Katherine has Cancer Stage 3 and although  she’s far away from her family  with no health insurance and with a deep fear that she might never be a Mom  she feels the Hope and Faith in her Mind and Heart  and this  gives her the conviction that anything can be fought and defeated  including Cancer.We are  convinced that with All of Your Support  She will beat this disease and continue to Live the Happy Life God has reserved for Her. In the Process  She wishes to help  Women become aware of the Importance of their self care and annual checkups   so they can avoid the devastating news that so unexpectedly hit Her.

storyTitle: Help Jill kick cancer to the curb!
story: This is for you  Jill -- A wife  a mother  a sister  a friend  and soon to be a survivor of Stage 3 Uterine Cancer.Less than a month ago  the world as we knew it came crashing to a devastating halt with the news of Jill having Stage 2 Uterine cancer. As her family began to pick up the pieces and start to process this travesty  Jill underwent a radical hysterectomy and hoped for the best possible outcome. After hearing the results from her lab tests done post-op  that wasn't the case. The tests indicated that are now cancerous cells outside of the uterus   resulting in Stage 3 cancer.The Bertolero family (John  Jill  Kevin and Justin) is the most selfless family we know  always going out of their way to help anyone and everyone -- now it's our turn to help them. As most of you know  they own their own business and work side-by-side every day. Having said that  you know that means having to pay out of pocket for their own health insurance. With Jill going undergoing chemotherapy and trips to Roswell Cancer Center in Buffalo  NY  both John and Jill will be missing work  thus making it difficult to afford the towering costs of cancer treatment.Your donation  no matter the amount  will greatly help with their medical expenses and everyday necessities. I know Jill  John and the boys mean the world to all of us  so what better way to show our love and support. But most of all  keep Jill in your prayers and help her beat this. She is a strong woman  and is determined to KICK CANCER TO THE CURB!! Love to all of you!

A family crisis can come out of nowhere and knock you completely off your feet. The Harms family knows this first-hand. And as their friends and family  we want to do all we can to help them get back on their feet  and to be able to stand through the storm they find themselves in.After serving the Lord faithfully for many years in Indonesia  Phil and Shelly Harms  together with their son Simon and daughter Sophie  had to suddenly return to the US. Their son Simon is in crisis  and needs emotional  spiritual and mental help. For the sake of the whole family they left behind their ministry  home  and life on the field  to come and get help in the best place possible.The medical costs are already beginning to add up – hospital care  therapists and other professionals  medicines  etc. Some of this will be ongoing for the foreseeable future. And their health insurance was through Shelly’s teaching position overseas and does not cover anything here in the US. They will need to get insurance for the family here to help to pay for all these expenses – a huge expense in itself!And because this was so sudden  everything they own is still back in Indonesia. Phil will need to make a trip back to close out their home  sell what he can  and arrange to ship their household belongings back to the US. This alone will cost thousand dollars. And finding and renting a home in the Lakeland FL area will cost so much more than they have been paying overseas… and they need a car… and a myriad of other things!We are thankful for those of you who faithfully support their ministry each month – they will continue to need you more than ever. But the expenses already incurred and those coming will be far more than their usual ministry support income can handle. Frankly  they are overwhelmed!So many people have asked what they can do to help Phil and Shelly and the kids  and so as their ministry teammates and friends  we thought a campaign like this would be an easy way for friends and family to contribute to meet these overwhelming needs.All funds raised through this campaign have been set up for Phil and Shelly to have exclusive use and control of the funds for the family.One behalf of the Harms family  we would like to thank everyone for their love  prayers and support through this difficult time. May the Lord bless you richly! Mike & Heather Eastwood

My name is Ashley  I am a friend of Marco. We met through work and Marco is the coworker that looks out for everyone and makes everyone smile  even on our bad days. Recently Marco was diagnosed with kidney failure and has been in and out of cinics for dialysis treatments due to his kidney failure from a previous medical treatment. It’s hard showing up to my shifts and seeing my ray of sunshine slowly dimmer. Marco doesn’t want anyone to see him sick or in pain  he wants people to still see him smiling and happy. He wants to be healthy and be able to live a normal life  and \be able to enjoy more than one slice of pizza a week.\"Due to unfortunate circumstances Marco does not qualify for health insurance to cover the cost for a kidney transplant and all the medications that come with it. The transplant would help Marco ditch the dyalisis clinics he has to attend three times a week  It would help get him closer to a more normal routine and most of all  it will help prolonggate his life.I can only wish everyone that reads this would meet Marco and see how he can light up anyone’s day. I thank you for your time and help so that I and everyone who loves Marco get the chance to see him shine and continue to make us smile."

I'm one of those individuals that could not afford health insurance due to my age even with the Affordable Care Act. I was hoping to get to Medicare but   unfortunately   had a medical emergency last week and am unable to personally pay the out of pocket expenses. Any help would be so appreciated!❤

Chandramaya (whom some of us call Sunita) is a passionate English teacher from Kathmandu. Mother of an 18 month old son and 8 year old daughter  she seems to have unlimited energy to support others around her. Her life was as normal as any of ours -- until she was diagnosed with thyroid cancer recently. She is currently under treatment in New Delhi  due to lack of key medicines needed for her case in Nepal. Treatment in India would also greatly increase the chance of saving her voice during surgery. That touched the teachers among us even more. Doctors have said that hers is a treatable case  and they have scheduled the next big steps in chemo and radio therapy. - - - Update: For those who wish to support directly-- Chandra Maya Adhikari; Nepal Investment Bank  Kathmandu  Nepal; Account: 00205080250023; Swift code : NIBLNPKT - - - As those of us who grew up in Nepal know  there is no health insurance in our part of the world. So  going for an intense  long-term treatment abroad has not only added a whole lot of challenges to a young family. It is saddling them with insurmountable debt. Together  we might be able to make a difference. With request from Chanda  three of us--Mangal Tamang her former classmate and her former teachers Shyam Sharma and Prakash Subedi--decided to create this initiative for supporting her. We would truly appreciate anyone who can contribute -- to save the life of a teacher  mother  friend.God bless!

Julia is a 17 year-old student  writer  speaker  political activist  Unitarian Universalist  camp counselor  and all around amazing person. She loves children and devotes a great deal of her time to them  especially those with special needs. Julia is also no stranger to the inside of Doctor’s offices and emergency rooms.In May of 2018  after years of medical appointments  tests  and frustration attempting to analyze what was thought to be random pain  Julia  was finally diagnosed with Amplified Musculoskeletal Pain Syndrome (AMPS) . This news was both a relief from the terror of having an invisible illness with no known cause and a new challenge for Julia.So what is AMPS? The short answer is an agonizing medical condition that can cause pain anywhere in the body. These episodes can be intermittent or constant and can affect the whole body or be localized to one area. The degree of pain children with AMPS experience is far more intense than one would normally expect. For Julia it manifests as extreme  constant pain in her lower extremities  frequent migraine headaches  and sporadic cases of Costochondritis. The pain in Julia's ankles and legs continues to increase despite physical therapy  and she is now using a wheelchair in order to attend school and to continue her advocacy and social justice work.Minor cases of AMPS can sometimes be treated with routine physical therapy and a daily workout routine. For more severe cases like Julia’s there are a number of AMPS pain clinics in the US. The closest to Julia’s home in Austin  TX is Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City  MO.Upon diagnosis Julia was placed on a 6 month wait list for the clinic. As luck would have it  a cancellation allow her to be evaluated there in September resulting in her acceptance into the clinic for treatment. Many calls to the clinic and insurance company later  Julia starts treatment on Monday  November 12th!The specialized treatment offered by these clinics involves much more intensive physical therapy to help her body break the continuous feedback loop of pain it has come to normalize. It’s a grueling process - and comes with an impressive 80% success rate - understandably leaving Julia both excited and nervous.On average  the treatment can extend anywhere from 3 to 6 weeks  which means Julia and one of her parents will be living in Kansas City for that time. We are hoping for a 4 week (or less) stay for Julia. She will be in treatment for 8 hours a day and living at the Ronald McDonald house near the hospital by night.After a seven year long struggle the end may finally be in sight! We ask that you please contribute what you are able to and/or share this campaign with friends and family. The funds donated to this campaign will be used to help pay for traveling to and from the clinic  housing in Kansas City  and other costs associated with Julia’s treatment that are not covered by her health insurance.To read more about/by Julia  take a peek at her website  Polite Rants .

My friend Marnie was struck by a sledder while playing with her children in the snow on December 29. Her ambulance ride and emergency room treatment count towards her $7500 2018 health insurance deductible  and sadly all follow up  including diagnostics and an impending surgery  will count towards a brand new 2019 $7500 out of pocket limit.She has already used her $1000 emergency fund to cover the first bills and is trying to figure out how to handle the remaining payments without jeopardizing her family’s security.Marnie is my co-worker and a hard-working  committed employee of the Whidbey Institute  as well as a community advocate and a volunteer for social justice projects. She is also a mother of three with two children still at home and one off to college.Marnie estimates her out of pocket costs for this injury to be a total of $15 000 by the time it’s done  plus many hundreds of dollars in incidental costs. Her recovery time is estimated to take 6-12 months.Marnie’s work at the Whidbey Institute is invaluable. Her generous spirit and warm demeanor constantly uplift and remind me of how I want to walk in the world. She always has time to answer a question  offer a kind word  or listen with focused attention.Please consider donating or sharing the word with others in your network about this opportunity to help a hardworking friend and mom! Any amount helps! Even $5 or $10 will help with her many ferry trips to the doctor.The details of Marnie’s diagnosis include ruptured tendons and ligaments requiring surgical repair  a dislocated and fractured patella  a bone fragment trapped between the patella and underlying structures  and a severely damaged meniscus. Surgery will probably take place in February  as her surgeon can’t operate until the swelling is reduced.

As some of you may already know  my dear friend Carolyn Crane and her husband Jack Pope have been fighting his cancer for over two years. Jack was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer  soft tissue sarcoma  in 2016. After recovering from multiple surgeries  chemotherapy  and radiation  Jack was stricken with stage 4 melanoma in his brain last March. He has continued to fight but is now home with hospice care. Carolyn has been by his side every step of the way. They have  held each other up during this incredibly difficult time with love  gentle humor  and a shared passion for their rural homestead. No one I know has fought harder to hold on to this life  but now Carolyn must face a future without her beloved. As the sole breadwinner in the family and with basic health insurance  Carolyn has struggled to finance Jack's treatment and care. She has seen to it that he had the best available  and as a result is deeply in debt. Jack continues to need home care that is not covered by insurance and Carolyn is also exhausted from working several jobs without a break over the last two years. She needs a rest. In addition to financing current needs  I would like to help her start her next chapter without the burdens of debt and exhaustion  or at least have them alleviated somewhat. I respectfully request donations of whatever you can afford. If you cannot afford to give  then please consider prayers  in-kind donations for self-care   and loving words  as these will help to feed Carolyn's soul. I also make this request in honor of Jack  who has made my friend so happy  and for his continued  peace and well-being on his journey.

Shawn was just diagnosed with Colon Cancer. Shelby has been having serious back problems for the last year. She cant work  so he works 40+ hours a week to pay the bills  which is barely enough. His health insurance wants a 6500 deductible before they cover any of it. Shelby already has some medical bills. They were just married in September last year  they plan to have kids in the future. Please help them to reach the deductible and get through this long upcoming journey. Thank you.

Dear friends and family  As many of you know  Nate has severely suffered from Diverticulitis flares for many years. At this time  he is at UW Health Hospital in Madison  WI where he has been for the past 12 days. Nate has undergone Emergency Surgery stemming from this debilitating disease that quickly became life threatening. While we are very fortunate in many ways  high health care costs and the lack of paid family and medical leave have left him unable to afford this critical procedure and his regular occurring bills on his own. We're asking our community for support. Nate has been afflicted with stomach and bowel issues since he was a child. Over the years he has sought to find out what caused his pain with no clear results. Flares would come and he’d be given antibiotics by clinics and hospitals with the hopes that it would fix the problem  but still he had no idea what the problem was. Just before he turned 30 he finally had a diagnosis  Diverticulosis. Unfortunately for Nate  his diverticulitis flares continued regardless of changes in diet and exercise. On February 21st  Nate was in extreme pain from another diverticulitis flare and visited his local urgent care for antibiotics. On this visit the doctor expressed concern and sent for a CT scan to be done immediately. From there things spiraled into an unexpected direction  Nate was advised that the scans showed a lot of inflammation with several abscesses along with a large abscess which was perforating. He was checked into the ER and then admitted shortly thereafter. After 3 days in the hospital  another CT scan was completed and the doctors found that the infection had gotten much worse. Nate was rushed into Emergency Surgery on the 25 that which point they found that his colon had ruptured and the infection had caused so much inflammation to his colon that it had fused itself to his bladder. During surgery they removed his Sigmoid Colon and completed an Ostomy. Additionally  his colon had to be chipped away from his bladder causing damage to his bladder. His bladder was repaired and a Foley Catheter was placed to keep the bladder drained while it healed. As a result of the severity of the infection the surgeons were unable to stitch his incision up  instead the inside strength layer of the abdomen was closed and the 8 inch incision down the outside of his abdomen was left open with a few staples strategically placed on the skin layer. This will allow for the incision to slowly heal from the inside out. Since the surgery Nate has made progress towards healing  though slower than expected. The first 5 days after surgery were found to be the most difficult. The recovery period has been rough for him and has been accompanied by lots of abdominal pain from the incision as well as pressure from gas and bloating as his body learns to process foods again.At this point Nate is 9 days into his recovery from surgery and is working with the nurses and doctors at UW Health to learn at home care. In order to leave the hospital his white count has to be below 15 and his incision must be healing properly. Nate has currently missed about 2 weeks of work and will additionally miss another 2 weeks or more before he will be released to return to work. In 3 months he will have to undergo another surgery to have his colon re-attached to itself which will lead to an additional 2 weeks of missed work during the procedure and recovery. We are cautiously hopeful that under the care of these doctors  this surgery could be curative  freeing Nate from the debilitating pain that he has suffered from for many years. While we feel incredibly fortunate that Nate’s infection was caught before a more dire result  we need your support to help carry the financial burden of the surgery  hospital stay and multiple unforeseen missed days of work. Due to the high cost on his health insurance and at least six weeks of income that Nate will lose without access to paid family and medical leave  we are asking those who are willing and able to give to help him recover from this difficult time. Thank you for your love and support. If you've read this far  we're already grateful for your care and compassion. If you can't support financially  and would like to offer support in other ways  you are also appreciated  we are so thankful to have you in our lives.

I want to thank you for taking a moment to hear Trudy’s story  and tell you how much Trudy and I appreciate your prayers and encouragement.In December 2018  Trudy was diagnosed with HER2 Positive Cancer.  An invasive carcinoma in her breast  it has metastasized into a nearby lymph node.  A life changing diagnosis.  Unexpected for Trudy  who leads our family on an extraordinary healthy lifestyle focused on organic  non-GMO eating and aversion to chemically infused food and pharmaceuticals of any kind.Her “journey” is underway with 6 rounds of Chemotherapy infusions  followed by surgery  and possible radiation.With your help  the financial obligations of this major life event can be eased a bit.  Although we have good health insurance  the high deductibles  and out-of-pocket medical obligations for 2018 - 2019 are challenging.Your kindness and support for Trudy’s treatment is overwhelming. With God’s blessing  it is our hope and expectation that my beautiful wife will beat cancer  live a happy healthy life  and enjoy watching our beautiful daughters grow up.With LOVE and HOPE   Please HELP TRUDY BEAT BREAST CANCER!                                                        PLEASE SHARE ON FACEBOOK AND SOCIAL MEDIA.                                                                                              Port is put in place.                                                                                                 First round of treatment.                                                                         Two bags down  three to go.                                                                    Sharing “going bald” with Bryce and John.                                                                                  \I wear PINK for my Mom\".                                                                                    Back for next treatment.                                                                       Love of family will help conquer cancer.                                           Getting comfort anywhere you can find it  even from Charlie.                                                                               Four treatments down......Two to go!"

Sharon deLagarde  our dear colleague and friend suffered a stroke on 11/13/2018.  Sharon has unfortunately been out of work since the incident and has exhausted all of her sick days. As of January she has had no income  and is paying for her health insurance as well as all her other expenses (rent  groceries  transportation  etc.). Sharon is at risk of losing her apartment and health insurance while she is going through the process of recovery and healing. Unfortunately  stroke recovery takes an extended period of time  and while she has made some progress  she will not able to return to work anytime soon. Sharon has been a dedicated paraprofessional for 15 years and is well loved by the children and staff. She is always willing to help others  and we want to help her now. Please consider donating to help Sharon! We appreciate your support.

storyTitle: Alesha's journey to healing-God has the final say!
story: **** SUPER LONG POST  BUT WELL WORTH THE READ! Please SHARE this post. Word of mouth travels fast  and time is critical in this delicate matter. ******SHARE POST*******This GoFundMe campaign was launched for those who have asked how to make monetary donations to support Alesha while she is unable to work and care for herself.  The biggest misconception is that people involved in motor vehicle accidents come out on top with loads of money.  That couldn't be farther from the truth in this instance.  Health insurance and Auto Insurance companies are the hardest to get anything out of and right now there is no payout and many medical related things we will have to figure out a way to cover.  Alesha experienced a catastrophic motor vehicle accident resulting in a spinal cord injury  classified as a functional/mobility impairment secondary to T9 ASIA impairment scale   She was admitted to Sheperd Center in Atlanta  Georgia on January 8th  2019 for further medical management and to assess physiological impairments to initiate all aspects of acute rehabilitation including but not limited to: Physical Therapy  Occupational Therapy  Therapeutic Recreational Therapy  Case Management  Rehab Nursing and Neuropsychology.  She is expected to be discharged from the Sheperd Center as early as February 26  2019.  In the past patients with these type of catastrophic injuries would be afforded inpatient care for 4-6 months  but unfortunately its no longer that way.  Alesha will transition to Shepherd Center's intensive outpatient rehab Spinal Cord Day program. As a result of her spinal cord injury  she is unable to stand  walk  transfer or negotiate steps without assistance.  She is wheelchair bound and will need caregiver assistance from her mother and support system.    This type of life change will not only effect Alesha's employment  but her mothers so that she can be available to care for Alesha.Funds will assist with paying bills  car payment & insurance premium  housing  medical treatment  therapy  counseling  rehab  adapting to life in a wheelchair.  There is no amount too little and it means a lot that people want to donate from the heart to support  Alesha and relieve some of the financial strain so she can focus on her recovery.Now this is not a letter begging for anything  it’s just a simple cry out for people of faith to gather together and tap in to all the resources we can to help a family that is in great need. Blessings we are in need of:1. Looking for people who may know private owners  realtors  friends/family with rental property who will to rent to me with a family of 7. I am in need of a home to be moved into by February 15 2019 so time is CRITICAL!!!  I have challenged credit but I pay my rent and utilities on time. Possibly a 4-5-bedroom ranch style with a basement.  In need of wide doors that is wheelchair accessible with a walk-in shower in one of the bathrooms. We need the option of special accommodations and/or modifications to add a ramp to get my child in and out of the home. 2. Anyone who may have a MOVING COMPANY and would like to donate a truck for the move.3. People with resources on gently used handicap bathroom accessories (shower chair) to properly bathe and seat her.  4. Someone who has resources on ordering medical supplies in bulk that may come at a reasonable price. Things of that nature. 5.  Anyone with a mini-van for donation or sale (for a special price or payment arrangements) with or without a wheelchair lift.  We will need a spacious vehicle to transport Alesha in for therapy and doctor appointments for her continued care. I am humbling asking for everyone who sees this post to help brainstorm and put our minds and resources together to turn a bad situation into a mighty testimony!Once again  we thank you all for your love and support at this trying time in our lives. We do believe in the POWER OF PRAYER  so keep interceding on our family’s behalf.  We also  know the power of SOCIAL MEDIA and that with a simple click of a button this message can be shared all over the world in a matter minutes. So please SHARE SHARE SHARE this post and let’s keep it going so that we have the opportunity to tap into as many resources as possible.Thank you and God Bless!

Our mother  Graciela Pedroza  suffered a severe stroke on Friday  October 19th while coming back from Mexico. She was in Zacatecas for her father-in-law’s funeral services and was on the road when the stroke occurred. While she was rushed to a Mexican clinic in Juarez  she did not receive proper care and her brain underwent severe damage. Fortunately  she was taken to the University Medical Center in El Paso  Texas  where she is currently receiving medical care.
