God has answered all of them  some maybe not the way we wanted but by his grace most of them have been what we asked for or better.  When I was diagnosed in July of 2017  it was stage 4 acute kidney/ renal failure. We prayed for it to get better but by September it was stage 5/end stage chronic kidney failure. In His wisdom God had said no to that prayer. But then sent me on a journey!! He broke me down and began to teach me what trust is and where my trust should be. He opened my eyes to the grace He pours out to us every day through Jesus. He taught me the importance of prayer and opening up to the prayer Warriors He has put in my life. He put a selfless Christian woman in my life  my kidney sis. And then He never stopped loving me or letting me know He was there.  I am at peace today with whatever God does next with this surgery. How could I be anything else when He has gotten me over many hurdles? They said I would be a difficult match.  I would need dialysis for 1-5 years  most likely about 2 years and yet He found a match for me quickly. Last night was my last time on dialysis and that marks just under 3 months  not 2 years! Praise be to God! There are over 100 000 people waiting for a transplant  but only about 16 000 - 18 000/ year. I am blessed.  Then about 3 weeks before surgery I was told that my antibody number had gone up. This meant I would need to go through a desensitizing program. That is when they moved surgery from 1/2 to 1/3. I was going to have to do a series of things that come with risk and I was scared.  It would involve an IV of immune suppressing drugs that can cause some issues  then I would have had a line or port placed in my chest/ neck area. This would be used for 2 plasma treatments  the week of surgery. My blood would have been cycled out  plasma removed  antibodies hopefully reduced and plasma returned. Then the afternoon before surgery they would have checked my antibody level. If if wasn’t where they needed it to be the transplant would have been cancelled! More prayers by my faithful prayer warriors and God said  ”ok  I can change this”.   About a week later I got a call that my antibody number had dropped to lower than when we had first started the process. They asked a few questions about if I’d done certain things that month. I hadn’t so all they could say was that they had no idea how or why my numbers had dropped but they were cancelling the scary desensitizing program. Praise be to God! So does God hear our prayers  absolutely  so keep praying. Is it always a yes? No  but it is always for our best. God had a plan back in 1980 that would save my life in 2019. In 1980 while I was walking through the doors of Wisconsin Lutheran College as a student  Cindy was born. Little did I know the God would use WLC as my connection to my kidney sis. That is how we met years later when she was working there.  If God can do all of this  how can I be anything else but at peace. He knows what He’s doing! Continue to pray Warriors! God loves us. I love you all too. Thanks for hanging in there with us.” #annsplanted #donatelife #trustourgod

My big brother Dave Murra has been diagnosed with Chronic Pancreatitis and is very sick.  He currently has a feeding tube to provide him nourishment since he cannot eat.  If he does eat  it makes the pain unbearable.  Dave has not been able to work since early this summer.    We are moving Dave and his family back to his hometown of Brookings  SD  in order to be closer to his doctors in Minneapolis  and to be closer to  his family.  Dave is being treated by the doctors at the University of Minnesota and has had to make several trips to Minneapolis for stays in the hospital  with several more trips to follow.  Once the doctors decide he is well enough for the surgery  they will be performing the Whipple Procedure on him.  This is a very serious surgery where he will need to spend 1-2 weeks in the hospital.  Once he is released  he will need to stay somewhere near the hospital in order to be monitored by his doctors. While Dave does have health insurance coverage with the state  he does not have any income to pay for living and travel expenses for him and his family.    Dave  and his long-time girlfriend Sammie  have 2 daughters Jamie and Abbie.  Please consider donating to help Dave get thru this terrible illness.

Wrenleigh Harper is a beautiful blessing! Looking at that precious face  you wouldn’t know she is fighting big battles. On January 7th  Madelyn received a call from Wrenleigh’s pediatrician. Her newborn screen came back abnormal. He made arrangements for us at St. Louis Children’s Hospital to begin testing.  While there  she was seen by a team of residents  fellows  immunologists  rheumatologists  and cardiologists. Lab work  spinal tap  X-rays  echocardiograms  and genetic tests were done. Many of those were done in house and several were sent out to Mayo Clinic.  On day #10 we were able to come home with some information while final results were still a week away.  On January 23  at 23 days old  Wrenleigh was diagnosed with DiGeorge Syndrome  also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome. This syndrome is when part of chromosome number 22 is missing  resulting in heart defects  cleft palate  learning and development problems  mental health problems  thymus gland disfunction  and autoimmune deficiencies. On January 29  Wrenleigh was admitted to St. Louis Children’s Hospital for heart failure. In addition to the 2 known heart defects (right aortic arch and large VSD)  the cardiologists discovered she has a rare anomaly called Hemitruncus. She will be having surgery to repair the VSD and Hemitruncus within the next two days.  Recovery time will be 2-4 weeks inpatient at St. Louis Children’s Hospital. THIS IS HER BIGGEST BATTLE YET! It is heartbreaking to see this beautiful baby of 7.5 pounds struggle to breathe  feed  and sleep.  There are many long days ahead for her. On Monday night (January 28) I prayed for God to put the doctors  nurses  and entire medical staff in place to take care of her. I felt we were in a place of uncertainty. As Madelyn and I walked into the ER of Children’s Hospital and the nurse took her into her arms and began to talk to us  I knew He had set His plan in motion. Our first request is prayer for Wrenleigh  family  and the medical staff. Madelyn will be staying with her following the surgery and during her recovery time at home. Her sick leave time is exhausted because of the pregnancy complications. Wrenleigh has private health insurance with a high deductible ($6500). Medical  travel  and out of pocket costs continue to grow. A big “thank you” to our SuperHeroes for your donations  prayers  and encouraging words.￼

￼I'm Amy Hedges  and on December 6  2018  my dad  Steve Riexinger was diagnosed with multiple Pulmonary Embolisms originating from a recent knee injury. He is lucky to have caught the symptoms as early as he did  and to be alive. He was in the hospital for a week  receiving extensive  lifesaving treatment. The medical bills are adding up  and for my dad owning his own business  the health insurance options are not great. ￼ Steve and Kathy are the most generous  selfless people I know  never hesitating to help friends and family in need. My dad spent this whole past spring and summer caring for his own dad during his final days  and then caring for his mom after his dad's passing. Steve's knee injury occurred on his most recent trip home from Buffalo  right before Thanksgiving. My parents have the biggest hearts. My whole life  I've watched them give  in every sense of the word  whether it be free legal counsel  help with a home improvement project  car repairs  computer repairs  and everything in between  they have always been there to lend a hand. Now they need our help. All donations collected will go directly towards medical expenses ONLY! In the event that they collect more than amount needed to cover medical expenses  Steve and Kathy will be donating to charity. Thank you! ￼ ￼

My sweet friend Carol was a high school English teacher who loved her job and working with students on literature and writing.  Her husband Kevin was retired from his job as a stage hand  and had just been diagnosed with Lewy Body Dementia  a type that fluctuates between better and worse days  but he was so far functioning pretty well and was out and doing things independently.In January 2018  Kevin and Carol were the victims of a car accident that turned their world upside down.  She had 8 broken ribs and a broken sternum  and Kevin’s Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) became much worse.  He was unable to walk or do things for himself such as showering and shaving  and was confined to a wheelchair  unable to get from there back and forth to bed without a lot of help.  It became obvious that he would have to be moved to somewhere they could care for him properly.  He was extremely forgetful and easily confused. He now has hallucinations and frightening dreams which give him paranoid delusions. Medication is of limited help for him. It has been a very hard year for them.Carol was able to return to teaching with the new school year in August  but a urological condition became considerably worse  and soon she was placed on short-term disability. A urologist told her about a device that could be implanted like a pacemaker and would help her condition so that she would be able to work again. She had a trial period of using it externally  which was successful  and things began to look up.Unfortunately  her employer decided that they could no longer keep her position open.  Her health insurance goes away at the end of the month. She was able to schedule the surgery to permanently implant the device before the insurance ends  so a lot will be covered. However  she will still have to come up with over $900.00 in co-pays  plus additional doctor and anesthesiologist charges. She needs to be able to pay the co-pay by January 20th to go ahead with the surgery. The short-term disability will end on the 22nd  the same day as the surgery  leaving no time for follow-up appointments to evaluate how well the surgery worked. After that  she will have no income at all.  She is 62 and in poor health  so it may be hard for her to get a job. She might have to apply for a small Social Security check and an even smaller teacher pension if she can’t return to work. Being able to return to work is contingent on the success of the surgery. She is terrified about what she will do without any income before she can begin receiving some retirement or return to work.  The process will take weeks and perhaps months.  She doesn’t know what she will be able to do for health care either.  Her income situation is complicated  and she is doubtful she could qualify for state-provided health care or be able to afford something from the government marketplace.Meanwhile  her husband needs to be visited regularly to keep his spirits up. His disease is fatal  and she has no way of knowing how long he will live. She has been able to get to most appointments and fulfill obligations  which will be problematic when she runs out of gas money for her car.Carol feels terrible about asking for help  so I am asking on her behalf.  If you can help in her in any way  I know she would be so grateful.   She needs help with the copay for the surgery  and to cover utilities and living expenses for the next few months until she can work again or transition to retirement or disability.

Two months ago Lacey went into the ER with severe neck pain. She was in and out of the hospital for over a month trying to get treatment for what appears to be vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome  a life threatening condition that affects connective tissue. In order for Lacey to receive the treatment she needs  she first has to get a diagnosis.This is a time consuming and expensive process. Both neurosurgeons who treated Lacey in the hospital are concerned that she has vascular EDS  but because the condition is so rare testing is not covered by health insurance. EDS is a genetic disorder  and it runs in Lacey's family. We are fairly certain she has vascular EDS  but she needs to overcome the hurdle of diagnosis in order to continue with treatment.Lacey's neurosurgeon has referred her to a rheumatologist at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville  but the expense of this visit is prohibitive for Lacey on her own.This medical emergency happened weeks after Lacey moved to Tallahassee  and she was in the process of getting covered by Medicaid at the time. Unfortunately  she did not have any health insurance when she had to go the ER. Lacey was not able to start her new job at TMH for over two months while she was in the hospital. She then incurred over $20 000 in medical expenses. She is in the probationary period in her new job and will eligible for insurance in six months.Even when she has insurance  Lacey will not able to afford this diagnostic process on her own. Here is a breakdown of expenses related to the diagnosis:$1000-$2000 for genetic testing$300 for a new patient appointment with the rheumatologist at the Mayo ClinicAdditionally  Lacey will have to pay for special diagnostic imaging (ex: a sit-down MRI)  a skin biopsy  and additional tests.Living with EDS means major arteries  muscles  or organs may dissect or rupture at any time. Lacey has already had three arterial dissections. They are very scary and very painful.Any amount you can contribute would be deeply appreciated and would put Lacey closer to getting the answers and the medical care she needs. She would use these funds primarily for her first visit to the Mayo Clinic.More info on Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

storyTitle: Help For Dave Park's Brain Aneurysm
story: This is a campaign to help my step son Dave parks pay for medical expenses and bills. As I am writing this  Dave is undergoing emergency brain surgery in Morton Plant hospital in Clearwater Florida. Doctors are trying to do everything possible to save his life! Last night on 11/19/2018 my 38-year-old step son Dave Parks suffered a bleeding Brain Aneurysm.  Dave is a dedicated father of two children Conner (13) & Cameron (8). Dave and his partner of 14 years (Dawn) have been working hard every day to raise their two young children in today’s trying world.  Dave works as a line cook in a restaurant and leads a very modest and humble life. He and Dawn work 7 days a week to keep a roof over their children’s head and lead the best life possible for their children.Because of the extreme high premiums and the cost of raising two young children  Dave could not afford health insurance and currently does not have any coverage.Dave is a dedicated father and coach in the community he lives in and volunteers all his off time coaching and mentoring two youth football teams in the Dunedin Florida area.At this point in time  we don’t even know Dave’s prognosis  but if he survives this ordeal  the neurosurgeon’s said that he has a long long road to recovery.All proceeds will go to Dave’s medical expenses and his family’s daily living bills so that his partner and children may continue onward during this horrible ordeal.Please send your love  prayers and support to his family during this extreme time of need. Let’s help Dave and his family through this difficult time and help him get through this!

On March 7th Gloria Kontaratos came in for a Hysterectomy. The next day she woke up in pain and had no feeling in her lower legs and feet. After 5 hrs of enduring this pain in post op  she was moved to another floor. Then it was a proactive nurse who listened to her complaints and cries and took action. She saved her life. After testing they discovered a blood clot the size of a golf ball in her Thoracic Artery outside her heart. Pieces broke off and traveled down her body causing Compartment Syndrome and damaging use of her feet. Amputation is still a possibility. They next performed 2 Fasciotomy surgeries on both sides of her legs. Due to the amount of blood clots  both were not a success. Removing the blood clot by her heart has a high risk factor. She was placed on blood thinners and being monitored daily to see if there is any change. Wound Vacs where placed inside her legs to help bring swelling down for closure. After 2 weeks of wound vacs closure was not a success due to the swelling. They then performed another surgery attaching Derma Closure devices. She still has no feeling in her feet. It's a day by day process waiting on wounds to reach the point for closure. Once released from hospital she will have to go directly to a Physical Therapy Rehabilitation Center to learn how to reuse her legs and feet before returning home. She will have to live with the golf ball sized blood clot hoping blood thinner will prevent something like this happening again. She tested positive for a P.F Gene This has been an uphill battle since day one. 5 surgeries in 3 weeks. Her physical therapy has been pushed back weeks due to delayed wound closures. The devices used on her recovery cause extreme daily pain. Life events always happen and no one is ever prepared for them. We definitely were taken back by this blow that struck both of us hard. Reality is also starting to set in. Gloria will be out of work for months maybe even more. Bills are already building up. We are reaching out to anyone who can assist us in our future trials. We are asking for any financial help to keep her health insurance going  Medical bills  Home bills  Medical equipment  Rehab  Adapting our home for her physical needs  transportation etc. Shes fighting hard. She is working on keeping her mental and spiritual attitude positive as we continue receive unsettling news regarding her health. Thank you for reading this. Anything will help even sharing this. Gloria is the strongest person and has the biggest heart. We hope to get through this storm with your love and support. Thank you. George & Gloria Kontaratos. 917 834 8684 Compart Syndrome  https://youtu.be/aE_kjN4SBiEDerma Closure  https://youtu.be/Wd4itRkCVpkWound Vacs https://youtu.be/KiPVzfcD1_A

storyTitle: Love & Support for our beloved Loma
story: Hello dearest family-friends of our beloved Loma!   Many of you know  a few months ago  Loma struggled with a series of health issues and mishaps that ultimately landed her in the hospital with Pneumonia.  Once the medical part was under control  she was moved into a rehabilitation facility.  As she was recovering  — receiving physical  occupational and cognitive therapy —  it became abundantly clear that moms days of living alone in her little apartment in Kauai have passed.  At 91  she now needs lots of loving support  ongoing.  After looking into various possible options  we concluded that having mom close by in an 'assisted living’ community was the best and only sensible choice to best support her.The great news is that Loma is now 'back home'  near to friends and loved ones  living in a wonderful community  and receiving all the medical  physical and social support she needs in order to thrive in this latest phase of a well-lived life.The challenging part is that the financial expense of this assistance is significant.  The costs of 'room & board' at the facility (Sunrise Senior Living)  along with the 'assisted care support level' she requires  is thousands of dollars each month beyond what I can personally be able to sustain  without lots of help...  Added to this are past due expenses from the emergency room  hospital and rehab stays in Kauai.  Sadly  Loma's only health insurance - Medicare - doesn't cover any of this.  The $35 000 fundraising target covers the added resources needed to pay off the medical bills and to keep mom at Sunrise through the first half of 2019.   It's simply too much for me to be able to handle on my own.  So  dear ones  I am asking for this help  I'm asking for angels  asking for miracles  for grace -- for mom.   SponsorsIn addition to the immediate request for assistance  I am looking for \Angels\" that would help to sponser mom  ongoing.  If you happen to be -- or know of -- one of those angels  please contact me directly at (213) 500-7711.Thank you everyone for all the support we've been receiving.  Please continue to send your loving and and your light moms way.  It means everything and makes all the difference.  Please share this with anyone at any time.  And  if you are so moved to give financially  please know that any amount is greatly appreciated.In much loving and so much gratitude for all the blessings... Paul"

storyTitle: Emergency Surgery - Help Save Carlos' Vision
story: Who: Carlos Garcia - a father  Marine  my brother  and all-around nice personWhat: Sudden retinal detachment surgery  at risk of permanently losing his vision if he doesn't undergo pneumatic retinopexy  (PR) immediatelyWhen: He met with a vision specialist today (March 31st) due to issues with his vision and was told he is at very high risk of permanent blindness.  His surgery is being scheduled within 24 hours due to the potential loss of permanent eyesightWhere: Carlos lives in Oxnard  CA.  A specialist from Texas is flying in to perform the surgery  as he believes immediate surgery will have the highest chance to save his eyesightWhy: We need help financially because Carlos has been without health insurance due to his line of work - he works as a body guard/security and all jobs are contract-work  without health benefits.  Carlos has also been out of the Marine Corps. too long for the VA to assist (and if you have ANY experience with the VA  you do *not* want them working on your eyes)Any financial contribution will help.  Carlos' family and friends are working together to help make the situation less stressful for him.  We appreciate you taking the time to learn about Carlos' situation  sharing this call for help  and helping him at this time. Carlos is easily the most selfless and most giving person I know.  In the 36 years I've known him  he has never been one to walk away from helping people.  That translated into him serving 5 years in the Marine Corps.  and into how he's been as a father to his two boys  Evan and Ethan.  Carlos will stop on the side of the highway to change a tire  he will stop at an accident and secure the area until help arrives  he will fly across the country to help a grieving friend without a second thought. But one thing about Carlos is how stubborn he is when it comes to accepting help - and that's where his friends and family come in.We learned today from Carlos that he is suffering from a retinal detachment  in one eye and after speaking with his vision specialist  he has to undergo surgery within 24 hours if there is any chance to save the vision in his eye.  The surgery is nothing short of a medical marvel  and a surgeon from Texas is flying to California to perform the surgery as I type this.  But Carlos needs our help.Due to Carlos' line of work as a body guard/security guard  his jobs are all contract-based and offer no benefits.  Carlos typically works two jobs putting in over 60 hours a week to be able to live in California close to his kids  and as I mentioned before  the last person he thinks of providing for is himself.  So we are hoping to raise the money for Carlos' surgery and recovery.  Any amount will help.  Please share this with anyone you feel may is inclined to help or share.  From Carlos  his friends and family - thank you.

This picture is of my daughter  Kate. She is medically disabled. Over the last ten years  keeping Kate out of the hospital has almost been a full time job. She suffers from an autoimmune disorder  and following a pancreatic transplant in 2017   she has suffered with open fistulas and bowel blockages that cause severe and constant pain. In 2018 alone  Kate was hospitalized 41 times  resulting in her being an inpatient more than she was at home. The medical bills for last year alone were crushing and she and her husband continue to manage those on a monthly basis.Last week her husband was laid off from his job with only a two week severance package. Unfortunately  that means that on March 31  2019 they will have no health insurance.  By God’s grace  Kate will qualify for Medicare through her disability later this summer.  In the meantime  they do have the option to COBRA with her husband’s current insurance  but the cost to do that is $2 348.00 per month. She has been working diligently on her nutrition levels so she can have yet another surgery to hopefully resolve some of her current issues. As you you can see  Kate cannot be without health insurance for even one day. Turning to family  friends  and acquaintances is not what she wants to do  but she has no other choice at this time.I appreciate you reading Kate’s story. I know she will certainly appreciate your prayers  words of encouragement  and any financial help you are able to share with her during this difficult time.Thank You.

“All About Ashley” My dear friend  Ashley  was the victim of a hit and run driver in Paris  France  on 10 November 2018. She is in serious condition and has sustain four factures (hip  jaw  eye socket and skull)  additionally and more seriously  she has sustain life threatening trauma to her brain that resulted to swelling  brain hemorrhage and a collapse of brain vessels. As a result of her injuries she will require major ongoing medical care and future rehabilitation for some length of time. At present  she is out of the coma and as of now has been removed from the respirator  all really great signs  however  due to the serious nature of her brain trauma  she is still and will remain in the Neurological Trauma Intensive Care Unit for some time to come as they continue to monitor and treat her trauma conditions. Ashley recently lost her personal health insurance and therefore has no next-of-kin / dependent health insurance coverage. Therefore  she now has major medical bills  of which will continue to mount  as well as  the rehabilitation bills to come. To ensure that Ashley continues to receive the most urgent and best care possible for a quick and full recovery  funding is needed to help her cover cost while her parents work with the French Administration to complete her repatriation process  which once approved  will provide her with basic healthcare coverage but will still only cover a portion of her ongoing medical and rehabilitation expenses. Ashley is special to so many people  including her dog  Kaia and her cat Yuna. Ashley loves to travel the world  meet new people  learn new languages and cultures  play piano  sketch all manner of things and she loves to cook and bake. Although she doesn’t often show it as it is very personal to her  her spirituality is one of her most profound qualities. Ashley was just about to head back to Michigan when this happened  let us all join in and do all that we can to help her recover and return home as soon as possible. Please help us on this “All About Ashley” mission  to help her and her family weather this tragic event by donating whatever you can. Other ways to help are to keep Ashley and her Family in your thoughts and prayers and share this with as many people as you can….so please  spread the word….”All About Ashely” let’s bring her home soon and recovered. ￼\n￼￼￼

Good day!  Thank you for viewing our page.  We are here to raise money for my uncle  Ken Pearson.  Ken was diagnosed two years ago with Prostate Cancer.  For the last two years he has done everything holistically he could to keep the cancer at bay  but as of his last scans  the cancer is growing and it is time to decide on a course of treatment.  My aunt and uncle have done extensive research on ALL options available for prostate cancer.  In the end  they have decided to pursue a treatment option that is relatively new to the medical field.  This treatment is called HIFU (High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound) which is an FDA approved  minimally invasive procedure that offers personalized treatment and dramatically reduced side effects.Ken and his wife  Donna have spoken to Dr. Cordell Nwokeji in Kingwood  TX who has been instrumental in them finding this treatment and easing their concerns regarding such a new option.  He has told them all about the procedure  which is a same-day  outpatient procedure.  It is non-invasive  is radiation free and is personalized to each individual patient for a more targeted treatment.  They will have to travel to Texas to have this procedure done with this doctor who they feel very fortunate to have had contact with.This procedure is unfortunately very costly and at this time  Ken and Donna's health insurance will not cover this procedure.  That is where you come in  dear reader.  We are asking for donations to help us raise the money so that my uncle can receive this treatment.  Ken is someone who gives back regularly to his community by helping out at his church (NLC Cabot) and he and Donna lead a Divorce Care class at their church.  They are constantly doing for others and because of this I am hoping others will reach out and help them in this endeavor of raising the money for this treatment.  We hope that you will consider making a donation so he can get the treatment he needs. If you want to donate but would rather send a check to Donna and Ken  please email Donna at Donna.Pearson@patientpoint.com to get the mailing address. We thank you in advance  and God Bless!

storyTitle: And the Beat Goes On:Support Greco against cancer
story: Gregory Freeman  affectionately known as Greco to his friends andfamily  is a former policeman  a retired fireman for the City of Detroit and a popular Detroit area musician.  He is also a single father of two  a caring and giving son to his mom whom he currently takes care of  and a tremendous asset to our community.  Unfortunately  Greco had to retire early from his job serving his community; which he loved  due to an injury sustained in the line of duty. However  this hasn’t stopped him from living his best life. Greco very much enjoys bringing people together and making them happy. This is the driving force behind his work as a musician.Greco is a very popular and renowned musician  composer  arranger singer  and percussionist. He performs and records with many talentedlocal and international musicians. For more than 40 years  he hasexperienced the power of music and as a way to give back to ourcommunity; he shares his love for music with inner city schools inDetroit and the surrounding area  fully aware that many young childrendon’t often have the opportunity to experience the richness of livemusic.Our loving and caring friend Greco has recently been diagnosed with an aggressive form of stage 4 lung cancer that has also spread to his bones. His health insurance only covers a fraction of his medical bills - which are mounting daily. Due to his painful and debilitating condition Greco is unable to work at this time to meet his medical  family and other financial obligations.We  his friends  are coming to you for help as we would like to takesome of the burden off of Greco and his family during this difficult time. We are asking if you would join us and donate to this special fund for our brother and friend Greco.We thank you in advance; no gift is too small or too big.

The brain tumor is back...and my vision is going...and they're not even related. The pain in my head is becoming excruciating again. No surgery this time. They want to do focused radiation. 5 days a week for 6 weeks. Ugh. But at least it's not surgery. THAT was traumatic. But  there's an 80-90% chance the tumor will not grow back after the radiation  and I like those odds. There's a big co-pay with every visit  so 30 co-pays. A month-and-a-half ago  I woke up to some vision loss in my right eye. I've seen an ophthalmologist who has run some tests  determined it wasn't in my eyes  it's in my brain  it's not related to my brain tumor  and by the way  there's loss of peripheral vision in both eyes  too. Now I need to see a specialist-specialist - a neuro-ophthalmologist  who specializes in where the eyes communicate with the brain. Many expensive tests in my future. This is especially frustrating and upsetting because I'm WordPress web designer  a graphic designer  and a fine artist  and I've just started painting again since my brain surgery  and now I'm losing my vision. I need to see. I hope we can stop it. Then I found out that there is an excellent likelihood that I lose my health insurance as of January 1  2019. I'm working on that  too. The money raised will help me get all this taken care of. We're not sure what the symptoms will be when all this is done. I'm still working  doing graphic design and WordPress web design  I'm still painting until I can't see any more. The picture below is a watercolor I recently did of my grandson. I had so many plans for my art. Things are now up in the air.I can't begin to pay for all of this. I'm only 2 1/2 years out from my brain surgery in 2016  and frankly  still recovering. I've been working hard  thank goodness  but it's been exhausting.Won't you please consider donating so I can get the health care I need? I will be so grateful for anything I can raise. It gives me more time. Otherwise  things don't look good for me. Any amount you can donate - as soon as possible - will be deeply appreciated. My grandkids will thank you. My kids will thank you. My mom and my sisters will thank you. I thank you.

Update: We finally got Kay back to Montana  but unfortunately  she was only able to stay home for a day and a half before we were ambulanced back to the hospital. Her heart rate was extremely fast and the doctor suspected another bout of dehydration. We will be in the hospital again for at least a week while they run many tests and hopefully start and immune system treatment. We will have another bone marrow biopsy in the near future as well. Thank you so much to those who have donated  kept her in your prayers  and sent cards. They brighten her spirit!Hello everyone. As many of you know  Kay has been pretty sick for the last few months. She went into the hospital right after Thanksgiving and stayed for 8 days. She ended up having to go back in on December 27th with severe dehydration. She has 3 autoimmune diseases affecting her liver  blood  heart  and blood sugars and unfortunately  they don’t always play nicely together. She started in ICU and slowly got better as doctors here in Bozeman tried to figure out what caused her decline. However  no matter how hard they tried  she was still struggling. So she was air lifted to Salt Lake where she unfortunately fell and fractured her hip  needing surgery. She has been working so hard in PT so that she can come home. We still have a long road ahead of us and many doctors here in Bozeman and a home health care team will monitor her here as we continue to try and make her better. Rick has been with her every step of the way! He has been an amazing support system for her. Putting his own rest  fears  and even a hurt shoulder on the back burner while he cares for her. He is truly remarkable ❤️They have developed many needs and payments over the course of the last 2 months. She has great health insurance  so thankfully  we don’t see very many medical costs coming from this  however the sudden transfer to Salt Lake has incurred many costs from travel  hotels  medical supplies  and of course  food. We have most of the gear and supplies she will need already  but we have need of a lift recliner upon her return home. Many of you have reached out to many of us asking how you can help. There are many different ways to help: We can always use prayers! We still have a long road ahead with many doctors appointments and many questions still yet to be answered. Please keep us in your thoughts and prayers as we navigate her road to recovery  I’m afraid it’s going to be a very long road. She would love cards - we could shower her with love! It would boost her spirits tremendously ❤️ Their home address is 236 Cameron Loop Bozeman  MT 59718. She loves hearing from you guys!We have debated doing this for quite some time. But they love helping people and we know that people want to help them. There are so many stressors in their life right now  emotional  financial  physical  mental - that we all felt if we could take at least one stressor off of their plate  that we should. Thank you all so much for keeping Rick and Kay in your thoughts and prayers. It has kept them and us going. She loves you all so very much!

￼I'm Amy Hedges  and on December 6  2018  my dad  Steve Riexinger was diagnosed with multiple Pulmonary Embolisms originating from a recent knee injury. He is lucky to have caught the symptoms as early as he did  and to be alive. He was in the hospital for a week  receiving extensive  lifesaving treatment. The medical bills are adding up  and for my dad owning his own business  the health insurance options are not great. ￼ Steve and Kathy are the most generous  selfless people I know  never hesitating to help friends and family in need. My dad spent this whole past spring and summer caring for his own dad during his final days  and then caring for his mom after his dad's passing. Steve's knee injury occurred on his most recent trip home from Buffalo  right before Thanksgiving. My parents have the biggest hearts. My whole life  I've watched them give  in every sense of the word  whether it be free legal counsel  help with a home improvement project  car repairs  computer repairs  and everything in between  they have always been there to lend a hand. Now they need our help. All donations collected will go directly towards medical expenses ONLY! In the event that they collect more than amount needed to cover medical expenses  Steve and Kathy will be donating to charity. Thank you! ￼ ￼

Brian was diagnosed with Stage 3 Seminoma Testicular Cancer in December  2018.  Testicular cancer is rare among cancers but it is the #1 diagnosed cancer for males aged 15-35.  Brian had surgery on January 7 to remove a large testicular tumor.  The cat scan showed retroperitoneal lymph node and lung involvement.  We are still waiting results of the MRI to determine if the brain is involved.  Brian will be starting a very aggressive 9-week regimen of chemo (BEP X 3) on Monday  February 11.  He does not have health insurance and will not be able to work while undergoing treatment and possibly a few weeks after.  We are asking for help with paying for his surgery and basic living expenses so that he can concentrate on getting back to health.  Brian is 30-years old.   Thank you in advance for any help you can give.  Most of all we desire your prayers. PSA:  Ladies - if caught early Testicular Cancer is easily cured with tumor removal and surveillance.  Encourage your sons  brothers  husbands  uncles  dads  etc. to perform routine testicular exams regardless of their age but especially between the ages of 15 - 35.  If a lump is found do not settle for antibiotics or \it's probably fluid\".  Demand an ultrasound and follow up on the results."

My sweet friend Carol was a high school English teacher who loved her job and working with students on literature and writing.  Her husband Kevin was retired from his job as a stage hand  and had just been diagnosed with Lewy Body Dementia  a type that fluctuates between better and worse days  but he was so far functioning pretty well and was out and doing things independently.In January 2018  Kevin and Carol were the victims of a car accident that turned their world upside down.  She had 8 broken ribs and a broken sternum  and Kevin’s Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) became much worse.  He was unable to walk or do things for himself such as showering and shaving  and was confined to a wheelchair  unable to get from there back and forth to bed without a lot of help.  It became obvious that he would have to be moved to somewhere they could care for him properly.  He was extremely forgetful and easily confused. He now has hallucinations and frightening dreams which give him paranoid delusions. Medication is of limited help for him. It has been a very hard year for them.Carol was able to return to teaching with the new school year in August  but a urological condition became considerably worse  and soon she was placed on short-term disability. A urologist told her about a device that could be implanted like a pacemaker and would help her condition so that she would be able to work again. She had a trial period of using it externally  which was successful  and things began to look up.Unfortunately  her employer decided that they could no longer keep her position open.  Her health insurance goes away at the end of the month. She was able to schedule the surgery to permanently implant the device before the insurance ends  so a lot will be covered. However  she will still have to come up with over $900.00 in co-pays  plus additional doctor and anesthesiologist charges. She needs to be able to pay the co-pay by January 20th to go ahead with the surgery. The short-term disability will end on the 22nd  the same day as the surgery  leaving no time for follow-up appointments to evaluate how well the surgery worked. After that  she will have no income at all.  She is 62 and in poor health  so it may be hard for her to get a job. She might have to apply for a small Social Security check and an even smaller teacher pension if she can’t return to work. Being able to return to work is contingent on the success of the surgery. She is terrified about what she will do without any income before she can begin receiving some retirement or return to work.  The process will take weeks and perhaps months.  She doesn’t know what she will be able to do for health care either.  Her income situation is complicated  and she is doubtful she could qualify for state-provided health care or be able to afford something from the government marketplace.Meanwhile  her husband needs to be visited regularly to keep his spirits up. His disease is fatal  and she has no way of knowing how long he will live. She has been able to get to most appointments and fulfill obligations  which will be problematic when she runs out of gas money for her car.Carol feels terrible about asking for help  so I am asking on her behalf.  If you can help in her in any way  I know she would be so grateful.   She needs help with the copay for the surgery  and to cover utilities and living expenses for the next few months until she can work again or transition to retirement or disability.

Two months ago Lacey went into the ER with severe neck pain. She was in and out of the hospital for over a month trying to get treatment for what appears to be vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome  a life threatening condition that affects connective tissue. In order for Lacey to receive the treatment she needs  she first has to get a diagnosis.This is a time consuming and expensive process. Both neurosurgeons who treated Lacey in the hospital are concerned that she has vascular EDS  but because the condition is so rare testing is not covered by health insurance. EDS is a genetic disorder  and it runs in Lacey's family. We are fairly certain she has vascular EDS  but she needs to overcome the hurdle of diagnosis in order to continue with treatment.Lacey's neurosurgeon has referred her to a rheumatologist at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville  but the expense of this visit is prohibitive for Lacey on her own.This medical emergency happened weeks after Lacey moved to Tallahassee  and she was in the process of getting covered by Medicaid at the time. Unfortunately  she did not have any health insurance when she had to go the ER. Lacey was not able to start her new job at TMH for over two months while she was in the hospital. She then incurred over $20 000 in medical expenses. She is in the probationary period in her new job and will eligible for insurance in six months.Even when she has insurance  Lacey will not able to afford this diagnostic process on her own. Here is a breakdown of expenses related to the diagnosis:$1000-$2000 for genetic testing$300 for a new patient appointment with the rheumatologist at the Mayo ClinicAdditionally  Lacey will have to pay for special diagnostic imaging (ex: a sit-down MRI)  a skin biopsy  and additional tests.Living with EDS means major arteries  muscles  or organs may dissect or rupture at any time. Lacey has already had three arterial dissections. They are very scary and very painful.Any amount you can contribute would be deeply appreciated and would put Lacey closer to getting the answers and the medical care she needs. She would use these funds primarily for her first visit to the Mayo Clinic.More info on Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

storyTitle: Help For Dave Park's Brain Aneurysm
story: This is a campaign to help my step son Dave parks pay for medical expenses and bills. As I am writing this  Dave is undergoing emergency brain surgery in Morton Plant hospital in Clearwater Florida. Doctors are trying to do everything possible to save his life! Last night on 11/19/2018 my 38-year-old step son Dave Parks suffered a bleeding Brain Aneurysm.  Dave is a dedicated father of two children Conner (13) & Cameron (8). Dave and his partner of 14 years (Dawn) have been working hard every day to raise their two young children in today’s trying world.  Dave works as a line cook in a restaurant and leads a very modest and humble life. He and Dawn work 7 days a week to keep a roof over their children’s head and lead the best life possible for their children.Because of the extreme high premiums and the cost of raising two young children  Dave could not afford health insurance and currently does not have any coverage.Dave is a dedicated father and coach in the community he lives in and volunteers all his off time coaching and mentoring two youth football teams in the Dunedin Florida area.At this point in time  we don’t even know Dave’s prognosis  but if he survives this ordeal  the neurosurgeon’s said that he has a long long road to recovery.All proceeds will go to Dave’s medical expenses and his family’s daily living bills so that his partner and children may continue onward during this horrible ordeal.Please send your love  prayers and support to his family during this extreme time of need. Let’s help Dave and his family through this difficult time and help him get through this!

On March 7th Gloria Kontaratos came in for a Hysterectomy. The next day she woke up in pain and had no feeling in her lower legs and feet. After 5 hrs of enduring this pain in post op  she was moved to another floor. Then it was a proactive nurse who listened to her complaints and cries and took action. She saved her life. After testing they discovered a blood clot the size of a golf ball in her Thoracic Artery outside her heart. Pieces broke off and traveled down her body causing Compartment Syndrome and damaging use of her feet. Amputation is still a possibility. They next performed 2 Fasciotomy surgeries on both sides of her legs. Due to the amount of blood clots  both were not a success. Removing the blood clot by her heart has a high risk factor. She was placed on blood thinners and being monitored daily to see if there is any change. Wound Vacs where placed inside her legs to help bring swelling down for closure. After 2 weeks of wound vacs closure was not a success due to the swelling. They then performed another surgery attaching Derma Closure devices. She still has no feeling in her feet. It's a day by day process waiting on wounds to reach the point for closure. Once released from hospital she will have to go directly to a Physical Therapy Rehabilitation Center to learn how to reuse her legs and feet before returning home. She will have to live with the golf ball sized blood clot hoping blood thinner will prevent something like this happening again. She tested positive for a P.F Gene This has been an uphill battle since day one. 5 surgeries in 3 weeks. Her physical therapy has been pushed back weeks due to delayed wound closures. The devices used on her recovery cause extreme daily pain. Life events always happen and no one is ever prepared for them. We definitely were taken back by this blow that struck both of us hard. Reality is also starting to set in. Gloria will be out of work for months maybe even more. Bills are already building up. We are reaching out to anyone who can assist us in our future trials. We are asking for any financial help to keep her health insurance going  Medical bills  Home bills  Medical equipment  Rehab  Adapting our home for her physical needs  transportation etc. Shes fighting hard. She is working on keeping her mental and spiritual attitude positive as we continue receive unsettling news regarding her health. Thank you for reading this. Anything will help even sharing this. Gloria is the strongest person and has the biggest heart. We hope to get through this storm with your love and support. Thank you. George & Gloria Kontaratos. 917 834 8684 Compart Syndrome  https://youtu.be/aE_kjN4SBiEDerma Closure  https://youtu.be/Wd4itRkCVpkWound Vacs https://youtu.be/KiPVzfcD1_A

storyTitle: Love & Support for our beloved Loma
story: Hello dearest family-friends of our beloved Loma!   Many of you know  a few months ago  Loma struggled with a series of health issues and mishaps that ultimately landed her in the hospital with Pneumonia.  Once the medical part was under control  she was moved into a rehabilitation facility.  As she was recovering  — receiving physical  occupational and cognitive therapy —  it became abundantly clear that moms days of living alone in her little apartment in Kauai have passed.  At 91  she now needs lots of loving support  ongoing.  After looking into various possible options  we concluded that having mom close by in an 'assisted living’ community was the best and only sensible choice to best support her.The great news is that Loma is now 'back home'  near to friends and loved ones  living in a wonderful community  and receiving all the medical  physical and social support she needs in order to thrive in this latest phase of a well-lived life.The challenging part is that the financial expense of this assistance is significant.  The costs of 'room & board' at the facility (Sunrise Senior Living)  along with the 'assisted care support level' she requires  is thousands of dollars each month beyond what I can personally be able to sustain  without lots of help...  Added to this are past due expenses from the emergency room  hospital and rehab stays in Kauai.  Sadly  Loma's only health insurance - Medicare - doesn't cover any of this.  The $35 000 fundraising target covers the added resources needed to pay off the medical bills and to keep mom at Sunrise through the first half of 2019.   It's simply too much for me to be able to handle on my own.  So  dear ones  I am asking for this help  I'm asking for angels  asking for miracles  for grace -- for mom.   SponsorsIn addition to the immediate request for assistance  I am looking for \Angels\" that would help to sponser mom  ongoing.  If you happen to be -- or know of -- one of those angels  please contact me directly at (213) 500-7711.Thank you everyone for all the support we've been receiving.  Please continue to send your loving and and your light moms way.  It means everything and makes all the difference.  Please share this with anyone at any time.  And  if you are so moved to give financially  please know that any amount is greatly appreciated.In much loving and so much gratitude for all the blessings... Paul"

storyTitle: Emergency Surgery - Help Save Carlos' Vision
story: Who: Carlos Garcia - a father  Marine  my brother  and all-around nice personWhat: Sudden retinal detachment surgery  at risk of permanently losing his vision if he doesn't undergo pneumatic retinopexy  (PR) immediatelyWhen: He met with a vision specialist today (March 31st) due to issues with his vision and was told he is at very high risk of permanent blindness.  His surgery is being scheduled within 24 hours due to the potential loss of permanent eyesightWhere: Carlos lives in Oxnard  CA.  A specialist from Texas is flying in to perform the surgery  as he believes immediate surgery will have the highest chance to save his eyesightWhy: We need help financially because Carlos has been without health insurance due to his line of work - he works as a body guard/security and all jobs are contract-work  without health benefits.  Carlos has also been out of the Marine Corps. too long for the VA to assist (and if you have ANY experience with the VA  you do *not* want them working on your eyes)Any financial contribution will help.  Carlos' family and friends are working together to help make the situation less stressful for him.  We appreciate you taking the time to learn about Carlos' situation  sharing this call for help  and helping him at this time. Carlos is easily the most selfless and most giving person I know.  In the 36 years I've known him  he has never been one to walk away from helping people.  That translated into him serving 5 years in the Marine Corps.  and into how he's been as a father to his two boys  Evan and Ethan.  Carlos will stop on the side of the highway to change a tire  he will stop at an accident and secure the area until help arrives  he will fly across the country to help a grieving friend without a second thought. But one thing about Carlos is how stubborn he is when it comes to accepting help - and that's where his friends and family come in.We learned today from Carlos that he is suffering from a retinal detachment  in one eye and after speaking with his vision specialist  he has to undergo surgery within 24 hours if there is any chance to save the vision in his eye.  The surgery is nothing short of a medical marvel  and a surgeon from Texas is flying to California to perform the surgery as I type this.  But Carlos needs our help.Due to Carlos' line of work as a body guard/security guard  his jobs are all contract-based and offer no benefits.  Carlos typically works two jobs putting in over 60 hours a week to be able to live in California close to his kids  and as I mentioned before  the last person he thinks of providing for is himself.  So we are hoping to raise the money for Carlos' surgery and recovery.  Any amount will help.  Please share this with anyone you feel may is inclined to help or share.  From Carlos  his friends and family - thank you.

This picture is of my daughter  Kate. She is medically disabled. Over the last ten years  keeping Kate out of the hospital has almost been a full time job. She suffers from an autoimmune disorder  and following a pancreatic transplant in 2017   she has suffered with open fistulas and bowel blockages that cause severe and constant pain. In 2018 alone  Kate was hospitalized 41 times  resulting in her being an inpatient more than she was at home. The medical bills for last year alone were crushing and she and her husband continue to manage those on a monthly basis.Last week her husband was laid off from his job with only a two week severance package. Unfortunately  that means that on March 31  2019 they will have no health insurance.  By God’s grace  Kate will qualify for Medicare through her disability later this summer.  In the meantime  they do have the option to COBRA with her husband’s current insurance  but the cost to do that is $2 348.00 per month. She has been working diligently on her nutrition levels so she can have yet another surgery to hopefully resolve some of her current issues. As you you can see  Kate cannot be without health insurance for even one day. Turning to family  friends  and acquaintances is not what she wants to do  but she has no other choice at this time.I appreciate you reading Kate’s story. I know she will certainly appreciate your prayers  words of encouragement  and any financial help you are able to share with her during this difficult time.Thank You.

“All About Ashley” My dear friend  Ashley  was the victim of a hit and run driver in Paris  France  on 10 November 2018. She is in serious condition and has sustain four factures (hip  jaw  eye socket and skull)  additionally and more seriously  she has sustain life threatening trauma to her brain that resulted to swelling  brain hemorrhage and a collapse of brain vessels. As a result of her injuries she will require major ongoing medical care and future rehabilitation for some length of time. At present  she is out of the coma and as of now has been removed from the respirator  all really great signs  however  due to the serious nature of her brain trauma  she is still and will remain in the Neurological Trauma Intensive Care Unit for some time to come as they continue to monitor and treat her trauma conditions. Ashley recently lost her personal health insurance and therefore has no next-of-kin / dependent health insurance coverage. Therefore  she now has major medical bills  of which will continue to mount  as well as  the rehabilitation bills to come. To ensure that Ashley continues to receive the most urgent and best care possible for a quick and full recovery  funding is needed to help her cover cost while her parents work with the French Administration to complete her repatriation process  which once approved  will provide her with basic healthcare coverage but will still only cover a portion of her ongoing medical and rehabilitation expenses. Ashley is special to so many people  including her dog  Kaia and her cat Yuna. Ashley loves to travel the world  meet new people  learn new languages and cultures  play piano  sketch all manner of things and she loves to cook and bake. Although she doesn’t often show it as it is very personal to her  her spirituality is one of her most profound qualities. Ashley was just about to head back to Michigan when this happened  let us all join in and do all that we can to help her recover and return home as soon as possible. Please help us on this “All About Ashley” mission  to help her and her family weather this tragic event by donating whatever you can. Other ways to help are to keep Ashley and her Family in your thoughts and prayers and share this with as many people as you can….so please  spread the word….”All About Ashely” let’s bring her home soon and recovered. ￼\n￼￼￼

Good day!  Thank you for viewing our page.  We are here to raise money for my uncle  Ken Pearson.  Ken was diagnosed two years ago with Prostate Cancer.  For the last two years he has done everything holistically he could to keep the cancer at bay  but as of his last scans  the cancer is growing and it is time to decide on a course of treatment.  My aunt and uncle have done extensive research on ALL options available for prostate cancer.  In the end  they have decided to pursue a treatment option that is relatively new to the medical field.  This treatment is called HIFU (High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound) which is an FDA approved  minimally invasive procedure that offers personalized treatment and dramatically reduced side effects.Ken and his wife  Donna have spoken to Dr. Cordell Nwokeji in Kingwood  TX who has been instrumental in them finding this treatment and easing their concerns regarding such a new option.  He has told them all about the procedure  which is a same-day  outpatient procedure.  It is non-invasive  is radiation free and is personalized to each individual patient for a more targeted treatment.  They will have to travel to Texas to have this procedure done with this doctor who they feel very fortunate to have had contact with.This procedure is unfortunately very costly and at this time  Ken and Donna's health insurance will not cover this procedure.  That is where you come in  dear reader.  We are asking for donations to help us raise the money so that my uncle can receive this treatment.  Ken is someone who gives back regularly to his community by helping out at his church (NLC Cabot) and he and Donna lead a Divorce Care class at their church.  They are constantly doing for others and because of this I am hoping others will reach out and help them in this endeavor of raising the money for this treatment.  We hope that you will consider making a donation so he can get the treatment he needs. If you want to donate but would rather send a check to Donna and Ken  please email Donna at Donna.Pearson@patientpoint.com to get the mailing address. We thank you in advance  and God Bless!

storyTitle: And the Beat Goes On:Support Greco against cancer
story: Gregory Freeman  affectionately known as Greco to his friends andfamily  is a former policeman  a retired fireman for the City of Detroit and a popular Detroit area musician.  He is also a single father of two  a caring and giving son to his mom whom he currently takes care of  and a tremendous asset to our community.  Unfortunately  Greco had to retire early from his job serving his community; which he loved  due to an injury sustained in the line of duty. However  this hasn’t stopped him from living his best life. Greco very much enjoys bringing people together and making them happy. This is the driving force behind his work as a musician.Greco is a very popular and renowned musician  composer  arranger singer  and percussionist. He performs and records with many talentedlocal and international musicians. For more than 40 years  he hasexperienced the power of music and as a way to give back to ourcommunity; he shares his love for music with inner city schools inDetroit and the surrounding area  fully aware that many young childrendon’t often have the opportunity to experience the richness of livemusic.Our loving and caring friend Greco has recently been diagnosed with an aggressive form of stage 4 lung cancer that has also spread to his bones. His health insurance only covers a fraction of his medical bills - which are mounting daily. Due to his painful and debilitating condition Greco is unable to work at this time to meet his medical  family and other financial obligations.We  his friends  are coming to you for help as we would like to takesome of the burden off of Greco and his family during this difficult time. We are asking if you would join us and donate to this special fund for our brother and friend Greco.We thank you in advance; no gift is too small or too big.

Michael is our dear friend  loving father  loving husband and decorated police officer. He is diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia on Feb 22  2019 .Five days prior   he went to doctor for fever and cough. He was told he has lower respiratory infection and was given medications. He wasn’t getting any better and on february 21  decided to go to another doctor. They did a chest X-ray and blood test. He wasn’t getting enough oxygen   they found pneumonia and his plaelet counts 25  normal is 400. He was then transferred to Carilion Roanoke Memorial for bone marrow biopsy. It’s when he found out about his leukemia. He will be undergoing intensive chemotherapy treatments for the next month and will be living at the hospital for the duration. He has currently no income to limited income . He also doesn't have health insurance to cover his medical expensesIf you’ve ever met Michael   there’s a chance that you really like him. He’s stubborn  but extremely kind and generous. He can talk your ear off for hours or just listen when he needs to. He’s pretty great. We are looking for all generous friends and family to step up and help them through this trying time.We’re asking for your help to cover his medical expenses and really appreciate anything that you can offer.Many thanks!

storyTitle: Help Marie's Mission to Fight Hodgkin's Lymphoma
story: Marie is a 35-year-old wife and mother of two (Macoy-11 and Marlow- 6) from Andover  MN.  Just over a month ago Marie found a lump by her collarbone. She had it looked at right away and gave it time to go away on its own. She returned to the doctor to follow up as the lump had grown some and she was having a little pain.She was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s Lymphoma on November 23rd  2018. She recently found out she is in Stage III-A (favorable & non-bulky - both of these classifications are good). She will need to undergo 6 months of chemotherapy. Treatments will be every two weeks beginning mid-December. Marie is staying very strong and positive for her family and children. Her hope is to work as much as possible to keep her mind busy  still see all of her wonderful co-workers/ clients and provide financially for her family. Marie’s main goal is to be strong and ready for baseball season  she has never missed one of her children’s baseball games and she is looking forward to spending all her spare time at the ball field!! Marie has had a ton of love and support already from friends  family  and co-workers and is truly grateful for everyone’s support in her fight! Marie will try to keep everyone updated on her progress  likely through social media. Marie has been my best friend since third grade and the closest thing I have ever had to a sister. She is a hard working mother of two that would do anything for anyone. She is sweet but feisty  strong-willed and is planning on kicking cancer’s ass. In asking for donations  it was important to Marie to be transparent in telling where the funds will be allocated. While Marie has health insurance  there is a high deductible and her maximum out-of-pocket for 2018 is $4100.00  her insurance will then roll over and she is required to pay $4100.00 in 2019 as well.  While Marie's work is flexible  with all the upcoming appointments and chemo treatments  she will need to take unpaid days. Funds will also be used for lost wages over the next 6 months. I really want to take the financial burden off my friend and her family's shoulders by raising $4100 before the new year to cover her 2018 medical costs. Please help is any way you can  even $5 can go a long way with everyone’s help! Thank you!If you are not comfortable with donating online  you may contact me (Hilary Hansen) for her address by emailing hilaryjh82@gmail.com.

Last year we had a painful awakening. After a severe bullying situation that was a friend breakup gone wrong our straight A athletic student started to spiral. Her grades went down and she stopped going to track. She started to close herself off emotionally. Our daughter is/was clinically depressed  suicidal and anxious. Not knowing what else to do and on the advice of her pediatrician we  sent her to the John Muir Adolescent Mental Health Outpatient program to stabilize her. That was the start of multiple hospitalizations  intensive therapy for her and a lot of work on ourselves so that we could change patterns that contributed to her mental state. Last year she went to a residential program in Orange  CA and then came home to another intensive outpatient therapy program. She then stabilized in her school using resources made available to her by the school district  her therapist and psychiatrist. We thought we were further down the road to recovery than we are. It's easy let your guard down. I thought I could start growing my business again and that life would go back to normal.  The whole cycle restarted last week. She voluntarily hospitalized herself and she's back in outpatient with a possibility of residential care again. She is on the waitlist for the UCSF DBT program—only 1 of two bay area  intensive evidence-based DBT programs that takes insurance  and 4 in the state— it's a  6 month wait because the need is so great. It is the therapy that time and again is recommended by our mental healthcare team.  It involves weekly 1x1 therapy  group education and 24x7 coaching on mindfulness techniques. I am the primary caregiver but here's the problem; I'm self-employed so I can't go on paid family leave. There is no safety net for our family.  Here's what it's like to care for a mentally ill kid:Volatility: Any emotional setback can quickly spiral to suicidal thoughts. That means if we say the wrong thing she could wind up in the hospital. Some days she is completely fine.  Somewhere in the middle there's this:  my daughter may be overwhelmed and needs to leave school in the middle of the day.  She can't be left alone after that. Self-harm: You could  wake up to a daughter who has cut her wrists to deal with her intense emotional pain. It's the scariest thing ever. That was last week for us.Social interactions with peers are needed and yet problematic. You have to stay on top of social situations and monitor for substance abuse: For my daughter: After years of not finding her friend group and being subjected to bullying in Junior High she has lots of friends at her high school but the pressures of social media and to be noticed has contributed to her emotional spiral. She wants to be like everyone else but she isn’t like everyone else. Part of fitting in is smoking weed and drinking.  A friend who thinks they’re doing her a solid by helping her numb her pain with a hit on the wax pen is contributing to her crash. Teens on medication who have depression issues especially need to stay away from drugs and alcohol. Her interactions with peers must be closely monitored. Your life can change in an instant.Your child goes from pretty self sufficient to needing round the clock care from moment to moment.  You can’t work a 9-5 job. You need to be there. As her primary caregiver You are the driver  You are the personal assistant  the pharmacist   the researcher  the interviewer/interviewee  the canary in the coal mine  the insurance fighter   the emotional punching bag  the unwavering support  her “person”. You don't usually have a solid block of time in your day for much else other than to fall apart when everyone else is asleep.You have to work on yourself too: Speaking of falling apart some of this is the result of a pattern in our family and our family histories  that we need to break. That requires much self-reflection for both myself and my husband. We both have unresolved issues from our own childhoods that are now front and center. It also affects our current relationships and boundary-setting within our own families to protect our family. This is devastating in and of itself when you have family members who also have unresolved mental health issues that affect your immediate family and children. Sometimes it's not just your immediate family that falls apart. You can't forget about their siblings. We have  another daughter who isn’t mentally ill and she can’t be left behind. She needs care too. Her sister is not the same girl she grew up with and she misses her and the time when our life was stable. She doesn't understand why her sister wants to die sometimes.The financial impact of mental illness on a family is catastrophic. Losing income causes a stressful family environment. We’ve lost about half my income and one month before the breakdown I signed a 2-year lease on a photo studio that has largely sat empty (hindsight is 20/20 ) Health insurance is around $2000 a month but that doesn’t cover our maximum out of pocket. Insurance is about to turn over for us in April and the obligation to pay a max out of pocket will reset. We are in that gray area where we make too much money to qualify for public assistance and too little to pay the premiums  deductibles and out-of-pocket contributions combined. I need to take time to care for my daughter . While being worried about her my husband and I are  feeling so much anxiety about how we'll make ends meet. It's not good for her to be around stressed out parents.Other ways to help:  Recommend me:  I don’t have the time  the  means to market my business or the mental energy to network. I'm  taking word of mouth clients and recommendations because my marketing department has been on hiatus.  If you can't contribute please recommend me to friends and family who might need a wedding  portrait or headshot photographer.  I shoot  while my husband is home from work and I am committed to my craft and clients despite hardship.Meals: we won't say no to a meal dropped off.A shoulder. That's always nice. Help mental health awareness in your community.  Build community. Reserve judgement.  Understand that with the right treatment a person can be a fully functioning healthy member of society. Understand that mental illness impacts the whole family  that no one person caused it. Understand that a person who is actively seeking treatment is building skills that most people don't have.  I truly believe that going through fire  forges strength but it  takes the help of your community to make your way through it. It's humbling and scary to tell this story and ask for help so please give us grace as we heal. Do what you can to reverse the stigma in mental health. Educate yourself.  Reach out to me. I will be the shoulder that understands. Read this blog post and do one thing on this list:  25 Ways You Can Impact Mental Health Awareness in Your Community

storyTitle: Let’s Help JO Fight Ovarian Cancer
story: Our friend Jo went into her scheduled hysterectomy on January 14.  she got prepped for surgery and went under anesthesia as planned. After waking up  thinking the procedure had went as planned  she got the worst news anyone could receive. She had to be told that the surgery actually never took place. They had to stop the surgery before anything was removed. When the first incisions were made to her abdomen  fluid came gushing out. This was the first sign Jo had ovarian cancer. The tumor was in the way and the doctors could not go any further. The plan is to remove the fluid with several rounds of chemotherapy and then surgery to remove the cancer. After that will be several rounds of chemotherapy again. Funds that are raised will help offset all the gaps that are in their health insurance coverage. There will be huge amounts of deductibles and co-pays which will financially  burden this wonderful family. Not only those costs but the cost of lost wages and time away from work for her loving Husband that is the sole provider for the family of 5. Raising a family of five is hard  having to deal with Cancer and the financial devastation that comes with seems unbearable. The time is now. We respectfully ask you to donate and be Urgent. We together can take a huge burden off our friends and leave them to deal with the long road ahead with at least some financial peace of mind. There is also a food train that is set up so that you can help the family with providing dinner. Please find those details on Facebook

storyTitle: Jessica Wamsley's Brain Surgery and Recovery
story: The medical journeyI have been diagnosed with a symptomatic growth located in my pineal gland. I experienced my first symptom in 2006 and have seen so many doctors that have tried different treatments and have been given different diagnosis. There was no definitive explanation as to why these issues have come about but I have been labeled with peripheral neuropathy  CRPS  migraines  anisocoria  essential tremors  light and sound sensitivity  unexplained nausea  and tinnitus over the past 12 years. There were no abnormalities or explanations on tests with the exception of an enlarged and complex pineal gland.In 2016  I found a facebook group called Pineal Cysts and Tumors that has not only supported me emotionally  but also provided me with valuable information that linked me with doctors educated in my specific illness. Other members in this group had similar symptoms as mine and I was amazed that most doctors had very little knowledge of the pineal gland. In September  I became ill with hives and received what should have been a simple and easy treatment. I then became violently ill and felt myself take a turn for the worse. I have not been able to work or petsit since the beginning of September. Standing is unbearable after 15 minutes. Sensitivity to light and noise noticed. When people speak in a regular voice I think they are shouting. I can’t stand fluorescent lights. Stress seems to aggravate everything at this point. I noticed recently I get angry easily and am more impatient from when I last thought I was becoming impatient.  I am easily lost in the middle of a sentence and I will pause until I can regain my train of thought. (Thanks everyone for finishing my sentences and reminding me what we were talking about!) I get nausea randomly  or if their is an unexpected texture when eating. Debilitating migraines! Recently  I experienced my first aural migraine. My social  home and work life have suffered dramatically over the past 6 months. Lately I feel so tired; sleeping in a dark quiet room has become my life. I feel my quality of life has declined for so many years  but this year has been nearly unbearable. I don’t think there any other options at this point.  After feeling as if I did my \due diligence\"  I reached out to Dr. Sunil J. Patel in Charleston  SC after reading that he is one of the 5 doctors in the WORLD that regularly deal with the pineal gland. I sent my MRIs  CT scans  medical records and a list/timeline of my symptoms to Dr. Patel and was told \" I can cure you\" on November 16th 2018. My surgery is scheduled December 19th  2018 in Charleston SC.  https://www.broadcastmed.com/neurology/7419/videos/resection-of-pineocytomas-offers-symptom-relief Moving forward and costsI am expected to make a full recovery and should be able to return to work March 2019. This is where you come in  as you can imagine  my medical journey has become quite expensive. I have luckily been able to obtain COBRA continuation health insurance through my job which brings my $113 000.00 brain surgery to around $6 000.00 to $10 000.00. I have also cashed out my 401k and have been living off this money. Unfortunately  I am reaching the end of my funds and feel I have gotten so close to the end of this nightmare. I need help  your help to keep this journey going!Your donation will go towards basic living expenses and medical bills. I know you all can't wait to get me back. Help me get over this horrifying illness!"

Meet Billy White!  Billy is a very special person to so many people.  He's one of the most energetic people you will ever meet.  His sense of humor is one of a kind.  There are so many great things we could say about Billy but honestly I'm not sure if gofundme.com allows that much to be entered.  As you can tell in the picture up above Billy is a fighter.  Billy prides himself on being in great physical shape and also a great competitor inside the ring.  Billy is a MMA Fighter and Boxer.  But now Billy's fighting a new fight!  He's fighting his toughest competitor yet and possibly the toughest he ever will!  Just last week Billy was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia.  Now he's fighting for his life!  Billy has dedicated his life to the service of others.  Billy is a Deputy Sheriff with the Campbell County Sheriff's Office in Tennessee.  Billy also serves as a member of the Sheriff's Office Special Weapons And Tactics Team.  Billy puts so much on the line every time he goes to work and never thinks twice about what the cost could be at any given time.  He is an exemplary law enforcement officer and loved in the community.But now Billy needs our help.  We as Billy's family and friends are asking for help.  Billy does have health insurance but it will not cover the cost of all the medical procedures in front of him.  And of course it also doesn't help him paying his every day bills in which he will likely struggle to pay while off work fighting for his life.  Please anything you can give would be greatly appreciated!  Help us Fight Like White!

storyTitle: Gender Confirmation Surgery for Jonny (FKA Jenn)
