story: Hi everyone. I'm Michelle. Here I am with my cousin  Anna. And that sweet angel baby is her daughter  Ruby. Anna and Ruby are two of my favorite people on this planet. Since we were kids  Anna has been my singing mermaid sidekick. The Ariel (pronounced Ah-ree-ell  like how Sebastian the crab says it) to my Ariel (pronounced the regular way--also  shout out to our other sidekick  the mermaid Cereal a.k.a. Jessica!) The first time I met toddler Ruby  she immediately hugged me and called me Ahn-tay (Auntie) and melted my heart. And Anna's hubs/Ruby's dad Matt a.k.a. Giant Ruby--he's pretty cool too.  I mean  I want to be like  no one is good enough for my cousin! But he's proven himself through his endless support of his wife and daughter. They are honestly the most precious family! As many of you may know  in August 2017  when Ruby was just a wee one  Anna was diagnosed with stage 4 colorectal cancer that had spread to her liver. As you may also know  Anna kicked its ass--mostly. She's endured 13 rounds of intensive chemo  one week of intense radiation  one major surgery and a second surgery that was supposed to make the last of the liver tumors die away. This warrior woman has been through it all.Unfortunately  the last surgery wasn't fully successful  and new scans show the tumors still in her liver.This is where you come in  friends. This amazing  ass-kicking mama needs your help for the next round of treatments. The new treatment is called Y90 with Radio-embolization  and Anna will also be taking a chemo pill in combination with a liver angiogram which involves injecting the liver with microspheres that will emit radiation for twelve days. Anna and Matt are still waiting to find out if insurance will cover all this. And  through all of the treatments  Matt will continue working extremely long hours to meet expenses and maintain their health insurance. Fatigue is the number one symptom that Anna will face  so it will be difficult to care for Ruby or do work around the house.They'll use the money donated here to hire a nanny for Ruby  especially during the two weeks in which Anna can have no contact with her at all due to the radiation. It will also be used for any part of the treatments that insurance won't cover  and household expenses that might come up. This mama urgently needs your help. She is the strongest person I know--and the money raised here will help her maintain that strength through this difficult process  and will help take care of little Ruby. Anna and Matt want desperately to put this chapter behind them and focus all their love and energy on their precious Ruby Kae. #forrubykaePlus  I need my mermaid sidekick singing at full capacity!Do like Ruby and \Be kind\"! Our family thanks you for your support.With love Michelle"

PLEASE HELP DANI HEAL!Throughout her life  our 19 year-old daughter Daniela has suffered from a variety of recurring health issues such as acute throat infections  renal complications  tachycardia  general weakness and digestive problems  principally chronic gastritis that began at age 6 and has landed her in the emergency room on many occasions. Since childhood Dani has been under constant medical care for her diverse ailments  yet we have never received an explanation about the true origin of her painful digestive problems and overall delicate health. Now Dani’s digestive tract issues have become more severe than ever  seriously affecting not only her stomach but also her colon and duodenum. Last year she lost 17 pounds in an alarmingly short time  without any apparent reason. Since then she has undergone a battery of medical tests  but all results have come back either negative or inconclusive. Her symptoms are presently being treated  but none of her doctors has been able to determine the root cause of her illness. Dani is currently 25 pounds below the minimum normal weight for her age and height  and continues to lose weight on a weekly basis  despite regularly eating a balanced and nourishing diet.  We’re frustrated and desperate  watching our beloved daughter progressively get thinner and weaker with no definitive diagnosis or cure in sight.  Conventional medicine has failed Daniela  and we’re convinced that our only hope for resolving her health issues is \functional medicine \" which seeks to identify and treat the root cause of diseases. It views the body as one integrated system  and not a collection of independent organs. It treats the whole system  and not just the symptoms.Unfortunately  her health insurance does not cover functional medicine  and we don’t have the resources needed to pay the high cost of tests  treatments  and nutrition that Daniela may require for an extended period of time. So we’re reaching out to all of you in hopes that you can help us place Dani under the care of a recognized specialist in functional medicine  focused on finding the source of her health problems and totally curing her... once and for all! A college freshman majoring in Psychology  Daniela is a beautiful  intelligent  life-loving young lady with many dreams and goals that she looks forward to achieving. But every day that passes without finding the cause of her condition is crucial. Please help Dani heal so she can have a brilliant  healthy and successful life! Any donation you can make will be greatly appreciated. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts… and God bless you!¡POR FAVOR AYUDEN A DANI A SANARSE!A lo largo de su vida  nuestra hija Daniela  de 19 años  ha padecido una variedad de problemas de salud recurrentes  tales como infecciones agudas de garganta  complicaciones renales  taquicardia  debilidad general y problemas digestivos; entre ellos  una gastritis crónica que le comenzó a los 6 años de edad y que la ha mandado al departamento de emergencia en muchas ocasiones. Desde pequeña  Dani ha estado bajo constante tratamiento médico para sus distintos padecimientos  pero nunca hemos recibido explicación alguna sobre el origen real de sus dolorosos problemas digestivos  ni de su frágil salud en general.   Ahora los problemas digestivos de Dani se han vuelto más severos que nunca  y le están afectando no solo el estómago sino también el colon y duodeno. El año pasado  ella perdió 17 libras en un plazo de tiempo alarmantemente corto  sin ninguna razón aparente. Desde entonces se ha sometido a numerosos exámenes médicos  cuyos resultados han sido negativos o inconcluyentes. Actualmente le están tratando sus síntomas  pero ninguno de sus médicos ha podido determinar la causa raíz de su enfermedad. Dani actualmente está 25 libras por debajo del peso mínimo normal que debería tener según su edad y estatura  y sigue adelgazando cada semana  a pesar de alimentarse muy bien con una dieta balanceada y nutritiva.  Estamos frustrados y desesperados  viendo a nuestra amada hija perder peso y debilitarse progresivamente  sin un diagnóstico definitivo ni una cura a la vista. La medicina convencional le ha fallado a Daniela  y estamos convencidos de que nuestra única esperanza para resolver sus problemas de salud es la \"medicina funcional\"  la cual se concentra en descubrir y tratar la causa raíz de las enfermedades. Ve el cuerpo como un sistema integrado  y no una colección de órganos independientes. Trata todo el sistema  y no sólo los síntomas. Pero su seguro de salud no cubre la medicina funcional  y nosotros no tenemos los recursos económicos necesarios para cubrir los altos costos de exámenes  tratamientos y nutrición que Daniela pudiera necesitar por un tiempo prolongado. Por eso estamos acudiendo a ustedes para pedirles que nos ayuden a poner a Dani bajo el cuidado de un reconocido especialista en medicina funcional  dedicado a encontrar el origen de sus padecimientos y así poder curarla totalmente... ¡de una vez por todas! Estudiante de Sicología en su primer año de universidad  Daniela es una chica linda  inteligente y amante de la vida  con grandes sueños y metas que desea cumplir. Pero cada día que pasa sin encontrarse la causa de su enfermedad es crucial.  Por favor ayuden a Dani a sanarse para que pueda vivir una vida brillante  exitosa y sana! Cualquier cantidad que puedan donar será muy agradecida. Gracias de todo corazón… ¡y que Dios los bendiga!"

As many of you know Barry McDonald has recently been very sick and in the hospital for several months  due to an undetermined illness. He was transferred out of Mary Washington Hospital to VCU in Richmond last night to get a better determination of what is going on. Barry has always been a very hard worker trying to support his family and get his daughters through college and an upcoming wedding. He was a firefighter for Spotsylvania County for several years and on the Virginia Defense Force for 7 years as Sargent. He also coached and managed softball for East Orange Little League. He has been an auto body technician for over 25 years.  Barry is the type of person that would do anything he could to help someone and now it is our turn to help him and his family. Due to being hospitalized his health insurance has been hard to keep up with and paid as well as the rest of his bills.  His wife has had to take time off from work for all the procedures and now has to travel almost an hour to the hospital he has been transferred to. All donations will go to Barry and his family to help get them through this difficult time. Everyone that knows Barry  knows he would never ask for anything and that is why we have made this Go Fund Me Page to show our support to him and his family. Thank you so much. Every little bit helps.

storyTitle: Deanna’s Journey Advanced Stage Ovarian Cancer
story: The purpose of this page is to raise money for our beloved Deanna  who is battling advanced stage ovarian cancer.  Deanna is a young mother of 3 girls.  She and her husband  Marc  anticipate high out of pocket expenses not covered by health insurance.Please read the following note from Deanna.  Thank you for your prayers and support.For those who may not know  I was diagnosed with advanced stage ovarian cancer on Wednesday  February 13th.  My world was turned upside down that night.  I have fallen apart many times  but am always put back together by the overwhelming love of Christ shown through His healing word and through my family and friends.  I have seen God's hand at work throughout this process and feel extremely blessed to be able to share how He is working through this.  I feel like God is allowing me to go through this struggle for some greater purpose and I will not stop listening for His call.  I will not stop searching for the silver lining.Many of you already know how God worked opened up appointments in record time with Dana Farber and Beth Israel.  One receptionist even said to me  \Someone's in your corner \" to which I had to respond  \"God is in control!\"  She then told me she was tearing up.  (Thought - Maybe He just used me to speak into someone else's life...what a great feeling.)Let me back track to Wednesday  FEB 13th - I was in my car on the highway crying  on my way to my MRI at Newton-Wellesley.  I just knew it wouldn't be good news.  God gave me a divine appointment.  He placed me behind a jeep with a tire on the rear.  The tire cover had an eagle on it staring right at me.  I was behind it for a while.  God spoke to me through that eagle and reminded me that HE is STRONG and MIGHTY  I am strong because HIS spirit lives in me  and HE will carry me On Eagle's Wings (a song I grew up singing in the Catholic church - very dear to my heart)  He reminded me of His word:Isaiah 40:31 English Standard Version (ESV)31 but they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength;    they shall mount up with wings like eagles;they shall run and not be weary;    they shall walk and not faint.I can't explain how loved I felt at that moment  that God would speak to me in that way.  HE cares for me and will carry me through this.  I believe most of you know that at the end of the day of appointments last Friday I did find out that the cancer had not spread to my lungs.  So that was a huge sigh of relief.  That means that I can proceed with surgery first  which supposedly (hopefully) has a better long term outcome.  I LOVED Dr. Awtrey at Beth Israel who comforted us and gave us a sense of hope.  He called me later that night to tell me he reviewed all of my scans and told me he can get everything out.  Sigh of relief!  He proceeded to tell me everything that he would be taking out of my body - and that turned my stomach.  He said he could get me in for surgery on Tuesday  Feb. 19th.  I was in shock at how fast that seemed.  He sensed that in me and calmly offered for me to have a 3rd opinion with his buddy at MGH.  He told me it was safe to wait another week and so he set me up to see Dr. Eisenhauer at MGH this past Thursday.  He felt I would be more comfortable having a 3rd opinion to break the tie.  So ...that was last Friday. Since my mom got cancer 9 years ago I have been studying alternative cancer therapies so I knew that I had to explore this route for myself to make a well rounded decision on a treatment plan.  I left a voicemail with a Naturopathic Oncologist in NH on Sunday night.  I did not expect to be able to see him but at least wanted to have a conversation and opinion over the phone.  Monday morning (President's Day)  my phone rings as I am getting out of the shower.  It was his office asking me if I could be there in 2 hours...the lady with the 12:00appointment called and cancelled because of the flu.  They usually book out 6-8weeks.  HOLY DIVINE APPOINTMENT!  We are 1 1/2 hours from his office.  We booked it!  I now have him on my team to work alongside my conventional team to give my body the best fighting change to overcome this cancer.  I started taking supplements on Tuesday and restricting my diet to inhibit the growth and spread of the cancer.  It's not easy.  I'm weak and tired from all the stress.Moving on to our 3rd opinion - scheduled for Thursday at noon.  I had to stop by Beth Israel to pick up my chest CT scan to bring over to MGH.  Marc had prayed earlier that morning and asked God to just let us hear something or see something that would confirm for us the decision we felt He was leading us to make.  We were one block away from BI and got stuck at a red light partially into the intersection.  Cars started going around us...then the light switched for pedestrians to cross.  Of all the people in Boston crossing the street  who would you think crossed the street right smack in front of our car but Dr. Awtrey  the surgeon from BI.  I waved and said hi to him and we went on our way to our appointment at MGH.  That was another DIVINE APPOINTMENT. He put us both there at that moment in this big city.  It was clear to us that the Lord was leading us to Dr. Awtrey.  WE all felt it in our hearts.  Our meeting at MGH confirmed it as well.  He was encouraging  in agreement with Dr. Awtrey  and said he'd send his own family to him.  That's all I needed.MY surgery is scheduled for Thursday  FEB. 28th at Beth Israel with Dr. Chris Awtrey.  It's a big surgery.  When I wake up I will be in complete menopause.  There is so much I am afraid of  but I'm trying to rest in the peace of God.  Here's how you can pray for us:1.  That God would choose to heal me 2.  For the best choices to be made for hormone replacement therapy 3.  For a speedy recovery (I will be recovering at home about a month before starting chemo)4.  For my family who will be caring for me - for strength - comfort5.  For anything else my tired mind can't remember right now :)I thank God for all of you in my life - I count it joy to go through this struggle because I know there is a greater purpose - somewhere over the rainbow...With Love DeannaDo not grieve  for the joy of the Lord is your strength. Nehemiah 8:10"

Hello Friends  Family  and social media community.My name is April Combes  my husband is Sebastian  and we have a 3yr old son named Kannon. I'm a stay at home mom to our son which I feel so lucky to get to do so.Some of you may know that I have a very hard time seeing. Most of you probably don't know that I have a eye disease that I have been struggling with for half of my life. I was first diagnosed with KERATOCONUS in my late teens. Glasses can't correct my vision due to Keratoconus  and back then my only options were cornea transplants or (RGP) Rigid Gas Permeable lenses.In my early 20's I moved to South Lake Tahoe CA and needed to get a new drivers license. I was unable to pass the vision test for DMV. So I went to a eye doctor and  was diagnosed for a 2nd time. The doctor was in shock I was even able to drive to his office. I told him I needed to be able to pass a vision test to get a drivers license. He fitted me for RGP contact lenses that were so painful to wear  it felt like shards of glass were in my eyes. I was able to use them long enough to pass the vision test to get my CA drivers license. Since I was never able to get used to the RGP lenses  the doctor advised I stop wearing them and look into cornea transplants. The thought of transplants with a risk of not working and losing sight completely  Freaked me out! So i did nothing and have been struggling ever since. Fast forward to now and the time has come that I need to be able to see! Technology has advanced so much that now I have a option for non-invasive procedures that will stop my degenerative eye disease and correct my vision so that I can see clearly  basically for the 1st time in my life. I'll be 40yrs old in March and my drivers license expires and DMV is making me go in for a vision test. I will not be able to pass and continue to drive without getting my eyes fixed.So What Is Keratoconus?It's a progressive corneal eye disease  it thins the cornea and forms it into a cone-like shape. Keratoconus is a degenerative condition  left untreated can result in the cornea bulging out so far the back layer of the cornea can rip open and the internal eye liquid rushes in and swells up the cornea. It will take 3-6 months of non-usable vision until fluid goes away. The cornea then will have a lot of new scarring and vision will be permanently worse. Also left untreated can result in only option being a painful invasive cornea transplant surgery.Some symptoms are:  Blurred & Double vision/ Sensitivity to light/ Glares & Halos/ Progressive nearsightedness/ Poor night visionI need 2 procedures done on both of my eyes. The 1st is called Holcomb C3-R Crosslinking  which will stabilize the Keratoconus from getting worse. It has a 99.3% success rate. The 2nd procedure is call Intacs. Intacs are tiny  clear  semi-circle inserts which will be placed in the peripheral layer of the cornea. Intacs reshape the curvature of the cornea from within. The cornea flattens which helps achieve more clear vision  less distortion  glares  double vision  and improved night vision. We'll have travel expenses as well due to we will have to travel to Southern California for a 3 day visit with the Ophthalmologist.Unfortunately this life changing procedure isn't FDA approved  which means health insurance doesn't cover it. So this is why we are putting our pride to the side and reaching out for helping hands to assist us with financial help. Its very scary to think in order for me to halt the progression of my eye disease and truly see how beautiful the world is for the 1st time  we'll have to go into financial debt.Thank you for taking the time to read my story and any amount is helpful and greatly appreciated!Much Love April  Sebastian & KannonThe Combes Family

\We don't know how strong we are until being strong is the only choice we have.\"In October my family received the heartbreaking news that my non-smoker mom  Renee Brose  was diagnosed with inoperable Stage 3B Non-Small Cell ROS1 Positive Lung Cancer. Various tests and scans confirm that the cancer has spread from Renee's lungs to her lymph nodes within the upper chest as well as lymph nodes near the collar bone  neck  and armpit. Fortunately  there is no sign of cancer on her major organs or brain. A rare ROS1 gene mutation (found in 1-2% of lung cancer patients) was identified meaning Renee will receive targeted treatment. On the down side  she still has to fight cancer. Not only is it a physical and mental battle  but it's a financial one as well. Lung cancer is still one of the most expensive cancers to treat. Even with good health insurance  treatments like chemotherapy and immunotherapy come with financial concern and unexpected costs. Our family would like to be financially prepared for medical expenses to help us focus on increasing and maintaining Renee's quality of life while fighting the war against lung cancer.Please donate today to help Renee!BACKGROUNDRenee  remarried for 23 years  mother of two and grandmother of one  worked in sales and marketing for years and decided to change careers and work with adults with disabilities. As a program coordinator in charge of 20 staff members and 60 participants  her goal is to empower persons with developmental disabilities to achieve greater self-sufficiency and lead richer lives. In mid-September Renee felt two bumps on her collar bone and thought they might go away. They didn't. In early-October she went in for a biopsy and received the news that she had lung cancer which had spread to her lymph nodes. Being a non-smoker  the news was a complete shock to us all. Even though there is a long road ahead  Renee is filled with great optimism and strength and is supported by many during this time.DIAGNOSIS: SCANS AND TESTSRenee had a biopsy  blood work  PET scan  MRI scan  genomic test  confirmatory FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) test  and EKG done before starting treatment.TREATMENTRenee will be on a ROS1 targeted treatment called Xalkori (crizotinib)  a chemotherapy pill.CURRENT CONDITIONRenee is fortunately healthy enough to walk  breathe  and function without too much pain. She has made the decision to continue going to work when she can and live the life she wants to live while being treated.“To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist  that is all.” -Oscar Wilde.LUNG CANCER FACTS-Lung cancer kills more people than breast  colon  and prostate cancers combined.-Lung cancer receives the least amount of federal research funding. 6% of federal research dollars spent on cancer research  are spent on lung cancer.-641 people will be diagnosed each day.-27 people will be diagnosed each hour.-Every 2 ½ minutes someone in the U.S. is told that he or she has lung cancer.-Smoking isn’t the only cause of lung cancer. Other known causes include exposure to secondhand smoke  air pollution  radon  and asbestos.-Major prospective studies support the relationship between particle pollution and lung cancer.Please donate today! Thank you for all the love  support  and donations!"

Our friend Mel is an incredible soul. She’s one of the funniest  smartest people I know. She has dedicated her life to helping others by becoming a nurse. Mel was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor. This is not her first time down this road. As a teenager  Mel survived an aggressive tumor requiring radiation and surgery and a melanoma a few years ago. Despite this  Mel is still her funny  weird  upbeat self and powering through this.Mel and her care team are optimistic about her prognosis  but her path to healing will be a long and arduous one.  The doctors believe the tumor is benign  but the only way to know is to have the surgery. Treatment involves brain surgery to remove the tumor. Her skull will have to be reconstructed and she'll spend several days in the Neurological ICU before being able to go home. Surgery is just the beginning of a long road to healing. She won’t be able to drive/bike or be left alone for several weeks after the procedure. This is going to be really tough because Mel is active and busy and constantly on the go. She is also fiercely independent and is usually the one taking care of other people. She’s not used to asking for help  but she needs it so we are circling the wagons and asking for your help and support. Although Mel has health insurance  it won’t cover all her medical expenses. We’re raising these funds to help Mel cover additional expenses outside of surgery and supplement her income as she goes through surgery and recovery.Please help in any way that you can. Any amount will be a tremendous gift during this time. If you can’t donate  please share with your network and those who know and love Mely. She will also be in need of rides and company during her recovery.Here's Mel in her own words:“Family/Friends I apologize if I haven’t reached out to you directly  but this process has been logistically  physically  mentally  and emotionally exhausting.I was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor. I am sure many of you  like myself  have a multitude of questions. Much at this point is unknown  and it is likely the answers to many questions will remain unknown until I complete the healing process. I do know that this type of brain tumor is usually benign (non-cancerous) and that imaging shows no additional tumors in my brain stem or spine.  Based on my symptoms my tumor removal is non-emergent  but the tumor is sizable so the longer I wait the larger it grows  the older I get the harder my recovery  and the greater I run the risk of developing more serious symptoms. Treatment is a frontotemporal craniotomy for total tumor resection. This involves removing a portion of my skull to cut out the tumor. My skull will then be reconstructed (I do not know what that entails). Due to vascular involvement  I MAY have an additional neurovascular procedure (this will require meeting with another surgeon). I will spend several days in the Neurological Intensive Care Unit before being discharged home. I will not be able to drive/bike or be left alone for several weeks due to potential complications related to my procedure.I am sure some of you have additional questions and/or will want to reach out to me. I ask that you refrain from asking me specifics about my tumor or my surgery. While I feel the love in these questions  answering them repeatedly puts my illness at the forefront of my mind and inhibits my ability to focus on the more positive aspects of my life. It is also disheartening to continuously be asked questions I do not have the answers to. If you would like to reach out to see how I am doing  I ask that you e-mail me  as many texts (while sent with the best intentions) can be daunting. Despite this unfortunate diagnosis  I am my usual goofy self. It’s going to take a lot more than a brain tumor to derail this happy train!For my birthday I am hoping you could help me raise money to pay for my medical expenses. For those of you who cannot give money  the gift of your time is appreciated when I need company during the recovery process. Additionally  if anyone knows any brain tumor survivors I could speak with I would be grateful if you could connect us.With love and gratitude Mel\THANK YOU FOR YOUR DONATION"

storyTitle: Sufri un Infarto y necesito su ayuda
story: Hola! Mi nombre es Tomás. Soy un productor audiovisual de 48 años de Caracas  Venezuela. Hace aproximadamente un mes y medio sufrí un ataque al corazón y me encontré en un estado crítico. La situación económica en mi país (Venezuela) me hizo imposible cubrir los costos relacionados con el tratamiento de emergencia que tuve que someterme. No tenía más remedio que confiar en amigos y familiares para cubrir estos costos médicos.¿Cómo comenzó todo?Sentí dolor de pecho agudo el pasado 21 de noviembre mientras caminaba desde el campus de la universidad hasta la estación de metro. Había empezado a sentirme mal mientras estaba sentado en clase escuchando detonaciones y represión estatal contra la manifestación de estudiantes fuera del edificio de la universidad. Decidí irme a casa cuando me di cuenta de que me sentía mal. A pesar del dolor  logré continuar mi camino a casa usando el transporte público  luchando para no desmayarme. Ya me había desmayado brevemente en el metro unos días antes  lo cual fue particularmente aterrador dada la falta de seguridad en Venezuela (temía que me robaran o me dejaran sin ningún tipo de apoyo de emergencia. Afortunadamente  logré llegar a casa ese día.Los síntomas empeoraron. Mi esposa y yo decidimos que tenía que obtener atención primaria a través del seguro privado que tengo  solo para poder revisarme. Los paramédicos determinaron que tenía que ir a una clínica (no cubierta por el seguro) para realizar todas las pruebas (por ejemplo  ECG) necesarias para verificar si estaba pasando por un ataque cardíaco o no. Efectivamente  tan pronto como me conecté a la máquina de ECG de la clínica  el equipo de emergencia confirmó que estaba sufriendo un ataque al corazón. ¿Qué hay que hacer? Un cateterismo cardíaco y la colocación de una endoprótesis en mi corazón para abrir la obstrucción de la arteria coronaria.¿Cuáles fueron los costos?Como usted bien sabe  Venezuela está pasando por una de las peores hiperinflaciones de la región y del mundo (la inflación ha superado el 1 millón por ciento anual). Por esa razón  mi seguro de salud se ha convertido en algo insignificante. ¡Cubre menos de un dólar! Sin embargo  el costo total de mi estadía y tratamiento en el hospital costó $ 6 500  que tuvimos que pedir prestados a familiares y amigos. Les estoy profundamente agradecido por su generosidad y ahora tengo que pagarles por su apoyo en un momento tan difícil. Además  tengo que adquirir un seguro de salud en dólares a partir de ahora. En este momento  la cobertura de salud que necesito tiene un valor de 500 US $.Actualmente estoy en la fase de recuperación. Estoy asistiendo a chequeos médicos y haciendo diferentes exámenes.Como productor audiovisual mi trabajo no garantiza un salario mensual estable. Lo que gano por proyecto no es suficiente para cubrir mi deuda o adquirir la cobertura de salud adecuada. Por eso decidí apelar a la buena fe de esta gran comunidad para pagar mi deuda y adquirir un seguro de salud basado en el dólar. La ayuda total que busco es de 7.000 US $.Sé que muchas personas lo apoyan  pero no pueden ayudarlo financieramente  hay muchos venezolanos que atraviesan tiempos difíciles  por lo que les pido que me ayuden a difundir esta campaña lo más lejos posible. Cada poquito ayuda.Dios los bendiga a todos Tomás GodoyP.S: Esta campaña es administrada por mi Amiga  María Alejandra Morillo  quien recibirá los fondos en mi nombre  ya que no tengo una cuenta en el extranjero.Hi! My name is Tomás. I am a 48 years old audiovisual producer from Caracas  Venezuela. About a month and a half ago I suffered a heart attack and found myself in a critical state. The economic situation in my country (Venezuela) made it impossible for me to cover the costs involved in dealing with the emergency treatment I had to undergo.  I had no option but to rely on friends and relatives in order to cover these medical costs. How did it all begin?            I felt acute chest pain last November 21 while walking from the university campus to the subway station. I had begun to feel ill while sitting in class listening to detonations and state repression against student's demonstration outside the university building. I decided to go home when I realized I was feeling unwell.  Despite the pain  I managed to continue my way home using public transport  struggling not to faint. I had already fainted briefly in the subway a few days before  which was particularly scary given the lack of security in Venezuela (I feared being robbed or left without any emergency support. Fortunately  I managed to get home that day. Symptoms worsened. My wife and I decided that I had to get primary care through the private insurance I have  just so I could be checked. Paramedics determined that I had to go to a clinic (not covered by insurance) to do all tests (e.g. ECG) required in order to check whether or not I was going through a heart attack. Sure enough  as soon as I was connected to the Clinic's ECG machine the emergency team confirmed I was going through a heart attack. What needed to be done? a cardiac catheterization and placement of a stend in my heart in order to open the obstruction of the Coronary artery.What were the costs?            As you may well know  Venezuela is currently going through one of the worst hyperinflations of the region and the world (inflation has surpassed 1 million percent annually). For that reason  my health insurance has become rather insignificant. It covers less than a dollar! However  the total cost of my stay and treatment in the hospital cost 6 500 US$  which we had to borrow from family and friends. I am deeply thankful to them for their generosity and now have to pay them back for their support during such a difficult time. In addition  I need to acquire a dollar-denominated health insurance from now on. At the moment the health coverage I require is worth 500 US$. I am currently in the recovery phase. I am attending medical checkups and doing different tests. As an audiovisual producer my work does not guarantee a stable monthly salary. What I earn per project is not enough to cover my debt or acquire appropriate health coverage. That is why I decided to appeal to the good faith of this great community in order to pay my debt and acquire a dollar-based health insurance. The total help I seek is 7 000 US$I know many people are supportive but cannot help financially  there are many Venezuelans going through tough times so I ask you help me spread this campaign as far and wide as possible. Every little bit helps.God bless you all             Tomás

storyTitle: Help  Roger Bailey Kick Cancer's Ass
story: Reaching out to our family  friends and anyone else that would like to help Roger kick cancer's ass  I ask you to help him  by donating. Any amount you can give would help and be extremely appreciated. On October 15  2018 my brother Roger Bailey was diagnosed with stage II  bladder cancer. At this time he is waiting for the bone scan & ct chest scan to be done so they can make sure that the cancer has not spread. After that he  will start chemo and other procedures depending on the results of the tests. At this time he is out of work and his disability insurance has not started yet so the bills are piling up and his medications are very expensive. His health insurance has a very high deductible and he has to pay $12000 out of pocket per year before insurance will start paying their share  even then not all of his prescriptions  will be covered. I am trying to raise $30000 to cover this year's and next year's deductibles and help to cover the cost of medication. Roger has helped his family and friends whenever needed. He is a great son  brother  father  grandfather  uncle and friend. He is very grateful to have a strong emotional support system but cancer comes with unforeseen expenses and hardships that I would like to help him cope with.Roger is not the type to ask others for help but I would like to make sure he has the financial support and resources to fight this. I want  to make the medical costs and financial burdens less of a concern for him   since this should not be what he is worrying about now.Please  any donation no matter how small will help. It would also help if you could share this page on facebook or twitter.  Thank you. I will be posting regular updates and let everyone  know how things are going as we get more information.Please note- on the donation page  there is a section in which you can make a donation to GoFundMe. The default setting is 15%. You can change the percentage or click \other\" and type in a dollar amount. These donations go to GoFundMe  not to Roger's campaign.*"

storyTitle: Lets help Elaine become a breast cancer Survivor!
story: In October of 2018  Elaine Faye was diagnosed with breast cancer  specifically invasive ductal carcinoma stage two that has spread to her lymph nodes.  She currently has very limited health insurance.  For those that know Elaine personally  you've undoubtedly been witness to her incredible work ethic  creative vision  kind heart  patience  generosity  talent and humor.  For the fans that have enjoyed her music  attended her shows and soundtracked their lives with her music  she's undoubtedly made a mark on your life as well.  Elaine doesn't have a father in her life.  Her mother passed away when she was 14.   The loving aunt that helped raise her left this world long ago.  What Elaine DOES have is all of us -- her community.  This is a call to YOU for support of Elaine during this difficult time.  She's been a true friend to many of us  has been an example of what it is to live bravely and passionately and to choose her one true love  music  whole-heartedly over the years.  I admire my best friend for all that she is and all that she continues to be.  I've watched her transform before my very eyes the past few months since being diagnosed.  Cancer has taught her about self-care  about love  about patience and openness and compassion.  It's shone a light on new passions and possibilities for her future.  But to get to the other side  where health  vitality and a grander life is possible  she needs our help to get through this difficult time.  So here's the deal...Since being diagnosed  Elaine has been working long  late hours as a bartender and spending her free time driving for Uber to pay for her medical bills.  Just imagine that for a second.  Imagine your whole life being turned upside down by cancer  having no supportive parents to fall back on and working weird hours each day so you can afford the treatment necessary to heal.   I can tell you from first-hand experience that her total treatment regimen daily is taking about 8 hours of each day  if not more.  She's no longer capable of doing this all on her own. Elaine has a long road to recovery and at the moment  she can't can't even afford additional testing to see if the cancer has progressed (or regressed!) and where it is in her body.  Please share this GoFundMe with every friend  family member  business partner  acquaintance  etc.  Tell them the story of who Elaine is to you and how she has impacted your life.  Let's support her financially so she can get through this time with peace-of-mind.  Love in action.  That's the motto here.  Thank you for loving my friend and donating to this cause.  Jaden LaRueA message from Elaine...

Margaret Whorton-Folsom (goes by Peggy); she is an employee of Aging Resources of Central Iowa. She has a commercial policy. It appears that United policies for larger groups do have this coverage but Aging Resources has only 17 employees.She has stage IV stomach cancer. Right after she was diagnosed in June  she had a scan that showed the inoperable tumor took up her whole stomach. She had been unable to eat due to this and had dropped to 102 lbs. A J-tube (into the jejunum) was placed for the nutrition. She has done very well with it and now weighs 121; her usual weight is 125-130. She's been having chemo too  of course. The nutrition comes in 8 oz cartons and Peggy uses 5 a day. It goes into a bag that's attached to the tube. Peggy had been ordering this on a monthly basis. Every statement says \patient responsibility $0.00.\" When she went to reorder on Dec. 28  she was told that the charge was $2100/month and she owed for back charges of over $12 000. (They later said they could charge her $600/month.) When Peggy was trying to pursue what had happened she was told that \"food\" was not covered  and the nutrition is \"food.\" We understand that Wellmark  Medicare  Medicaid  and the United Community Plan all cover the liquid nutrition. It should be covered. It's necessary for life. Legislation is needed requiring health insurance companies to cover medically necessary nutrition. Peggy's family and spouse Beth are in need of assistance to catch up on these bills that were placed in their lap. Their family realizes that these bills wont stop anytime soon but anything is helpful.Please help donate to help their family. If you can't donate please pass on this campaign and shed light onto their situation. Thanks!"

PLEASE HELP DANI HEAL!Throughout her life  our 19 year-old daughter Daniela has suffered from a variety of recurring health issues such as acute throat infections  renal complications  tachycardia  general weakness and digestive problems  principally chronic gastritis that began at age 6 and has landed her in the emergency room on many occasions. Since childhood Dani has been under constant medical care for her diverse ailments  yet we have never received an explanation about the true origin of her painful digestive problems and overall delicate health. Now Dani’s digestive tract issues have become more severe than ever  seriously affecting not only her stomach but also her colon and duodenum. Last year she lost 17 pounds in an alarmingly short time  without any apparent reason. Since then she has undergone a battery of medical tests  but all results have come back either negative or inconclusive. Her symptoms are presently being treated  but none of her doctors has been able to determine the root cause of her illness. Dani is currently 25 pounds below the minimum normal weight for her age and height  and continues to lose weight on a weekly basis  despite regularly eating a balanced and nourishing diet.  We’re frustrated and desperate  watching our beloved daughter progressively get thinner and weaker with no definitive diagnosis or cure in sight.  Conventional medicine has failed Daniela  and we’re convinced that our only hope for resolving her health issues is \functional medicine \" which seeks to identify and treat the root cause of diseases. It views the body as one integrated system  and not a collection of independent organs. It treats the whole system  and not just the symptoms.Unfortunately  her health insurance does not cover functional medicine  and we don’t have the resources needed to pay the high cost of tests  treatments  and nutrition that Daniela may require for an extended period of time. So we’re reaching out to all of you in hopes that you can help us place Dani under the care of a recognized specialist in functional medicine  focused on finding the source of her health problems and totally curing her... once and for all! A college freshman majoring in Psychology  Daniela is a beautiful  intelligent  life-loving young lady with many dreams and goals that she looks forward to achieving. But every day that passes without finding the cause of her condition is crucial. Please help Dani heal so she can have a brilliant  healthy and successful life! Any donation you can make will be greatly appreciated. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts… and God bless you!¡POR FAVOR AYUDEN A DANI A SANARSE!A lo largo de su vida  nuestra hija Daniela  de 19 años  ha padecido una variedad de problemas de salud recurrentes  tales como infecciones agudas de garganta  complicaciones renales  taquicardia  debilidad general y problemas digestivos; entre ellos  una gastritis crónica que le comenzó a los 6 años de edad y que la ha mandado al departamento de emergencia en muchas ocasiones. Desde pequeña  Dani ha estado bajo constante tratamiento médico para sus distintos padecimientos  pero nunca hemos recibido explicación alguna sobre el origen real de sus dolorosos problemas digestivos  ni de su frágil salud en general.   Ahora los problemas digestivos de Dani se han vuelto más severos que nunca  y le están afectando no solo el estómago sino también el colon y duodeno. El año pasado  ella perdió 17 libras en un plazo de tiempo alarmantemente corto  sin ninguna razón aparente. Desde entonces se ha sometido a numerosos exámenes médicos  cuyos resultados han sido negativos o inconcluyentes. Actualmente le están tratando sus síntomas  pero ninguno de sus médicos ha podido determinar la causa raíz de su enfermedad. Dani actualmente está 25 libras por debajo del peso mínimo normal que debería tener según su edad y estatura  y sigue adelgazando cada semana  a pesar de alimentarse muy bien con una dieta balanceada y nutritiva.  Estamos frustrados y desesperados  viendo a nuestra amada hija perder peso y debilitarse progresivamente  sin un diagnóstico definitivo ni una cura a la vista. La medicina convencional le ha fallado a Daniela  y estamos convencidos de que nuestra única esperanza para resolver sus problemas de salud es la \"medicina funcional\"  la cual se concentra en descubrir y tratar la causa raíz de las enfermedades. Ve el cuerpo como un sistema integrado  y no una colección de órganos independientes. Trata todo el sistema  y no sólo los síntomas. Pero su seguro de salud no cubre la medicina funcional  y nosotros no tenemos los recursos económicos necesarios para cubrir los altos costos de exámenes  tratamientos y nutrición que Daniela pudiera necesitar por un tiempo prolongado. Por eso estamos acudiendo a ustedes para pedirles que nos ayuden a poner a Dani bajo el cuidado de un reconocido especialista en medicina funcional  dedicado a encontrar el origen de sus padecimientos y así poder curarla totalmente... ¡de una vez por todas! Estudiante de Sicología en su primer año de universidad  Daniela es una chica linda  inteligente y amante de la vida  con grandes sueños y metas que desea cumplir. Pero cada día que pasa sin encontrarse la causa de su enfermedad es crucial.  Por favor ayuden a Dani a sanarse para que pueda vivir una vida brillante  exitosa y sana! Cualquier cantidad que puedan donar será muy agradecida. Gracias de todo corazón… ¡y que Dios los bendiga!"

As many of you know Barry McDonald has recently been very sick and in the hospital for several months  due to an undetermined illness. He was transferred out of Mary Washington Hospital to VCU in Richmond last night to get a better determination of what is going on. Barry has always been a very hard worker trying to support his family and get his daughters through college and an upcoming wedding. He was a firefighter for Spotsylvania County for several years and on the Virginia Defense Force for 7 years as Sargent. He also coached and managed softball for East Orange Little League. He has been an auto body technician for over 25 years.  Barry is the type of person that would do anything he could to help someone and now it is our turn to help him and his family. Due to being hospitalized his health insurance has been hard to keep up with and paid as well as the rest of his bills.  His wife has had to take time off from work for all the procedures and now has to travel almost an hour to the hospital he has been transferred to. All donations will go to Barry and his family to help get them through this difficult time. Everyone that knows Barry  knows he would never ask for anything and that is why we have made this Go Fund Me Page to show our support to him and his family. Thank you so much. Every little bit helps.

storyTitle: Deanna’s Journey Advanced Stage Ovarian Cancer
story: The purpose of this page is to raise money for our beloved Deanna  who is battling advanced stage ovarian cancer.  Deanna is a young mother of 3 girls.  She and her husband  Marc  anticipate high out of pocket expenses not covered by health insurance.Please read the following note from Deanna.  Thank you for your prayers and support.For those who may not know  I was diagnosed with advanced stage ovarian cancer on Wednesday  February 13th.  My world was turned upside down that night.  I have fallen apart many times  but am always put back together by the overwhelming love of Christ shown through His healing word and through my family and friends.  I have seen God's hand at work throughout this process and feel extremely blessed to be able to share how He is working through this.  I feel like God is allowing me to go through this struggle for some greater purpose and I will not stop listening for His call.  I will not stop searching for the silver lining.Many of you already know how God worked opened up appointments in record time with Dana Farber and Beth Israel.  One receptionist even said to me  \Someone's in your corner \" to which I had to respond  \"God is in control!\"  She then told me she was tearing up.  (Thought - Maybe He just used me to speak into someone else's life...what a great feeling.)Let me back track to Wednesday  FEB 13th - I was in my car on the highway crying  on my way to my MRI at Newton-Wellesley.  I just knew it wouldn't be good news.  God gave me a divine appointment.  He placed me behind a jeep with a tire on the rear.  The tire cover had an eagle on it staring right at me.  I was behind it for a while.  God spoke to me through that eagle and reminded me that HE is STRONG and MIGHTY  I am strong because HIS spirit lives in me  and HE will carry me On Eagle's Wings (a song I grew up singing in the Catholic church - very dear to my heart)  He reminded me of His word:Isaiah 40:31 English Standard Version (ESV)31 but they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength;    they shall mount up with wings like eagles;they shall run and not be weary;    they shall walk and not faint.I can't explain how loved I felt at that moment  that God would speak to me in that way.  HE cares for me and will carry me through this.  I believe most of you know that at the end of the day of appointments last Friday I did find out that the cancer had not spread to my lungs.  So that was a huge sigh of relief.  That means that I can proceed with surgery first  which supposedly (hopefully) has a better long term outcome.  I LOVED Dr. Awtrey at Beth Israel who comforted us and gave us a sense of hope.  He called me later that night to tell me he reviewed all of my scans and told me he can get everything out.  Sigh of relief!  He proceeded to tell me everything that he would be taking out of my body - and that turned my stomach.  He said he could get me in for surgery on Tuesday  Feb. 19th.  I was in shock at how fast that seemed.  He sensed that in me and calmly offered for me to have a 3rd opinion with his buddy at MGH.  He told me it was safe to wait another week and so he set me up to see Dr. Eisenhauer at MGH this past Thursday.  He felt I would be more comfortable having a 3rd opinion to break the tie.  So ...that was last Friday. Since my mom got cancer 9 years ago I have been studying alternative cancer therapies so I knew that I had to explore this route for myself to make a well rounded decision on a treatment plan.  I left a voicemail with a Naturopathic Oncologist in NH on Sunday night.  I did not expect to be able to see him but at least wanted to have a conversation and opinion over the phone.  Monday morning (President's Day)  my phone rings as I am getting out of the shower.  It was his office asking me if I could be there in 2 hours...the lady with the 12:00appointment called and cancelled because of the flu.  They usually book out 6-8weeks.  HOLY DIVINE APPOINTMENT!  We are 1 1/2 hours from his office.  We booked it!  I now have him on my team to work alongside my conventional team to give my body the best fighting change to overcome this cancer.  I started taking supplements on Tuesday and restricting my diet to inhibit the growth and spread of the cancer.  It's not easy.  I'm weak and tired from all the stress.Moving on to our 3rd opinion - scheduled for Thursday at noon.  I had to stop by Beth Israel to pick up my chest CT scan to bring over to MGH.  Marc had prayed earlier that morning and asked God to just let us hear something or see something that would confirm for us the decision we felt He was leading us to make.  We were one block away from BI and got stuck at a red light partially into the intersection.  Cars started going around us...then the light switched for pedestrians to cross.  Of all the people in Boston crossing the street  who would you think crossed the street right smack in front of our car but Dr. Awtrey  the surgeon from BI.  I waved and said hi to him and we went on our way to our appointment at MGH.  That was another DIVINE APPOINTMENT. He put us both there at that moment in this big city.  It was clear to us that the Lord was leading us to Dr. Awtrey.  WE all felt it in our hearts.  Our meeting at MGH confirmed it as well.  He was encouraging  in agreement with Dr. Awtrey  and said he'd send his own family to him.  That's all I needed.MY surgery is scheduled for Thursday  FEB. 28th at Beth Israel with Dr. Chris Awtrey.  It's a big surgery.  When I wake up I will be in complete menopause.  There is so much I am afraid of  but I'm trying to rest in the peace of God.  Here's how you can pray for us:1.  That God would choose to heal me 2.  For the best choices to be made for hormone replacement therapy 3.  For a speedy recovery (I will be recovering at home about a month before starting chemo)4.  For my family who will be caring for me - for strength - comfort5.  For anything else my tired mind can't remember right now :)I thank God for all of you in my life - I count it joy to go through this struggle because I know there is a greater purpose - somewhere over the rainbow...With Love DeannaDo not grieve  for the joy of the Lord is your strength. Nehemiah 8:10"

Hello Friends  Family  and social media community.My name is April Combes  my husband is Sebastian  and we have a 3yr old son named Kannon. I'm a stay at home mom to our son which I feel so lucky to get to do so.Some of you may know that I have a very hard time seeing. Most of you probably don't know that I have a eye disease that I have been struggling with for half of my life. I was first diagnosed with KERATOCONUS in my late teens. Glasses can't correct my vision due to Keratoconus  and back then my only options were cornea transplants or (RGP) Rigid Gas Permeable lenses.In my early 20's I moved to South Lake Tahoe CA and needed to get a new drivers license. I was unable to pass the vision test for DMV. So I went to a eye doctor and  was diagnosed for a 2nd time. The doctor was in shock I was even able to drive to his office. I told him I needed to be able to pass a vision test to get a drivers license. He fitted me for RGP contact lenses that were so painful to wear  it felt like shards of glass were in my eyes. I was able to use them long enough to pass the vision test to get my CA drivers license. Since I was never able to get used to the RGP lenses  the doctor advised I stop wearing them and look into cornea transplants. The thought of transplants with a risk of not working and losing sight completely  Freaked me out! So i did nothing and have been struggling ever since. Fast forward to now and the time has come that I need to be able to see! Technology has advanced so much that now I have a option for non-invasive procedures that will stop my degenerative eye disease and correct my vision so that I can see clearly  basically for the 1st time in my life. I'll be 40yrs old in March and my drivers license expires and DMV is making me go in for a vision test. I will not be able to pass and continue to drive without getting my eyes fixed.So What Is Keratoconus?It's a progressive corneal eye disease  it thins the cornea and forms it into a cone-like shape. Keratoconus is a degenerative condition  left untreated can result in the cornea bulging out so far the back layer of the cornea can rip open and the internal eye liquid rushes in and swells up the cornea. It will take 3-6 months of non-usable vision until fluid goes away. The cornea then will have a lot of new scarring and vision will be permanently worse. Also left untreated can result in only option being a painful invasive cornea transplant surgery.Some symptoms are:  Blurred & Double vision/ Sensitivity to light/ Glares & Halos/ Progressive nearsightedness/ Poor night visionI need 2 procedures done on both of my eyes. The 1st is called Holcomb C3-R Crosslinking  which will stabilize the Keratoconus from getting worse. It has a 99.3% success rate. The 2nd procedure is call Intacs. Intacs are tiny  clear  semi-circle inserts which will be placed in the peripheral layer of the cornea. Intacs reshape the curvature of the cornea from within. The cornea flattens which helps achieve more clear vision  less distortion  glares  double vision  and improved night vision. We'll have travel expenses as well due to we will have to travel to Southern California for a 3 day visit with the Ophthalmologist.Unfortunately this life changing procedure isn't FDA approved  which means health insurance doesn't cover it. So this is why we are putting our pride to the side and reaching out for helping hands to assist us with financial help. Its very scary to think in order for me to halt the progression of my eye disease and truly see how beautiful the world is for the 1st time  we'll have to go into financial debt.Thank you for taking the time to read my story and any amount is helpful and greatly appreciated!Much Love April  Sebastian & KannonThe Combes Family

\We don't know how strong we are until being strong is the only choice we have.\"In October my family received the heartbreaking news that my non-smoker mom  Renee Brose  was diagnosed with inoperable Stage 3B Non-Small Cell ROS1 Positive Lung Cancer. Various tests and scans confirm that the cancer has spread from Renee's lungs to her lymph nodes within the upper chest as well as lymph nodes near the collar bone  neck  and armpit. Fortunately  there is no sign of cancer on her major organs or brain. A rare ROS1 gene mutation (found in 1-2% of lung cancer patients) was identified meaning Renee will receive targeted treatment. On the down side  she still has to fight cancer. Not only is it a physical and mental battle  but it's a financial one as well. Lung cancer is still one of the most expensive cancers to treat. Even with good health insurance  treatments like chemotherapy and immunotherapy come with financial concern and unexpected costs. Our family would like to be financially prepared for medical expenses to help us focus on increasing and maintaining Renee's quality of life while fighting the war against lung cancer.Please donate today to help Renee!BACKGROUNDRenee  remarried for 23 years  mother of two and grandmother of one  worked in sales and marketing for years and decided to change careers and work with adults with disabilities. As a program coordinator in charge of 20 staff members and 60 participants  her goal is to empower persons with developmental disabilities to achieve greater self-sufficiency and lead richer lives. In mid-September Renee felt two bumps on her collar bone and thought they might go away. They didn't. In early-October she went in for a biopsy and received the news that she had lung cancer which had spread to her lymph nodes. Being a non-smoker  the news was a complete shock to us all. Even though there is a long road ahead  Renee is filled with great optimism and strength and is supported by many during this time.DIAGNOSIS: SCANS AND TESTSRenee had a biopsy  blood work  PET scan  MRI scan  genomic test  confirmatory FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) test  and EKG done before starting treatment.TREATMENTRenee will be on a ROS1 targeted treatment called Xalkori (crizotinib)  a chemotherapy pill.CURRENT CONDITIONRenee is fortunately healthy enough to walk  breathe  and function without too much pain. She has made the decision to continue going to work when she can and live the life she wants to live while being treated.“To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist  that is all.” -Oscar Wilde.LUNG CANCER FACTS-Lung cancer kills more people than breast  colon  and prostate cancers combined.-Lung cancer receives the least amount of federal research funding. 6% of federal research dollars spent on cancer research  are spent on lung cancer.-641 people will be diagnosed each day.-27 people will be diagnosed each hour.-Every 2 ½ minutes someone in the U.S. is told that he or she has lung cancer.-Smoking isn’t the only cause of lung cancer. Other known causes include exposure to secondhand smoke  air pollution  radon  and asbestos.-Major prospective studies support the relationship between particle pollution and lung cancer.Please donate today! Thank you for all the love  support  and donations!"

Our friend Mel is an incredible soul. She’s one of the funniest  smartest people I know. She has dedicated her life to helping others by becoming a nurse. Mel was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor. This is not her first time down this road. As a teenager  Mel survived an aggressive tumor requiring radiation and surgery and a melanoma a few years ago. Despite this  Mel is still her funny  weird  upbeat self and powering through this.Mel and her care team are optimistic about her prognosis  but her path to healing will be a long and arduous one.  The doctors believe the tumor is benign  but the only way to know is to have the surgery. Treatment involves brain surgery to remove the tumor. Her skull will have to be reconstructed and she'll spend several days in the Neurological ICU before being able to go home. Surgery is just the beginning of a long road to healing. She won’t be able to drive/bike or be left alone for several weeks after the procedure. This is going to be really tough because Mel is active and busy and constantly on the go. She is also fiercely independent and is usually the one taking care of other people. She’s not used to asking for help  but she needs it so we are circling the wagons and asking for your help and support. Although Mel has health insurance  it won’t cover all her medical expenses. We’re raising these funds to help Mel cover additional expenses outside of surgery and supplement her income as she goes through surgery and recovery.Please help in any way that you can. Any amount will be a tremendous gift during this time. If you can’t donate  please share with your network and those who know and love Mely. She will also be in need of rides and company during her recovery.Here's Mel in her own words:“Family/Friends I apologize if I haven’t reached out to you directly  but this process has been logistically  physically  mentally  and emotionally exhausting.I was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor. I am sure many of you  like myself  have a multitude of questions. Much at this point is unknown  and it is likely the answers to many questions will remain unknown until I complete the healing process. I do know that this type of brain tumor is usually benign (non-cancerous) and that imaging shows no additional tumors in my brain stem or spine.  Based on my symptoms my tumor removal is non-emergent  but the tumor is sizable so the longer I wait the larger it grows  the older I get the harder my recovery  and the greater I run the risk of developing more serious symptoms. Treatment is a frontotemporal craniotomy for total tumor resection. This involves removing a portion of my skull to cut out the tumor. My skull will then be reconstructed (I do not know what that entails). Due to vascular involvement  I MAY have an additional neurovascular procedure (this will require meeting with another surgeon). I will spend several days in the Neurological Intensive Care Unit before being discharged home. I will not be able to drive/bike or be left alone for several weeks due to potential complications related to my procedure.I am sure some of you have additional questions and/or will want to reach out to me. I ask that you refrain from asking me specifics about my tumor or my surgery. While I feel the love in these questions  answering them repeatedly puts my illness at the forefront of my mind and inhibits my ability to focus on the more positive aspects of my life. It is also disheartening to continuously be asked questions I do not have the answers to. If you would like to reach out to see how I am doing  I ask that you e-mail me  as many texts (while sent with the best intentions) can be daunting. Despite this unfortunate diagnosis  I am my usual goofy self. It’s going to take a lot more than a brain tumor to derail this happy train!For my birthday I am hoping you could help me raise money to pay for my medical expenses. For those of you who cannot give money  the gift of your time is appreciated when I need company during the recovery process. Additionally  if anyone knows any brain tumor survivors I could speak with I would be grateful if you could connect us.With love and gratitude Mel\THANK YOU FOR YOUR DONATION"

storyTitle: Sufri un Infarto y necesito su ayuda
story: Hola! Mi nombre es Tomás. Soy un productor audiovisual de 48 años de Caracas  Venezuela. Hace aproximadamente un mes y medio sufrí un ataque al corazón y me encontré en un estado crítico. La situación económica en mi país (Venezuela) me hizo imposible cubrir los costos relacionados con el tratamiento de emergencia que tuve que someterme. No tenía más remedio que confiar en amigos y familiares para cubrir estos costos médicos.¿Cómo comenzó todo?Sentí dolor de pecho agudo el pasado 21 de noviembre mientras caminaba desde el campus de la universidad hasta la estación de metro. Había empezado a sentirme mal mientras estaba sentado en clase escuchando detonaciones y represión estatal contra la manifestación de estudiantes fuera del edificio de la universidad. Decidí irme a casa cuando me di cuenta de que me sentía mal. A pesar del dolor  logré continuar mi camino a casa usando el transporte público  luchando para no desmayarme. Ya me había desmayado brevemente en el metro unos días antes  lo cual fue particularmente aterrador dada la falta de seguridad en Venezuela (temía que me robaran o me dejaran sin ningún tipo de apoyo de emergencia. Afortunadamente  logré llegar a casa ese día.Los síntomas empeoraron. Mi esposa y yo decidimos que tenía que obtener atención primaria a través del seguro privado que tengo  solo para poder revisarme. Los paramédicos determinaron que tenía que ir a una clínica (no cubierta por el seguro) para realizar todas las pruebas (por ejemplo  ECG) necesarias para verificar si estaba pasando por un ataque cardíaco o no. Efectivamente  tan pronto como me conecté a la máquina de ECG de la clínica  el equipo de emergencia confirmó que estaba sufriendo un ataque al corazón. ¿Qué hay que hacer? Un cateterismo cardíaco y la colocación de una endoprótesis en mi corazón para abrir la obstrucción de la arteria coronaria.¿Cuáles fueron los costos?Como usted bien sabe  Venezuela está pasando por una de las peores hiperinflaciones de la región y del mundo (la inflación ha superado el 1 millón por ciento anual). Por esa razón  mi seguro de salud se ha convertido en algo insignificante. ¡Cubre menos de un dólar! Sin embargo  el costo total de mi estadía y tratamiento en el hospital costó $ 6 500  que tuvimos que pedir prestados a familiares y amigos. Les estoy profundamente agradecido por su generosidad y ahora tengo que pagarles por su apoyo en un momento tan difícil. Además  tengo que adquirir un seguro de salud en dólares a partir de ahora. En este momento  la cobertura de salud que necesito tiene un valor de 500 US $.Actualmente estoy en la fase de recuperación. Estoy asistiendo a chequeos médicos y haciendo diferentes exámenes.Como productor audiovisual mi trabajo no garantiza un salario mensual estable. Lo que gano por proyecto no es suficiente para cubrir mi deuda o adquirir la cobertura de salud adecuada. Por eso decidí apelar a la buena fe de esta gran comunidad para pagar mi deuda y adquirir un seguro de salud basado en el dólar. La ayuda total que busco es de 7.000 US $.Sé que muchas personas lo apoyan  pero no pueden ayudarlo financieramente  hay muchos venezolanos que atraviesan tiempos difíciles  por lo que les pido que me ayuden a difundir esta campaña lo más lejos posible. Cada poquito ayuda.Dios los bendiga a todos Tomás GodoyP.S: Esta campaña es administrada por mi Amiga  María Alejandra Morillo  quien recibirá los fondos en mi nombre  ya que no tengo una cuenta en el extranjero.Hi! My name is Tomás. I am a 48 years old audiovisual producer from Caracas  Venezuela. About a month and a half ago I suffered a heart attack and found myself in a critical state. The economic situation in my country (Venezuela) made it impossible for me to cover the costs involved in dealing with the emergency treatment I had to undergo.  I had no option but to rely on friends and relatives in order to cover these medical costs. How did it all begin?            I felt acute chest pain last November 21 while walking from the university campus to the subway station. I had begun to feel ill while sitting in class listening to detonations and state repression against student's demonstration outside the university building. I decided to go home when I realized I was feeling unwell.  Despite the pain  I managed to continue my way home using public transport  struggling not to faint. I had already fainted briefly in the subway a few days before  which was particularly scary given the lack of security in Venezuela (I feared being robbed or left without any emergency support. Fortunately  I managed to get home that day. Symptoms worsened. My wife and I decided that I had to get primary care through the private insurance I have  just so I could be checked. Paramedics determined that I had to go to a clinic (not covered by insurance) to do all tests (e.g. ECG) required in order to check whether or not I was going through a heart attack. Sure enough  as soon as I was connected to the Clinic's ECG machine the emergency team confirmed I was going through a heart attack. What needed to be done? a cardiac catheterization and placement of a stend in my heart in order to open the obstruction of the Coronary artery.What were the costs?            As you may well know  Venezuela is currently going through one of the worst hyperinflations of the region and the world (inflation has surpassed 1 million percent annually). For that reason  my health insurance has become rather insignificant. It covers less than a dollar! However  the total cost of my stay and treatment in the hospital cost 6 500 US$  which we had to borrow from family and friends. I am deeply thankful to them for their generosity and now have to pay them back for their support during such a difficult time. In addition  I need to acquire a dollar-denominated health insurance from now on. At the moment the health coverage I require is worth 500 US$. I am currently in the recovery phase. I am attending medical checkups and doing different tests. As an audiovisual producer my work does not guarantee a stable monthly salary. What I earn per project is not enough to cover my debt or acquire appropriate health coverage. That is why I decided to appeal to the good faith of this great community in order to pay my debt and acquire a dollar-based health insurance. The total help I seek is 7 000 US$I know many people are supportive but cannot help financially  there are many Venezuelans going through tough times so I ask you help me spread this campaign as far and wide as possible. Every little bit helps.God bless you all             Tomás

storyTitle: Help  Roger Bailey Kick Cancer's Ass
story: Reaching out to our family  friends and anyone else that would like to help Roger kick cancer's ass  I ask you to help him  by donating. Any amount you can give would help and be extremely appreciated. On October 15  2018 my brother Roger Bailey was diagnosed with stage II  bladder cancer. At this time he is waiting for the bone scan & ct chest scan to be done so they can make sure that the cancer has not spread. After that he  will start chemo and other procedures depending on the results of the tests. At this time he is out of work and his disability insurance has not started yet so the bills are piling up and his medications are very expensive. His health insurance has a very high deductible and he has to pay $12000 out of pocket per year before insurance will start paying their share  even then not all of his prescriptions  will be covered. I am trying to raise $30000 to cover this year's and next year's deductibles and help to cover the cost of medication. Roger has helped his family and friends whenever needed. He is a great son  brother  father  grandfather  uncle and friend. He is very grateful to have a strong emotional support system but cancer comes with unforeseen expenses and hardships that I would like to help him cope with.Roger is not the type to ask others for help but I would like to make sure he has the financial support and resources to fight this. I want  to make the medical costs and financial burdens less of a concern for him   since this should not be what he is worrying about now.Please  any donation no matter how small will help. It would also help if you could share this page on facebook or twitter.  Thank you. I will be posting regular updates and let everyone  know how things are going as we get more information.Please note- on the donation page  there is a section in which you can make a donation to GoFundMe. The default setting is 15%. You can change the percentage or click \other\" and type in a dollar amount. These donations go to GoFundMe  not to Roger's campaign.*"

storyTitle: Lets help Elaine become a breast cancer Survivor!
story: In October of 2018  Elaine Faye was diagnosed with breast cancer  specifically invasive ductal carcinoma stage two that has spread to her lymph nodes.  She currently has very limited health insurance.  For those that know Elaine personally  you've undoubtedly been witness to her incredible work ethic  creative vision  kind heart  patience  generosity  talent and humor.  For the fans that have enjoyed her music  attended her shows and soundtracked their lives with her music  she's undoubtedly made a mark on your life as well.  Elaine doesn't have a father in her life.  Her mother passed away when she was 14.   The loving aunt that helped raise her left this world long ago.  What Elaine DOES have is all of us -- her community.  This is a call to YOU for support of Elaine during this difficult time.  She's been a true friend to many of us  has been an example of what it is to live bravely and passionately and to choose her one true love  music  whole-heartedly over the years.  I admire my best friend for all that she is and all that she continues to be.  I've watched her transform before my very eyes the past few months since being diagnosed.  Cancer has taught her about self-care  about love  about patience and openness and compassion.  It's shone a light on new passions and possibilities for her future.  But to get to the other side  where health  vitality and a grander life is possible  she needs our help to get through this difficult time.  So here's the deal...Since being diagnosed  Elaine has been working long  late hours as a bartender and spending her free time driving for Uber to pay for her medical bills.  Just imagine that for a second.  Imagine your whole life being turned upside down by cancer  having no supportive parents to fall back on and working weird hours each day so you can afford the treatment necessary to heal.   I can tell you from first-hand experience that her total treatment regimen daily is taking about 8 hours of each day  if not more.  She's no longer capable of doing this all on her own. Elaine has a long road to recovery and at the moment  she can't can't even afford additional testing to see if the cancer has progressed (or regressed!) and where it is in her body.  Please share this GoFundMe with every friend  family member  business partner  acquaintance  etc.  Tell them the story of who Elaine is to you and how she has impacted your life.  Let's support her financially so she can get through this time with peace-of-mind.  Love in action.  That's the motto here.  Thank you for loving my friend and donating to this cause.  Jaden LaRueA message from Elaine...

Margaret Whorton-Folsom (goes by Peggy); she is an employee of Aging Resources of Central Iowa. She has a commercial policy. It appears that United policies for larger groups do have this coverage but Aging Resources has only 17 employees.She has stage IV stomach cancer. Right after she was diagnosed in June  she had a scan that showed the inoperable tumor took up her whole stomach. She had been unable to eat due to this and had dropped to 102 lbs. A J-tube (into the jejunum) was placed for the nutrition. She has done very well with it and now weighs 121; her usual weight is 125-130. She's been having chemo too  of course. The nutrition comes in 8 oz cartons and Peggy uses 5 a day. It goes into a bag that's attached to the tube. Peggy had been ordering this on a monthly basis. Every statement says \patient responsibility $0.00.\" When she went to reorder on Dec. 28  she was told that the charge was $2100/month and she owed for back charges of over $12 000. (They later said they could charge her $600/month.) When Peggy was trying to pursue what had happened she was told that \"food\" was not covered  and the nutrition is \"food.\" We understand that Wellmark  Medicare  Medicaid  and the United Community Plan all cover the liquid nutrition. It should be covered. It's necessary for life. Legislation is needed requiring health insurance companies to cover medically necessary nutrition. Peggy's family and spouse Beth are in need of assistance to catch up on these bills that were placed in their lap. Their family realizes that these bills wont stop anytime soon but anything is helpful.Please help donate to help their family. If you can't donate please pass on this campaign and shed light onto their situation. Thanks!"

Shannon Adams has blessed the lives of so many for the last 33 years of her life. Her gentle spirit and ability to understand the needs of those around her has made her such an essential part of our world and community. Shannon’s strength  resilience  and sense of humor is beyond measure. And even though she would never ask for it  right now she needs our help.In late September Shannon was admitted to the hospital after dealing with constant nausea  vomiting  mysterious bruising and acute pain for weeks. They diagnosed her with a serious pyelo infection (severe infection in the kidneys) and aggressively treated her with IV antibiotics through a pic line.Once discharged  most of her symptoms continued even after the infection had cleared. The last few months have been filled with dozens upon dozens of tests  procedures  and medications.After further testing she has been diagnosed with a yet to be determined autoimmune disease  that is attacking her central nervous system. One of her most prominent symptoms has been her inability to eat solid foods and process protein. Doctors believe she has a motility disorder  where part of her stomach and/or intestines may be experiencing paralysis or nerve damage.With the hospital stay  on-going visits with specialists  weekly lab work  and constant testing the medical bills are mounting. Thankfully she has health insurance for the first time in years but even with that she currently owes $7000+ and she has not yet been fully diagnosed!Shannon is one of the best. She’s one of the most generous and selfless human beings to all of those around her. We want to help her break-through this struggle. All we can do is pray to see full healing in her body and give.Our wish is to see the mountain of stress she’s facing disappear and the most tangible way we see that happening is by having all of her medical bills covered.
