We want Shannon to focus completely on her health and healing and feel so taken care of  just as she has helped to make so many others around her feel.Shannon deserves answers in so many ways and we can be that solution in the area of finances. Let’s come together to solve this one worry in our girl’s heart and keep praying to see complete healing in Jesus name.

THE TRUTHI've never been a fan of online fundraising. Or  really  ANY fundraising.There  I said it.However  I understand its necessity and have supported several over the years. I NEVER thought I'd organize one for my family. It is a hard thing to decide to do. It is humbling. It requires swallowing your pride. It took a glaring-in-the-mirror pep talk. But here I am.THE REASONHeath  my husband of 22 yrs  has been diagnosed with melanoma. Yes  it's ONLY skin cancer (please  if you don't want a hysterical crazy-lady on your hands  don't say that to my face). It's a rapidly spreading  nasty cancer that can easily grow. Then easily infects other areas. Then can become other nasty cancers. His is very deep  very aggressive and located on his face.THE DOCTORSAt this point  Heath has seen a dermatologist  general surgeon and plastic surgeon.  A general surgery is scheduled for Dec 4 to remove a large section of tissue. Prior to surgery  a dye will be inserted into his lymph nodes in his neck to determine if the cancer has already spread to that area. The likelihood of this is estimated very high from the biopsy that has already been done. If there are infected lymph nodes  they will also be removed during surgery.      Best-case scenario: No infected lymph nodes. Only remove facial     tissue that is infected. Then follow with plastic surgery and recovery.     A predicable course of future follow up to remain cancer-free!     Scary-case scenario: Cancer has entered the lymphatic system.      Still follow with the plastic surgeon to repair his face but will also      require a follow up with an oncologist and likely radiation and/or      chemo treatments. Lots of unknown factors!I want to be very clear on a few points. 1) The plastic surgery is NOT optional. It is REQUIRED by the general surgeon. It is NOT cosmetic. It's necessary to maintain the ability to use his mouth and prevent drooping of his eye (see picture in the first comment posted).2) We do not know what the future holds. We only have the information we have been given and it can all change at any point. THE WHYMost of you likely know  we are self-employeed. Heath has had a photography studio for over 20 years. His passion. His dream. The only thing he has ever wanted to do. And he's good at it. REALLY good.  He loves capturing the most beautiful moments of people's lives so they can be cherished forever. However  as a result  he does not have health insurance. That usually isn't an issue because he's basically a healthy guy. Unfortunately  it IS an issue now. This is already expensive and we are only at the beginning. THE MONEY We want to be honest & upfront with how your money will be used if you decide to help us out. A payment of $1 500 is required prior to the general surgery. That means  IMMEDIATELY. The remainder is put on a payment plan. There will be another fee for the pastic surgery which should follow approximately 5 days after the first.  Then for the next year there are required follow up office visits with all three doctors mentioned. Currently  we estimate the medical expenses at an initial $10 000 for the BEST CASE SCENARIO. Here's a current breakdown:$215        Initial dermatologist consult & biopsy$125        Initial surgeon consult$110        Initial plastic surgeon consult$2700     General surgery estimated charges$3000     Plastic surgery estimated charges$700        Tissue testing$350        Follow up visits for 1 year$200        Travel expenses $2400      Living allowance for 1 month from loss of ability to work$10 000  Current NeedWe recognize there are likely things we have overlooked or underestimated. This is new unfamiliar territory for us.  Obviously  there will be a much greater need if we are faced with a different scenario. We have launched this GoFundMe with a $20 000 goal with that in mind. THE FAITHIt's hard to ask for help. It's uncomfortable to feel vulnerable. If you know us at all  then you know WE LOVE JESUS. Sometimes being faithful is uncomfortable too. Many times it was in hard times that the people of the Bible asked for Jesus' help. However  it was never  not once  hard for Jesus to extend His love  healing and deliverance. We KNOW our God is bigger than cancer. Mightier than the unknown. Constant in His loving peace.The word 'promises' appears 24 times in the NIV Bible and SIX of those guarantee that His promises are true and never fail. THE PRAYERThe greatest gift of friendship is prayer. Please pray for:• This journey Heath has begun • Reassurance for our three amazing children and their many questions• Provision for all of our needs• Total  complete and unquestionable healingWe covet your prayers and if you feel lead  please donate financially also. We sincerely appreciate your help!Thank you for taking the time to read our story.Much love to each of you!

Thank you for stopping by our page and taking a minute or two to read our story.  We are not the type of people to begin a Go Fund Me support page  but this is an emergency that is as simple making sure one has a roof over their head to live under  but as financially challenging to one who has been struggling to not financially drown for two years. It's a heartfelt and truthful story  with an unexpected medical miracle  but one that we trust that God will pull us all through.Here is the short story:In Jan 2016  my dad was diagnosed with a cancer that was supposed to be \easy to mange\" as stated by the doctors  but it ended up taking his life now in october 2018. In july  he was told he had 2 months left to live  so Nancy and I got married  but then he got better in some sort of a temporary miracle  but then he got really bad again late sept eraly oct of this year and he passed away. Unfortunately the job he had did not provide retirment options and his life insurace was taken away sometime in 2017  so now my mom is stuck with all the bills and the mortgage on a house and she makes a little over $1k per month and can't afford to go find an appartment for her  my sister  and her parents to live in on that income. We still believe God can perform miracles! Here is the whole story:“God is faithful  and he will not let you be tested beyond your strength but with your testing he will also provide the way out so that you may be able to endure it” (1 Corinthians 10:13). This is a verse that we are struggling to hang onto  but we trust that it will come true.Throughout our life  Luis and Ani Cavada put their household first  and they did things that were tough for them  but best for the family. Some of the activities they enjoyed doing were family dinners  just walking around the malls together  Luis would golf with his son on the weekends to help him build on his professional networking skills when he didn't work  and they liked to travel together. Their son Andres would travel with his father on business trips occasionally to learn more about what his father did  which is what inspired Andres to become an engineer just like his father. Luis and Ani also did their best to ensure their children had a great Christian education to ensure they had the bed chances at college possible. With this passion of keeping the home together and doing things  Luis did have some sacrifices to do. He would travel to China for two or three months per year for many years  or he also sacrificed by moving himself to Virginia for work when his job in Miramar moved to another state to ensure that his family could continue to grow and strengthen without interruption. Being away from his family so long really hit Luis hard  and whenever he returned back home  it was always in tears of joy from missing his us so much. There was nothing that Luis wouldn't do for us.On a day that Luis was returning back to Miami (at the time he was commuting to and from Virginia for weeks at a time to continue working)  Luis was stricken with intense back pains. To the point of making it difficult to walk. That same day he was flying back home so he did not want to be hospitalized in Virginia so he flew down to Miami and was admitted at Baptist Hospital. After a few days of tests  they admit him into the Oncology floor  with theories of him having cancer  but no final results. Finally  one night in January of 2016  we got some answers  but they weren't what we wanted to hear: he had cancer and was diagnosed with Multiple Myeloma. As any normal human would do  we all were stricken with grief  worry  anxiety  and sadness  but there was one person who held their head up high: Luis. He grabbed his family  looked us all firmly in the eyes and said \"It's going to be ok  we'll get through this together\". At this moment  we realized that God is in control  He always has been  always will be  and this is what Luis was conveying to us.Now  this cancer is not a commonly heard of cancer like colon or breast cancer. You have a 0.76% chance of getting this cancer ( https://www.cancer.org/cancer/multiple-myeloma/about/key-statistics.html)  and unfortunately Luis happened to be a part of that extremely small statistic  something that him nor his family ever thought would strike. Multiple Myeloma is a cancer of one's plasma cells  which are made in the bone marrow. With this cancer  the plasma cells become cancerous and they grow out of control going everywhere in one's body  which could cause issues with the blood counts (this could include platelets  red blood cells  and white blood cells)  weak bones  increased risk of infections  and potential kidney damage.For two years  with God's strength  Luis battled this cancer. He fought with all of the nasty repercussions of doing chemo and radiation (a few tumors arose)  side effects of the narcotics he had to take to numb the pain  side effects of coming off of taking these narcotics  and at some times  he struggled to do things on his own due to all the medications he was one. When he was first diagnosed  him and his family were also hit with the terrible news that his health insurance DID NOT COVER CANCER. At the time he was diagnosed  he was working for a contracting company that the only health insurance plan they offered did not provide cancer coverage. This was another significant battle that God was able to eventually pull him through. Baptist hospital was able to help out in the beginning to get his treatments going while he searched for new medical coverage.Finally  Luis is able to locate health coverage  but at a significant cost of around $800 per month which put an additional financial stress on his family. The financial issues did not stop though  deductibles for the procedures were high  deductibles for his medicine were high  and his disability that he was on (which we are extremely grateful for) only paid him half of the yearly salary he used to make. These financial struggles little by little strangled Luis and Ani. Luis had to take money out of his retirement just to financially survive  and also take out money from his life insurance. After a year of being on his disability  his life insurance policy was also taken from him due to being on disability for too long  and little by little  all the investments in savings and retirement were slowly being drained out of him. Money was not something easy to come by anymore  so more sacrifices had to be made.At that time  Ani's parents were living in an efficiency within that house  but the financial situation was so great  that they needed to rent out that efficiency to provide some sort of financial relief. God has put some great family members in our lives that were able to trust Luis and Ani by loaning them money and helping them find people that would build a new bedroom in the living room for Ani's parents to live in while the efficiency was rented out.Fast forward to July 2018  a new chemo procedure is performed on Luis  some bone marrows samples are pulled from him  and a sentence that no family member looks forward to hearing is spoken: Luis  you have two months left to live.This turns our lives upside down. He is too young! He has so much more potential in life! He has been fighting for so long! Ani will grow old and alone! He hasn't experienced the blessing of having grandkids! How can his own parents outlive their son! It shouldn't be like this  it's not fair! These were our emotions  we are human  and we are imperfect. Yet in all of this  there was still some peace. A peace that passes all understanding. The peace given to us by God. We asked God for peace  and we were given the peace. (Philippians 4:6-7). At this point  his son Andres was engaged to his girlfriend of 5 years  and they moved their wedding from November 2018 to a few days later from being given that news. This happened because of two things: 1. God's heavenly support2. The blessing that is Baptist Hospital  they were the biggest earthly help Nancy or Andres could have asked forOn July 28th  2018  Luis was able to see his son get married and for a moment  we all forgot about our dad's terminal news.A week or two later after the wedding  Luis is discharged to go home to leave this earth in the most amount of comfort possible: his home with his family. Through the grace of God  Luis begins to actually feel better! It's a miracle! This new procedure is finally taking an effect against his cancer. God's plan is seeming to be that He still does miracles  and Luis could potentially be a living testimony. His oncology doctor was even shocked and told him to prepare for a new procedure to be performed in early October  after he had said that there was nothing else he could medically do without significantly impacting his quality of life (at this point  the cancer had reached his spinal fluid and there were not medical treatments with success to treat his cancer there). Yet good news doesn't always stick around for too long though because God has something else planned.Towards the end of September 2018  Luis' health starts to go down again  and fast. He gets admitted into the hospital and they do multiple tests. It turns out one of his tumors has returned  a new tumor in his brain has grown  and the cancer is back and stronger than before. Luis is told this is the last time he would be in a hospital  and is sent home to live his final days at peace with his family. October 13th  2018  five days after he was supposed to get the second treatment  Luis departs from his family and has gone to be with the Lord. In his time of battling the cancer  we believe his faith grew  and his relationship with God was indeed strengthened. Now Ani is left to grow old by herself  and now has to find a way to financially survive.When we started to evaluate all the finances  it was clear as day that Ani does not make enough money to continue to pay the mortgage of the house nor make enough money to live in a smaller apartment with her parents. Even with the social security money from her parents was not enough to survive  so the decision to rent out the house was agreed upon. Yet  this house is not in the rental conditions it should be in. Due to the extremely tight financial situations  the home has not been able to be properly up kept. When the hurricane  passed through south Florida in 2017  they cause some damages to the home that have yet to be fixed due to Ani and Luis doing whatever they could to financially stay afloat. The situation is the following: due to the financial circumstances Luis and Ani were in for two years  Ani needs to rent her home for her  her daughter  and her parents to keep a roof over their heads. The amount we are asking for is nothing crazy  but for someone who had their husband pass away who had to use all of his savings and retirement for the family to survive  left Ani with no financial support to be able to tackle this burden on her own. This is the reality we live in  but it's one that we are doing our best to trust the God will make a way for Ani and her parents.It was never considered to create this page when Luis first passed away because the above mentioned solution seemed to be simple  but the financial obstacles do not stop for Ani  and here we are. We pray to God that He would bless you and move in you to help Ani  her daughter  and her grandparents pay for the home repairs that need to be done  so they can stay with a roof over their heads. During Luis' time battling cancer  we knew God could perform a miracle  and we still do.Thank you for your time  and may God bless you no matter what you decide to do after reading this."

Jeannie Erfft  our dear friend and prayer sister   is in end stage heart failure.  Without surgery  her prognosis is poor.  Mayo Clinic is the only place that is able to perform a life-saving procedure.  Unfortunately  her insurance is an HMO and they are denying her a referral to Mayo.This is an urgent and dire situation.  Jeannie's job provides health insurance for her family so she has to work during this painful and stressful illness.  Jeannie is a young woman with a husband and three children. She is a loving and giving person who has helped many people.  Please support her by giving her the opportunity to have this life-saving procedure done.  $4 000 is just the amount needed for her to have her initial visit to Mayo the first week in April  2019.

Our beloved friend Heather Holderby needs your help!  Lots of you know Heather from just being around Kansas City.  Some of you across the country know Heather from her old punk rock band \Sex Offenders\".  However you came to know her  I know you love her.  She's too stubborn and proud to ask for help  but she needs it so badly because she has an awful and extraordinarily painful neck/spine injury that requires expensive surgery and she has *no health insurance*.  She can't work because of the injury  she can't pay for pain management  and she is getting kicked out of her living space in February because she has no income. What happened:  Heather was recently bartending at Westport Flea Market and  because of how terrible their back rooms are set up  ergonomically speaking  she injured herself on the job. Her employer has been AWFUL about this at every step and is fighting her claim for worker's comp   saying that she hurt herself \"playing guitar\"  which is total BS.  Her attorney is not being responsive and she is stuck with him.  She was scheduled for surgery on Friday  January 25  but St. Luke's requires a 25% down payment on her $78 000 surgery. The injury: she has two torn discs in her neck that are oozing  and vertebrae that are crushed and protruding.  More than two months after the injury  her spinal cord is being affected  and she is suffering neurological damage  including reflex issues  numbness  and *severe* pain.The surgery: Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion  which includes replacing her damaged discs with cadaver discs (which  admittedly  is pretty badass) and hardware. The plea: Heather needs your help to pay for this surgery.  It's not clear that her employer will ever be held liable  and if they are  she will suffer for who-knows-how-long in the meantime.  The surgery itself costs $78 000 but the goal of this fundraiser is just the bare minimum cost to make the surgery happen.  $19 000 (the 25% down payment).  That's a lot of dough  but it is my hope that enough folks in the punk rock community and beyond will help her out as best as you can.  We thank you in advance for even reading this plea and considering it.  <3"

Danika suffered liver and kidney failure in May 2018. She needs a liver transplant to survive. She is 28 years old and lives in Bloomington  MN with her dog and cat. She was baptized and confirmed at Transfiguration Lutheran Church (West Bloomington). Her liver medical team is the U of M. Danika has Medicaid State health insurance to cover the main expenses involved with the transplant and post-recovery. She is disabled and receives an income of only $895 per month from Social Security. From this small amount she must pay rent and all the other expenses associated with living a basic lifestyle. It is not enough to make ends meet. The funds will be used to help offset any expenses not covered by insurance. For example  special foods  adult diapers  on site personal care  and transportation assistance. After the liver transplant  patients will be in the intensive care unit for two days. After that  they are in the regular part of the hospital for about eight to ten days. They then go home  though they may not feel all the way better for up to three months. This scenario is based on finding a match donor.  We are in need of a Living liver transplant donor now! We are looking for an angel between the ages of (20-50) blood type (O) and in good health. You will undergo surgery and 60% of liver removed. It will grow back to normality within (2) months. You will be laid up for (2) months. There are financial resources available as well as medical staff to take your questions. Furthermore  liver transplant recipients take medication for the rest of their lives to help prevent the body from rejecting the liver. The Anti-Rejection (Immunosuppressive) medication can make the person ill. Please help Danika through this horrible tragedy. The need is immediate. Please be as generous as you can -- either by donating money  or just by sharing this link on your social media to help spread the word. We appreciate your support. https://www.facebook.com/arlo.hennings

My mother was diagnosed with Leukemia at the beginning of this year. She’s been in the hospital since  undergoing chemotherapy and transfusions to try to kill off the cancer in her bone marrow. The doctors told her she’s going to be in the hospital for another 4-6 months as they try to win this battle over leukemia. Because of this  my mother will be missing at least half a year from work and is having a hard time affording her bills. Her work is helping her as much as they can but she will have to pay for her health insurance on her own very soon. 6 years ago she was diagnosed with breast cancer and had to fight that battle as a single mother. I tried helping her as much as I could at the time  but because my work didn’t allow me to take time off  she had to walk and take the bus to and from the hospital alone during her treatment. She’s the strongest woman I know  but any help is most greatly appreciated. All donations will go directly to her medical expenses  head wraps  rent  food  and anything else she may need during her treatment.If you cannot donate  please help us get the word out by sharing on Facebook  Twitter  Instagram  anywhere! Thank you all  we love you so much and Together we can beat cancer!

storyTitle: Love for Linda: Help My Mother See a Clear Future
story: Just over a year ago  January 25  2018  my mother was diagnosed with glaucoma; it took over half of her eyesight. In less than a month from now  her mortgage company is going to try to take her house from her. She needs your help.HOW DO I HELP? Donate if you can. If not  Linda is a landscaper (who  due to her current condition  now mostly works Chicago's Northwest side). If you're interested in hiring her  just call Linda's Lawn Care at (773) 507-5296. Or tell your family and friends to hire her!WHY SHOULD I HELP? My mother has always been a fighter. When her marriage ended in a difficult divorce  she built a successful landscaping business that has been her primary source of income for over 20 years. She has always had an aversion to asking for help  preferring to work for everything she has. As a single mother  she raised me  my disabled brother  and our baby sister all while working 6 - 7 days a week. During loan modification negotiations with her mortgage company… she fell ill. What she thought was an aggressive sinus infection  coupled with pinkeye  was actually an acute  closed angle glaucoma attack. Lacking quality health insurance  it was weeks before she could get treatment; someone finally told her to go to Cook County hospital  where she learned the severity of the situation. At only 58  it was unexpected  to say the least. She was also diagnosed with diabetes (now controlled)  hypertension  and suffered at least one minor stroke in the following months  due to the stress of her conditions. Given her illness and the subsequent recovery  she missed deadlines and her mortgage company began foreclosure proceedings on her home. We were informed of the judgment of foreclosure just before Christmas  and are currently in the “redemption period” with the sale date weeks away  as the mortgage company is reviewing all the documents we have submitted. She's endured her fair share of hardships: the long recovery process  and trying to use her other senses to aid her low vision while workingWHAT IF I DO HELP? As she catches up with bills and we wait for the landscaping season to start up again  we're trying to raise $15 000.This amount will help cover medical needs  can help with a few mortgage payments  and would be put towards other unexpected expenses (like truck repairs). With this money  the mortgage company may agree to a loan modification so my mother won’t lose her home of 33 years; she can continue to be as autonomous as possible despite her stretch of bad health  being more than capable to tackle the spring season. Please remember  every little bit helps  whether it's a donation  or a landscaping job. I’m infinitely grateful for all help we receive  and I know my mother will be even more so. Thank you. If you wish to know even more details  I have posted her story on Facebook as #LindaTheLandscaper which will be the hashtag going forward. Again  thank you.Even during some of our many hospital trips  we can make her smile

My name is Kelsey Gates and I'm 31 years old. I have a wonderful husband  Dustin  and an amazing daughter named Brailynn who is 5 years old. As lucky as I am to have them  I've been fighting the hardest battle of my life for the past 5 years. Six weeks after I had my daughter I was diagnosed with a brain tumor and had to have emergency surgery to have it removed. Since it was on my brain stem the doctor was not able to remove ALL of the tumor. Due to the massive amount of steroids I had to take to control the brain swelling  I ended up getting Avascular Necrosis and needing a left hip and shoulder replacement.      Over the past 5 years I have undergone 17 craniotomies in order to implant 2 shunts in my head as well as remove the tumor. After my last craniotomy in July  I was diagnosed with 2 blood clots in my lungs. Due to the size of one of the blood clots I am now in right sided heart failure as well. I'm currently on oxygen and require a walker to help me get around and to conserve my energy because my heart rate rises quickly when I exert myself.      I have worked as a 2nd grade teacher for the past 8 years  even while going through these issues. I've tried my best to recover and go back to work in order to keep my health insurance and pay medical bills. However  with these latest issues and the numerous doctors appointments I have  I am unable to return to work this school year.  Your donations would be greatly appreciated to help my family and I pay our bills and to help pay for our medical insurance while I am unable to work. My husband is working  but with an increasing number of medical bills on top of regular monthly bills  we need both of our salaries to survive. If you can donate any amount to help my family we would greatly appreciate it. Thank You!

I am humbly asking for your prayers  help  and support during the fight of my life. I have been battling cardiac problems (heart attack  congestive heart failure  a LAD Occlusion  cardiomyopathy  angina  pulmonary embolism  pacemaker  coronary stent  congestive heart failure  complete heart block  pacemaker  90% Aortic Valve Regurgitation which required Emergency Open Heart Surgery  partially collapsed lung) that are all the result of and secondary to autoimmune diseases (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus  Sjogren’s Syndrome Disease  Raynaud’s Syndrome  Cushing’s Disease) since February 2018. It is worth mentioning that they now want to remove the pacemaker that was implanted on my 40th birthday February 19th  2018 and replace it with a LINQ device  but they feel I am too ill to undergo the surgery at this time. So once I am \healthy\" enough  I will be having another surgery. (I am probably forgetting some of my issues because I get \"foggy brain\" along with everything else.)Prior to February 2018  I was under the impression that I was healthy and we were a 2-income household. Now I am bedridden most of the time and too sick to work. We have made it this long because we have downsized  used every RX discount available  I had short term disability thru my prior employer and my husband had an Aflac policy. We have cut every corner we can think of but unfortunately  there are no more corners left to cut.  Asking for help and doing a \"Go Fund Me\" is one of the hardest things I have ever had to do but I do not know what else to do. Almost a year later and I am still soooooooooo sick and need prescriptions  have specialist appointments and need treatments. I never in a million years would have thought that almost a year later I would still be so sick and bedridden most of the time. My health insurance is over $800 a month. I have 5 doctors/specialists that I need to see on a regular basis  take over 15 very necessary prescriptions (blood thinners  anti rejections  steroids  SLE meds  etc.) and self-injections. The co-pays  treatments and deductibles have been difficult to cover  but they are about to be impossible to cover. Despite the very aggressive medications & treatments that I currently take my health continues to deteriorate. My rheumatologist recently ordered chemotherapy treatments in hopes of giving me some quality of life back and getting my symptoms under control. Unfortunately  my health insurance company denied her request. They have mandated that in addition to my current prescriptions  treatments and self-injections that I must take an additional 2 self-injections for 12 weeks before they will approve the chemotherapy treatments. Of course  all these medications have very harsh side effects. This is on top of the disease's relentless symptoms. My body is attacking itself. I feel like I have been poisoned and I am in constant and relentless pain 24/7. I have been a fighter my whole life  but this disease shuts my body down. My muscles start to burn and no matter how hard I tell my brain to keep going my muscles start to burn and then they freeze up. I have literally cried  screamed and yelled with determination trying to push thru the pain but my body locks up. No matter how hard I try pushing thru is not an option. The autoimmune issues/diseases have robbed me of being a mom/wife  my health  my independence  my job  bring me unbearable pain  affect my thinking  my motor skills and have completely altered my physical appearance. Because of the long term high doses of steroids  I have developed Cushing's disease. I don't recognize the person that looks back at me in the mirror. (The cover picture was taken 4/2018 at Shand's Hospital when I was recovering from emergency open heart surgery  which was the result of my body attacking my organs. Since 4/2018 my appearance has changed drastically. Even though I am so ashamed of how I look in the pictures below I felt like I needed to share just how much autoimmune has physically changed me over this past year)Fortunately  I have the support of my 2 absolutely amazing sons and my husband. They have been so supportive during this difficult time and have done everything they can to try to nurse me back to health and help in any way that they can. Logically  I know I shouldn't feel guilty but I do. I would do anything to be a mom and wife again. To be their caretaker instead of them taking care of me. I hope and pray every day that any of my medications and/or treatments will start to restore my health  but if I can't afford them anyways then there isn't much hope of my health improving at all. This my sole motivation for doing this. Thank you for taking the time to read a little about my story. It is very difficult to try to condense everything that has happened since 2/2018 but I hope I have given some insight into the trials and tribulations that we have faced during this last year. Even if you decide you'd rather not help I hope you take one thing from all this  please listen to your body and take time to care for yourself. I look back now and think how did I miss this? My body was all but screaming at me! But when you are busy living life you just keep pushing and just keep going. Please know that if you don't listen to your body you could end up like me  40 years old  chronically ill and having to ask for help just to try to fight for your health.   My amazing boys. They have been so strong and helpful throughout all this. Picture of the muscles on my left side locking up and locking down and showing the fluid retention that shifts throughout my body. My joints and muscles will swell and are warm to the touch. After an exceptionally bad flare the muscles bruise from the inside out. I developed a bump on my left elbow. Below shows the muscles locking down on my left side.  It is extremely uncomfortable and painful. My skin turns all sorts of colors. I turn pink  red  bright red and sometimes purple. This was after open heart surgery 4/2018This is prior to my April Shands hospitalization. My left arm swelled  I was unable to touch or be touched. The long term high doses of steroids cause fluid retention. It constantly shifts  but doesn't go away. The picture doesn't really show it  but my joints swell  are warm to the touch and feel like I have splinters &/or barb wire in them. Most days I have limited use of my hands  specifically my left wrist. A pic of how the fluid shifts throughout  but never goes away I am constantly bruised from head to toe. Log in to use Ginger Limited mode A pic of how the fluid shifts throughout  but ×"

We need your help to get Lucinda through her current battles. In September 2017  Lucinda was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. Although she fought relentlessly to overcome the cancer and come out on top  her victory was short lived. In December of this year Lucinda was informed her cancer had returned -- this time in the form of stage 4 cancer attacking her brain and bones. Adding to Lucinda's considerable pain and grief  her loving husband  Chuck  unexpectedly passed away on Christmas Eve. Chuck and Lucinda were married for 20+years and have 3 beautiful children together. Since Lucinda was unable to work due to the aggressive cancer treatment  Chuck was the sole provider of both income and health insurance.  With Chuck gone  Lucinda is left to grieve her own loss as well as helping their children through this difficult time -- all while still going through debilitating cancer treatment. We ask that if you are able to donate please do so  there is no amount too small. If you cannot donate but would like to help in other ways (food  etc.)  please email me.  Your thoughts and prayers are also needed and greatly appreciated for this grieving family. Lucinda is a strong woman with a beautiful loving heart. She is also a very loving  caring mother who needs an army of people to help her through this devastating situation. Thank you for your consideration.

storyTitle: RUSH STEGALL NEEDS A NEW LIVER
story: My husband  Rush Stegall   needs a liver transplant. We are working with the best team in the world  Ochsner Medical Center  in New Orleans.We are having to move to NOLA to be close by when we get the call. We are keeping up our household plus renting a place in NOLA. Let's not forget the cost of the surgery. We have health insurance but all other expenses are out of our savings.Rush has helped so many people over the years. He has the biggest heart of anyone I know.  If you can find it in your heart to help  you have no idea what it would mean to us.Anything you donate will directly to saving his life. The situation is dire  this is our only hope.We also appreciate prayers  good thoughts  good juju and any kidness the universe has to offer.I will be posting updates on Facebook so everyone can follow us on our journey.

Hello my name is Yvette and I am dealing with breast  cancer.Because of unforeseen circumstances with my medical leave and my job my insurance  has been cancelled  I  had surgery and not yet start my radiation because of complication and because of this I have been out of work going to 5 months. So that cost me to have complications with my insurances. We are working to resolve the problem but right now we owe money we don't have. And my insurance gave me till January to pay what I owe.  If  you are able please donate to my Fund anything will help . I need my health insurance for my treatments  .I appreciate your Kindness.Sincerely Yvette

storyTitle: Justine is getting brain surgery, yikes.
story: Hi  I'm Justine's friend Casey and I made her let me make her this gofundme. It's really hard to ask for help. You know how when people try to say something isn't hard they say \it's not brain surgery\"? Well. This is definitely  literally brain surgery. Turns out it's actually pretty hard. Here's a description from Justine of what is going on at the moment: \"Over the last year (and probably much longer) I've been experiencing a variety of symptoms including headaches  cognitive issues like memory problems and forgetting words  progressive pain  numbness  and tingling in different parts of my body  dizziness  trouble swallowing  and host of other symptoms. In trying to figure out why all of this has been happening  I spent the last year going to five doctors and having lots of different medical tests done. Over that year the symptoms have gotten progressively worse  with headaches lasting days  and neurological symptoms becoming more frequent and severe. I’ve finally been diagnosed with a condition called a Chiari Malformation  which basically means my brain is just a little bit too big for my skull and it’s getting squished. The only treatment for this condition is brain surgery. So right now  that’s what I’m preparing for.I have a surgical consultation on 1/21 to go over the finer details of my treatment plan and put the surgery on the books.\" Justine is lucky enough to have good health insurance  but even so there many expenses involved in her treatment  such as:*Her outstanding medical bills from the long road to diagnosis*Her copays for tens of thousands of dollars in surgery  procedures and medications*She'll probably need to take some unpaid time off of work during her recovery.  She'll need to be able to pay bills  rent  etc during this time.*She will need physical support during her recovery time  which may require her to travel to be near her family  or to hire a home healthcare assistant.Her surgery will be soon (the date is being set January 21)  and the last thing Justine needs is to stress out about money when she should be getting well. Your assistance will help her maintain normalcy in a decidedly abnormal time. Justine would also love your help in the form of:*Assistance with household tasks like cooking  cleaning  shopping  playing with kitties. These tasks are getting more and more exhausting and a hand would be amazing.*Companionship! Come over! Be friends!*Rides to appointments"

As a mother  there's nothing worse than hearing the words  \you have cancer\" because you know it will be very hard on your children  no matter how old they are or how well you explain it. For a single mom  the worry is compounded with \"who will take care of me when I'm too sick to do anything?\" and \"how will I manage the extreme financial stress?\" The answers to those questions force a person to confront their vulnerability at a time and pace that is unimaginable. This is happening to my dearest friend  Melissa and the hits keep coming. Melissa was diagnosed with Stage 3 breast cancer in May 2018. This was one year after a different doctor told her the lump she felt was just bone. I hate to think this was because she didn't have health insurance at the time  but that doesn't really matter now. Melissa is solely focused on fighting for her life. This isn't her first battle with this disease  as she left her home/job in California to take care of both of her parents in Georgia until they both eventually died of cancer. In between her role as full-time caregiver  she was also homeschooling her daughter. She spent YEARS putting everyone else's needs ahead of her own. When she became sick  there was no family left to care for her.  What happens when the caregiver needs to be cared for  but no one is around to do it?! They make plans to manage their own care without blinking an eye. Melissa prepared her home for the really bad days following chemo treatments when she would be too sick to walk to the restroom across the hall by dragging her mattress closer to the bathroom door. She used a wheeled office chair to carry her body into the kitchen so she could eat food directly out of the refrigerator. Thankfully  her wonderful neighbor had organized a schedule of cooked meals donated by neighbors and Melissa's business partner  Conrad  has dutifully taken her to all of her doctor appointments and stayed by her side during several months of chemotherapy. Prior to the chemo  I went to GA to take care of my friend when she had surgery. For ten days  I cared for her and her three dogs rescued from shelters that she loves so much. It was hard for her to be the patient and to let someone else do all the work. Melissa is not comfortable asking for help from anyone  but she trusted me and I am grateful for that trust. As the medical treatment continues with months of radiation ahead  the financial obstacles have become increasingly difficult  if not impossible for Melissa to bear alone. She is self-insured and recently had to change medical plans do to a massive premium increase. This resulted in a need to change providers mid-treatment after it was discovered that she was no longer eligible with the less expensive insurance plan. There was a very costly day of evaluations by specialists  along with medical procedures to prep her for radiation that was not covered at all before she was notified about the limitations of the new insurance carrier. Due to the inoperable location of a tumor in her neck  the need for intense radiation right now is critical! She also has a spot on her lung that the specialist intends to target with radiation. When Melissa came home from that anxiety-filled day that left her feeling more vulnerable than ever  she was hit with the news about the insurance blunder. She doesn't have the time or the energy for this fight on top of everything else.As her friend  I've asked Melissa to trust me once again by reaching out to others through this fundraiser to help her fight this cancer. Please support Melissa  who has been so courageous and positive through this battle with cancer. She has cared for so many others in so many ways. It's her turn to receive care and to experience the kindness of strangers. She is everything that's good in a person; loving  compassionate  generous  creative  smart and incredibly funny. Please share her story with as many people as you can. Help give this selfless woman a chance to beat this disease without worrying about being evicted from her home. No one should have to fight cancer alone. Thank you for listening. Chaunte' KashiwaPost chemo:Melissa  before she met cancer in person:"

Hello Everyone! As most of you know I have been in a hospital and/or skilled nursing facility since September 6th 2018 dealing with wounds  infections  therapy and other physical issues. Well  the time has come to be discharged (on January 4th) to return home. I’m looking forward to being back with my family and I’m thankful for everyone who has been praying for me as the Lord continues providing me strength on a daily basis. While its certainly good news that I’m going home  it also presents challenges and needs. I require home weekly assistance from nurses  physical/ occupational therapists and also a home health aide.My health insurance policy will only partially cover the nurses/therapists and they will not provide ANY coverage for a home health aide. In order for me to have this needed help it will require us to privately hire an aide which will be 100% out of pocket. Unfortunately  this is not possible for us to do without financial assistance and it’s with this in mind that I decided to humbly share my need with you on this Go Fund Me page.The amount of funds we are able to raise and collectively pull together will determine how many days a week and also for how many weeks I will be able to have an aide come to help me. Having this daily assistance with my needs will also serve an important secondary purpose as it will help to prevent recurrences of contributing factors that initiated my need for hospitalization back in September.Every donation no matter the amount makes a difference and further helps me get the daily assistance I need. I thank you from my heart for any financial support you’re able to give and I am grateful for your continued prayers.Sincerely Stephen

PLEASE HELP ME GET THE BRAIN SURGERY I NEED  AND GET MY LIFE BACK!I have always been a very active person with a love for the outdoors. I love art and enjoy photography and painting. I have always enjoyed traveling and going on adventures. I had even booked and paid for a cruise in January of this year  and looked forward to turning 40 years-old in the middle of the ocean on November 29  2018. However  life has other plans for me and I will be having brain surgery instead. My tumor was found on August 15th. I have brain surgery scheduled for December 10th. The Backstory For the last four or five years  I have been struggling with several symptoms; such as fatigue  sleeping issues  heat sensitivity  light sensitivity  pressure headaches  and tremors. In January of 2018  my symptoms began to get worse  and I began to develop new ones  including vision issues  stuttering  getting stuck on words  losing my balance  cognitive issues  emotional outbursts  ice pick headaches  muscle spasms  vertigo  and more. After several blood tests  eye specialists appointments  MRIs  and EEGs  we finally found out what was going on. I have a Pineal Tumor. The PlanDue to the type of tumor  and the location (Geographic center of the brain)  there are only 2 neurosurgeons in the United States that will remove it. Therefore  I will be traveling to Charleston  South Carolina for brain tumor removal surgery with Dr. Patel at MUSC on December 10th. He is the Chair of the Neurosurgery department  and I truly believe I could not be in better hands for this surgery. The CostThe total for the hospital (surgery  anesthesia  hospital stay  etc) will be around $58 000.As of 11/6/18  the hospital is requiring HALF as down payment before surgery. They had originally agreed to $10 000 down  but the supervisors decided the total was too great of a risk so now they want the $29 000 down payment by November 23rd!!!! Down Payment has been PAID!!!! Surgery is definitely happening.I am trying everything I can to get insurance coverage. I had insurance through my job  which i lost in September. I can possibly qualify for insurance through Missouri  however Missouri Medicaid is considered out of network by the hospital in South Carolina and won't be accepted as payment. I do not currently qualify for disability. I do qualify for special enrollment through the health.gov marketplace. However  when i enter my zip code  there are only 5 plans offered and they are all from a company (Ambetter) that is also out of network for the hospital. I can purchase Short Term Health Insurance  however  they do not cover any pre-existing conditions or anything that consulted on 12 months prior to enrolling. So  my insurance options are not hopeful at this point. Travel and lodging: Due to safety reasons  I have to stay in Charleston until after my 2 week follow-up appointment and suture removal. Travel and lodging expenses for myself  and my family will be around $3000 total. This includes renting a home in Charleston for 2 1/2 weeks (as I will need privacy and quiet while healing. Also  there is no way that I am going to be in Charleston for 3 weeks and not have my family with me)  gas and hotel stays for the 2400-mile round-trip.Follow-up and Recovery: I will have to travel back to Charleston in a year after surgery for follow-up scans to check for regrowth. I will also need physical therapy  briefly  to help me get my balance and strength back after surgery. Medications will add to the expenses. After brain surgery  i will not be able to work for a few months and will require help with many of my daily life activities. This will make it more of a strain to pay for household expenses. Help me get my life back!I don't feel like \me\" anymore. This tumor is taking so much away from me and my family. I don't like to travel anymore  because the vertigo and motion sickness are too much to handle. I can't enjoy time outside for very long due to severe light sensitivity and heat sensitivity. I can't spend much time playing with my one-year old before I am too tired to even move or tremors force me to sit out. Tremors and vision issues make photography and painting a frustrating challenge. My severe insomnia and fatigue make it nearly impossible to enjoy life or function. My emotional outbursts and anxiety are crippling. I have been slowing turning into someone else  and I need \"me\" back. My family needs me back.Please donate! Help me get rid of this tumor and get my life back!Please share  share  share with everyone you know. The more people that see this  the better my chances of meeting my goal are!Thanks so much for your support!Much love Melanie(Moey)I am also selling tshirts that I designed for brain tumor awareness. The link is below if you are interested.  http://www.bonfire.com/help-support-brain-surgery-for-melanie/"

Basha was diagnosed with Stage 4 lung cancer in December.   Before her diagnosis she was offered a new job and was ready to start on Jan 2nd.    After receiving the news of the advance stage of her cancer  she was unable to start her new position.   Her health insurance from her previous job runs out the end of February.  She has begun her treatments but this will be a long road - 6 to 9 months without an income or insurance.  Insurance is $2100 a month to cover herself and the family.  Any donation will be greatly appreciated to help reduce the burden of expenses.

On 4/27/18 our dear friend  Julie Owens Wilkie  was diagnosed with Stage IV rectal cancer. After months of chemotherapy and radiation treatments  doctors discovered Julie’s cancer had metastasized to her liver and lungs. She has decided to begin more chemotherapy that will hopefully shrink the tumors and provide pain relief. Julie has been working during her treatments  but lately has been needing more time off. The family has health insurance coverage through Julie’s work  but will be very expensive if Julie is unable to keep working. Her husband Dusty works at Wilkie Residential Builders  but has been missing a lot of work due to Julie’s frequent treatments  appointments and hospital stays.  If you are financially able  please consider giving to this wonderful family. Please keep Julie and her family in your prayers as they continue on this difficult journey.

Freddie Willie Jr  35 has been battling brain cancer (Anaplastic Astrocytoma; stage 3) since May 2017. He has gone through radiation  many different forms of chemotherapy  3 brain surgeries and several hospitalizations to date! His most recent visit to MDA did not deliver good news and the family is preparing for a possible 2nd opinion and will travel out of state for continued care. Freddie  his wife and their 3 children along with family and friends are not giving up the fight! Freddie has not been to work since October (after the swelling of his brain  his 26 day hospital stay and therapy) money has been overwhelming tight. Not to mention an unexpected move on top of things! His job and all his work ppl have been very very understanding and have gone out of their way to donate time to Freddie and help keep him covered by insurance as long as possible! However this time is up. Holly has been back and forth with trying to get Freddie approved disability retirement insurance thru his job so he can keep his health insurance but it has not been approved at this time! There is a lot to applying for any type of disability and the progress that many of you do not know and hopefully you will not ever need to know. This family has been battling this battle for almost 2 years and at this point the financial strain has become almost the undoing of this family!! IAs you all know Freddie and Holly’s last visit to MDA was not a good one and Freddie has been making improvements (Holly had talked to an all natural vitamin specialist and added some new things to his diet; as well as the continued therapy) but with the MRI showing new spots and the swelling of his brain everything has been so unknown! The fear is great but the fight is greater! Holly has been looking into different facilities and is hoping to get approval for a 2nd opinion and to take Freddie to another world renowned cancer treatment facility whom is known as #1 for brain cancer txt (there are a couple however their all out of state)! They have been so happy with MDA but as many of you know the options that were given last month were NOT idea and Holly still is unsure what the right direction to go in! A 2nd opinion is their hope at this point and I know that it would help ease their minds. They will be following up with MDA soon and hopefully Holly can give you more details on the progress later! To say the least this family is asking for you all to come out and help support  donate  socialize and/or pray for them!

Agradecemos a todos el apoyo que han tenido con nuestra hija.  Anaceci ha evolucionado muy bien  y en estos momentos nos encontramos en la última parte de su tratamiento.  Les pedimos seguir apoyando y compartiendo para poder llegar a nuestra meta.  Ana Cecilia  our toddler of 17 months  developed a severe case of pneumonia due to complications with the flu virus.  She is in critical condition.  The hospital in our hometown did not have the equipment needed to treat her so the doctors recommended to transport her to Mexico City in an air ambulance.  Ana Cecilia is currently in intensive care  and is connected to an ECMO  which takes her blood through an artificial lung and pumps it back into her bloodstream.  The doctors are optimistic and tell us that we need to wait for her body to continue fighting.  It is uncertain the time she needs to be in intensive care  doctors tell us probably 14 to 30 days.  Right now we are covering expenses through our health insurance  but we are close to reaching the coverage limit.  We are grateful to family  friends  and the entire community of Tampico and beyond who have kindly donated to pay for hospital and doctor expenses beyond our insurance coverage.  Ana Cecilia is fighting  she is doing her best  and your donations will help us make sure that she continues to receive the medical attention she needs.  We are forever grateful for your help.  Carlos Montiel and Mariana Lam.Ana Cecilia  nuestra hija de año y medio se encuentra hospitalizada en la Ciudad de México debido a un cuadro de neumonía por influenza  su situación es crítica.  Actualmente se encuentra conectada a un pulmón artificial  debido a que la infección afectó severamente sus pulmones.  Los doctores son optimistas  nos dicen que es cuestión de tiempo y que ella siga luchando.  Es incierto el tiempo de estadía en el hospital  se manejan desde 14 hasta 30 días.  Por el momento  los gastos se están cubriendo con nuestro seguro de gastos médicos  pero la realidad es que estamos muy cerca de llegar el límite de cobertura.  Agradecemos infinitamente a nuestra familia  amigos  y a toda la comunidad de Tampico y otros lugares por sus generosas donaciones.  Todos los donativos serán destinados a cubrir los gastos hospitalarios que se vayan generando con el paso de los días.  Anaceci está luchando  está poniendo todo de su parte  ahora nos toca a nosotros como padres conseguir que su atención médica dure el tiempo que ella necesite.  Mil gracias por tu ayuda.Carlos Montiel y Mariana Lam.

UPDATE: Now that we've reached the $4 500 goal  any additional funds will go towards helping Lily visit the Lupus center at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore  MD.  https://www.hopkinslupus.org/ Many of you know that Lily has been sick for a few years now. She has multiple autoimmune disorders but was most recently diagnosed with Lupus in 2018. The medication Lily needs is called Benlysta and it's very expensive. Lily used most of her health savings account paying for the January 2019 medication copay of $2 480.44 and doesn't have enough left over to pay for February's medication or to reach her insurance's annual out of pocket maximum of $4 500.00. This also means Lily won't have any funds left in her health savings account for other expenses like medication  dental care  etc.  (Lily has a high deductible health insurance plan which means that full insurance rates and privileges only kick in once she reaches $4 500 in out-of-pocket expenses.) Lily already works full time for the American Cancer Society as well as working part time doing pet care through Rover . Even the extra income from working two jobs isn't enough to cover the upcoming February medical expenses. While she has done her best to manage on her own as much as possible  it is time to ask for the help of friends  family  and the community. (In addition to pet sitting services   Lily also does custom hair color by request! Accepting new clients now. ^_^ ) Any and all funds raised will be used towards upcoming medical bills or to help rebuild the HSA balance lost when making the January payment. Supporting documents such as bills  receipts  or insurance statements will be posted in the comments below.

storyTitle: Brain Tumor Surgery for Rock Star Darren Hendon
story: On Friday  March 15th  we received the devastating news that my husband  Darren Hendon  has a brain tumor. If you know Darren  then you know what a truly amazing generous upbeat soul he is. He is my blessing in life  and the absolute best husband ever. In the 27 years I have known him  he has always been kind  loving and supportive. He is also the person who continually goes out of his way to help others in any given situation. He would literally give you the shirt off his back. Even now  his cheerful positive outlook is a joy to all who cross his path. We call him Rock Star because he loves music  especially classic rock.Darren and I now  and 27 years ago :-)We have not yet found health insurance that will cover the cost of his brain surgery. Hopefully this will change  but as of now  I am setting pride aside and asking for prayers  healing energy  and financial assistance to help us get through this difficult time. It is very difficult and humbling to ask for help  but we have faith that the Lord will provide  and believe that this may be an avenue for His work.HOW YOU CAN HELP:Prayers and healing energy  thank you. If you have the ability to donate  it will mean more than I can possibly express. If you can forward this to others  that would be awesome.If you have suggestions for fundraising or other advice  please let me know.Thank you so so much for your support and prayers! You are literally saving his life.MEDICAL DETAILS:His tumor is a macroadenoma  measuring 2.3 by 2 centimeters  a little smaller than a golf ball. It is most likely benign  thank God  but is in a difficult position at the bottom of the brain  pushing on his pituitary gland and his optic nerve  just above the brain stem. It has permanently affected his pituitary gland  and has compromised his optic nerve  so his vision is threatened as well. It has evidently been growing for several years  and it will need to be removed very soon.The tumor has wreaked havoc with his adrenal system  and caused his sodium levels to drop to life threatening lows on numerous occasions when he has lost consciousness. We have had to take many scary ambulance rides in the last few years  not knowing why he was so deathly ill  so we are grateful to have finally learned the reason. Because of the location of the tumor  it will be a delicate surgery. We are hoping they can go in through his nose and sinuses to reach it  but due to its larger size  it may require going through the skull. He is scheduled with Dr. Oyesiku at the Emory Department of Neurosurgery and will also be undergoing a neuro opthalmology exam  and further tests with the endocrinologist as well. We will post updates as we receive more information.We do not yet know what the total for surgery and related costs will be  but we were told by Tiffany Jackson at Emory's Neurosurgery Financial Aid that it will probably be over 100 000 and that the hospital will require payment prior to the surgery. Thank you for your time and consideration. We hope to be able to pay it forward in the near future!Please share this link on Facebook or any other social media if you are moved to do so. Every bit of help is appreciated :-)Blessings to you and yours  Deb GulliverUPDATE 3/26:Darren saw Dr. Oyesiku and his staff at Emory today.  He definitely needs surgery...specifically a transsphenoidal adenomectomy.  Due to the large size of the tumor  and the fact that it has compromised both the optic nerve and the pituitary gland  it will need to be done soon.We are extremely grateful for ANY help given...Thank you so so much!

Hi  my name is Barbra. This is my story of my past 6 years with Chronic Neurological Lyme Disease. How I got hereMay 2013I had been working in my garden for a couple of days. The next day I woke up with a skull crushing headache  stiff neck  joint pain and fever. Two days later of intense symptoms  my husband noticed a bulls eye rash on my body. I tested positive for Lyme disease and Anaplasmosis.  I was put on antibiotics right away  but each day my symptoms kept getting worse. From that point on  I quickly declined. Neurological symptoms took over my body.  Burning head  crushing headaches  stiff neck  tinnitus  joint pain  dropping items  twitching  frozen body (where I can’t move) and brain shaking (it felt like my brain was in a blender). My dizziness was so intense that I could not sit up for 8 months. It felt like a G-Force so strong  that if I tried to lift my head it would push it down.I could not walk. I was unable to process information and struggled to speak. I was unable to care for myself.TodayOver the past 6 years  I have been fortunate to have a few great doctors by my side. They have fought hard for me  shown me compassion and are constantly working to find ways to help me and their other Lyme patients.95% of this disease’s expenses is not covered by health insurance. We have paid out of pocket for doctors  antibiotics  stem cell therapy  ozone therapy (which has been my one life saver)  ER visits  MRI’s  pain management  herbs and vitamin therapies. My current/past treatments have helped a lot  but I am still not making enough progress. Presently  my symptoms are about 30% better than 2013. However  six years later  I am still bed bound each day. I am unable to do things like wash my hair  prepare my meals  spend time with my friends and family  watch a movie  take my dog for a walk and sometimes just getting out of bed is impossible due to the pain. What does it feel like for me to live with Chronic Neurological Lyme disease each day?- Electrocution to the brain: That comes up the center of my brain and shocks me. It is extremely painful and can last for hours or days. - Head on fire: Feels like I have been set on fire.- Nerve pain up the spine  hands  face.- Tremors- Ice pick headaches combined with head pressure- Memory loss: short term memory loss  confusion  difficulty with speech and word finding- Dizziness- Tinnitus - Numb limbs making it difficult to walk.- Joint pain- Muscle twitching- Nausea- Chronic FatigueMy next stepI cannot continue to live like this  because it is not living. I want to feel human and be myself again. I have done lots of research and after reading other Lyme patients testimonials  I believe Klinic St George in Germany is where I need to be. Dr Douwes is the physician that discovered hyperthermia as an effective treatment for Lyme diseaseThe Klinik has been treating Lyme patients since 2000 and cancer patients since 1992.They have had great results in using Hyperthermia treatment to fight Lyme disease. You can read more information about the treatment on their website:A link to Klinik St. Georg: https://www.klinik-st-georg.de/en/klinik-st-georg/lyme-specialized-center/lyme-treatment-protocol/Testimonials from patients that have gone to Klinic St. Georg: https://www.klinik-st-georg.de/en/patient-information/testimonials/I have been awarded a grant and been accepted by Klinic St. Georg for treatment. - The Klinic has reserved a spot for my care.- A Lyme foundation has awarded me a grant to help pay for this   treatment.                                                                                     I feel very blessed and am thankful for this opportunity.Unfortunately  even with the foundations help  we will still struggle to come up with the remainder amount.We would be so grateful for any small donations to help me get to the Klinic. All proceeds will go towards my treatment and recovery.WHAT YOUR DONATIONS WILL COVER My Lyme treatment will be as an in-patient with 24 hour access to doctors and nursesBreakdown of cost:€17 500 for two week treatment at the clinic$1 000 for flight€200 for shuttle to and from clinic. * The balance of cost will cover additional funds to pay for the after-care protocol and medications they send me home with. Want to learn more about Lyme disease?Lyme in the 21st CenturyThis is an older documentary but very informative.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tvCI0-iHhuIUnder our skin http://underourskin.com/uos1/#filmYour support means the world to me. Whether it be financial or just sharing my page to help me spread awareness about Lyme disease. Thank you for taking the time to read my story. Thank you.Barbra

UPDATE: Now that we've reached the $4 500 goal  any additional funds will go towards helping Lily visit the Lupus center at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore  MD.  https://www.hopkinslupus.org/ Many of you know that Lily has been sick for a few years now. She has multiple autoimmune disorders but was most recently diagnosed with Lupus in 2018. The medication Lily needs is called Benlysta and it's very expensive. Lily used most of her health savings account paying for the January 2019 medication copay of $2 480.44 and doesn't have enough left over to pay for February's medication or to reach her insurance's annual out of pocket maximum of $4 500.00. This also means Lily won't have any funds left in her health savings account for other expenses like medication  dental care  etc.  (Lily has a high deductible health insurance plan which means that full insurance rates and privileges only kick in once she reaches $4 500 in out-of-pocket expenses.) Lily already works full time for the American Cancer Society as well as working part time doing pet care through Rover . Even the extra income from working two jobs isn't enough to cover the upcoming February medical expenses. While she has done her best to manage on her own as much as possible  it is time to ask for the help of friends  family  and the community. (In addition to pet sitting services   Lily also does custom hair color by request! Accepting new clients now. ^_^ ) Any and all funds raised will be used towards upcoming medical bills or to help rebuild the HSA balance lost when making the January payment. Supporting documents such as bills  receipts  or insurance statements will be posted in the comments below.

storyTitle: Brain Tumor Surgery for Rock Star Darren Hendon
story: On Friday  March 15th  we received the devastating news that my husband  Darren Hendon  has a brain tumor. If you know Darren  then you know what a truly amazing generous upbeat soul he is. He is my blessing in life  and the absolute best husband ever. In the 27 years I have known him  he has always been kind  loving and supportive. He is also the person who continually goes out of his way to help others in any given situation. He would literally give you the shirt off his back. Even now  his cheerful positive outlook is a joy to all who cross his path. We call him Rock Star because he loves music  especially classic rock.Darren and I now  and 27 years ago :-)We have not yet found health insurance that will cover the cost of his brain surgery. Hopefully this will change  but as of now  I am setting pride aside and asking for prayers  healing energy  and financial assistance to help us get through this difficult time. It is very difficult and humbling to ask for help  but we have faith that the Lord will provide  and believe that this may be an avenue for His work.HOW YOU CAN HELP:Prayers and healing energy  thank you. If you have the ability to donate  it will mean more than I can possibly express. If you can forward this to others  that would be awesome.If you have suggestions for fundraising or other advice  please let me know.Thank you so so much for your support and prayers! You are literally saving his life.MEDICAL DETAILS:His tumor is a macroadenoma  measuring 2.3 by 2 centimeters  a little smaller than a golf ball. It is most likely benign  thank God  but is in a difficult position at the bottom of the brain  pushing on his pituitary gland and his optic nerve  just above the brain stem. It has permanently affected his pituitary gland  and has compromised his optic nerve  so his vision is threatened as well. It has evidently been growing for several years  and it will need to be removed very soon.The tumor has wreaked havoc with his adrenal system  and caused his sodium levels to drop to life threatening lows on numerous occasions when he has lost consciousness. We have had to take many scary ambulance rides in the last few years  not knowing why he was so deathly ill  so we are grateful to have finally learned the reason. Because of the location of the tumor  it will be a delicate surgery. We are hoping they can go in through his nose and sinuses to reach it  but due to its larger size  it may require going through the skull. He is scheduled with Dr. Oyesiku at the Emory Department of Neurosurgery and will also be undergoing a neuro opthalmology exam  and further tests with the endocrinologist as well. We will post updates as we receive more information.We do not yet know what the total for surgery and related costs will be  but we were told by Tiffany Jackson at Emory's Neurosurgery Financial Aid that it will probably be over 100 000 and that the hospital will require payment prior to the surgery. Thank you for your time and consideration. We hope to be able to pay it forward in the near future!Please share this link on Facebook or any other social media if you are moved to do so. Every bit of help is appreciated :-)Blessings to you and yours  Deb GulliverUPDATE 3/26:Darren saw Dr. Oyesiku and his staff at Emory today.  He definitely needs surgery...specifically a transsphenoidal adenomectomy.  Due to the large size of the tumor  and the fact that it has compromised both the optic nerve and the pituitary gland  it will need to be done soon.We are extremely grateful for ANY help given...Thank you so so much!

storyTitle: Help Olivia Wright and her Family
story: Livie Wright is a wonderful  precious little girl who is very sick right now.  She was admitted to the Children's Hospital ICU on February 2nd with two viruses  and strep  and pneumonia!  The team of doctors are considering treatment options and some surgical intervention is going to be required to help clear her lungs so that she can breathe properly and fight back against all these illnesses.  It is likely she will spend a week or more in the ICU at the hospital.  Livie's parents and older sister have also been hit hard by flu and strep so this is an incredibly difficult ordeal for all of them.  Livie's parents work at a private Christian school and will be facing large medical bills.  Will you please help take that pressure off of this family by donating toward the medical expenses that will remain uncovered by their health insurance?Thank you so very much

My name's Samson  I'm a trans man that's been on hormones since June 2017. The next step  the biggest step  of my transition is getting top surgery. Life's been quite a wild ride since coming out  but I've been withholding from starting a fundraiser for quite some time now. I've been telling myself that surgery can wait until I have stable health insurance  that it can wait until I earn the money myself or until the government covers it. None of these things are going to happen soon enough. Will I die without this procedure? Absolutely not  but I can assure you that my quality of life will immediately ring at a much more vibrant frequency. I can't really fit into words what it would mean to me to have a chest revision done. I simply want to see the skin over my heart heal. I want to heal. Our government is taking an even darker turn against my people. If you can't donate  then please just listen to our cries. We are here.

Hello friends and family. Our sweet friend Sonia has been diagnosed with cervical cancer. The good news is we caught it early. Her doctor wants to do a laparoscopic hysterectomy ASAP. Unfortunately we don’t have health insurance at this time  however we are applying and waiting for approval. We are asking for financial help to pay the $7000 deductible (if we get the insurance) and $3000 to pay the bills during her recovery time (she will be out of work 4-6 weeks) I will also be taking time off to help her while she’s healing up. The monthly insurance payment is $700 a month which will be hard for us to come up with as well. Anything at all would be beyond appreciated. If you can’t donate  please share! Sonia has a heart of gold  and spreads joy to anyone she meets. Please help us restore her sparkle. Thank you.

Today is the day  it’s bone marrow transplant day!!Rosie was diagnosed with a rare Leukemia in May of 2018. Rosie has been hospitalized a majority of the past 7 months.The recovery will be another 6 months to a year. The funds raised will be used to pay for health insurance and medical expense.

Thank you for taking the time to read our story.  I have started this GoFundMe campaign for my sister Sandi.  This past Christmas while being treated for a life-threatening bleeding ulcer  she was diagnosed with Stage 4 Pancreatic Cancer which has already metastasized to her liver and lungs.  She is 42 years old. Surgery and radiation are not an option  and chemotherapy is the only treatment possible.  Her Oncology team planned to begin the most aggressive chemo treatment available more than a month ago.  But in the past several weeks  she has been hospitalized twice  for more than a week at a time  for serious complications due to the rapid growth of the tumor/cancer  and has had to endure numerous surgeries and procedures. This has unfortunately weakened her to such a degree that the doctors now can only treat her with the mildest form of chemotherapy  the first session only able to begin one week ago.  Her strength and health have deteriorated quickly. All of these things have significantly reduced her time left with us.As you can imagine  the hospital bills are piling up. Even with good health insurance  the costs of her medical care and medications are extensive. We  her very small family  are providing for her all of the care  comfort  and necessities of life that we are able to .  She doesn't ask for much  but we are having trouble providing the things that she needs - much less the things that she would be so grateful to have to make her last months more comfortable. Items such a special memory foam mattress pad to make all the time she must spend in bed more tolerable  proper food for her very specialized diet  message therapy to ease the pain of her poor aching body  wheelchair  adjustable or hospital bed  many many medications  and of course the hugely expensive cost of doctors and healthcare.Then there are the things we'd love to do for her if we could. For example:  one last trip to Disney World (in a wheelchair of course)  a trip to Myrtle Beach to see our younger sister graduate from college in May  a Spa Day to make her feel pretty again  see a ballet  last family portraits  etc..  But we can't provide these things because due to a very unfortunate  ill-timed turn of events  the main financial provider of the family was laid off just last week because of downsizing in the company he worked for.  This makes it a challenge to even pay the mortgage  utility bills  food  and normal expenses of life. The rest of the family includes our mother who works 6 to 7 days a week (but in seasonal job which hasn't yet started back up for this year)  a younger sister still in college  and myself- who works two jobs. We're doing the best that we can and \getting by\"  but your help would be so very appreciated. So that we can afford the extra things that would make Sandi more comfortable in her final months.  We are very thankful for any amount you can afford  and if you can't donate monetarily  we are grateful for your prayers.  And if you are comfortable sharing this campaign with those in  your own circles  we will appreciate it very much.Please let me know if you have questions  or if you would like any additional information.I will also be sending updates through this page  to let you know how your generous donations are being used.Thank you so very much and God Bless."

My girlfriend Lauren needs help getting moved back to St. Louis so she can get the support she needs to get well. Lauren moved out to Logan  Utah to start classes in the fall of 2017 with the intent to get a doctorate.Her troubles started before we moved her to Utah  and they have compounded since being in Utah.Her life has has become greatly destabilized due to the poor care she received while being in school. She is now unable to work in the University or outside of it  putting her at risk of losing her apartment  cats  and health insurance.

storyTitle: My beloved sister's battle with breast cancer
