I would’ve never made it without the endless love you’ve shown Zoey and I and I’m forever in your debt.Jen

Pat had oral surgery in August 2018 to remove a cancerous tumor from his lower left jaw.  His jaw was removed  replaced by a bone in his leg and then a skin graft was performed from his thigh to replace a portion of his left cheek.  He spent 20 hours in surgery  instead of the six to eight hours originally expected.  A little over a month after surgery  he started his radiation treatments  totaling 32 in all.  The recovery from the surgery and radiation has taken a lot out of him but he is slowly recovering day-to-day as he goes to speech and physical therapy twice a week.  He is happy to say that he is officially CANCER FREE and is now focusing on the healing process.  He is asking for some assistance to help pay for the expenses associated with what health insurance did not cover.

A little bit about Mandy… Mandy is kind  compassionate  selfless  and endlessly optimistic. She handles life with true grace  and until she lost her hair  many people would never have guessed what she has been going through. She continues to spread brightness and joy to all those around her. Caring for others is part of who she is  and no illness will ever change that. But now  she is the one who needs some help  and any contribution would mean the world to Mandy. First  the blood disease… For the past 3 years  Mandy has had a rare disease called Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)as well as Aplastic Anemia. PNH is an acquired  life-threatening disease of the blood  which is characterized by destruction of the red blood cell  blood clots  and impaired bone marrow function. For Mandy  this means she experiences frequent infections  easy bleeding and bruising  headaches  fevers  blood clots  abdominal pain  and back pain. PNH is such a rare disease that even the experts do not know what causes it or the best way to treat it besides a bone marrow transplant. Mandy has participated in 3 separate medical trials  the most recent of which was in February 2018. Finally  this trial showed signs of working! Her bone marrow improved. At the same time  after a long wait  Mandy also found a bone marrow donor through Be the Match  an organization that matches bone marrow donors with recipients. This was great news we had all been waiting and praying for. Unfortunately  any possibility of a bone marrow donation had to wait  because something new became the main concern. Now  the cancer… In March  Mandy was diagnosed with Bladder Cancer. This is very rare at her age  but her doctors believe that the blood disease made her susceptible by compromising her immune system. It is stage 3 bladder cancer because it goes through the full thickness of the bladder  but it has not spread outside the bladder. Due to her blood disease  she cannot do the IV chemotherapy that most bladder cancer patients undergo. Mandy has to take chemo pills  which are less effective than IV chemo. She also gets radiation on her bladder. Meanwhile  she continues to take her trial drugs for the blood disease. Now  she is starting her 4th  round of chemotherapy and radiation on Friday  November 23rd.  The costs… Despite all this  Mandy still works as a CNA  taking care of other people when she is not busy receiving medical care for herself.  She has been fortunate enough to have been given a grant from Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation to cover the once or twice weekly doctor visits and blood draws. The grant also reduces the cost of other expenses  but after health insurance and the grant  she still has to pay the following:·     $218 for chemotherapy drugs every week ($965 per month)·     $8 700 per round of radiation (4th round starts soon)·     $500-$900 bladder scans every 6 weeks·     $1 500 bone marrow biopsies every 3 months·     $1000 per Emergency room visit every few months·     $350 dental treatment for gum disease due to chemotherapy·     $1600 root canal (not from chemo but still important) To add to the expenses  at the end of October  Mandy had her car broken into while she was picking up her trial meds. Among the stolen items were her winter coat  backpack  chemo drugs  and even her medical journal. Needless to say  the financial burden is immense. If you are able to help  any contribution makes a difference and would mean a great deal.Endless thanks Mandy’s friends and family

storyTitle: Liam began his life with end-stage renal disease
story: ￼Our son  Liam  was born full-term in what we thought was a normal delivery of a healthy child.  Soon after his arrival  he began to lose weight and showed little interest in feeding leading to a visit to Nemours in Orlando at the age of three weeks.Liam is now three months old and has since been diagnosed with end-stage renal disease  microcephaly  and partial agenesis of the corpus callosum.  Prior to his three stays in the pediatric intensive care unit and three visits to the emergency room  Liam suffered a stroke due to dehydration caused by his kidney disease.  No cause for these underlying conditions has been identified.Liam has been home since New Years Eve and is now on continuous feeds through his feeding tube and on a regimen of 10 medications administered throughout the day until he reaches 22 pounds at which time he can receive a kidney transplant.Despite having good health insurance  Liam's medical bills have been coming in daily from a number of providers and hospitals and are beginning to pile up.To make matters exponentially worse  during Liam's inpatient stay  mold was found throughout our home which was purchased just three years ago.  We were told that the home is unlivable until the mold is taken care of and this mold could be the cause for Liam's conditions.Two homeowners insurance claims have been denied and we now are incurring costs of mold assessment to identify the species which could be impacting Liam.  We will need to have all mold removed from the home by a mold remediation company  which will require partial reconstruction of the interior of the home  as well as the roof (the source of the water issues)  and the duct work.We are raising funds to make sure Liam is healthy  grows to 22 pounds to get his transplant  to identify whether this mold is the cause of so many ailments from which he suffers  and to assist in removing the mold in a manner which is safe and allows Liam and our family to get back into some new state of normality.  We appreciate everyone who has reached out with support and who has been on this painful journey with us for several months now.  We are hopeful that 2019 will bring something positive and the tide will turn.

Praise the Lord!! Shana got amazing results today from her Pet Scan. The cancer is contained in her right breast and lymph nodes. She will have three more chemo treatments  then reevaluate the cancer again. Shana is in a lot of pain with her bones aching and is extremely tired. Please pray for her to have energy for her two boys and be able to make it through each day. Thank you!!!! Shana is feeling every prayer and is humbled by your love.CANCER ☠️!! Why??!!Shana Sanders  age 27. Was diagnosed in December 2018 with Her2 positive stage 3 breast cancer in her right breast  under her arm and in her lymph nodes. Shana will begin treatment this coming week (1/21/2019) Having an MRI  Petscan  as well as a Port-o-catheter surgically placed.  Shana’s chemotherapy will start on Friday 1/25/19. Chemo will be once every 3 weeks for four treatments (12 week total). Shana’s chemo treatment will be a very aggressive.  Followed by double mastectomy.  As well as reconstructive surgery.Shana has no health insurance or disability insurance. She just started a new job as well as helping us out at Southern Grace Salon when she can. Shana is very positive and has said multiple times that \Jesus has a plan.\" She is wanting to share her story to help others as she goes through this unbelievable time in her life. This is the Shana we all know and love. Shana is a very private person  No one has asked me to do this for them. Shana is loved by everyone that meets her. She has a heart of gold  a great listener  loyal friend  wonderful sister and loving daughter. Shana has been the only parent to her two beautiful boys their entire life. Brayden age 7 and Camden age 4. Not only the burden of high medical bills  but daily bills will be a struggle for some time.  Power  water  daycare  medicine. Join me and all who love Shana to support her in anyway we can. Southern Grace Salon will have bracelets as well as t-shirts. All proceeds will go directly to Shana.  Team Shana all the way!!"

On February 2  2019  David Minor suffered a medical emergency that resulted in life-saving emergency surgery  observation/recovery in ICU with 24 hours medical care  tests and an extensive stay in the hospital. In another 2 weeks or so  he will undergo another surgery.Although he has health insurance  the medical bills and medication costs are extensive and your contribution will help with the hardships he’ll be facing for some time.We all know that David Minor has helped and touched all of us in a positive way.  Now we all have an opportunity to return the help and generosity he has shown us.  No one is obligated to contribute  only if it within your hearts to do so.  No amount is not too small for our dear friend and colleague David Minor.

Kelly was diagnosed with Poly Cystic Liver and Kidney Disease 13 years ago.  It all started with a doctors visit due to extremely high blood pressure and during a scan of the heart they caught a glimpse of the liver seeing cysts. They sent her to a kidney doctor since high blood pressure can present from kidney issues.  It was then she was diagnosed with PLD and PKD. Through the years her liver cysts grew at a steady rate while the kidney cysts  to date  have remained small. We were told there was nothing they could do to stop the growth.  With this disease the liver continues to function while the cysts fill the liver causing it to grow larger and larger.  The liver starts consuming the space in the abdomen pushing and squishing all the other organs. It is painful and a normal life becomes more and more difficult.  A normal liver weighs 3# to 4#  at time of transplant on Feb. 16  2019 Kelly’s weighed 50#!The hospital expense alone for this surgery is in excess of $500 000. Kelly does have health insurance that will help with this and other medical expenses. However with high deductibles  co-pays  and existing medical bills these medical expenses add up. She will be out of work for 4 months or so if all goes well. The short term disability only pays 60% of her salary plus she has to pay her portion of the the health insurance directly. She will have twice weekly travel expenses for lab work and doctors visits  and has been told occasionally she will need to stay nearby the hospital. Kelly’s family and friends have decided to put her case on GoFundMe to spread word about her transplant and for people to keep her in their thoughts and prayers as the process continues. Anything contributed here will be gratefully appreciated in Kelly’s honor and to her family and friends who are by her side every step of this process. Updates will be posted here for everyone to follow as well. Thank you you for your prayers and support!

It’s with a very heavy heart that we inform you that our mother  Patricia Whitehead  is very ill. Patricia took herself to the Emergency Room on December 26th  because she felt that “something wasn’t right.”  Upon arrival  she was immediately admitted to the hospital  where it was determined that she is suffering with 95% blockage of the main artery feeding her brain.  She was taken into surgery  and unfortunately suffered a stroke while the surgeons were attempting to place a stent in one of the many blockages she has.  Currently she is stable  and they are letting her rest and get stronger in an effort to attempt a second stent procedure this coming Friday  January 11th. Patricia still faces many challenges ahead of her.  Her children have started this Go Fund Me account to ease some of the financial burden.  As many of you know  her livelihood is “Up a Creek” bar and she has no form of health insurance.  It’s come to our attention that her home will also require extensive work in order to provide a clean and healthy environment  upon her return home. Please HELP US as we do our best to help our mom  in this time of need. We ask that you humbly share this link with friends and family  and if possible  donate.  Any amount will help  as she will not be able to return to work in the foreseeable future. Mom has put on hundreds and hundreds of fundraisers for other people over the years between the Rodeo Inn and Up A Creek  hopefully that can be reciprocated in her time of need.  We thank you for your support  love and prayers  and will continue to update this site as we learn more.

I’m Julee  a single mother to three amazing school age kids living in Texas.  In Dec 2015 I found the courage to leave a bad domestic situation after 18 years of marriage.  I had been a stay at home mom for six years.  I returned to the workforce and moved my kids to a new home where we began a fresh start as I went through a stressful divorce.  The divorce was final in Nov 2016 and their father chose to not maintain a relationship with them  which has been heartbreaking.  These challenges brought the kids and I closer together and for the first time in their lives we were truly happy and enjoying life. My reasons for EVERYTHING!!!In Jan 2018 I was laid off from my job of 2.5 years and found myself without income or health insurance for the first time in my adult life.  I began looking for a job but but noticed I struggled - I wasn't feeling quite right.  In Mar 2018 I realized my abdomen was swollen and hard.  I had difficulty moving and was winded easily.  Going up the stairs in my home was nearly impossible. I became weaker each day.  I could no longer look for a job as I was too sick to work.  I finally went to a cash pay primary care physician in May 2018 who ordered an ultrasound of my liver.  Within two days of my ultrasound the doctor called and said my swelling was due to ascites (fluid buildup in the abdomen) caused by liver failure.  This diagnosis was odd to me - considering I seldomly drink alcohol.  I was then sent to a Gastroenterologist who told me I had cirrhosis based on the ultrasound report and prescribed Lasix to reduce the swelling and sent me on my way.  The first month the Lasix worked  and I lost 30 pounds  but that fluid quickly returned  and the medication stopped working.  I visited the Gastro doctor two more times.  He said because I was uninsured he would not run tests to determine the root cause of my liver problems due to the cost.In July 2018 just as I was trying to get my health figured out  our downstairs AC unit quit working in the middle of a brutal heat wave.  It would cost $6000 to replace and I did not have that kind of money.  We made do without AC for the remainder of the summer.   With unemployment running out and more expenses on my hands I had no choice but to push through my illness and return to work in August.  I was fortunate I quickly found a good job close to home.  I took a pay cut  and the job is temp to perm  but I’m thankful to be employed.   Six weeks after starting my job  the pain and discomfort became more than I could bare. I decided I had to pay cash and go to the ER to get the fluid drained.  I took Friday September 14 off work and little did I know my life would change once I walked into that hospital.Before and After having 9 liters of fluid drained from my upper abdomen in Sept 2018.I was immediately taken for a CT scan of my abdomen and parsentesis (draining of the fluid in my abdomen).  They were able to retrieve nine liters of fluid from my upper abdomen.  I could suddenly breathe and felt like a new woman. This elation would be short lived.  After returning to the ER from my procedure I was admitted to the hospital.  Not long after getting up to my room a hospital doctor came in and matter of factly said to me \Your liver isn't causing your problems.  You have ovarian cancer.\"  I must have looked like a deer in the headlights  but this doctor didn't seem to notice.  She said they saw a tumor on my CT scan and think is had spread to my lung that I need to see an Oncologist as soon as possible.  I spent less than 24 hours in the hospital and without insurance the bills are already up to $30 000 and more bills arrive every week. The fluid drained while I was in the ER went through pathology testing and amazingly had no cancer cells in it.  In order to begin treatment they need cancer cells to determine the type and stage of the cancer.  I was now left with only one option...surgery.  A surgery the hospital will not schedule if you do not have health insurance.I was finally able to obtain health insurance through the temp agency I am working for.  My policy doesn't go into effect until Nov 1.  I will have to meet my $6000 deductible for 2018 and come January 1 I'll have to meet the deductible yet again for 2019. My doctors have planned ahead and are ready to begin treatment as soon as my insurance goes into effect.   I'm scheduled for surgery on Nov 2 to obtain tissue samples for biopsy  drain my ascites  install my port for chemo and do some general exploring to see what is really going on in my abdomen.  After 2 weeks of recuperation during which I won't be paid for my time off work I'll go through six rounds of chemo and eventually a hysterectomy.  My goal is to hear I have NED (no evidence of disease) in six months time.Though some days I feel so bad I can barely get out of bed I have not called out sick from work at all. Being a contractor  I only get paid when I'm working  and I need to keep working to provide for my kids and maintain my insurance which the monthly premiums will be lowering my paychecks as well. I've had to swallow my pride and reach out asking for help.  In addition to our usual living expenses I now need to pay off enormous  medical bills  purchase a new AC unit  pay property taxes   and the holidays are rapidly approaching.  I want the holidays to be extra special for my kids this year.  They have been so patient and understanding that Mom has been out of commission for most of this year.  I also need to find a way to get to California to visit my 95 year old grandfather who can't travel to visit me.   I don't know what the future holds  but I do know I want to make more memories with the people I love most.I'm trying to maintain a stress free lifestyle  however this financial burden makes it impossible.   If you feel inclined to contribute financially I would be most appreciative.  I understand if you are not able to contribute financially I will gladly accept any prayers or positive vibes you can send my way.   Thank you in advance for your support."

I am beyond sad to report that Ted passed away peacefully on Christmas Eve  with Stacey  by his side.  Thank you all for your continued support and love for his family. My brother-in-law Ted Kegelman is being treated at Tufts Medical Center for heart failure. He had a long arduous surgery on Thursday  12/20/18  and suffered complications. He is now on Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and Impella life support.  We are praying for his recovery! If you would like to help my sister Stacey  during this time  with medical expenses (over and above health insurance coverage)  as well as the cost of travel and hotel costs in Boston during his stay at Tufts  please give to this fund.

This is Rebecca Frayer  a 20-year-old high school senior in special education. She lives with her parents in Sarasota  Fl  who work modest hourly wage jobs  and her dog  Belle. She loves art and is very proud of the ribbons she won for her art at the county fair. She’s been looking into future career options and has an interest in Physical Therapy and Art. She even has a gift trust for her future education  but that money will now need to help pay for her medical needs. After complaining of mild pain for a few days  Rebecca suddenly had severe pain and was rushed to the ER where they found a large ovarian cyst. The mass must be removed immediately and it’s unknown yet if a hysterectomy will also be needed. Surgery is scheduled for December 13th and Rebecca currently has no health insurance. Her father was just able to sign her up for basic insurance that starts in January  but it does not cover any surgical procedures. Though they are of modest income  Rebecca and her family do not qualify for Medicaid. The hospital estimates a total bill of $60 000 plus the surgeon’s bill is $2 400. The surgeon must be paid up front and the hospital requires a $20 000 down-payment by Monday  Dec. 10th. Rebecca’s trust has $14 000 available and she desperately needs your help to get the remainder. She only has 3 days to get $8 400 more for the down payment or the surgery will be canceled until the money is paid. This is an immediate need. After the surgery  approximately $40 000 will still be needed.Thank you for your assistance.

storyTitle: Help Lisa fight second battle with NH Lymphoma
story: My name is Lisa. I am a health care worker  single mother of one very incredible child  and am currently undergoing cancer treatment for the second time. What scares me the most about this second fight is the real possibility I may not survive the financial devastation caused by this illness.I was first diagnosed with stage four Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma in 2015. I had multiple tumors  many of which were sticking right out of my body  and I was terrified.  Despite my unwavering faith in God  a very positive attitude  and strong determination to overcome all challenges  I remember begging God “please just let me live long enough to see my 16-year-old son graduate High School.” With the Grace of God and much love from friends and family  I did get to see my son graduate and go on to get accepted to an outstanding college.I went into remission in 2016 and began a new mission. I have always chosen jobs that focused on making a difference in the lives of others.  I had previously worked teaching and coordinating school programs for low-income  high risk children  and as an AIDS prevention outreach worker in poverty-stricken areas  but now I wanted  to “give back” for the outstanding care I received from the doctors  PA’s  NP’s  and other staff that saved my life. So I returned to college to study medical terminology and have worked for the past two years at a medical center front desk helping support more than 400 patients and medical staff weekly.   Once again my life took and unexpected turn; a recent check-up and biopsy revealed my cancer had returned. As a result  I began treatment for Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma and multiple tumors on March 21st  2019.  I will be out from work for two to three months and have no other means of income. Even with “good” health insurance  the staggering cost of cancer treatments  labs  scans  co-pays  co-insurance  transportation  lodging  prescriptions  along with two months of regular living expenses will total more than $15 000.While I know I need to focus what little energy I have on enduring the horrible side effects of this cancer treatment and staying positive and strong in the face of this disease  I am instead consumed by worries and fears of whether I will be able to financially survive this illness.  It is for this reason I am reaching out for financial support.I greatly appreciate any help you can offer at this time. My hope is to be able to return in a few months to doing what I love most  making a positive difference in the lives of others through my work in healthcare.With Love  Gratitude  and Blessings to you Lisa

storyTitle: Help Jack Pay Emergency Heart Surgery
story: Jack Copenhaver is my neighbor. A great guy and always around to help. Recently  he had a heart attack and five stints to repair the damage. What I didn’t know was that he did not have health insurance and was one month short of qualifying for Medicare. I know he appreciated us calling 911  but now he is saddled with this unbelievable bill. Jack would be reluctant to ask for help  so I’m doing it for him. Any help from family  friends or others that are willing to help would be greatly appreciated. If you have any questions feel free to contact me and thanks for your generosity

Kerry is a Christian  wife  mother of 4  and an important part of her work family.  With a heart of gold  Kerry is known for always putting everyone else's needs before her own.  Always calm  cool  and collected no matter what life throws her way.  In January 2019  Kerry was diagnosed with cervical cancer.  The news was surprising  yet she remains positive and focused on her recovery.  On February 4th  a PET scan and MRI showed the tumor was contained but it has spread to the lymph nodes in her pelvis.  Due to the size of one of the lymph nodes  chemotherapy will begin on Valentines Day and will take place every 3 weeks for 12 to 18 weeks.  Radiation will begin immediately after for 5 days a week for 7 weeks.For years  Kerry has maintained good health.  She's very conscious about eating and drinking right.  As she starts this journey  she's researching foods that will help nourish her body as she undergoes treatment.  Friends  family and coworkers are constantly sending her information and goodies to help as well.  We are all aware of the financial burden any sickness can cause.  Without health insurance  Kerry will endure additional costs.  This page was created to help with the financial needs as she goes through this journey.  Updates will be given as we embark this journey with her.  Thank you for your prayers and support!  Keep them coming!

With the new year came some bad news. As of February 12th  2019 my dad  Tom Brittan got diagnosed with stage 4 pancreatic cancer. The doctors are treating this cancer very aggressively but after moving to Colorado this was the last thing our family expected to happen. We came here with the  anticipation of engaging in a better life that had less stress  anxiety  and more fishing.Although this is a difficult time for our family it has brought us all closer  we have all pulled together to help out at this time of need. My dad was working full time before his diagnosis  but as of right now he is going on disability and has health insurance  unfortunately we are not sure how long his health insurance will be valid. Making the cost of his treatment unknown. He has already acquired large out of pocket cost for medications  copays  uncovered treatments  etc. due to this we are reaching out to family  friends   acquaintances  and fellow patriots for your love  support  and having his back through this difficult time. Please feel free to share  push this message out to help my dad through his treatments.Follow him on Facebook (Tom Brittan Jr.) for any updates with him and how his treatment is going.Anything helps! And all donations are more than appreciated ❤️

Rachael Ballengee  my beautiful friend and amazingly talented massage therapist  has been out of work for some time because of a mass found on her brain.  She does not have health insurance   many of my self employed friends can understand this scenario.  Physicians have not given her definate diagnosis or treatment plan as of yet. Rachael wants to come back to work and get back to her normal life but her pain & the medications she must take make it difficult for her and she is not allowed to drive.    Some of Rachael's friends wanted to start this gofundme to help out with expenses because the bills still come rolling in .  Rachael is a loving and generous soul that gives all she has to others and never asks for anything in return.   I love this sweet woman.  If you feel led to help  I know your generosity will be so appreciated.   Thank you..You can also help by sharing this  if anyone can get it to some BTI graduates and former faculty members   that would be awesome.

Jaxson Jay was born at 27 weeks weighing just 1lb 7oz as a result of a two-vessel umbilical cord.  Jaxson is now fighting for his life at UH Rainbows Babies and Children’s Hospital in downtown Cleveland  Ohio - approximately one hour drive from their home in NE Ohio where Natalie and Josh are also raising two young boys.  Natalie worked up until the day she was rushed to downtown Cleveland for surgery to deliver Jaxson and Josh continues to work several jobs to support the family and maintain health insurance.  They could use our help in this great time of need.  Please consider making a donation to assist this family with their medical  travel and any other expenses as they do everything they can to maintain a normal life for their two boys at home and give as much love and strength to little Jaxson to help him survive.Thank you for your consideration.  God bless.

Season's greetings  all! My name is Fiona Polk  your humble would-be fundraiser  and the lovely lady in the green sweater beside me is my mother Adele Polk  a former language teacher at Woodbridge Senior High School. During the last few months Mom has had a number of serious health issues  including a minor heart attack  kidney failure  massive fluid retention and  at one point  slipping into a diabetic coma. These problems resulted in three hospital stays in as many months; after the proverbial dust settled  Mom had had a stent  a pacemaker  and a catheter put in. Now  not only does she have to take 10 different types of pills in addition to her insulin  she is required to go to dialysis three times a week  and is now too weak to go outside without a walker.Obviously Mom can no longer work with all of these handicaps/health issues. Unfortunately  she has used up all of her paid leave  which means we are not receiving any income. Furthermore  since she has no paycheck to take a premium out of  she no longer has health care through work. We are in the process of applying for Social Security/Disability and Medicare/Medicaid  as well as regular and disability retirement pensions - but as almost everyone knows  getting paperwork through the bureaucratic system takes a long time.That is where this GoFundMe comes in. Bills and drug prescriptions don't pay themselves  especially if one does not have health insurance (did you know without insurance insulin costs over five hundred dollars? I didn't). We are several months behind on almost every bill  including the mortgage  and as the days grow ever colder  losing any one of our utilities would make a hard time exponentially harder. Any amount of money you can give will help. If you find yourself unable to donate due to hard times of your own  rest assured I understand completely -  sharing this campaign with some friends or family will help just as much. All funds will go to paying utility and medical bills  as well as food  gas and prescriptions. Remember  every little bit helps  so do what you can as soon as you can; I can only sweet talk the debt collectors so long.Thank you so much for taking time to read about our troubles. Merry Christmas  and Happy Holidays!

To our beloved friends and family  we are humbly asking for your kind and generous donation in support of Freddie Jimena. He was hospitalized on October 7  2018 due to unforeseen brain aneurysm and stroke. To date  he is still at the hospital recovering from surgeries and procedure he underwent. He will be going through rehabilitation treatment after being discharged from the hospital and unfortunately not all medical expenses will be covered by the health insurance. We the family of Freddie Jimena appreciate and thank you in advance for your generosity and support through this difficult time.

storyTitle: Get a chair lift for Kate
story: This is my sister Kate. As you can see  she has a genetic deformity in her legs. Unfortunately  she does not have health insurance so she can't get her legs surgically repaired.  Kate is a pet sitter  so her mobility is very important. Kate lives in a house with stairs. Her bedroom is in the basement. To get to the kitchen and the rest of the house  she has to climb 12 steps. This has become increasingly difficult and painful.  We are asking for donations for a stair lift so she can have access to her entire home. Any help will be greatly appreciated.

Kerry is a Christian  wife  mother of 4  and an important part of her work family.  With a heart of gold  Kerry is known for always putting everyone else's needs before her own.  Always calm  cool  and collected no matter what life throws her way.  In January 2019  Kerry was diagnosed with cervical cancer.  The news was surprising  yet she remains positive and focused on her recovery.  On February 4th  a PET scan and MRI showed the tumor was contained but it has spread to the lymph nodes in her pelvis.  Due to the size of one of the lymph nodes  chemotherapy will begin on Valentines Day and will take place every 3 weeks for 12 to 18 weeks.  Radiation will begin immediately after for 5 days a week for 7 weeks.For years  Kerry has maintained good health.  She's very conscious about eating and drinking right.  As she starts this journey  she's researching foods that will help nourish her body as she undergoes treatment.  Friends  family and coworkers are constantly sending her information and goodies to help as well.  We are all aware of the financial burden any sickness can cause.  Without health insurance  Kerry will endure additional costs.  This page was created to help with the financial needs as she goes through this journey.  Updates will be given as we embark this journey with her.  Thank you for your prayers and support!  Keep them coming!

storyTitle: Get a chair lift for Kate
story: This is my sister Kate. As you can see  she has a genetic deformity in her legs. Unfortunately  she does not have health insurance so she can't get her legs surgically repaired.  Kate is a pet sitter  so her mobility is very important. Kate lives in a house with stairs. Her bedroom is in the basement. To get to the kitchen and the rest of the house  she has to climb 12 steps. This has become increasingly difficult and painful.  We are asking for donations for a stair lift so she can have access to her entire home. Any help will be greatly appreciated.

I have been honored with knowing David Axelrod for almost a decade and in 2017 he became my brother-in-law. He is one of the most caring and compassionate people I know. David has always gone above and beyond to help others. David has always struggled with medical issues. He was diagnosed with a brain tumor when he was 13 years old and  due to this  had brain surgery. David has struggled with neuromuscular issues and chronic pain throughout his life. He has been to several specialists and finally  about three years ago  David was given a definitive diagnosis of Stiff Person Syndrome.You may be wondering  “What is Stiff Person Syndrome?”Stiff person syndrome (SPS) is a rare  progressive syndrome that affects the nervous system  specifically the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms may include extreme muscle stiffness  rigidity and painful spasms in the trunk and limbs  severely impairing mobility. Spasms can generate enough force to fracture bone. https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/5023/stiff-person-syndromeSince SPS is so rare  there aren’t any organizations dedicated to fundraising or support. SPS is progressive in nature and David will continue to deteriorate as he gets older. David currently struggles with completing everyday tasks like using the stairs  carrying items  picking up items and getting up from a seated position. David has very intense sleep cycles  which cause him to fall asleep easily and be difficult to wake. David has slept through smoke detector alarms before  which I am sure you can agree is a very scary situation. There are not many treatment options for the condition. David was receiving a treatment multiple times per week through IV injections but unfortunately developed severe side effects last year  which caused him to need hospitalization. David takes several medications daily to help manage the condition but none of them will help reverse the condition or help him live a normal life. One thing that would help is a Service Dog. A service dog would allow David to maintain his independence and provide him with companionship. David has been a dog lover for many years and he grew up with dogs. The service dog will be trained to assist David with his needs and help him to continue to live independently. David is connected with a local training organization to ensure that the dog is properly training to assist David with his needs and become the quintessential service dog.Unfortunately  service dogs aren’t covered by health insurance and to properly train a service dog can cost upwards of $30 000. David has already been looking at potential matches through local rescue organizations. The optimal companion would be an adult large breed dog around 2 years old.  We are hoping to help David with some of these costs so we can make this a reality for him.Thank you for all of your support!

My name is Nicole  and I am coordinating / creating this on behalf of my Aunt and Uncle for my father - David Gomolski - and their business - Millgrove Service Center.  Here's what's going on... ~~~Our youngest brother has gotten frostbite on his hands / fingers  picture (GRAPHIC) in 'updates'.   Due to this he's been in the hospital since January 22nd.  Because David only has 20% of his stomach left due to Cancer a few years back  he has encountered some complications with recovery.  He was recently put on a ventilator in the ICU due to Pneumonia and previous scarring on his lungs (from when he was much younger). With that being said  we are humbly asking for help.  We operate a family run business in Auto Repair.  With David being stricken down  we must continue to pay his health insurance.  Being that he's family  we have not been able to run the business as usual.Bills are piling up  we are getting apprehensive and  overwhelmed with the fact that David is in this condition.  Our main focus has been on prayers for our little brother.Anything that anyone can do would be of tremendous help at this point  and help to lift this very heavy burden.Humbly we ask thru Jesus our Christ...

My Deborah has stage four cancer of the abdomen. Her surgery on August 20th revealed that her ovaries and other organs were affected. We are now scheduled for more surgery at the Hillman Cancer center in Pittsburgh. I have exhausted my savings and all other sources. I myself am out of work do to a pulmonary embolism on July 15th. I won't be released to return to work until December.I would like some help to cover the expenses of my financial obligations  plus the expenses to stay at the \Family House\" while Deborah undergoes a 10-12 hour surgery and 14 days in the hospital for observation. This will be starting on November 14th In order for us to prepare for this trip  I need the help to cover bills such as: Rent. car payment. health insurance and hotel and car. Please help me help my Deborah."

storyTitle: Help My Dad Back on His Feet!
story: We are raising money for our father  Tim Love. Tim is a father of two  and husband of Sandi. He has a loving grandson  who he would love more than anything to take on the baseball diamond. He is the proprietor of Love That Music! in Kernersville  North Carolina and has been a staple of the Kernersville community for over a decade. Tim has been active in the Kernersville community  sponsoring music at the Factory  local venues  and annually for the Spring Folly since 2008. After a recent major setback we are trying to raise funds for a hip replacement.            For a couple years Tim has been diagnosed with End Stage Avascular Necrosis of the Right Hip (bit.ly/AVNecrosis) the damage has gone untreated and is progressing into the left hip. As the disease has progressed  the pain has worsened greatly  and all the joint cartilage has worn away  leaving a highly painful bone-on-bone condition that makes it difficult for him to walk and perform even the simplest tasks.  At this point  too the grinding of bone on bone his right leg is over a full inch shorter than his left. This has caused compensation in his gait causing degenerative cartilage damage in his right knee that also needs repair. As many know and have seen  he has been experiencing degenerative symptoms for near half a decade or more. Since 2013 dad has been without health insurance.In May  2018 he went to see a local orthopedic surgeon in Kernersville.  Upon examination of his x-rays the surgeon exclaimed “That’s terrible! How do you walk?”  The surgeon commented that the disease had progressed to end-stage  and that joint breakage was a high possibility.  The surgeon informed dad at that time that he and Novant Health partnered with a national charity organization called Operation Walk USA.  The doctor also informed that he was Novant’s representative to the charity and that he needed a candidate to put forward for 2018. The doctor took one look at dad’s X-Rays and upon seeing the severity of the decay  told him “you’re my candidate this year.”  Surgery was scheduled for the week of December 3  2018  and in the words of the surgeon “if you make it until December”. Dad was referred to the office manager  emails and cell phone numbers were exchanged  and the process toward a hip replacement appeared to be initiating.  However  after two months only silence was received from Novant. Dad followed up with Novant  finally to be informed that Novant would not be participating with the charity due to “all the sign-offs required from the higher-ups\. This was a devastating blow to the family having the solution ripped from our hands. This was ultimately the last straw as all hope for getting back to mobility seemed to be fading quickly.Since this turn of events dad has resorted to using a cane to assist walking. Most days at the store are more than he can bare. Facing pain that would make normal men weep  he refuses to take strong painkillers  only on a strict regimen of Ibuprofen to help take the edge off. However  despite this  he can barely climb into most any car to drive. On long drives the pain causes him to pull over so he can stretch out. These are things most folks do not see when they come into the store because he is hell-bent on keeping things normal.The money from this fundraiser will go to helping replace Tim’s hip. Right now he is in contact with the Costa Rica Medical Tourism board. This is a JCI recognized hospital specializing in procedures such as this. The cost is lower  thus more feasible for folks in situations. (A lot of employers have started sending their folks here for services too) Any surplus funds will be used for sending a helper (one of kids) with him as proxy in case god-forbid that is needed. Anything beyond that will be used either for knee surgery OR to help pay it forward to someone else in need.We just all want to see Tim back on his feet and your help either in sharing or contributing is the blessing we need!"

A yellow Labrador puppy  currently nicknamed Tiny Tim  was born with a defective leg. The breeder took good care of him but it’s been determined that the leg can’t be saved  but Tiny Tim is destined for big things! The breeder agreed to let the little guy be a great learning tool as well as go into training to become a Therapy Dog for a local school. The kids at the school will get to learn all about how working dogs are trained and what it takes to care for one. Even better  the babies special needs will help inspire students with special needs and will help generate empathy and understanding for those with special needs i our community. Unfortunately  while the breeder donated him to the training program  the little guy’s special needs come with a few price tags. The goal of this campaign is to raise funds to cover his leg surgery  to fix his umbilical hernia (his mom kept messing with his umbilical cord sutures)  and to cover his doggie health insurance and training so he will he free to the school he’s assigned to.*** the total fundraising goal has been lowered a little due to a wonderful donation. VetriScience  a veterinary supplement company  graciously donated $10 000 to cover the cost of his surgery with a specialist!!! That means everything else we raise can go towards his training  medical insurance  and future needs so that he can be donated to the school without giving them any burden for his care. How amazing is that?!?
