storyTitle: Help my husband Win over the Cancer
story: Hola Dios te bendiga   mi nombre es Leidy Dávila   mi esposo es Jairo Dávila   estamos casados hace 27 años  Dios nos bendijo con tres hermosos hijos  David  Daniel y Dominique. El 17 de septiembre de este año  nuestra vida cambió drásticamente   puesto que ese día llevamos a mi esposo de emergencia al Hospital  ya que en siete días dejó de caminar y no podía hacer sus necesidades fisiológicas   pensábamos que era una simple hernia discal y resultó siendo lo que menos esperábamos  un cáncer que oprimía su médula espinal   metástasis que venía de la próstata. Decidieron operarlo de emergencia  puesto que las consecuencias podían ser graves y no garantizaban que volviera a caminar. Han pasado tres meses  he visto cómo Dios  está haciendo milagros en la vida de mi esposo   sus piernas se están recuperando  los tratamientos médicos están evolucionando y sus médicos se sorprenden. Sabemos que es Dios quien está obrando.Debido a esta causa mayor  de las cuales sus piernas aún no responden del todo y al impedimento de no poder trabajar es que acudo al apoyo de nuestros amigos y a cada uno de ustedes que Dios ponga en su corazón bendecirnos y ser parte en este proceso de recuperación. Confío en Dios que este cáncer se va del todo de su cuerpo y que estaremos bien recobrando nuestra vida y felizmente seguir adelante  trabajando y sirviendo  a Dios.Necesitamos $10.000 para su tratamiento que no cubre nuestro seguro y gastos que conlleva esta enfermedad. Mil gracias  por bendecirnos y le pido a Dios que te multiplique esta ofrenda.Hello and God bless you My name is Leidy Davila and my husband Jairo Davila has been married for 27 years now. God blessed us with three beautiful children  David  Daniel  and Dominique. Our life had a drastic and dramatic change on September 17  2018 because that day we took my husband to hospital with a severe medical emergency. He had not been able to walk for seven days and could not do his necessary physiological functions. We thought that it was a simple spinal hernia but the results were something we could not even imagine; a cancer nodule that was pressing on his spine. The root of the problem was a metastasized prostate cancer that made the situation even worse. The hospital immediately decided to take him to operation table because things were getting worse and they couldn't even assure he would walk again. Three months has passed and I have seen how God is working his miracles in my husband’s life. His legs have been recuperating and the medical treatments have progressed and his doctor has been stunned with the case. We need to know God has been doing what he does best. Due to how severe his legs were his legs are not still at 100% and his legs don’t allow him to work. Yet thanks to the support and help from our family  friends  and all of you that God has led you to help us and join us in the process of healing. I trust in God and know that this cancer will be completely healed. God will restore our lives and happily move forward  working for and serving God. We need $10 000 for his treatment that is not covered by our health insurance and living expenses that his disease brings. Thousand of thanks for blessing us and I want God to multiply whatever donation you give.

Ola pessoal  estamos aqui para pedir sua ajuda para Paulo De Melo nesse tempo difícil. No dia 31/10/2018 ele passou por uma cirugia no cérebro  e foi diagnosticado com um  tumor maligno glioblastoma no estagio 4. Des da cirugia ele esta impossibilitado de trabalhar  e sua esposa tem que cuidar dele e sua filha de dez anos. E o plano de saude não cobre todo o tratamento. Com o ocorrido inesperado eles precisam muito de ajuda para sustentar a casa e os medicamentos caros. Também estamos pedindo suas orações pela a saude dele neste momento. Nos ficaremos muito grato a todos vocês quem puder nos ajudar.  Dear friends and family  we created this GoFundMe page to ask for your help for Paulo De Melo in this difficult time. on Oct 31st  2018 he went through a surgery on his brain and was diagnosed with stage 4 Glioblastoma. Ever since the surgery occurred Paulo has been unable to work and his wife as well to take care of him and their ten year old daughter. His health insurance won't cover all the treatments. Because this happened unexpectedly we ask for all the help we can get to help support their family and the medical expenses. We also ask for prayers for Paulo and his family during this difficult time. We are grateful for any amount that is given to help. Thank you.

storyTitle: My Son Kevin's Battle withOsteosarcoma  Cancer
story: Approximately five months ago my youngest son  Kevin noticed a small lump inside his mouth near his upper gumline. His doctor diagnosed it as an infection and prescribed antibiotics several times with no positive results.      Eventually Kevin was referred to an oral surgeon who performed a biopsy of what had tripled in size. The biopsy was sent to the Mayo Clinic and Kevin was referred to Dartmouth Hitchcock. It was there where the lump in his mouth was diagnosed as Osteosarcoma (bone cancer)     The tumor in his upper jaw is very aggressive and is considered life threatening if left untreated. The first step for treatment will be a potentially life threatening 8-10 hour surgery on Dec 19th to remove the tumor which will include part of his upper jaw  top teeth and a portion of his nose. He will then require bone grafts  plastic surgery skin grafts and new teeth along with speech therapy. All of which will be very expensive and not all covered by health insurance. We won't know until after this first surgery if Kevin will require chemotherapy and/or radiation treatment or further surgeries.     Kevin has a great support system of family and friends in place and is doing his best to stay positive. We as a family are all praying for a positive outcome from surgery and as speedy a recovery as possible. I'm asking of my family and friends to please share this post or donate anything you can to help cover medical bills  his stay in a rehab facility  homecare etc. Please pray for my son during this difficult time.Thank you Sandy Russell

storyTitle: Zap Medical Debt of a Stranger for the Holidays!
story: Hi  Pals! Let’s surprise someone with debt forgiveness for the holidays!! Radical gift giving! $10 donation can clear $1 000 of medical debt for some lucky soul. It’s true - read this NYT Article:  https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/05/nyregion/medical-debt-charity-ny.html   Give what you can  no matter how small. If you can’t give  send good vibes. And please SHARE.  :)Let’s forgive some medical debt! - Stacey and DianaWATCH JOHN OLIVER’S VIDEO EXPLANATION HERE:  https://youtu.be/hxUAntt1z2cRIP Medical Debt is a nonprofit whose sole purpose is to locate  purchase and then abolish the unpaid medical debt of folks put into collection. RIP buys bundled debt portfolios for pennies on the dollar and then pays off the debt - with no tax consequences for the recipient  and it clears their credit! LET’S BRING SOME FOLKS THE GIFT OF DEBT FORGIVENESS FOR THE HOLIDAYS!!! More below....READ HERE ABOUT  ‘RIP Medical Debt’: https://www.ripmedicaldebt.orgWhy Medical Debt?• 43 million Americans now owe about $75 billion in past-due medical debt.• More than 1 in 3 Americans struggle to afford the cost of their medical care.• Medical debt contributes to more than 60 percent of all bankruptcies in the USA.• 75 percent of all individuals in medical bankruptcy had health insurance coverage.• Until resolved  medical debt lingers on one’s credit report  negatively impactingthe ability to buy or rent a home  buy a vehicle  get a loan or get a job.• People with medical debt tend to avoid medical care to prevent additional debt.

Chuck just had heart surgery.  I know he has health insurance but I'm not sure what will be covered.  I know he does not have the sufficient PTO to cover the 6-8 weeks he will require to recover.  He has a couple of weeks accrued  but that won't last long.  Thanks for your help.  ~Andy  Chuck's supervisor.

Hi  My name is Sally-Grace and I need your help. I broke my wrist tripping out of the bathtub on my way to work. The ER told me to immediately go to an orthopedic surgeon. That's where I learned I will need surgery. I have no health insurance through my current employer. I will not be back at work for 8 weeks. My Costumers at the food court where I work miss me and I miss them! Due to loss of a paycheck I need funds for the surgery needed to get my wrist back into working condition. The bills keep coming (rent  phone  car  etc.)  but I am at a loss and I turn to your kindness and support. Keep me in your prayers. You are in mine.

On Wednesday  October 17  2018  Tamekia and her friends and family celebrated her being a 3-year Stage 1 DCIS Breast Cancer Survivor. The next day  Tamekia had her appointment with her oncologist. At this appointment  a mass was discovered on Tamekia's right lung. A chest scan was conducted which led to an MRI of her brain. A body PET/CT scan soon followed which confirmed the presence of the mass  but also indicated her lymph nodes as additional areas of concern  and pointed to a \hot spot\" on the right side of her tail bone. A bone biopsy was performed on Monday  October 30  2018. The following Monday  November 5  2018   Tamekia and her husband met with her oncologist to discuss the biopsy report. Her oncologist informed them that the results of the biopsy were not good  concluding with a diagnosis Tamekia was not expecting  Stage IV Metastatic Breast Cancer. Shortly thereafter  Tamekia began an extremely aggressive treatment plan. This plan includes daily chemotherapy medications and monthly bone and ovarian suppression injections. In addition to the medication and injections  Tamekia will need future tests and scans to be performed in order to monitor the progress of the treatments and the growth of the tumors.  Tamekia is provided top-notch health insurance by her employer  but even so there are co-pays  deductibles  and some treatments that just aren't covered. As of Monday November 12  2018  Tamekia has incurred approximately $10 336.39 in medical costs and expenses.  These costs and expenses are only Tamekia's initial expenses to begin her  aggressive treatment plan prescribed by her oncologist.  In addition to this enormous medical bill  Tamekia is on an all organic - no carb/sugar diet. Tamekia is currently scheduled to have more tests performed in the upcoming days/weeks so that her oncologist can decide on the best method for surgical procedures needed regarding her right lung  right ovary  right breast  and right side of her tail bone. It is Tamekia's understanding that she can only be treated for the cancer on the right side of her tail bone which should keep it from spreading. Even though Tamekia has met her medical insurance deductible for the year  she still is responsible for the $10 336.39  in addition to all other daily medical expenses and lifestyle changes due to her recent diagnosis. Tamekia's medical insurance year will start over on June 1  2019  which will cause Tamekia’s co-payments for prescription medications to then cost anywhere from $300.00 - $1 200.00 until she meets her yearly deductible.  Tamekia's friends and extended family  along with her children  husband  mom  and brothers are asking for your thoughts  prayers  and any financial support you can offer to assist them during this difficult time. Please feel free to use this website to donate and help Tamekia and her family with her current and forthcoming medical bills  costs  and expenses. During times like these  Tamekia needs to focus solely on her recovery  not on how to afford her treatments. Tamekia and her family would also like to provide a mailing address for alternative donations of items needed such as gift cards to Publix  Trader Joes  Shell  Exxon  or general Visa gift cards. This address is: Tamekia Hunter RossPO Box 3398Sumter  SC 29151-3398Tamekia and her family are forever grateful for your prayers  generosity  and compassion as they continue to fight for a speedy recovery!! Much Love  -Tamekia's friends and family"

Twelve years ago  Kirby had a lung transplant at UAB. Since then  Kirby has been thriving  happy  healthy  enjoying life  and being Pops to all his grandbabies.  On the afternoon of April 6  2019  Kirby fell off a 10 foot ladder while working in his yard  a favorite hobby of his. He was getting the back yard ready to install a pool for his grandbabies.  Kirby was ambulanced to Ocean Springs hospital where they determined he had broken his sternum  his ribs  his back  and his pelvis.  Before we left Ocean Springs to come to Birmingham Kirby was intubated after several failed attempts to get his breathing under control. OS Hospital and UAB also tried to coordination Life Flight  but could not due to the heavy fog. So after a nearly 5 hour ambulance ride we arrived at UAB. The Drs here quickly got to work. He was admitted into the trauma intensive care unit. They are currently doing a bronch to clear his lung of a mucus plug  we know he has a small pneumothorax which at this time does not need a chest tube  and that the pelvic breaks are a bit more extensive than previously thought and surgery for that is a possibility. We are currently waiting on more CTs. He has been sedated since the intubation and he is on heavy pain meds. His wife  Barbara  is staying with him in Birmingham for his treatment  but they need your help. Kirby and Barbara have health insurance  but it will not cover everything. UAB determined they owe a $2500 deductible on top of any treatment that he may receive. Barbara cannot work while staying with Kirby. She will need help with food  lodging  and transportation.  Please help in any way you can. All prayers  thoughts  and donations will be greatly appreciated.

storyTitle: Chipping Away at Chantel's Medical Debt
story: What do chronic illness  the government shutdown and LinkedIn strategy have in common? Well  they are all topics I address in this video. Refusing to file for bankruptcy  I plan to continue chipping away at the debt I've created from the diagnosis and treatment of my MS without health insurance. After exhausting our financial assistance options  there is still debt to be paid. Also  with the government shutdown  we are now on week two without income from my husband's Federal Officer career  making money extremely tight!That is why I plan to offer LinkedIn strategy and coaching for donations! Let's jump on a one-hour call to strategize and I'll let you decide how much to donate. Is it work $100 or $5000? You decide!

I'd like to thank anyone that takes the time to read this as it's most difficult to write.  My husband  my best friend  and Grandpa to 5 little ones was diagnosed 2 weeks ago with Mantle Cell Lymphoma.  MCL is a rare type of cancer of the lymphoid cells; it is an aggressive B-cell type of Non Hodgkins lymphoma.  70% of patients are first diagnosed with advanced stage (stage IV) in where the cancer cells have spread into masses replacing the lymph nodes and spread to other organs.  This is what happened with Shane.He went in for a \scope\" after visiting two emergency rooms complaining of a sore throat.  Both emergency rooms dismissed him saying they didn't know what it was but to contact a physician for a scope.  Shane did and they found that cancer was located in both his tonsils  neck and esophagus (GE Junction) as well as under his arm pits and in the stomach lining.We visited Mayo Clinic last week and the prognosis was relatively positive aside from what the survival rate is. There is no cure for this cancer and the odds of him beating chemotherapy and radiation are good with a 2-5 year survival rate; we know with the great doctors we have at the West Michigan Cancer Center and Mayo Clinic - we're going to with God's help surpass that. Shane was told that we needed to start aggressive chemotherapy and radiation immediately as this is aggressive which is what we are starting next week (November 13th) with our Cancer Center.  He is looking at having to go to U of M every 6 weeks spending 3 days there rotating with spending 3 days at another clinic for radiation.As of last month Shane had to leave his employer due to chemotherapy and radiation treatments.  Health insurance did not cover 90% of the local emergency room visits nor the extra fees of treatments or the physician. Our insurance did not cover a week's worth of treatments at the Mayo Clinic in MN either and now we are facing treatments of chemo and radiation - again - not covered.We learned that because Shane did not have short or long term disability - he doesn't qualify for anything.  The Unemployment Agency told us that he won't be able to qualify for Unemployment either because the State of Michigan has requirements that he MUST go look for employment while he is claiming. This is something that Shane can't do because he will be in chemo and/or radiation 3 days straight - I'm not much on asking for help; but as his wife I run an in home child care full time; and well there just isn't much there to help pay these bills.  We know that the bills are going to pile up and with my husband not being able to collect Social Security  or SSI disability there is no way to pay these medical bills. We're pleading with everyone - if you know of any organizations to help with medical bills  or if you can help in anyway - we'd so appreciate it more than you know.  All monies collected will go directly to the medical facility or provider and we will gladly provide proof of this if needed.Again - thank you for taking the time to read this -"

storyTitle: We Are Turning the Corner on Beating Cancer!
story: April 9  2019:We are truly in need of your help  please.   For those of you who have donated (thank you again) and those of you who have not...Please realize our situation is an urgent one.    Soon to be working again after having suffered years of abuse at the hands of my former employer  which many of you witnessed firsthand  we are turning the corner on beating cancer!  Your kindness in caring is helping me keep our health insurance (a must!) and literally putting food on our table.   People throw so much away...spend huge moneys on dinners out....overpay for drinks...etc...while we are struggling.It's awkward to ask  but those of you who know me know I would help if the situation was reversed and that it is necessary I reach out.Please help as I have helped so many.I am very grateful.Thank you for your kindness and caring.gf.me/u/qyx5t3Love from  Steve  Eva  Megan and Morgan UPDATE:Finally some good news in our fight against cancer!Eva had her second major surgery a few days after Thanksgiving.  There have since been two additional procedures and WE HAVE TURNED THE CORNER IN THE FIGHT AGAINST THIS MONSTER!There is much pain and aftercare  but she IS doing better so there is some light at the end of the tunnel.I am reaching out again to those of you who were kind enough to care about me and my family when you contributed to my Go Fund Me campaign  to ask for an additional donation  please...and those who have not yet donated.Though soon to be employed  many of you know I left a long-term abusive employer...which left me in an urgent and dire financial circumstance.Medical and related costs have exhausted all savings.   Maintaining our health insurance  which just increased another 9%  is a must  as medical bills were otherwise over $250 000 with more to come.Many of you know I have always generously given to and supported the fundraising efforts and needs of over 125 charities as well as schools  temples  churches  hospitals  foundations  etc..and individuals and the community at large. Folks can always count on me for support.  Thank you to each of you for your kind words letting me know the countless number of lives that  I have positively effected and helped make a difference for.I still need to get Morgan an insulin pump.  This will greatly greatly help his ongoing diabetes treatment and allow him to feel more like a kid again… And to feel more like all of his friends and the kids around him in school etc.He has an amazing soul and spirit and my 12 year old daughter Megan with her kind heart and compassion has been extraordinary!There has been so much trauma associated with Stage III cancer…My kids asking \will mom be ok?\"... \"is mom going to live?\" and \"how long is mom going to live?\" and \"are you ok  Dad?\"I stay as steady and strong as possible for all of them.The costs not covered by insurance…prescriptions  for example  that have been many many thousands and thousands of dollars...(chemo medication and other medicinal supplies for my wife and for my son) have been astronomical.The treatment she is receiving has  thus far  kept her alive.EVERY DOLLAR DONATED NOW MAKES A HUGE DIFFERENCE TO ME AND MY FAMILY. Thank you for your kindness and for your caring. We are very very grateful.We are winning the battle and you helped!Steve  Eva  Megan and Morgan"

storyTitle: My Lung Cancer Medical Treatment Fund
story: My Healing Journey.It's no longer a secret or private illness when you post on social media. Realizing that  my prayers is for those of you who read this to please continue to respect our family's privacy and space  in the details.Recently  I was diagnosed with Stage IV Lung Cancer. This diagnosis came as a result of several biopsies  MRIs  bloodwork  CT Scans  and increased physical pain over the last few months. The Love and Support coming from my Family  and you all cannot be expressed in words. Thank You.  First and foremost  I am a Christian and full believer in my Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. His healing is all ready declared in my life through his voice and his word. (Psalm 91)  This IS a celebratory moment in this story! Praise God! As a mother of 4 beautiful children and wife of 22 years  I AM BLESSED! My husband is a educator and gifted Track Coach. I have ran my own business for 15+ years.  God has used this as a vehicle to provide greater sources of income  time freedom (to be home and heal)  and a better quality of living just to name a few.  For those who know my heart and humility  I will also say we have not arrived yet.  Gods abundance is never capped and we are grateful beyond measure to watch it grow. What we have learned through this journey of healing is the cost associated with the best medical care available.  Treatments  medicines  facilities  prescriptions  and all associated cost are met primarily by out of pocket cost. The rest through my health insurance. For those who have a desired heart to give and can  your donations are appreciated.  ALL donations  will be applied to medical cost associated with my treatments.  Let every penny  nickel  dime  and/or dollar you give be blessed with respect to all religions. I pray in return for Gods increase in every area of your life.  If  you don't have the means to give  it's ok. Prayers don't cost a thing!! Our God hears every single one of them!In closing  I thank you for your prayers  support  love   and unshakable faith. I understand your sadness  but please don't have a pity party. I don't want that for you.  I know this is extremely difficult for us all.  My strength grows with your prayers  belief and conviction as we watch my miraculous testimony unfold. I look forward to Living out GODs calling in my life and to share my healing with the world! Join me in that victory together!With All the the Love in me Kimberley Royal#CancerSurvivor*ALL donations by donors will be kept private and anonymous.  Donor information will not be disclosed. Thank you

Beatriz Montes  is a parent beloved by her church community  her Kids Unlimited Academy Community and her Southern Oregon community.  Beatriz and her husband have served  their delicious Taco Pancho food to not just their paying customers  but anyone in need.  Beatriz's beautiful and generous spirit can be experienced  not only in her food  but in the faces of her five beautiful children and her beautiful smile.   3 months ago Beatriz lost her sister to cancer.   A week ago Beatriz learned that she too has cancer and it has moved from her colon to her liver. Beatriz can not access health insurance. This go fund me page will serve as a critical source of financial support she and her family will need to offset the mounting medical costs.  Please share this page with as many as possible and do what you can to support this woman we all love so much.

storyTitle: Rachael Needs Surgery- Road to Recovery
story: “We all get by with a little help from our friends. Hey guys  I’m Amelia Travis - founder of Stoked Yogi  colleague and mentor to our friend  Rachael Croll. Do you know how it feels to struggle  to be alone in the face of adversity  and to have to ask for help? It’s not easy. And it takes a strong woman to do it. Out of the blue in the middle of March  Rachael ruptured her achilles tendon. As a solo entrepreneur in the yoga and paddle board business  this is a devastating injury. In summer 2018  Rachael found out she had invasive malignant melanoma  and with grace and patience she navigated surgery and mounting medical bills - despite not having health insurance.Rach has a long road ahead: Surgery  4-6 months of recovery time  and physical therapy.  She is committed to continuing to employ local yoga teachers to run classes for the community. After kicking cancer at 30  this is a rough follow up. It feels like insurmountable challenge - but none of us have to go it alone. If you're reading this  we need your help! If you have the ability to give $1  $5  $10  or whatever you’re capable of - you’re not helping Rachael to pay for the vital necessary surgery she needs immediately  but you’re keeping Rachael's beautiful  community based business - Salty Buddha - afloat so it can continue to spread loving kindness throughout the gulf coast of Florida. Rachael is a balance in beautiful opposites: her easygoing nature is complemented by a crazy badass work ethic that keeps her moving  shaking  and showing up for her community daily. As the owner and founder of Salty Buddha Yoga & Paddle Co.  Rachael literally shows up and serves the Anna Maria Island community and visitors the goodness of yoga  breath work  connection to nature  and her sunny disposition every. damn. day. She works with a smile and takes the time to stop and have real  meaningful conversation with every person she comes contact with. Rachael has a way of making every human feel special - like you're totally groovy  even in the darkest hour. Rachael Croll is my friend  and if you’re reading this  she’s your friend too - even if you don’t know it yet. And by supporting this cause:You’re doing your random act of kindness for the day/week/month.You're making a statement that women owned businesses deserve support. You're making emergency surgery possible for someone who desperately needs it!Most importantly  you’re agreeing that we belong to each other. THANK YOU for having the heart to help someone who would help you with every breath she has. We love you and appreciate you. If you can't donate  you can still help! Please share!**** BELOW is Rachael’s STORYI bought a longboard skateboard thinking it would be another fun way to cruise around my beautiful island and be active outside. I used to have one back in college and it was always so fun and freeing to cruise around campus. I’m also just a sucker for boardsports... it’s sorta my passion. I got my shiney new longboard and took it out for her first cruise. The roads were a little slick cause it had been raining earlier. But I was too excited to notice. I’m loving my board and cruising around  next thing you know I take a misstep off the front  and the nose of the board crashes into the back of my ankle. It wasn’t a gnarly wipeout just a huge crack and pop noise as the board slammed into my ankle. I keeled over in pain... unsure if I could walk back to my house. I made it back  hobbling with tears in my eyes. I have a pretty high tolerance for pain. But when I got back to my house  I laid on my bed in fetal position and sobbed loudly. The pain was unreal. I debated going to the doctors or not because I don’t have health insurance and I didn’t want to spend a few hundred bucks to be told to ice and elevate my foot which is what I was already doing. A few people told me not to waste my time  if I tore something it’d be more black and blue or I’d be in more pain. I did some research and performed some reflex tests on my calf and ankle. I started feeling the back of my leg  foot  and ankle. Comparing one to the other. As I followed the big thick tendon that moves from your heal to calf (Achilles tendon) mine stopped. And it felt almost like there was a hole there. My research told me that the worst case scenario for an injury like this was that my tendon had ruptured and that I would need surgery. I listened to my intuition  made an appointment directly with an orthopedic doctor and he confirmed my self diagnosis. My Achilles’ tendon had ruptured. I need surgery. As I sat there tears began to fall down my face. 5 minutes before I had explained to him that I run a paddleboard business and just opened a yoga studio space and that my whole world- work  passion  and play all revolve around being active and using my legs. As he was explaining to me the pros and cons of surgery and that I’d be off the water and out of the studio for the next 6 months... I couldn’t stop the tears. He was so kind  and looked me in the eyes and told me I’d get through this. He had so much empathy... what a miracle I happened to get him as my doctor. So I cried and he held my hand and we let it sink in for a few moments. Then off I went to get a cast  simultaneously receiving so much information about what my life would be like the next 6 months I felt dizzy. All I could think of was-  I cant work for 6 months. I don’t have health insurance. How on earth am I going to get through this and not end up living under a bridge. Between the MRI and doctors consult and cast  I’m already out hundreds and hundreds of dollars. The surgery and the necessary physical therapy I need  will cost thousands and thousands of dollars. I’m a single  self-employed woman. The monthly cost for me to have health insurance is astronomically high. I thought that after all I’d overcome last year... that there was no way I’d have another crazy medical emergency... I was wrong. Life is so unexpected! Last Year- 2018:8 months ago  after listening to my intuition that a spot on my body looked funny  I visited a dermatologist and was diagnosed with invasive malignant melanoma. A very aggressive and fast moving cancer. My tumor was a level 3 out of 5 in depth and was growing at an alarming rate. They took a big chunk of my stomach out along with the tumor and sewed me back up with over thirty stiches. My doctor told me that had I waited just 3 more months we would have been singing a completely different tune. I had caught my cancer just before it could compromise my lymphatic system and travel to other parts of my body. I got lucky. I caught it. And they got it. I’m still making monthly payments toward my medical expenses and surgery for kicking melanomas butt. Cancer stuff isn’t cheap when you pay out of pocket. Three months after I healed from my cancer journey  I stepped on an oyster bed and gashed my foot open. There was serious concern regarding infection and I went through three rounds of antibiotics along with getting ten stiches in my foot. Off the water and unable to do the work I love... again. I was sad  but it was only a minor setback. A couple weeks... I could deal.But this.... 6 months. 180 days of not being able to do the things I love most. One half of a year. It breaks my heart. I know I’m here on this earth to do the work I’m doing. I know that I will learn and grow in so many ways I cant even imagine over these next few months. But I’m devastated I can’t get out there and interact  guide  and teach. Because it brings me SO much joy. I will stay strong and positive  but I know that I cannot endure this journey alone. I will need help. I will need to lean on others. I will need to call upon family and friends.  I’m open and grateful for any support and help I’m fortunate enough to receive. MUCH LOVE

Hello friends  and family. Im reaching out on behalf of my friend Cesar Fernandez. Cesar and I met in high school and have been friends ever since. I was his best man when he got married  and I’m godfather to his amazing son Max. Cesar was recently diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma. He’s begun his sessions of chemo  and is staying strong during his treatment. Both Cesar and his wife Rosie have good jobs with health insurance  and have always been financially responsible. Unfortunately as some of us know  your never ready for something like this. Mentally  financially  or physically. Cesar has a hard road ahead of him  but I know he’ll get through this. This is my attempt to ease some of the financial stress that just comes with cancer. Unexpected trips to the ER  insurance deductibles  etc. Anything you can contribute is greatly appreciated. Thank youDanny

Imagine getting \that\" call...that unexpected call that always comes at THE most inopportune time with devastating family related news. That is what happened to our family last Wednesday when we got a call saying that our father  Marc Placeres had had a seizure and was being rushed to the hospital  the subsequent MRI revealing a golf ball sized tumor in his brain. The family rushed to his side at the Mayo Clinic in Lacrosse  WI from across the country in time for him to wake up from the brain surgery to remove the mass. Unfortunately  our worst fears were realized and then some as the mass was not only not benign  but was a rare  and the most aggressive form of brain cancer  a Glioblastoma. This particularly heinous form of cancer likely wasn't even there 3 months ago when Marc started getting persistent headaches  which illustrates how rapid this sort of tumor can develop. The skilled doctors at the Mayo Clinic removed what they could  but were unable to remove it all due to the nature of the disease and unfortunately he has been diagnosed as terminally ill. We'll get to his story in a bit  but first a bit more context of the scenario. Marc recently changed jobs and unfortunately had a lapse in health insurance coverage. His seizure took place on 27 March 2019 followed shortly by subsequent surgery and oncology appointments in the next couple of days. In a cruel twist of fate  his insurance coverage started on 1 April 2019  too late to save him from the astronomical prices of that level of care. In spite of his new company’s efforts to help him out  they were unable to get him covered by the insurance company  and now as he is unable to work  he doesn't have health insurance at all. We have applied for Medicare  and Social Security Disability insurance  however that only amounts to a pittance of the total costs accrued. Now onto the man that Marc himself is  and the legacy he must unfortunately leave behind too soon. He immigrated from Argentina accompanied by his sister and parents seeking asylum from political unrest at the time and  out of gratitude for the country who helped save him  he joined the Marine Corps where he served active duty from 1977 to 1981 and continued with the reserve unit until 1993.  After the Corps  he studied Mechanical Engineering at the University of Northern Iowa and continued that line of work till his seizure. He also raised 8 children  including biological  adopted  and step-children. He instilled a sense of duty to his children and three of us are veterans as well. He is also a proud grandfather of three beautiful girls and two energetic boys. This is where  we hope  you can help. We come to you  hat in hand  asking for any support you can manage to make things easier for our family financially as we struggle to shoulder this unimaginable burden. The uninsured medical bills feel insurmountable at a time when the situation even with full insurance coverage would itself feel insurmountable. All contributions will go 100% to medical bills  cost of living  and end of life care. If you choose to help out  thank you very much for your contribution  no matter how much. Words cannot adequately express our gratitude for your compassion and it is a debt we fear we could never repay. If you chose not to  or otherwise cannot help  thank you for taking the time to read this far and please do not ignore persistent headaches. Semper Fi! If you are unable to donate please share this page with everyone you know and if there is any other way you can help please contact me. More info about the Glioblastoma cancer:   https://www.abta.org/tumor_types/glioblastoma-gbm/"

Ami’s Journey Tennis...the sport that creates so many friendships. Ami was one of the first friends I met on the court. Her genuine spirit  love for animals and infectious giggle instantly drew me to her. Life happens and sometimes separates us from our game...yet friendship remains. Ami has recently been diagnosed with stage 3 colon cancer. Two years ago  Ami’s parents health started to decline  so she left her job to move in with them to assist with their needs. Little did she know  at the young age of 50  her parents would be the ones taking care of her. Ami sacrificed her income and unfortunately  her health insurance to take care of her loved ones. She will undergo a minimum of five weeks of chemo and radiation  then subsequent surgery to remove the remainder of the tumor. With medical bills rising and her pet sitting business on hold  let’s help alleviate some stress for Ami.  Please donate to Ami’s cancer fund.

My name is Barbara Cherry.  I have metastatic breast cancer that has spread to my spine   lymph nodes   liver and pelvis.   I am married to Robert Cherry and we have fought this terrible disease for 6 years.  We thought we had beat it but a year ago it came back.  The past year we have been to MD Anderson twice for tests and to help our local oncology department decide on the best treatment.   I am starting a new chemo protocol and need your help.  Because I am stage IV means that if they can keep the progress at bay I could live several years to enjoy my kids and grandkids.  My husband lost his job 7 hours away that he had had for 10 years.  We thought we could afford to take some time off to do battle with this disease but the company he worked for decided not to pay our health insurance like they said they would for a year.  So since June of 2018 we pay $1354 dollars a month for our healthcare plus all the copays for doctor visits   prescriptions etc.  and that’s before we even try to pay any bills or live.  .  We live in a small town and employment opportunities are slim thus  my husband worked away all those years.  He is fixing to start a local job but it pays practically nothing commensurate with his talents and experience.  I am not in good health and need him here with me so he is willing to work locally but it’s just not enough .  My chemo is $15k a month.   We have exhausted all of our savings fighting this disease and just trying to live this past year.  Breast cancer is a horrible disease.  Any cancer is a horrible disease.  I know they’re are millions of people who suffer as I do and there is nothing unique about me   nothing remarkable only the fact I want to fight this all I can with the most up to date treatment possible .  I want to enjoy my grandkids and have some time with them .  We are a praying family that trusts in God daily to meet our needs.  Our prayer is that someone will be able to help us while there is still time.  My husband says they’re is no such thing as a normal life   a fair life   there’s just life.  This is the hand we have been dealt and even if you can’t afford to give I at least ask for your prayers for me.  I believe God hears the prayers of his people.  Pray for us and his guidance in this trying time in our family’s lives.  Thank you for any any help or prayer  Loving Regard Barbara

￼Going back to our childhood  my best friend Dana and I would play house together as most little girls would. Dana would always pretend she was the mother of twins. Her childhood dreams were about to come true...Dana and her husband  Andrew  were expecting twins! Dana's pregnancy was going beautifully and on October 20th at 20 weeks pregnant the news came in that she and her husband would be having a boy and a girl who were due to arrival on March 12  2019. Just two short weeks later on November 4th  Dana and Andrew received the devastating news th￼at her pregnancy had taken a turn for the worse and Dana was at risk of going into pre-term labor at any given moment and possibly losing the twins. On December 1st after being in utero for only 25 weeks and 4 days  Andrew Vincent and Victoria Hope Meredith were welcomed into this world. Andrew was born first  weighing in at 1lb 4ozs  Victoria was born shortly thereafter via c-section  weighing in at 1lb 5ozs. Thankfully both tiny perfect little angels were born breathing on their own  and only requiring a cpap machine to help them. These little chickens as they are lovingly referred to are about to be 3 weeks old and are doing amazingly well despite their tiny statures. Since Andrew and Victoria decided to come so early and are considered mirco-preemies they are going to be in the NICU for months to come. Dana and Andrew do have health insurance coverage for these little ones but the co-payments x 2 will be extensive. Dana is a school teacher and has devoted her life to give all that she is to her students. She is one of the most loving and genuinely caring individuals I have ever been blessed to have in my life and her husband is just as loving and caring as she is. You honestly could not ask for better people to raise these precious little babies. I am hoping with your love and support for this beautiful family  we can help alleviate some of the financial strain they are facing so they can focus on loving their babies and watching them grow and get healthy enough to come home. All proceeds from this fundraiser will go directly to cover the twins medical costs. Any additional proceeds will be given as a donation in the twins honor to the hospital they are currently calling home to help other struggling families in a similar situation. Thank you so much for your love  prayers and support!!

storyTitle: GI Jack Leyrer is Fighting Back!
story: GI Jack is Fighting Back!A man  a son  a soldier  a fighter  a hero  a veteran  a husband  a father  a friend  a now...veteran in serious need of help.As a proud American soldier who fought in Desert Storm  Jack Leyrer dug a foxhole  had one canteen of water  very little food and spent 72 hours awake  under straight gunfire fending off the enemy.  He stayed alive and fought for his country!Jack is honored to have served his country.  He performed 20 years Active Duty and worked 10 years for the Department of Defense.  He fought in Desert Storm & in Bosnia  was on the Freedom Team  received the Bronze Star from President Bush  received the NATO metal  and put his life on the line for his fellow Americans.  He also suffers from PTSD.  Jack is a giving person and needs your help.  It’s our turn to step up and show Jack that his life and fighting for his country was not in vain.  Jack is married to Mari and they have one son  Kyle. Jack is currently living in a nightmare that he can’t seem to wake up from.  He has suffered three strokes: Stroke # 1 Valentine's Day 2014  Stroke #2 Thanksgiving 2018 and Stroke #3 Christmas 2018.  Thanksgiving and Christmas 2018  Jack had strokes that disabled his ability to function.When Jack had his stroke at Thanksgiving  he landed in Covenant Hospital.  The stroke affected him in a way that when he ate or drank he choked.  He needed rehab. Because of the type of health insurance he has and the high co-pay  the rehab place couldn’t take him so they sent him home with a visiting nurse.  He couldn’t be evaluated at the VA Hospital for two weeks.  With the assistance of a Senator Dan Kildee’s representative and Saginaw County Commissioner Chuck Stack (also a Veteran)  Jack was able to get in to be evaluated faster.  Within 10 minutes of his evaluation they knew he needed to be admitted.  The VA admitted him.Mari and Kyle brought Jack home for two days  for Christmas where they enjoyed family traditions including Kyle reading The Christmas Story.  Upon returning Jack to the VA  he had a stroke and was immediately taken to Covenant Hospital.Tests were performed and no blood was detected on the brain. Jack had surgery to repair a hole in his heart.  When Jack came out of surgery he was far worse than when he went in.  He couldn’t move his left side  couldn’t speak or walk plus he was not dealing well mentally.  The next day they performed another surgery to insert a feeding tube.  Jack was not getting better and Covenant was going to send him back to the VA.  With help and many phone calls  HealthSource seen that this Veteran needed rehab and agreed to admit him.  Now that Jack is at HealthSource he is improving.  He has a long road ahead of him.  Jack loves the staff and is getting good care.  Jack successfully took his first steps the other day!  THIS SOLDIER NEVER QUITS!Jack knows what he’s going thru is hard on his family and he wants to get better so he can take care of them instead of the other way around.  He has NOT given up. The struggle is real.  Jack’s family and friends are not giving up on him. Mari has sought help thru every agency she has been told to call and has been turned down with each one.  No one is willing to help this Veteran and his family.  Mari has cancelled cable  her land-line phone  and is trying to survive on the mere basics but is scraping the bottom of the barrel and the barrel is about to be busted up to burn for heat.Your contribution will instantly help with this serious situation.  Here’s what you can do to help!Donated money will help with:BROKEN FURNACE.  For the 2nd time this winter the furnace quit. The temp in the house is a chilling 42 degrees.  Space heaters and blankets are keeping Mari and Kyle warm.  Continued help with their Consumers Energy bill.  The shut off notice was paid by many donations last week.  Consumers threatened to shut off their heat and electricity.  Gas so Mari and Kyle can visit Jack everyday.  Their support is extremely important in Jack’s healing.Food.Frankenmuth Credit Union is prepared to accept your donations at any of its 23 branches. Just walk in and let them know that you would like to “Help Jack Leyrer” or you can mail checks made payable to FCU with “Help Jack Leyrer” in the memo line to PO Box 209  Frankenmuth  MI 48734.  They are in danger of losing their house.  Jack has filed for medical disability which can take at least 6 months or more for approval.  In the meantime  his pension is not enough to cover the house payment.Important Information:Stay tuned for details about #gijackwehaveyourback fundraiser information!We encourage you to share this post.  Jack needs your help.  The Leyrer’s need your help.  Thank you for your continued prayers and your donations.

storyTitle: Assist  Kelly Muldoon with medical/living expenses
story: My sister Kelly was diagnosed with stage 3 cervical cancer in 2012. She underwent weekly chemo and daily radiation treatments (internal and external) and fought like hell. Her remission lasted 4 1/2 years  which was pretty miraculous. Unfortunately  treatment options are limited for recurrent cervical cancer (which is now stage 4). She has undergone chemo for the last year. The damage to her body has been extensive. She has developed a fistula in her bladder that requires  surgery. Kelly has been unable to work for the last year. She recently had to resign from a teaching position she held (and loved) for 17 years. Her pain is so extreme that she’s unable to perform her job. She is without health insurance and income.  If you are able   please donate what you can to Kelly’s medical  and living expenses. She needs all of our help.

I have been diagnosed with stage 3 colon cancer and have no health insurance. We are struggling and have a smart  beautiful 15 year old daughter. In order to have a chance at recovery  I need chemo and radiation before they can operate on my tumor. This requires purchasing an insurance plan. We are grateful for any and all help — thank you

As you know  our dear friend Juan Llano had a scooter accident this month where he hurt himself pretty badly.  An ambulance trip to the ER and staying over night has racked up a considerable bill and without health insurance he could use any help from friends and family.Let's go guys!  Show your love  help us reach the goal!

For decades my high school friend  Susie  has been growing cysts which now completely cover her liver and kidneys.  She has a hereditary disease called Polycystic Liver and Kidney Disease.  Susie is faced with constant bloating and swelling in the abdomen  severe pain  and always feeling full with a shortness of breath. The only treatment available is to have her football-sized liver removed and replaced with a donor’s liver  either living or deceased.  Susie has been on the donor list for a new liver since November 2017.  The disease has greatly impacted her quality of life over the last decade  but we’re extremely hopeful that 2019 will be the year where Susie receives the long-awaited call from the Mayo Clinic for her liver transplant.In the spring of 2018  I volunteered to be Susie’s living liver donor.  I’ve known Susie since our freshman year of high school (1984 a.k.a. loooong ago!)  and while there’s been miles and years between us  we’ve maintained a genuine and lasting friendship. When I heard what she was enduring  I couldn’t help to think how healthy and fortunate I’ve been in my 48+ years of life  and I greatly wanted to make an impact and help restore her back to health.  My blood type was a match – so I headed to the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale to undergo the psychological and medical evaluations.  Unfortunately  my anatomy wasn’t favorable for a liver donor surgery.  We were both crushed  but held faith that another liver would present itself.  As Susie continues to climb the donor list  so do her medical bills! Even with decent health insurance  there are deductibles  co-pays and unforeseen expenses.  Since I was unable to donate part of my liver to my dear friend  I am on a mission to raise funds for Susie’s continual medical expenses.  Every penny will be helpful as Susie will have ongoing medical bills for the rest of her life.  Thank you in advance for your generosity and concern ~ monetary assistance and/or prayers are greatly appreciated.

It isn’t often in one’s life when you meet someone who has changed so many lives by just being themselves. My friend Janie is that person! I met Janie over 20 years ago. We met while working in dentistry together  when she was a dental assistant. She was the one who  when you go the dentist scared to death  she greets you in an upbeat manner. She holds your hand  patiently answers all the questions you have and would call you that evening to see how you were doing. Her “calling” in life was caring for people who she called “Her” patients. Anyone who worked with her knew she loved her job  it truly was a calling for her.     Fast forward 20 years later and Janie has advanced her way through the dental field by becoming a Consultant for dentists and their teams  helping them master what she was so good at. She directly had an impact on dental practices and the high quality care they delivered to their patients.      In May  my friend Janie received some devastating news. She was diagnosed with breast cancer. Over the summer months she completed her surgeries in addition to 6 weeks of daily radiation treatments. Which means she has not been able to work for over 6 months. In November she went back to the doctor for a follow up (hopefully an “all clear”) she was hit with some unbelievable news yet again. A large cyst which was there 6 months ago was completely gone  however it was hiding something very suspicious behind it that the doctors didn’t see before  possibility of more cancer. She may have to go through this entire process ALL OVER AGAIN.     Janie’s health insurance only covers 50-80% of all of these procedures  surgeries  doctor’s visits  scans  tests and 5 years’ worth of chemotherapy medications. The amount to date is staggering.      Janie is just now able to start back to work. She is a single parent household who has two teenaged children who rely on her. One who is in her first year of college and tuition is due twice a year…and the other who has medical issues  frequent specialist visits  along with very expensive monthly medications. Being able to keep up with the monthly household bills and also have the fear of losing everything  including her home  and what she has spent the last 10 years building is extremely difficult.      Janie is a very proud and independent person. I am writing this letter as a way to ask for her to get help. Janie has always given to anyone in need even if that meant she had to go without. She donates to many charities throughout the year and has even opened her home to friends who had no place to go. I know many of her friends and family have said  “let me know if there is anything I can do to help out”….I think this is where Janie now needs our help the most.Anything amount you can donate would be appreciated and would help with her increasing large bills.      Please help someone who has been a giver her entire life.

In 2016 our niece Denise was diagnosed with ovarian cancer while living in South Carolina. After being cleared and moving to Pittsburgh in 2018 to live with us  she was unfortunately diagnosed with Stage 4 Metastatic Ovarian Cancer and she is now terminal. Back in 2016 she came to find out that she was misdiagnosed and was found to have 2 types of cancer. Unfortunately the one type went untreated and it metastisized into her lungs  stomach  and liver. She has wonderful doctors at UPMC Magee and she will be seeking another opinion in March at the Cleveland Clinic. She is currently on her second chemo treatment  as the first one did not work.She is continuing to work as much as she can and despite having health insurance  getting her bills payed has been extremely difficult.

On November 14  2018  Paul was shopping at Fleet Farm in West Bend  he was feeling dizzy and decided to call his son  Derek  to tell him. Derek told him to wait there and that he would come pick him up but Paul thought he was ok to drive home (15 min drive). Paul got home and was pulling into the garage but instead of hitting the break  he stepped on the gas and went into the dry wall of the house. No major damage took place to the house. Paul doesn't remember that happening at all. Derek came out of the house and put Paul in his car and took him to the West Bend clinic to get checked out. On their way to the clinic  Derek called Paul's wife  Sharen  who was at work at the time. She met them at the clinic and was there waiting with a wheelchair for Paul. As soon as Paul sat in the wheelchair  he had a major seizure. The clinic called the ambulance who took Paul to St. Josephs Hospital.  They did a CT scan and it showed no bleeding in the brain. They needed to wait until the next day to get a MRI. He did get an MRI which showed a small tumor on his brain. He did some more tests while he was in the hospital and was told by the doctors that he needed to schedule an appointment for surgery to remove the tumor. He went home and and Sharen called to schedule the surgery. On November 19  2018 he had is surgery. It was a very long day for him and the family. The surgery was successful and they were able to remove everything except the outer tissue of the tumor which would have caused a stroke if they removed that as well. He would be going through Radiation Therapy and Chemo Therapy treatments to try to kill those cell tissues that were unable to be removed from surgery. On to recovery! The day after Christmas December 26  2018  he started his chemo and radiation therapy. He needed to go to the St. Joes Hospital for his radiation therapy everyday Monday through Friday for 6 weeks. It seemed to be helping and he was getting better. On February 7  2019  he finished his chemo and radiation therapy! Soon after that he started feeling very tired and nauseous. The doctors said this was normal and it was the treatment finally catching up to him. On February 16-17  2019 Paul started falling quite a bit at home and he lost functionality in his right arm and leg. Paul was frustrated and Sharen was exhausted. Sharen decided to take Paul to the Memomonee Falls Community Hospital Emergency Room on February 18  2019. She wanted to get him checked out to make sure he didn't have a stroke due to his weakness in his right arm and leg. They got there around 11am. He was examined by the ER doctor and was told he needed an MRI. He got that but they couldn't see anything because his brain was so swollen. They decided to give him a more extensive MRI which would show more. They did that and after   they wanted him transferred to Freodert as soon as possible but there were no rooms available in the Neuro ICU. They put him on steroids to get the swelling to go down in his brain. Finally  around 8pm a room opened up at Freodert and an ambulance took him down. When they got to Freodert and got him settled into a room  the Neuro doctor came in to see him. He showed Sharen  Paul  and Sharen's sister  Karen (who is a nurse) the MRI images from before his first surgery and the images from the MRI he just got taken that day. The tumor size has doubled compared to the tumor size before his first surgery. On February 19  2019  they scheduled his surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible for Thursday February 21  2019 and are praying for success. After his surgery   the plan is to start a stronger form of Chemotherapy. His family is really going through a hard time with all of this. Those of you that know Paul  know him as a fun guy with a great sense of humor and a huge heart. After Paul retired from WE Energies  Sharen and Paul's health insurance has really gone downhill with what insurance is willing to contribute to all of these medical expenses. Please don't feel obligated to donate. If you would just like updates on how he is doing  those will be posted here.

storyTitle: Hope for Marissa - URGENT MEDICAL TRANPOSRT
story: URGENT MEDICAL TRANSPORT NEEDED!All 7 doctors agree that moving Marissa to tertiary care hospital is VITAL! Insurance company is denying coverage of transport. PLEASE HELP! Marissa is fighting for her life. Her infections keep spreading and she is not healing. She is hospitalized  unable to work  unable to care for (and often unable to even visit ) her new preemie  and her situation is dire. Will you help?Some of you know her story. Many of you do not. Here is her story and our ask for help.Born at just 31 weeks gestation  Marissa came out fighting. She went on to develop into a beautiful  smart  talented  loving young girl. Then  at age 11  she was diagnosed with an aggressive form of Multiple Sclerosis (MS). Being born a fighter  Marissa has endured a multitude of treatments  hospitalizations  medications  and battles over the past 10 years  and has worked hard to fight her disease.Fast forward to 2018. Marissa has spent about 9 weeks of the year in the hospital over the last six months. She worked when she could  but has been unable to work since October due to her health. She is a much-loved  hard-working pediatric dental assistant.Marissa got an infection this summer  and due to her weak immune system  fighting infections is difficult. And  because she learned she was growing a beautiful human inside her  treatment options became limited.Remember when I said that Marissa was born at 31 weeks gestation? Well  guess what! Her sweet little boy decided to come early like his mama! He was born on Christmas Eve 2018. While we celebrate this sweet baby’s birth and the excellent care he is receiving  we also rejoice in knowing that Marissa’s treatment options have increased now that her baby boy is out of the womb. Unfortunately  her infections continue to spread... Please join us in praying for Marissa and her sweet boy. She has health insurance (new year  new huge deductibles)  but the financial burden is taking a toll  and adding up quickly. Any assistance in this regard is greatly appreciated!MS is her disease  but it does not define her. Marissa continues to radiate love  gratitude  and joy in all that she does. Thank you!

storyTitle: Lisa Olson's Stem Cell Transplant Medical Fund
story: My name is Lisa and I live in Kansas. I am 56 years old  married (to an awesome man  Jeff) and have two amazing children  A. J. and Scott. I also have a beautiful daughter-in-law  Hannah and the most precious grandson ever. I have family that is close to me and family that is far away that give me lots of moral support along with many friends  near and far.In 2007  after I had a lump removed from my left thigh  I was diagnosed with Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma or NHL is a blood type of cancer that is found in the lymph nodes and/or in the bone marrow.I underwent 20 radiation treatments at that time.All was good with the NHL being in remission  until 2014.In July of 2014  I went to the ER to have my leg checked out due to severe swelling.After many tests  I was diagnosed with Grade II Follicular Lymphoma. Follicular Lymphoma is a common type of NHL that is less evasive as other NHL lymphomas. I underwent 6 cycles of chemotherapy. I came through the chemo treatments with flying colors. I felt great and was able to continue to work at both of my jobs throughout treatments.In January of 2015  I again went to the ER due to swelling and redness in the right side of my neck. After a CT scan  it was determined that I had formed a blood clot around the chemo port that was in my right-side shoulder area. They diagnosed me with DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) and SVCS (Superior Vena Cava Syndrome). I underwent a surgery to help try and break up the blood clot. The surgery was some sort of a success  but it didn’t break up the blood clot totally. I was then put on a blood thinner for 3 months. After that 3 months  the blood clot was gone.In February of 2015  through at CT and a PET scan  they found a mass in my colon. I was then diagnosed with colon cancer. I had a colon resection done to remove the mass. They were able to get all of the mass but the cancer had metastasized to mesenteric lymph nodes. I then went through 6 more cycles of chemotherapy. Once again  I came through with flying colors and to this day  the colon cancer has not returned.In February of 2016  my left leg began to swell again so I went in for a CT and a PET scan. They found a lymph node that had grown in size since my last CT and PET scan. They did a biopsy of the lymph node and I was then diagnosed with Diffuse Large-B Cell Lymphoma. This type of NHL is the more aggressive type. It is fast growing as where the Follicular Lymphoma is slow growing.I went through 6 cycles of chemotherapy  in which I lost my hair and had some complications. During this time  I also lost my Father in April of 2016. This made it a little bit harder to get through  but I made it through  because I knew that is what he  my family and friends wanted me to do. My last treatment was in August of 2016.Everything was going well  my hair grew back  much thicker and curly this time. I wasn’t quite at 100%  but I was getting there. My CT and PET scans looked good up until November of 2018.In November of 2018  I went in for my 6 months checkup and CT scan. They found a mass in my left-side groin area. I went in for a surgical biopsy and it came back as Diffuse Large-B Cell Lymphoma  again.So  my plan of care and treatment will be different this time. I will be going through an Autologus Stem Cell Transplant in Omaha  NE. I have to get 2-3 cycles of chemotherapy here in Salina  then a PET scan and if everything is good  I will then travel to Omaha for the stem cell transplant. I will be there for about 5-6 weeks or longer. The first two weeks will be schooling on what to expect and a bunch of tests a long with the extraction of the stem cells. The next 3-4 weeks will be more chemotherapy and then the actual transplant. Once I am well enough to be discharged from the hospital  I will have to stay in the Omaha area for about 1-2 weeks. This is to make sure that the transplant was successful and that my immune system is working like it should.I am not one that likes to ask for help. I usually am the one to offer help when or if needed with whatever I can do. This whole process will put us (my husband and I) in a huge financial bind. As most people know  having health insurance does help  but it doesn’t always cover everything. As everyone also knows that because you have major health issues  life goes on  as does the bills  such as house payments and of course  the medical bills that the health insurance won’t cover.Any help would be so greatly appreciated  you have no idea!! If you can’t contribute  I totally understand. If you could say a prayer  that will make me just as happy. I’m a firm believer in prayers and have seen them work many times.Thank you all for reading my story and I apologize for it being so long and detailed. I wanted everyone to know the whole story.I have a moto:It’s Not About BraveryIt’s About Doing What I Need To DoBy Not Giving Up Or Giving InTo Win. Thank you again and may God bless you in so many ways!!

Miriam  or MinnaZimm to many of us  has been a tremendous ally in our goal of providing clean water for God's children in Guatemala for many  many years. She has traveled the country from border to border with her water teams  helping in so many ways. From arranging schedules  to booking trips  translating  tour guide  friend  teacher  and so much more. If we needed help- she has been there.Now- she needs our help. Miriam has recently been diagnosed with an advanced stage of cancer. Her doctor has suggested a treatment through private channels  in order to better the chances of a favorable outcome.  Yes- there is some variety of government treatment available  but those of us who've traveled those routes know that the delays and actual treatments are not likely to help us in our quest.So- With an initial estimate north of $5 000 to get started  plus incidentals as always occur  plus the reality that her work must slow or stop  we need funds. Jason Perkey from Texas and I (Richard Smith from Tennessee) are asking for your help to raise $8 000 to get this treatment underway AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.   Prayers are of course our first concern. Secondly- please share this with your friends and interested acquaintances so that we can start moving forward again with getting treatments underway!In her own words  we share this from Miriam-Unfortunately  this message isn’t a happy one.  I am writing it to share my anguish with the hope of receiving your support. On August 2018  I went to pick up lab results. When the doctor explained them  it sent me back 30 years ago when my sister gave us the news about her cancer; by then this word only meant death.Even though nowadays the fight against cancer goes on and there is no one I know who can say that do not have a friend or relative who has battled this terrible illness  it is still a frightening word.For five months  I went by myself with this burden through all the analysis I needed  looking for the less expensive way  and reading everything I could about it. Trying to find the best solution before I give the news to my family to diminish the pain and concerns for them. I also looked for advice with friends who are doctors and have their specialty on this matter I found that the best option for cervical cancer is the hysterectomy. There are two treatments cervix conization and cryotherapy to delay the advance of it. The less expensive is cryotherapy  which I am following while I put together the money to pay for the surgery in a private hospital.It was very tough to tell this to my family and still only the closest ones know about it  just imagine how hard it is to tell my friends and everybody. I have been always willing to help others but to ask help for myself it is another story.I am not covered by health insurance  I feel scared of public hospital after the experience I lived with their mistakes and so much pain I suffered from my leg accident. This is why I am humbly requesting for your financial support. I am grateful to every kind donor that chooses to contribute for my surgery expenses.Blessings Miriam

Paul was in a very bad accident around 7:15 PM tonight. I do not know all details yet but I will post what i do know that family has already shared. Paul was the passenger of a vehicle that hit a tractor with a manure spreader attached to it. Paul was Mercy flighted to Strong Hospital. He is currently going in surgery to see if they can fix his eye  but they are not sure. He also has a broken Tibia that will need surgery  a possible spinal fracture  and bleeding on the brain. I also was informed that he does not have any health insurance. So this is gonna be a blessing in any way we can all help! ❤️Heidi and her kids will be staying at the hospital as much as they possibly can  but Paul is the sole provider for their family.  Paul  Heidi and kids can use all the support they can get! I thank you all for reading this and I will updated more as I know! ❤️

storyTitle: Myriad Multiple Sclerosis (MS) Woes for Cindy
story: Hello friends and considerate strangers. In the fall of 2014  Cindy was diagnosed with Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis (RRMS)  and it came as quite a shock after a year of various tests to determine the cause of what included blurry vision  loss of balance/difficulty walking  fatigue  and extreme pain in her torso.However  this illness was not new to her as her mother was diagnosed with MS in spring 2008 and eventually passed away from complications of this disease five years later. Unlike her mother  though  from the start Cindy has doggedly fought to keep her quality of life. Despite this  various challenges have presented themselves in the past four years since being on her own after divorcing.Loss of work because of MS exacerbations during this period has led to her current financial need to cover medical expenses and housing costs. Her teaching position does not offer health insurance  and shouldering this burden on a part-time adjunct salary has drained her monetary reserves. To whittle her “life budget ” she recently moved into a room with a landlord that is proving to be unsuitable after only two months. She left this lodging on February 16  2019  and has been relying on the kindness of many to house and feed her as the arduous task of searching for an affordable room to rent in Southern California begins again.The medical bills will never stop as her MS has progressed within the past year bringing over 20 new lesions on both her brain and spinal cord. The new DMT (disease modifying treatment/therapy)  as well as other complementary treatments for her systemic scleroderma  eat up one-fourth of her yearly earnings. This has left her with little to afford the basics which include  at this point  food and housing. Again  she is extremely humbled and thankful to have had the help of a mighty army of friends that have assisted with these issues  especially in the past year.All Cindy wants to do is continue working as much as possible even though she has recently transitioned from teaching to only tutoring on her campus. Her hands can no longer grade papers for long stretches  and she is unable to stand in a stationary position for extended periods of time: Both are definitely necessary for an effective professor! Other physical issues that flare up from time-to-time include: decreased cognitive functioning  inability to drive long distances  continued torso pain  lack of vision in her right eye  and the co-morbid symptom of depression that plagues many of those with MS.In spite of all this  Cindy refuses to give up or give in because she saw what this inaction to fight brought for her mother. Cindy continues to jump the physical and psychological hurdles MS can bring in what she hopes is a dignified way. She has reached a point  though  where she is asking for even more helping hands so that she can get out from present medical bills and afford a decent place to live that will provide comfort and peace. She feels embarrassed to admit she needs this kind of help  and even if you have chosen to simply take the time to read her story  it is appreciated. Thank you  and may your life be full of as much joy and happiness as possible.
