Theryn C. Bond is a Memphis activist and political advocate for progressive candidates. In October 2018 she was diagnosed with fibroids and began treatment  but when returning from a trip over Thanksgiving she required 4 transfusions and had to be hospitalized. Then  in November  Theryn was diagnosed with Stage 2b cervical cancer. Since then  she has started an aggressive treatment plan. The initial plan was for 25 radiation sessions and 5 chemotherapy sessions. Following that  4 internal radiation sessions are now added beginning mid-February. During the first internal radiation session  doctors will assess whether further chemotherapy and surgery are required.  We all know how strong she has been for others  but now she needs our support. With these treatments  Theryn has been accruing over $1k in medical expenses each week since the beginning of January (in addition to 2018 bills for the ER visit  a week-long hospital stay  and several consultations). She still has health insurance through her employer while on medical leave  but has spent over $1500 out of pocket so far--and it is still too early to tell how long she will be on leave from work. We anticipate that she will reach her out-of-pocket maximum for both 2018 and 2019. We want to ensure that Theryn isn't burdened by a lifetime of medical debt. Her other needs (transportation  meals  caregiving  and housing) are being met by a group of friends Theryn nicknamed Barbie’s Dream Team. Theryn’s spirits are good and you know she’s a fighter!  Please show your love and concern by donating today. Feel free to share her fundraiser with your contacts via email  social media  and in your social groups. Help us get our fighter back into action!

Hi  my siblings and I have decided to start a GoFundMe for our incredible mom  Nikki Smith.This year our mom was diagnosed with breast cancer in her left breast. After many different tests and procedures  the doctors determined the cancer was caught very early and she can start treatment before it spreads into other areas. A few weeks after discovering the cancer in her left breast  they found another mass in her right breast that her initial mammogram did not pick up and was discovered through one of her MRI scans. She will now have to go through all the same tests and procedures for the new mass and incur double the expenses.Her procedures so far have included multiple mammograms  ultrasounds  biopsies  MRI scans  and genetic testing. Many tests were repeated in order to ensure a correct diagnosis. Coming in the next few weeks  she will be having a partial mastectomy of her left breast and will go through at least five weeks of radiation therapy. Following that  they will continue following up with the left breast and begin making plans for the right breast.Our mom has been very brave and has had a positive outlook throughout it all but has felt extreme stress financially. She currently works over 50 hours a week to support her family. She is a single mother with four kids: Abby  Alex  Bryanna  and Aiden. Everyone who knows her  knows she is a selfless  loving person who would bend over backwards to make those around her happy.Although our mom does have health insurance  her deductible and out of pocket expenses are very high  at $10 000 each year. She has nearly met her $10 000 deductible for 2018 already  and it will automatically reset beginning 2019. After the deductible is met  the coverage that the insurance provides will only be a portion of the total cost of treatment. Our goal is to raise $30 000 to help limit her financial burden while she's also dealing with the emotional stresses of having a breast cancer diagnosis.We’re extremely hopeful that her treatments will work in getting rid of the cancer and are hoping to do anything we can to help her physically  emotionally  and financially. We're humbly asking for any donations; even $1  $5  anything  donated will be gratefully accepted by her daughters and put directly towards her medical bills. Please donate using the GoFundMe link or at her oldest daughter's Venmo account (@abbyniccole). Thank you so much! ***February 4th: hi everyone! i get a lot of questions about my mom and how she’s doing  so i wanted to give everyone a little update! her partial mastectomy went incredibly well  her doctor was able to remove all of the cancer and she recovered quickly. she begins radiation TODAY! originally she was scheduled for five weeks of radiation  monday-friday and thankfully that was reduced to only four weeks. please keep her in your thoughts and prayers today as she begins. we are hoping she feels peace and comfort during radiation  and minimal negative side effects and fatigue. again  a huge thank you to everyone who reaches out and especially those who have been able to donate to help her financially during this time. our go fund me/Venmo are still open and any donations or even sharing the post is so so dearly appreciated. thank you everyone!

If you've clicked this link its because we all know and well can't help but love Daniel Nush. His witty sense of humor is what most of you recognize  along with his incredibly long list of random facts or details of things your average person cares zero to know.. until you find yourself wondering what size the average toilet flange is.. Don't ask me because I have no idea  but Dan probably knows. As some of you may know the morning of Christmas my dad had a heart attack. During this time they were able to place a stent that ultimately saved his life. He was put on medications to help the stent heal properly and was doing great. Two nights ago he was brought back by ambulance to the hospital because he was unfortunately not doing well. All of his heart issues are looking sound  but he was internally bleeding. This has caused him severe issues with his vitals. He's received a blood transfusion and has been underway quite a few tests etc. Lastnight he began bleeding more and was sent into a second round of cauterizations to hopefully stop all the internal bleeding and is currently in the intensive care unit.  He's in great spirts and is stable and being extremely well taken care of. My dad as many of you know is self employed and employs a few family members.. With my dad being in the hospital  he obviously is unable to work and not that it needs much explanation but we all know how expenses pile quickly. On top of it all  he does not have any health insurance something many self employed battle with. My dad is the first person to give it all  to anyone who needs it. He has an incredibly big heart and has a very hard time asking for help. (Which is why I'm doing this) any donations received will be going directly to my dad to help lift off the weight of this all. Medical bills  medications  loss of wages. Thank you so much for taking the time to click  even if you're unable to donate- The time out of your day for checking in on how he is doing is well appreciated.

Our very dear friend  brother  father  son  partner  and colleague Andre Jack Gipson or \Dre\" as many of us know him  is staying strong and fighting a long and difficult battle with Amyloidosis. As many of you may know  Dre is a two time organ donor recipient  and as part of his care  must take medication to keep his organs from failing. One of the risks of this medication is the dangerous build up of protein in the organs  called Amyloidosis.  It is when an abnormal protein called amyloid builds up in your tissues and organs. When it does  it affects their shape and how they work. Amyloidosis is a serious health problem that can lead to life-threatening organ failure.Dre was lucky enough to make it to the hospital in time to catch it back in September... but with such a rare disease that often affects the liver  nerves  heart  and kidneys  the medical bills for everything from diagnosis  to treatment  to after care  have been mounting to thousands of dollars.With all that Dre has done for the many people in his life  at home  at work  with his family  with his community and all with a smile  that scratchy laugh  and with a big heart  it only made sense for us to try and return the favor. Dre's health insurance will not be sufficient to cover everything that is needed to treat his condition. Some of the prescriptions alone will cost hundreds of dollars to fill. His best chance at fighting this condition is at Mayo Clinic  seeing the best doctors that can provide the care and treatment to give him the best chance of beating this. And those tests  treatments  and doctors visits are averaging $1000 or more each.If Andre has ever helped you out in a jam  made you dance with his DJ skills  cracked you up laughing with jokes  or went of his way to make sure \"You good? You know I got you.\" as he often says to us all  then please consider donating to this GoFundMe fundraiser to help him get through this time. And to let him know that \"We got him\" this time."

Hello friends and family As most of you may have learned from our dear Ann-Marie  late this summer she was diagnosed with breast cancer. She found the mysterious lump herself and went in right away to have it checked. The thrilling news is she caught it early and already feels “it” (she refuses to use the word Cancer and likes to refer to it as a “parasite”) is shrinking after undergoing three of the six rounds of chemotherapy. However  there is still a long way to go to complete this arduous regimen once she completes the chemotherapy. She will then be scheduled for surgery  radiation treatment  then a year of additional infusions over 2019. Ann-Marie  Roger  and Ethan have made this fight the primary focus of their lives. As you may imagine  it has taken an emotional  physical as well as financial toll.To help reduce the financial stress that might get in the way of her healing  we decided to create this campaign on their behalf.The Financial Challenges Ahead:As you can imagine  the medical expenses are starting to mount. Ann-Marie and Roger are facing two years’ of health insurance deductibles and premiums until she is able to return to work later in 2019. In addition  Ann-Marie has decided to fight her cancer using an integrative approach which means using methods and alternative therapies in addition to convention medicine. As a result  certain medications and supportive treatments are not covered by insurance. Also  Ann-Marie is unable to work during her treatments and it is not yet determined when she will be able to return to work in a full time capacity thus losing a significant portion of their household income. We have created this fund to help reduce the financial stress so that Ann-Marie and her family can focus on tackling her cancer and begin the healing journey. Any contribution you feel comfortable in making is deeply appreciated.If you have any questions  please feel free to contact either Kim Larson Sydnee Dreyer or myself at the addresses listed on the email you received. If you have any questions please feel free to contact either of us at the address listed on the email you received.  We encourage you to share this link with friends of the Ramseys.  https://www.gofundme.com/create/story/annmarie039s-healing-journey Lastly we wanted to share words from Ann-Marie that she posted on Facebook to express her gratitude to all of you for your well wishes  meals  visits  walks and general outpouring of support.  Please read aloud with a subtle Georgian lilt to get the full effect of her sweet  inimitable style!\So I wanted to say THANK YOU for all the wonderful comments  thoughts  cards  and texts I've received from you all as a result of my \"parasite\" post! I tell ya  as the superfluous layers have fallen away in this process  the fountain of gratitude has risen up! As nasty and crappy as this stuff is  it has really made me realize the preciousness of a day  each day  and the value of good friends and family  not to mention an amazing community of support to bring by meals  provide rides  help when I need it. It is truly humbling. I'm currently in my third round of chemo and am tolerating it pretty good despite some of the wretched side effects. I feel the parasite dying which makes it all worth it. That thing is going down  literally! Hoping each of you will have a wonderful and magical holiday season full of inspiration and love!\""

Update on Mandy since first posting this: Feb 2019After all this time  we have finally found out that Mandy has a rare form of Ovarian Cancer. She will be having surgery tomorrow to remove all 4 of the tumors. Much time time was wasted and the tumors have grown large  we are still holding on to hope.  Thank you for your continued prayers and support.Unfortunately some missteps took place in Mandy's treatment. A scan revealed that the chemo prescribed for her was not effective  the tumors have actually grown larger.  Two of the tumors have actually started to fuse together around her uterus. The teratomas themselves are not actually cancer  but can contain cancer  a pet scan did reveal that cancer is present in her body  but at this point we are uncertain of what type of cancer she even has.  We are venturing from Wichita to Kansas City  to KU Medical to seek new treatment options for her.  Surgery will be in her future to remove the 4 tumors. While presently she does have health insurance  but with the new year  meeting the deductible before insurance will cover starts over. As would be expected this whole experience has been horrific for her  and has turned her world upside down   the effects of chemo have been devastating and this journey is far from over for her. Mandy does not have any children of her own and this weighs on her mind as well. Mandy is very strong and brave and would be the last one that would want anyone to feel sorry for her.  She has now been out of work since October 2018   Asking for help is also incredibly hard and it has only been through the generous support that she has been able to stay on top of her bills.  Anything that you can donate would be greatly appreciated  please feel free to share this. We are still trusting and believe that miracles happen.Thank you so much for your prayers and support it means so much to us.We created this gofundme page to help support Mandy  as she is going through Cancer Treatments. Mandy has been out of work since October 2018 and presently has no income coming in  as she is not well enough to work  we are relying solely on the kindness and generosity of those who are able to donate to this fund.  Mandy's story does not differ that much than so many others who have been struck down with this horrible disease. She was this beautiful  young 32 year old who thought she had finally reached this place where she had her life pretty well figured out. She started a new career as a Postal Carrier  a job she loved because as she will admit  she loves to organize and sort things  so this was perfect for her.  She has a deep love for animals  particularly her fur baby Chester.  Plans included to one day go to London  New Zealand to take the Lord of the Rings Tour.  Mandy has an Art Degree and is a talented and gifted photographer  one of her favorite past-times is taking trips with her best friend Nancy to find unique out of the way places to photograph  it would be her dream to be a band photographer  but that's another story.Her whole life changed this past Spring  when stomach pains prompted a trip to the hospital  a volleyball sized mass was found surrounding her ovary. The word germ call Teratoma became embedded in our brains  at the time she was repeatedly assured that it is very rare for a Teratoma to be cancerous  roughly only 2% are  a surgery followed and she lost her ovary  the mass was sent to mayo clinic and while she was out delivering mail  her Surgeon called to tell her she had cancer. It was very devastating. She had a Pet Scan  that revealed no cancer present in her body and we rejoiced that this was behind us.  Until this past September when 4 new tumors were found  one by her other ovary  two in her uterus and one along the surgical line  that she can feel when she touches her stomach. Teratoma's are incredibly fast growing  so she was out put on an intense round of three types of Chemo  three cycles that consisted of one week of 5 days  followed by 1 day the next two weeks  and than the cycle begins again. It was the plan that this would shrink the tumors  making surgery less invasive  unfortunately that didn't happen  the tumors did not shrink but actually have grown. The Chemo has left Mandy incredibly weak  a good day is when Mandy can walk on her own  most days she is transported by wheel chair. She misses her life  her friends  she holds on to her hope that she won't lose her other ovary and that one day she will have a child.I truly know and believe that Mandy will come through this  she is strong  brave and determined. This experience has softened her heart even more to those around her  she has a great desire to help others  to make a difference  to let others know that they are not alone in this journey. We ask please  more than anything for your prayers  we know that God has an amazing plan for Mandy's life  He makes beauty from ashes  she will come through this and have such an amazing story to share  one of strength  bravery  will power and such amazing love. We continue to stand on His promises  that despite what the scans show  by His Stripes she is healed. We thank you so much for your generous support any amount can help and we are so very grateful  for your prayers  we truly believe that God will place the right people in her path to help her.Thank you from all of us  her friends and familyMay God bless you

a brief summary of PANDAS The short version - My family back home are going through a very difficult time at the minute. I am just trying to do something proactive to help them. All the details of their situation are below. Thank you!This is a hard story to tell. My parents are private people and watching how their lives have changed these last couple years has finally made me get up and do something to help them. I am originally from America  where my parents and brother live  but I currently reside in England with my husband and three children. Being so far away has been really hard for me and I have been trying to find the words to sympathetically retell a story  or better yet a nightmare  that struck home 3 years ago.Some family and friends that are close to us may find this hard to read as not a lot of people have been privy to the details. My little brother  Carter  who is now almost  19 years old  has been diagnosed with a rare syndrome that has only been recently making headlines. PANDAS or now known as PANS syndrome is an acronym for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorder Associated with Streptococcal infection. It’s an infection that eventually travelled to his brain after having a Strep A infection when he was 16 years old.  There isn’t a lot of research and there is still so much more to understand as this diagnosis is more common in preadolescence boys  not mature 16 year olds. But this is what happened to my family. Carter has been for most of his life a very happy  content  smart  athletic child. Kind didn’t even begin to describe his nature. He was a stand up boy and loved life! He was funny and mature for his age so he knew how to get along with anyone. He was the favourite babysitter at our Church  he worked hard  played hard and saved hard. Carter has always been a perfectionist. He was my parent’s miracle baby (my Mom suffered 3 miscarriages and 2 stillbirths in between my other brother and Carter) and lived up to that title. He had dreams of being in the FBI by the time he was 30!In 2016  after having a severe bout of Strep twice  my brother’s attitudes and personality completely changed. What felt like overnight  Carter was someone my parents didn’t recognize. He was lethargic  anxious  unable to cope with a normal day. It took several months for my Mom to get a doctor to listen to them and understand that this was something entirely different than the usual teenage anxiety. Eventually a blood workup was done and the diagnose was PANDAS. As he was already coming out of puberty  doctors were not sure what the future held for Carter. Would he be “normal” again? Would he be able to go to school? Would he even be able to enjoy simple every day things? Every day was a challenge for my Mom and Dad  trying to understand where their beautiful boy went. He didn’t talk to my parents  he wouldn’t come out of his room  he began to hate himself  argue with everyone and he struggled to deal with how he felt. He often would say “I have so much pain and I don’t know where it’s coming from. I just want it to go away.” Carter missed his entire Junior year of High School where he was once in the top of his class. He lost a lot of friends as so many didn’t understand what he was going through. After a year  a lot of hard core antibiotics  medications  therapy and diet changes my parents saw little glimmers of hope in Carter. He went back to school his Senior year. He still didn’t attend very often but was given permission to complete his work at home. He had to accomplish so much to complete 2 full school years in one year as he really wanted to graduate with his class.  He did it. He actually did it by the skin of his teeth. Three days before Graduation Carter was told he was going to graduate. What a relief! However  the problems didn’t stop there. The pressure from that year weighed heavy on Carter and he struggled to continue to cope with everyday life. Unfortunately  the same summer Carter graduated (June 2018) my parents lost both of their jobs. Leaving them with no insurance to keep Carter in the therapy or the extensive amount of medications he needed. Which lead to him spiraling out of control again. Last month I received a horrible phone call very early in the morning. My brother tried to take his own life. He didn’t like who he had become and didn’t want to suffer any longer. After attending the ER  he was taken by ambulance to an Adult Psychiatric Centre where he stayed for 4 days. My brother was alive  but just as broken. My parents have had to move home and areas to try and give Carter a fresh start. The care for his medical bills is once again stacking up as my parents have no way to pay for the hospital care and ambulance. They have been out of jobs for nearly 6 months and are looking at other options. My Dad spends most of his days applying for jobs where he has had several first and second interviews with nothing coming of them. My Mom has fortunately been recommended for a position in a large business and they have hired her! However  she hasn’t started yet and although they will be able to have good Health Insurance through her new job soon  it will not cover any medical costs retrospectively. I have wanted to fly over and help where I can  but that also is a price we can’t afford. I just want to give them a little bit of help. I want to show them and Carter that the world does care and that they are loved. My family have always attended Church  believed in God and that all things happen for a reason. But I feel for so much of their life  they’ve never been given a break. Carter isn’t himself and may not ever be the social young man he once was. But I know with a little bit of financial help  they can find the right therapy for him and make his life more tolerable. He would like to be able to attend VCU and go into their Pharmacy program to be able to get in from the ground up with up and coming medications. But that dream seems so far away right now. I love him so much. He will always be my baby brother. Please help! I wanted Go Fund Me to give them a fresh start and some help and while this account is active  I will also be doing some fundraising of my own here in England. So watch this space. Thank you!

He would like to be able to attend VCU and go into their Pharmacy program to be able to get in from the ground up with up and coming medications. But that dream seems so far away right now. I love him so much. He will always be my baby brother. Please help! I wanted Go Fund Me to give them a fresh start and some help and while this account is active  I will also be doing some fundraising of my own here in England. So watch this space. Thank you!

Doug met with the Nephrologist yesterday and was told his kidney function was at 10%. So far  we had initially decided together with the Doctors to not proceed with dialysis in hopes of a living donor match sooner than later.  Yesterday  that all changed and the Doctor is saying he needs to start dialysis immediately.  We have run out of options because it is so urgent. They will be surgically implanting a \port\" into Doug's neck/chest area  which actually is not the best case scenario  but the quickest healing method of delivery of dialysis.  This is not the option we would have chosen if we had a choice  it is prone to a lot of complications.  Needless to say  Doug will be off work for a while during the healing process and because he has no short or long term disability  he will have no income to pay his bills.  We are humbly asking you for help for him to maintain his bills (vehicle  health insurance premium  Co-pays  Prescriptions  and any other medical expenses not covered by his insurance).  We are hoping to take one of his \"stressors\" away by doing this  since we all know stress can cause high blood pressure; and high blood pressure is a huge factor in kidney disease.  Please donate and share on your page and ask your friends to do the same. We have chosen the target goal of $7 777 because we are in need of as much luck as we can get! Thank you so much for your continued love and support."

storyTitle: Making Light Work for Ranny Mast
story: In March of 2018  our Heartwood Montessori School colleague  teacher  friend and sister  Ranny Mast  was diagnosed with recurrent Ovarian Cancer. Ranny was first diagnosed with Ovarian Cancer in 2014 and underwent surgery and chemotherapy into 2015. Her past experience has made her very knowledgeable about her care and her needs during treatment. One of the therapies that Ranny found  and is proving to help her greatly  is Mistletoe.  Although newer to the US  the liquid extract of mistletoe has long been used in Europe to improve quality of life and increase the survival rate of cancer patients.  Ranny has been receiving mistletoe injections three times a week  since March  when she was diagnosed. Mistletoe therapy is a viable non-FDA approved treatment option that is not covered by insurance.Ranny has been able to receive these injections even though her physican  Dr. Stacy Mulkey  is based in Colorado. However  after completing her current chemo treatments  Ranny and her doctors  both here in North Carolina and in Colorado  have decided it would be in her best interests to go to Colorado to Namaste Health Center  which is known for its innovative oncology treatment strategies  for more intensive treatments.   http://www.namastehealthcenter.com/#namaste During her three week visit at Namaste  Ranny will meet with different practitioners  including Dr. Mulkey  her integrative oncologist  on a daily basis.  She will be spending approximately six hours a day at the clinic.  She will receive daily Mistletoe infusions and high dose Vitamin C infusions  as warranted. All will be custom made to fit her terrain and diagnosis.  Additionally  she will receive hydrotherapy  ozone  orthobiomomy treatments  acupuncture  and she will meet with a nutritionist.  A three week visit to the Namaste Clinic is approximately $17 000 for the treatments involved  as well as food  lodging and travel.  None of this is covered by health insurance  and yet  it holds much promise for her health. We cannot let the fact that our health insurance system is ineffective factor into this important health decision for Ranny's family. It's hard for us  at times  to know what we can do and how we can help Ranny and her family. This gofundme gives us a way to help the Mast family and support Ranny  while she gets the treatment she needs without worry of further financial hardship for her family. Ranny continues to research and hold out hope for something  anything  that will work to stabilize this disease. She has touched each of us in such different and special ways. Let's do our part and contribute what we can to help her make this possible. At Heartwood  we say that many hands make light work. Let's make this financial burden light work for the Mast family!

3 days after this photograph was taken  in the early hours of Saturday morning  Dave suffered a heart attack - luckily  his wife Sue knew better than to believe it was just indigestion and got him to hospital.Dave crashed  but the medical team were able to bring him back  while Sue watched on  helpless behind an observation window.An airlift from New London to Yale New Haven  and multiple surgeries later  Dave seems to be on the road to recovery - and our love is with him and Sue.BUT - despite health insurance  this medical episode WILL demolish what little financial reserves Dave and Sue have  and very possibly bankrupt them.Dave and Sue are much loved by our musical community  and give freely of their time  hearts and care to others.Please help us do whatever we can to reduce the pain of the inevitable financial catastrophe that's about to hit them.

Last year Mike McCrady successfully won a hard battle with colorectal cancer. While going through the testing required for his cancer treatments  doctors discovered a genetic defect in his heart that greatly decreases its functioning. Now that Mike is physically healed from his cancer  it is time that he gets his heart fixed so that he is able to completely appreciate his remission. As of right now  Mike's heart condition is taking a great toll on his body  and he is unable to work full-time. Also  in order to be cleared for open heart surgery  he also needs $5 000 in periodontal work that is not covered by the family's health insurance. He is still behind on financial commitments from when he was going through chemo therapy  and the recovery time for his upcoming surgery is at least 3 months. Without some assistance  Mike and his daughter Megan will not be able to afford their bills and expenses. Mike does not qualify for unemployment  and Megan is only able to work part-time as she is in her first year of grad school at Augsburg. They do not take asking for your help lightly  and are very grateful for anything their friends  family  and strangers are willing to give. Megan and her dad are two of the greatest people I know  and they deserve to be able to heal without financial stress. Please give what you can to support these wonderful people. Even if you are unable to help financially  please share this page so that someone else can.

A very special and kind friend to many people was hit by a car on Saturday  and the driver who could've cared less about the beautiful person they had just run over sped away from the scene like they hit a speed bump.  I know how bad this is going to hurt her as she is one of my best friends. I also have the same health insurance.. .  If everyone throws in a few bucks it will help her so much.

As many of you have heard  my son-in-law  Ralph Trolian has recently been diagnosed with Hepatocellular carcinoma (liver cancer).  His tumor is roughly about 9 cm and because of size and proximity to the portal vein of his liver  they are unable to operate at this time.  The current treatment plan is for Ralph to undergo chemoembolization at Johns Hopkins University’s Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center  in Baltimore  MD.  Depending on how the tumor reacts  he may undergo the chemoembolization treatment anywhere from 1 to 7 times.  Each time will require him to stay overnight in the hospital for observation. He will also have to undergo radiation treatment  5 days a week for 3 weeks. The hope is that they can shrink the tumor enough so they can eventually surgically remove the cancerous portion of the liver.It will be a long hard road for Ralph. Because of his diagnosis  Ralph has had to shut down his small business.  Thank God  he had health insurance through Michelle’s (Shelly’s) work.  If this diagnosis had come 6 months ago  it would have been a different story.  However  since Michelle has only been working at her current job for six months  she has not gotten to the point where she earns leave… if she doesn’t work  she doesn’t get paid. With Ralph’s current treatment plan and the hospital being 3 hours away from home  there will be many missed days of work.Despite having health insurance  Ralph and Shelly will be faced with staggering medical bills because insurance only covers 80% of the bill.  We do not know how much this will cost in the long term but one website states that liver cancer treatment can cost $50 000-$100 000 (Liver Cancer Treatment Costs ).  Paying for 20% of that is mind boggling.  They will also have to pay for a place to stay during the 3 weeks of radiation treatment.  Even if they are approved to stay at the patient and family  reduced-cost housing at Johns Hopkins  that is $64/night or almost $1000 which does not include food and other expenses while away from home... And more missed days of work with no income.I would love to help Ralph and Shelly so that  WHEN Ralph is cured of this horrible disease  they will not have to worry about how they will pay off their medical bills. I want them to have the happy life they deserve.  Any help you can give is appreciated.  The chemoembolization treatments start Apr 2nd so we need to jump on this now. Any donation  large or small  is greatly appreciated.  Thank you for your continued love and prayers.

Amanda has been diagnosed with breast cancer a few weeks ago.  She has Invasive ductal carcinoma  stage 3 triple negative  with lymph node involvement.  She is receiving treatment at Derrick Davis Cancer Center at Forsyth Hospital in Winston Salem  NC.  She is also 19 weeks pregnant with her 3rd child.   She is having several rounds of chemo treatments until the baby is delivered.  Then several more rounds of a stronger chemo followed by a double mastectomy and radiation if all goes as planned and tumors shrink.   This unfortunately comes after a period of surviving melanoma stage 3 cancer during her 1st pregnancy.  Thankfully the child was born healthy and her melanoma was successfully treated.  According to her doctors the two cancers are unrelated.   Amanda(33) has been married to her devoted husband Josh Doub(31) for 7 years.  They have two boys Baron(4) and Reid(2).  Josh is a Marine Veteran who served in Iraq as a fire team leader and now works for a battery company in a distribution center.  Amanda is a fulltime mother but waitresses and clean houses for much needed additional income.   They both have a heart for helping people in need.  Just recently Josh unselfishly made 2 trips to eastern NC area that was hit extremely hard by Hurricane Florence to feed people in distress.He took it upon himself with help from a friend to gather food & supplies. He searched for communities with hurricane and flood damage.  He set up his grill  started cooking and served hotdogs/hamburgers free to all.  He also fed power crews working long hours to restore power.  Josh put his strong desire to help into action and was able to bless many people.   As they approach an extremely difficult time in their lives I (Aunt Sandra) would like to ask on their behalf for a financial blessing. Josh fortunately has health insurance thru work to cover most medical cost.  However  their income has dropped dramatically due to Amanda's inability to keep up with her daily routine due to doctors visits  treatments  and lack of physical strength.  Josh has missed and will be missing numerous days of work to support his wife when necessary.  Family members are supporting with child care and many other ways.   The goal is to help them get thru one year of bills and expenses(mortgage  car payments  utilities  insurance  and other monthly bills)so the burden of money is not on their minds.  Their finances are already quickly depleting with almost 12 months of medical issues still ahead.  Any donations will be a tremendous blessing to this young family and unbelievably appreciated.   Our prayers will constantly be with Amanda and Josh and anyone who feels a desire to help them.      Thank you so much for taking the time to read!!!!!!!!   Aunt Sandra
